"I'm fine," I say, my head half-protruding from the head hole like a bashful turtle. My arms are all twisted inside the uncompromising metal. "Thanks for the warning."
"Not a problem, love," he says.
As I struggle to free myself from my metal cocoon, I recognize that there's a hinged strap on the side: something that would have made the struggle a whole lot easier.

But then a sizzling sound sets off behind me. I'm so charged with Essence that I must've transferred too much to the burner. The porridge bubbles over the edges of the pot, edging off the wooden spoon that bridged the center. Scrambling from the floor, I reach my hand to withdraw heat from the stove, feeling that transfer of energy return to my circuits.

"Gods damn it," I tell myself. And when I reach to grasp the handle of the pot, my foot slips in a mess of oats on the floor, casting a plume of molten chunks across the floorboards and the cabinetry.
A voice rises from the other side of the house: a different pitch with the same sentiment.
"You alright in there, Rayna?"
Rayna? Who's Rayna?
"Yeah, just a little accident," I say. "Looks like I'll be skipping breakfast."
"You can't miss breakfast if you're defending the village," he says. "Come to the window."

"One second," I say, before throwing my armor on the right way, finding  buckles and straps that are stitched there for a reason. When I'm sufficiently sharp, clothed in bright crimson and silver that's trimmed with gold, I reach for the window sill to drag it open.
A stocky, bald man squats on one of the stools in the shadow of the building, his collection of fresh breads proudly displayed across the front of the booth.
"You're not Rayna. Your voice sure sounds like hers, though. Are you a friend?"
"This is my house," I tell him. "I just moved in."
"Oh. Sorry," he says. "Well, you're certainly prettier than she was!"
Someone slaps him across the face. I bend down to see where it came from, and it's his wife, unloading the rest of their produce: they must have just arrived.
"I'm Derry. And this is my wife, Carmen. We sell fresh bread here every morning." I shake their hands, bending awkwardly to meet their eyes from four feet off of street level.
"The last girl preferred waking to the smell of fresh bread," Carmen says. "She regaled us with tales of her quests in exchange for a loaf. Maybe you can do the same?"
My peckishness speaks first.
"Of course. What do I owe you?" I ask, drawing my fingers into my coin purse for a couple Kine.
"The first one's free, because I think you'll make a great customer. It's fresh, with a special blend of spices in there," he insists.
His wife turns from unloading the cart. "Say, what happened to the other girl?"

I withdraw the key from my pocket: without the cover of night or blurred vision, I can inspect it a lot easier. The surface is rough where her name was ground away. I can see the shape of her letters interspersed between mine. It's been sanded enough that I'm sure she's not the first: it's evident that the names of cadets were stacked and scratched nearly halfway through the metal shaft — at least twenty of them — and I doubt all those tenants left to move into a permanent home.
The brief pang of fear surprises me, nearly overriding my hunger.
"A shame she was drafted," Derry says, but his face lightens. "But you seem lovely, too. Keep us entertained with stories of your little . . . quests, and we'll share a little," he insists.
"I can do that," I manage: tempted, but too timid to ask how many faces they've seen before.
"And what's your name, dear?"
"Katiya. Miss Katiya Breakey," I say.
"You have a wonderful day, Miss Katiya," he says, flashing a toothy smile before handing me a steaming breakfast bun.

The hunger is more persuasive than the urge to clean the mess. I rush through the front door with the delicious bread dissolving between my teeth, and as I turn to set the lock, I catch the sight of a familiar face.
Bertram struggles to bend down and tie his boot. I'm not the only one that's not used to the armor.
"It's like the old village all over again," I shout.
It startles him. He mulls over a response as I approach, struggling harder to tie a simple knot. "Less fire, though. I hope it stays that way."
"Speaking of disasters," I say, "I don't mind watching you struggle for a while, but are you going to let me help you?"
Bertram blushes, then nods. I stoop down to tame his laces, laughing at how stiffly he stands on the porch.
"You know, you're supposed to tie them BEFORE you can't bend over," I say.
"I would surely remember if this nagging headache went away. I think I lost part of my mind last night. Say — where's double-L? Didn't you leave with him?"
"I did."
"But he didn't stay," he replies.
"I guess not," I tell him.
He looks like he's about to add some commentary, but hinges his mouth shut before the insults can fly, settling instead for something else. "Should we walk together?"
"That sounds great."
"And maybe every morning?"
"That sounds even better."

The walk is quick since we already live in the military district, a few blocks from the boundary of the Gaffe Royal Base. We discuss the letters from our families, the identical layout of our houses, our headaches, and reminisce on the few moments of joy we experienced together in the capital.

With my best friend here, I can almost convince myself that it's all going to be alright, and I relish in the nostalgia of shared memories. The feeling carries all the way until we arrive at the posting board, ready to start on our first day.

"Since you started on your first day, you haven't been drug tested. What's gonna change their mind on Monday, bro? My work never runs drug tests," he says. Gunfire cracks over the TV, flashing the empty walls with pops of color.
"No shit, Miguel. Their corporate structure banks on baked box-boys like you. The ones that forget they're lifting crates and stocking shelves and selling printers for eight hours a day."
"That's manager Miguel now — I order the little guys to do it. I'm a number-puncher like you now," He brags. "Oh. But except I'm actually good enough to get promoted."

The words hit at the same time as a round-ending enemy airstrike. The bombs collapse my soldier to the dirt as the word DEFEAT brandishes across the screens, reassuring us that "we'll get them next time." But his quips hurt no more than the vibrations in the controller.
Miguel cracks another lukewarm beer, kicking the box of the remaining 27 over to me. I put down my custom controller.
"I get bringing over a six-pack of some IPA, maybe a 12-pack of Coors or something, but thirty?"

He manages a straight face as his brown eyes pierce mine, wiping the suds from his scruffy lip rug. "You know, Jesus was wrong when he said 'man can't live on bread alone.' He didn't know you could drink it yet."
"Is that right?" I laugh.
"They've been rolling around the back of my car for a couple weeks after going to Katy's house. You know, high school Katy?"
"No?"
"The pregnancy scare one, with the nice—."
"Yeah, no — I remember," I say. Her face flashes in my mind from our junior prom group. Miguel took her while I took Kei.

"Well, I took her friend home and stole the thirty-rack since no one touched it. Those guys are all fuckin' hipsters, man, so far up their ass about IPA's and stuff, they won't drink just to get drunk anymore."

"Coming from the guy who doesn't smoke just to get high," I tell him. "Passionate stoners are worse than drinkers. You couldn't be any more uninteresting when you're talking about 'Sour Dee' or whatever," I say.
"Fuck off."
He burps. I crack another warm one, and when the timer on the pre-game lobby counts to zero, I lift my controller again. But he hits me with something that isn't just a snide comeback.
"Do you miss high school?" He asks.

It takes me a moment to think. I haven't really considered it, though I've noticed myself staying away from those places we hung out between classes and after school. Those places have some gravity I'm afraid will get me sucked into that past, when I've worked so hard to put those good times behind me.
"I dunno. It's like a friend you haven't seen in a while. Nice to visit every once in a while and relish in the past. But it's best for both of us if we move on, you know?"
He drops the controller into his lap. My thumbs dig into the sticks when I climb a ladder for a sniper nest, only to get blasted off by a camper.
"You trying to say something?"
"No, dude," I start. "I—"
"You can use that losing take on Kei or Kylie all you want, but on your friend?"
"No, of course not! No, man. You're my best friend. You-"
"I'm messing with you, fucker," he says.
He laughs, swigging the rest of his beer between deaths.

He says, "I do. I mean, a part of me does. I hated high school until the end of junior year when our group really started to hang out. It's like, I never felt like I was a part of something until then. And . . . I don't know if I really felt it since."
"Yeah. I wonder what the others are up to," I ask.
"Kayla's having her second kid already. Another girl, I think. Her and Johnny Boy are still together."
"I was surprised. Getting married half a year after high school? I didn't think they'd make it this far."
"You never went to their wedding, though."
"I was in college halfway across the country, bud," I say.
"How about Kei?" He asks. "You were trying to get with her for a while, but you never had the cajones to do it before she graduated after our junior year."
"I've told you before," I say. "She's at my work."

"No shit!" He laughs. "Puta madre, the yellow thirst was real for you, man." He cracks another can after getting mowed down by an LMG. "Are you gonna shoot your shot? You told me you got some experience in college, right?"
"Yeah. But I don't know..." none of those nights in college really fulfilled me. I was always missing something. "I'm not into the clubbing scene like you are."
"All you have to do is ask! It's not like high school. Alcohol changes things. The fellas I met in college showed me all around the city. I know that shit like the front of my hand!"
"Back. The back of your hand," I say.
"Whatever. But we need to get you laid, now that you got this fine house. Shit, man, I wish I could afford something like this. People our age probably never will."
"But you still live here in Hearthland Ridge," I say.

"Paying for a studio! Like living in a fuckin' box for seventeen hundred a month," he says. "Walls so paper-thin I can hear everything. I'd rather go out and get some pussy than cuck myself to the soundtrack of someone else getting it."
"Uh, sure," I say — sometimes I wonder if he tries to fit as many of those words as he can into a sentence.

"But really. I'm proud of you, man," he tells me. "Really. You've worked hard and you've made it. When I was trying to work my way through our senior class, you were grinding at math and shit. You have an actual chance to get wifed up. It's not in my blood."
"What do you mean?" I ask.

"Well, I don't want to. I like the chase better,  you know. Settling down? That's like giving up. What do you do, then? With that feeling, you know, when you have a couple rats with some chick and you know you're locked in for the next forever?"
The feeling's all I've been able to think about since I got back here. No more regimentation. No convenient road map of class to class to graduation: now it's all just open-ended.
"But, like, nothing against you if you're into that. Having rats can be dope. They mow your lawn and shit."
"Someday. Maybe. I'm just too boring, I think," I say.
"Boring? You were the heart of our group back then, dude. You brought us together. You're good at that."
"But nothing's forcing any of us to be together anymore," I say. "Look at how many have moved away from here. It's just you and me now, right?"
"Kayla and John are in California. Michael went to Kansas. He likes flat woman, so I guess he wants a state that can get him off just by driving on the roads."

The beer comes up my nose. I drop the controller and the batteries pop out. "Ugh. Fuck, man," I say, balancing the pain of carbonation in my nose with the urge to laugh, imagining Mike trying to stick his wiener in a Kansas anthill.
Miguel says, "Maybe we'll be stuck here forever. But hey, as long as we're both here."
"I just wish . . ." I start to say, but instead, I reach down and pop the batteries back in the controller.
He slicks his hair back again, finishing another one. "Is it cool if I crash here? I mean, I can drive high, but not drunk."
"Sure, man. But I don't have a cot or a sleeping bag or anything."
"Please. I've slept on floors my whole adult life!" He gestures to the box with 23 stones left. "Now are you gonna help me finish all of them?"
"All of them?"

"All of them," he says. "It's Friday. I know we're old and shit now, but stay awake a little longer, like we're twelve and it's a sleepover in your parents' basement, and I'll tell you a bedtime story."
"Oh, great. About what?"
"One time I was playing on your Xbox when you were out of town. When you had me pet-sitting, and..."
"I'll pass. But—" I think, as long as I'm not drinking alone, it can't hurt. What's the worst that can happen?

"No, I get what you're saying, but what do you mean?" Miguel says, slurring his words as he melts into the futon: the only piece of furniture our drunk asses could assemble. The overturned boxes are makeshift tables that keep the cans off the floor, since we're feeling too lazy to dig for a trash bag.

I lift the can to my lips, but I don't let the poison pass the threshold. Past experience tells me that I'm toeing my limit: lost enough to let my stupid emotions leak on my face, to conjure words to try to push them down, but not enough to kneel at the porcelain throne. I know the feeling is real because the wetness on my face gives it credence, and I often think he's the only friend I've got left to listen.
If only I could get him to.
"How can you get it if you don't know what I mean?" I ask.
"I get it, bro, just not what you mean." Miguel lifts the cracked smartphone above his face as he lays on the futon, thumb-scrolling through an endless barrage of ads and entertainment.

"What I mean is that I don't feel it anymore. My life is just work, then sleep, then work, then go to sleep, but it's nothing more than that. I don't have it like you do. You always have the energy, but I don't know how you find it." The tears leak further: I can't remember the last time I was drunk enough to let them out. "But I know the time is in between there somewhere, I mean, I'm certain I could fit in anything if I tried. But I'm always just so damn tired."
He swipes right a couple times in a dating app, still refusing to look up. "Time isn't the only thing that's too small of yours to fit." He laughs. Then the vibration from a match startles him.
Miguel's thumb slips and he flings his phone in the air, letting out a grunt when it crashes into his nose.He jolts upright to rub the pain out, looking at me for the first time in an hour.
"Oh, shit. You're serious."
"Yeah, you think this is just a bit?"

"No, of course not." He sets his phone on a cardboard box and thinks for a moment. "Why I 'feel it.' I don't know . . . I guess I just got a big family that always keeps me busy. My cousins are young, and my siblings are still in college, so I end up going to their parties and stuff."

"So it's like college never ended for you. Never realized I'd miss it so much . . . my roommates made the damn experience," I say. It didn't matter if we were in the dorms or slumming it in an expensive renter-fixer-upper west of campus: those fuckers forced me to get out. "Most nights, when I was studying in my bedroom, nose stuck in a textbook, they'd pick the lock and barge in — shooting me with flaming Nerf darts, assaulting me with a pizza cutter, or dragging me to one of their parties."
He takes the last swig of his seventh can. "Just like my older cousins. They show up to my house to drag me clubbing, even if I pulled a 'tenner' at work."
"Man. If my brother was still around, I'm sure he'd be over here all the time," I say.
"Of course. Our families had a lot of fun together: barbeques, parties at the park..." The list trails off when he crunches the can in his hands.
"You remember those weekends in middle school when we tried to beat the Halo campaign in a single night?"

"Yeah. And your brother would buy all those energy drinks, sneaking them downstairs for us," he says. "Oh, and the summer tent sleepovers, remember that one night you were so scared of the lightning you couldn't move, and my dad had to carry you back inside?"

"I was stuck in the sleeping bag, so soaking wet from the rain I almost slid out of his arms," I say. We share a laugh. "Or the RV trip we took for the out-of-state Lacrosse game—when we got stuck on the side of the road. We used up all the power playing GameCube and my dad was furious!"

He laughs. "Yeah. And we had to ask one of the families running behind to pick us up. The whole time we waited there, your dad was screaming at Triple-A, and your mom was trying to cook, but the RV tipped so far to the side that she couldn't set anything on the counter..."
"...And all we could do was just pass the ball on the side of the road, wondering whether or not we were gonna make the game."
"But we won that one, right?"
"Yeah — I ripped the game-winning corner pocket."
"Oh yeah. Their team was trash. The goalie scored on himself."
The nostalgia can only abate the emptiness for so long. I take another swig, feeling the body high mix with the dizziness from the flat beer. Without them, the next words might not have left me.
"But now it's just like . . . I dunno. I only know that it sucks, you know?"
"Of course."

"Like, I'm trying to care, but I don't. My mind doesn't want me to be happy." I nearly fall out of the folding chair when I'm talking with my arms. "We're not forced to get out there anymore. To meet new people, to keep friendships alive. All our friends are getting married or serious while we're just left behind. My parents nag me about it all the time: getting impatient since I'm the only one left that'll keep the family name going. And—"
"That shit doesn't matter. That's not what it's about," Miguel says. That video of you, dude, the one on the news, you remember? I think about that shit a lot: it was dope, man."
He's gaslighting me again.
"And what did I say?"
"You just gotta do, man. You gotta do things just to do them."
I furrow my brows. "To do what?"
He wets his lips on a last sip before he tries at something profound.

"The doing is what makes happiness come, when even . . . even when you're, like, not happy, and shit, you force yourself to do things, so happy shit can happen more often and shit, so you can have the chance to enjoy it," he insists.
I'm lost without words, so he decides to muddy the waters even further.

"You get the gist of what I'm saying? Like, you have to decide to do no matter what. Like even when you don't feel like it, you know, you do. The doing, I mean, is something you choose which gives a chance of something good. Or something, at least. You know?"I feel like I just had a seizure. "What the fuck does that even mean?"
"I don't know, man. Maybe I'm bad at . . . no, maybe you suck at listening," he says. "I said that shit perfectly."

I mutter to myself, trying to piece together what he said. It takes me a couple seconds. "Force yourself to engage with the world. Give happiness its best chance to come out, because it's all you can do."
"That's exactly what I said!" He snatches another can, using the light of the TV to inspect all the dents from rolling around in his Corolla.
"Like hell you did!" I roll my eyes.

His verbal seizure must have made him tired. He puts the can down instead of cracking another one, and after a long yawn, he pulls the unzipped sleeping bag off the floor and wraps it around himself on the futon."That thing goes down flat, you know," I offer. "It doesn't have to be a couch."
"Too much effort. I've slept on worse," he says. "I gotta get to sleep so I can make it to church tomorrow."
"And show up hungover? I doubt you'll make it through the service," I say. "But, hey, if you stay a while after, I'm sure you could catch the double-A meeting."

He's too tired for a clap-back. He's not even scrolling his phone anymore: just sprawled there with his feet dangling over the wobbly armrest, arms tucked beneath him, his face buried into a folded towel.
I glance at the stove. "It's only like 12:30."
"Long day . . . leading idiots . . . feels so late," he says, turning to bury his face in the leather crevice of the couch.
"So much for an all-nighter, huh?"
"Nnnn," he mumbles into the towel. "Guessn't."
"I guess we're not young anymore," I say. "We didn't even make it through half the rack."
"Nn."
"So are we gonna finish these?"

"So we're already finished. Is that as bad as it gets? Or is this just because it's the first day?" Pax asks. "Maybe Aldrin wasn't lying. I thought we'd be at the enemy's doorstep most days, waiting for one of them to break through." He chows down on a raw potato that he withdraws from his pocket, spitting scraps with every syllable. "But this is great — a little work for as much produce as you can eat!"
"As long as you don't get caught, you idiot," Ryder says.

The two hike behind us as the sky shifts to dusk, eclipsing all the light from the setting sun. I can feel slivers of potato catching in my hair. Bertram and I shiver in their shade as we struggle for footing, stumbling down the switchbacks of the southern foothills. Despite the half-baked ramblings that often get him in trouble, Pax is right this time. There wasn't a single scouting mission on the board beyond patrolling the town.
Does it really get this easy?

I wait until the switchback slithers east and the trail straightens, catching the fading light on my first quest form. It's stamped and scribbled with an illiterate farmer's signature, dirtied from folding by my soil-soaked fingers. Something catches my eye before we turn another corner: a small statement that the guildscribes helped the farmer write, the only part of the form scrawled in coherent letters.
"Hah, did you see this section?" I ask Bertram. Pax and Ryder look over our heads without bending. "List the concern and how it demands the strength of the Royal Guard's Knights."
Bertram squints, reading the two words before a laugh seizes his throat.
Ryder reads it instead.
"Defending vegetables."
"From what?" Pax asks. "Hungry bellies?"
We share a laugh.

"If this is as hard as it gets, then this is a vacation," Pax says, showing us his large, calloused hands. "I grew up on the outer farmlands of the Capital, working fields from dawn to dusk. Every day I was strapped for time. But this was nothing."
Bertram agrees. "Farming up here is practically a hobby with how that town in the North supplies us. Blackwater, I think? They supply the whole damn capital, but shouldn't they be covered in frost?"
I agree.
"Most maps don't even chart the land north of the Purgatory Mountains," I say. "It should be a frozen wasteland."
"It sure is. I used to live there, up in Blackwater," Ryder says. It's probably the first fact he's volunteered since I met him.
"No way. I've never met someone from up there," I say.
"Me neither," Pax says. "I guess there's no reason to leave when there's no chance to starve, right?"
"There's no reason to leave because you can't. Not unless you spend your whole life plotting an escape."
The words are enough to halt us.
"An escape?" Bertram asks. "Why would you have to escape? I thought they were part of the empire. Some kind of commune of field-hands and farmers, with enough Essence to keep the climate year-round."

"There's not enough Essence in all of Fosroth to allow that," Pax adds. "Trust me. The Capital lands are unworkable in the winter. I couldn't even use a spade on them before I left. So I can't even imagine working the lands up there."
"That's because the lands are—"

His words cut off when a crimson glow saturates the northern hills. We're too slow to shield our eyes when a blinding light flashes from beyond the Purgatory Mountains, as if brought by Ryder's invocation.

It barely catches our eyes as we descend the southern foothills. Any one of us could have missed it if we blinked at the wrong time. But before we can second-guess this shared experience — held as a glow in our retinas when we close our eyes — we find the faintest column of crimson light stretching skyward, like a glowing thread tethering our world of Fosroth to the stars.

It fades like lightning before we have the time to speak its presence. An eerie silence overshadows the town. The wind withdraws with bated breath. The crickets refuse to rub their wings. But to us — a naive band of knights that only know battle through secondhand stories — it's the truest evidence of a war we've gotten yet, and it runs my skin with gooseflesh.
Our pace hastens down the treacherous trail. The trembling words fill every inch of impedance that keeps us from an outright sprint.
"I thought the war was contained to the east, not the north! How would they even get around that far?" Paxton huffs.
"It'd be almost impossible for the enemy to take Blackwater," Ryder says.
"But the column was red!" Bertram says. "There's surely a Mask up there that just did something. It might have even been their Divine Wish..."

"You mean they just jettisoned all their Essence?" I ask. Essence on the order of the Gods breaks the very laws of this world. Only a select few carry the blessing in their blood. But using it all at once comes at the cost of life.

We tap our circuits for Essence, for the strength in our legs to descend faster and faster, predicating the call to Gaffesend Base. The trail ends on the side of the long, wrapping road we tried to cut, and then it's a dead sprint.

I refuse to be late on the first day. My sickening fear and small size propel me far ahead of the others, drawing on more anxiety than Essence as I tear past the landmarks of our small town. The trail transitions from matted dirt to concrete, to cobblestone, then back to concrete, until I'm rushing along the west edge of the lake in the military district: dragged forward by the weight of the thin breastplate; begged by my burning lungs to stop or else I might collapse into the water.

I pass the threshold of the gate, gasping for breaths as my last sprint dissolves into a jog. It becomes immediately obvious that weren't the only ones to notice: most of the recruits gather outside the guard post, swarming around the re-purposed adventurers' guild like flies to excrement.
I spot my brother Erik leaning against the doorframe.
"What's happening?" I ask.
"Some major Essence event."
"Yeah, we saw it. We were on the southern hills."
I gasp for breath. He hands me his canteen. One long drink later, I find my mouth wet enough to continue.
"Should we be afraid?"
"Afraid? Guards aren't supposed to be afraid," he says, staring down at me with our father's amber eyes.
"Not afraid . . . I meant concerned," I say. My mind's too busy redirecting resources to my starving muscles, and I can feel it in the heat of my flushed face.
"I don't think so."
I try to slide past him to get in, but he traps me with his brazen arms. "Relax," he says. "You're going to be fine. You know I wouldn't let anything happen to you."
"I know that," I tell him.
"You always get so damn worked up. Just breathe," he demands. "We're safe here in the city."

I draw several long breaths in my nose and out my mouth before he releases me, just as Bertram, Pax, and Ryder finally catch up.  We enter the main room of the command post, packed to the walls with knights and soldiers. In the corner, the Line Type machines send a one-way barrage of signals across wires. There are three of them: one for the war front, one for the capital, and one that's used for up north, rarely getting an answer to anything.
"Status of Blackwater?" Aldrin orders.
"Clearing the line right now to get their response," a guard says.

Loud chirps on the line screech with the strain of such distance. The vibrations resonate different-shaped keys that dance in their fixtures, stamping against a swiftly scrolling sheet of paper. A long half-minute passes, and the guard impatiently waits until there's enough information to report on.
"Blackwater is safe," the guard says first. "A civilian event in the north district. General Ullrich sending Royal Guard to investigate, not a Mask event, full stop," he says.
The room breathes a collective sigh of relief.
"Was it perpetrated by Chymaeran meddling?" Aldrin asks.
"I don't think so," he says. "I—"
"We don't 'think' here! We speak when we know, and we know when we do," he barks.
"Uh-Understood, sir."
"Relay to the Valensends in the Capital. And send it to the boys at the front, so they don't have something extra to stress over tonight," he says.
"Prompting the line," the others say, setting the mechanical keys in position.

Aldrin turns from the command zone to address the mix of soldiers and guards. "Looks like an oddity: maybe Essence stores ignited. If it was a Divine Wish, we would know it — it surely would have done a lot more damage. I've heard some group up there called the 'Carmine' hoards dead Essence, so maybe it was them," he says.
He turns to the guildscribes.
"We'll run a couple scouting parties, just in case. Write up some quest forms for the new knights: this is a good excuse to get some experience and some exercise."
The guildscribes nod before he turns to us again, waiting until all the novice knights file in through the double doors.
"Things should die down in a week, but we're going to keep the city on alert. We want to be sure that the Chymaera aren't using this as an opportunity to strike."

I know what he's going to ask for next when his eyes dart between the new recruits. I try to dissolve into the crowd, hoping the discomfort in my chest is just exhaustion from running across the town.
"I need volunteers for night watch, to head north and see what's going on," he says. "It's worth a quest. Extra work means an extra day off."
I falter when I'm shoulder-to-shoulder with my colleagues. Guilt and shame tug me forward, but that same crushing feeling I found in the cabin is so much stronger.
"This is easy. No more than several hours," he says.
You're all going to do this, is what I hear.

I can only watch as my colleagues step forward, arranging themselves in groups, but I taste the smoke. I'm snared in the past. I can see the Chymaerans and their glowing, amethyst eyes as they penetrate the shattered glass windows, stretching with their sharp obsidian limbs to finish what the fire began.

This self-immolating spite can only swell when the lust for flight outpaces fight. My hands run cold as if the Chymaeran Curse were churning in my circuits, chilling my veins, and I have to lean against the wall to catch a breath.
Bertram follows me outside. I'm fortunate that the others are too distracted to witness this moment of utter weakness.
"What's going on, Kat?"
"I feel sick," I tell him.
"Right now? All of a sudden?" He asks.
I feel like I'm going to lose my breakfast and lunch. It's only then that he realizes he's drawing attention.
I feel a shock pulse my body when the worst comes to pass, unable to speak or explain when Aldrin steps outside.
"What's going on here?" Aldrin asks.
I don't want to look weak, but maybe I should just tell him. There's no way out of this. After I think I have a grasp on my nausea, I open my mouth to speak.
But Bertram beats me to it.

"She's been feeling sick since the farm," he says. "They were trying to be nice with the samples and the free meal, and we were trying to be respectful: first day, you know. But after all the running..."
"She seemed fine minutes ago," Aldrin says.
I doubt this farce will work. I say, "No, I—"

"Because she didn't want to look weak on the first day," Bertram says. "Don't you know how hard it is for her? She talked to me the whole way back about it, being a female guard and all, trying not to prove the stereotype."

"Oh," Aldrin says. He approaches, placing his glove on my shoulder. "I respect that. We refuse to have that kind of backwards thinking in our ranks. We're trying to get rid of it. But you're not of use to me if you're not at your best," he says.
I can feel the cold night air again. I manage to stand upright without the wall.
"T-thank you," I say, wiping my mouth, although my stomach and its contents are still there.

"Go home and get some rest: this is hardly a task, I just wanted an excuse to give you junior guards some exercise," he tells me. "And Berry—would you mind walking her home?" He hands two quest forms to him. "Bring these back to me tomorrow. I'll give you credit." And then he whispers: "Just don't tell anyone else."
"Yes, sir. Thank you, sir," Bertram says, taking my arm before he escorts me towards the complex. We make sure to pass the gates before we drop the act.
"What was that about?" Bertram asks. The grasp of his hands on my torso is so strong that I hardly have to walk.
"I ... I don't know," I tell him. "I thought I got over this. I thought I wasn't so damn weak and pathetic..."
"You're not pathetic! You earned your presence here," he assures me. "You had a bad day, is all."

"But how can I last when it's really down to the wire, when it's real, if my mind fights me at something so simple, so stupid and pathetic and weak, like this?" I let out an exasperated groan. If he wasn't holding me, I might bash myself in the face with my gauntlets.
"We'll take it step-by-step. You have time. Space in some scouting missions between the banal tasks," he insists.

"But that was the first step. It was a step down. It was so low that it couldn't have even been called a step, and I tripped," I tell him, feeling the tears well up in my eyes. "We went through the same thing that day, how does it not come back to haunt you? Why don't you run? Why are you so still?"

"I don't know," he tells me, still holding me upright when all I want to do is crumble. "I just live in the absolute present. I just find that I'm less attached to it all: maybe I just don't care what happens."
"What does that even mean?" I ask, wiping my eyes.
"I don't know. Maybe I'm just bad at describing it," he says. "Maybe..."
I can feel him quickly release his hands when he realizes he's holding me up by the contours of my breastplate.
"Sorry."
The suddenness gets me to crack a smile. It escalates further. Pretty soon we're both laughing, and I wipe the tears from my eyes.
"But really, though. I promise that I'll always have your back. I won't go off and die on you," he says.
"You better not," I tell him, still letting off a couple chuckles before my lungs settle. "We'll defend some more vegetables tomorrow. Maybe even something more dangerous."
"Really sharp carrots?"
"Maybe."
"I'll look forward to it," he says.
There's a certain hesitation in him when he stands close, as if there's something more he wants to say. But the moment passes. Instead, he hands me my copy of the quest sheet.
"Well," he says. "I guess I'll see you tomorrow."
"Until tomorrow," I say.

I wave to him as I fumble for the key in my pocket; feeling for the name etched into the iron; making sure it's still there; praying to the Gods that it won't be ground any further. There's a sweet smell of grilled meat that makes me hungry: someone cooks a pig on a spit across the way.
Longing for rations after a long day, I turn my head to the entry window, trying to decide what I'll make. But instead, I find an odd, unflickering light illuminating the walls.
"Huh."

My body is out of adrenaline, so I'm strangely calm. I approach the window instead of the door, trying to remember if I latched the back window after getting free breakfast from the merchants. I press my ear to the thin, wavy glass for an auditory cue: unable to see clearly through the drawn curtains, holding my breath until I hear the words of a foreign tongue. The words lack the harshness of Chymaeran dialect. Maybe it's Ahkvasan? Auvryan or Verdalan? One of the old dialects?

I can only make out the silhouette of a stumbling man, holding something thicker than a rapier but thinner than a sword. He doesn't seem to be taking anything. Maybe this is a test — maybe Aldrin didn't mean it and wants to see if my actions can match my claims to courage.

I approach the front door, allowing the burgeoning anger of my incompetence to consume me, leaving no space for fear. My hand is steady, unsheathing the dagger as I gingerly turn the key in the lock until it clicks. There's no room for explanation that this isn't a test or a burglar, so I let the Essence saturate my circuits.

I turn the handle and rush the intruder. I spring forward with such force that the floorboards nearly snap when they give. My circuits run hot with Essence. My hands glow orange with heat, ready to burn their flesh until they beg to be sent to the Reservoir of Souls.
I cross the entire span of the bottom floor.
But just before I'm ready to deal his death, he turns to face me, and I'm unable to reconcile the oddness of his appearance.

The man looks no older than I am, somewhere halfway mixed between a Royal and a vagrant. The fineness of his silken shirt is accented with a checkered pattern of light blue boxes. The fabric is whiter than snow. His stubble is unkempt and shaggy though his light brown hair is clipped finer than all the royals I've ever seen. His brown eyes widen with panic as I intercept him, casting him over the kitchen table, and against the back wall, searing the fabric of his fine shirt with fire before I can withdraw the heat from my hands.
He drops the strange sword against the ground, and it looks like a metal training stick that ends with a basket, not even a blade.
Is it a broom? Is he some kind of housekeeper hired by the Royal Guard, another service like the knocker?

He's far too weak to put up a fight when I straddle him against the floor, his face smudged in the puddle of porridge I left when I was rushing out the door. He's so weak that I have to lighten my grasp or else I might break his bones.
It's then that he spills his first string of words to me. And somehow, I understand them perfectly.
If he wasn't handsome, I would have slit his throat. My mind can't catch up fast enough for all the semantics, but I know exactly what he means.
I can feel it.
My face flushes. "You degenerate! You lecherous, filthy animal, breaking into my house to . . . to—"

"I swear, I didn't break in here," he insists. His face is redder than mine. He covers his crotch with his hands, as if hiding the pitched tent can make me forget. "The door was open. I just walked in."

"The door was locked, you fool," I say, pointing to the narrowly-cracked entry door behind me, but he gestures with his head to the small closet. "The closet? How would you break in through a damn closet? There's no windows in there."
"I know, but please. I'm as confused as you are," he says. "Give me a chance to explain."
"You're excited, not confused!" I point the dagger between his legs. "You don't have the right to be confused right now. I'm the one that's confused at how—"
"—Would you let me explain? Dear God!"
"It's Gods, you heretic," I tell him. "Respect other races. We're not the only one that shares Fosroth, and all our Gods have proven their presence."
"God, I said," he says. "A real god, not the ones you cosplay freaks pretend to worship."

"Do you want to be executed for apostasy? Because I can do that for you, right now," I notice that his eyes keep falling on the closet. The closet, my bare legs, my breastplate, and then the closet. I circle between him and the door, leaving only the entrance as an escape: like coaxing a rat out of the house without having to kill it.

"What I want is to go home," he says. "Not to get stabbed by a letter opener. I'm your neighbor, and the door between our units was open. I was simply trying to tell you," the liar insists. He heaves for a couple breaths. "Did you really have to tackle me to get your point across?"
"You do not live here. This is the Military District. Besides — you've proved that you are far too weak to live here," I say, approaching him with the dagger.
"You bitch, I can bench a plate at least," he says.

"Putting plates on benches? What, are you a fat oaf that eats outside all day?" but he looks reasonably fit beneath his ruined shirt. Defined shoulder muscles, trained without Essence . . . maybe he's a laboring refugee from the North?
He raises his hands as he tries to stand up with only his legs, but he can't. "I'm sorry to intrude. Look. I know you might be into cosplay or whatever, but this is taking things way too far."
"Cosplay?"
"Costume play. At first I thought it was old people living here: the kettle, the candles . . . I mean, the whole damn house is set up like Skyrim."
Costume?
A fucking costume?
"This is not a COSTUME!"
He shrinks at the thunder in my voice. His singed nobleman's shirt hangs open as he edges towards the front door on his hands and knees, and I follow him step-for-step.
"Do you know how hard I worked for this?"
"Yeah . . . lots of trips to the craft store," he adds.
"How hard I worked to wear this proudly as a guardian?"
"Yeah. Did you make it during the craft foam sale? I go there for the graphing pencils."
"What the Res are you talking about?"
"Mechanical pencils," he rambles. "Point-five is a toothpick, and point-nine is like a fucking crayon—"
"You dare to insult me like this? For what, because I'm a female guard?"

"No. Of course not, you're very convincing." His voice crackles on every other syllable, trying to inject some abject form of flattery. "It's amazing. Prop knife? Form-fit foam from the craft store, spray-painted to look like metal armor? Even the stitching looks like an eighteenth-century corset. I can tell you've put a lot of time into it. You're a lot like my older cousin, and I'm sure you have loads of followers like she does. I know I'd follow you."
"You're too yellow to follow me anywhere," I say.
"On-line, I mean," he says.
"On what line?" I ask. "The front? You would never get close. They'd keep you busy peeling potatoes with such soft hands."

"Soft hands? Please. You're the job that banks on soft hands. While you're busy pleasuring perverts over your webcam, I work in an office. Designing the damn future. Because the rest of us have to work real jobs, not getting paid by thirsty horndogs that jerk off to Shakespeare."
"The real work is defending the ungrateful, undeserving gentry like you. Why don't you crawl back to mummy and daddy dearest for another bump to your filthy allowance?"

That last line would provoke any true noble. I expect him to go cry fowl to his underpaid servants, to his nanny, or to his absentee parents, complaining all way up the chain to my captain. I sincerely hope he does, because Aldrin is backwater enough to hate anything that wears its wealth and wreaks of privilege.

But hes's not that kind of upset. He doesn't seem offended in any way. This idiot still holds a sense of humor, as if he thinks it's all a ruse. The further the corners of his mouth crease on a laugh, the more it infuriates me, and as he stands, he opens his stupid mouth to cross the line.
"Enough pretend. Your knife isn't even real."
"Pray tell, does this feel real?"

I take a slash at his arm, trying to carve him with something small and impermanent: small enough to disappear in a day, but enough to remember the lesson. But the fool flinches, blocking my dagger with his left hand.
Idiot.

The edge catches on his palm, drawing an instant, deep line of gushing blood. His expression changes in an instant, as if surprised that knives have an edge to them. Maybe I'll have to explain next that my Essenced fire actually burns, and water actually drowns.
"You . . . you actually . . ." he starts, his back pressed against the front door as he watches the blood trickle down his left wrist, absorbing in the tarnished fabric of his charred left sleeve.

I flick the crimson from the dagger, flipping it around to imply the next strike will impale him. "It's time for you to leave. It's getting late, and by the Gods, I'd rather abstain from filing a casualty report tonight."

He fumbles for the door with his working hand, wrapping his left palm in more of the pristine, white fabric, struggling to grasp the handle when his eyes are on the weapon. "Jesus Christ! Are you insane? Do you have no boundary with your stupid fantasy? Castle Law or not, I'm calling the police."
"Get out," I say.
"You're going down for this," he says.
"I said, GET OUT!"

As soon as the door cracks enough to silhouette his body against the night, I lift my leg and boot him square in the chest, planting a muddy print on the last untarnished space in the fabric. He falls over the first set of steps and lands in the dirt, groaning as I slam the door shut.
He'll live.

I rush to the window, throwing the shades open just enough to peer into the darkness, drawn by my biting curiosity to see what unfolds.  What an idiot — now he's struggling to tear the sleeve off his bloodstained shirt, ripping at the fabric where my Essenced plume singed it black.

But it still bothers me. Why was he so drawn to the shallow closet? Even under duress, I don't know how he could be stupid enough to insist he entered through a door. There's surely nothing in this column of a cottage worth breaking into — especially into the home of a Royal Knight — unless he's some devious cretin that is after my intimates.
After I back away from the window and toss the bloody dagger in the sink, I approach the closet door.
Or at least I thought it was a closet.
The space beyond the door frame spans for less than a foot before the faint candlelight is swallowed by darkness. But the darkness is so dense and miasmic, like peering through murky water.

The tunnel opens itself to me as I approach the door. From the lines implied by the floors and walls, the small cupboard should be no deeper than a couple feet (enough to store winter uniforms and snowshoes for the cold season), but I find no definite end. The edge where the splintered floor meets the jagged wall just fades into obscurity, all the way though to the unit on the other side, where an unfamiliar twinkle of multicolored lights pierce the smooth walls.
The corridor might be short, but it's still just a little too long. The neighboring wall would have to be deeper than the walls around Fort Gaffesend!

It must be a trick of his.  He could be a cross-blood like Pax, except Auvryan; able to mess with minds; skilled enough in his race's  gift to conjure convincing illusions with his Essence. Maybe that's why he seemed so powerless with his Human gifts. Maybe he conjured that splitting headache before I barged in, or maybe he speaks through thoughts, unaccustomed to verbal speech, speaking words of a foreign language though my mind heard something else. Is my mind being twisted further, to show something that isn't there? Does he still deceive me from beyond the door? I refuse to fall for this pathetic excuse of a trick, so I decide to test the bewildering portal.

I reach first with my gauntlet, dragging through the viscous black as if collapsing spiderwebs. I notice the breeze at my back, strong enough to pierce the layers of my uniform, ushering me deeper and deeper. My trembling hand passes where the wall should be, and then my arm, and then the rest of my body, and as all the sound of the quaint cottage and the outside world fade behind me, I realize I'm twice as deep as the rules of space should allow. I think of the old stories of the Verdalans, the masters of space whose bodies descended from the fibrous jungle, defending their ancient capital with an infinite wall of twisting jungle. Just as their Essence warped space, entrapping their adversaries in endless loops of attrition, I feel my stomach twist as my senses confirm a truth that the mind refuses to accept.

The room is dark, and though I can't make out the meager spread of items, I can sense how strange the shapes in this room are: so smooth and straight, as if they were cut by divine hands. When I find a glint in the artifacts on the shelves and walls—even the shelves themselves—I marvel at how much metal must have been wasted to produce all these things. He must be rich if he can waste money like this: maybe he's so rich that he bribed the Guard to let him live here, in a prime spot looking across the water.

Does he actually live next door? Did I really mistake this as a closet? My metal boots clatter like hooves against the reflective wood floor, and I trace my finger along the polished granite table, trying to imagine how the resources got here.
A crunch startles me. On the floor are what looks like hand-painted ration cans, but they're all crushed and ruined.

I'm startled again when I hear snoring in the corner, and I find another odd stranger. A friend? A lover? Maybe a visitor past curfew? My feet sink into the carpet when I approach him, wondering again how the scruffy noble could ever afford such luxurious flooring.
The entire room stinks of man, but this one smells especially bad. He mumbles in a drunken stupor before he awakes, blinking his eyes like a toad.
"Uh . . . hey."
"Hello," I say, wishing I had not ditched the dagger.
He asks, "And you are?"
"Katiya. Katiya Breakey-Hilde," I say.
"My homie's got no chill if he's bringing girls like you over while I'm here. Must be desperate since he's got no hoes."
"A hose? Why would you—" I begin to ask, but he cuts me off.

"I think he's upstairs," he tells me, squinting his eyes, and then some semblance of recognition crosses his face. "Wait a minute — you must be from that fantasy escort service down in Denver, what was it called, uh . . . Call To Adventure, or something like that?"
"I only do escort missions through the Royal Guard," I say.
"Hah. Good one," he says.
"It is good," I say.
"Good." He clicks his tongue. "Figures. My boy Cody could never score a baddie like you."
"Cody," I say.
"Yep."
An odd name.
"And I'm Miguel."
Another odd name.

He says, "But he's a real one, let me tell you. My friend is the best dude you'll ever meet. I love that guy. You might be here for just a night — and, look, I know the whole thing about falling in love with a call girl — but give him a chance, huh? Even if it's just a booty call thing," he says.

His hand grazes the table, accidentally casting some black, slender object on the floor. It bounces twice before colliding with something else. I hear a click, and then behind me, a flash of colorful light envelops the room. I gasp when I turn to look, and my heart jumps into my throat.

Behind the bright window, a mother and daughter are screaming at each other. It gives me such a start that I collapse into the couch. The woman is screaming, the daughter is screaming, I'm screaming, and the man is shouting, trying to free himself from my armor.

I spew a string of apologies as the woman in the window says something about wanting her body back, just as all I want is to go home. Too panicked to realize that the best direction is from whence I came, I sprint for the door as the other guy curses, grasping his leg.
I'll just go around like Cody. We'll trade places.

Just like my intruder, I trip backwards out the door, scraping the edges of the cement with my plate armor as I slide down the sculpted stairs, coming directly to a stop beneath a blinding torchlight. I scramble to my feet to try and run, but everything is so bright and unfamiliar that I fall to my knees.

The sky is cloudless, but I can't find a single star. Lake Garrison is nowhere to be found; instead of the distant lights of my hometown of Hillfar, a pattern of white-and-red dotted lights slide past each other on a hill, somewhere far beyond the eaves of two houses on the other side of the road.

Something loud is approaching. I try to curl into a ball to protect myself, but the armor stiffens me too much. A massive automobile tears past, lighting the entire street with headlamps lodged in the front, unlike anything I've ever seen. It sounds like they have an entire orchestra in there behind the glass, but the deafening music fades . . . only to be replaced by two more loud metal chariots that shake the ground.
I'm quivering as I lay there in the grass, wondering where the garden is; why the lake isn't directly across from me; why stars shifted in the sky so swiftly.
An old woman walks on the side of the street, and I consider she's a lamplighter until I see her holding a leash. She notices me crumpled in the grass on the verge of tears.
"Are you alright, sweetheart?" She asks.
"No," I cry.
Her familiar crosses the grass, nuzzling me with its wet nose before it licks my face.
"Oh, that's Doby. She's real friendly with all the young'uns living around here — do you mind dogs? Or are you more of a cat person?"
"I'm a human person. A living human—"

"—I swear to the good Lord in heaven: if this neighborhood is turning into one of those 'college' towns the Facebook talks about, with all these young'uns in their new houses playing trapping music, I'm going to lose it!"

I haven't the time to protest when I hear a hissing noise, and it sounds like the elder is conjuring a serpent. Before I can react, I feel a cloudless rain, followed by a direct blast of water to my face, saturating the clothes beneath my armor in seconds.
"Why? Why do you torment me?" I plead, my tears now inseparable from the water soaking me down to my underwear.
"I didn't set the timer on those sprinklers," she says, and then adds, "damn beatnik."

As I kneel in the muddy grass, sullying my new pants, I watch as the cantankerous woman retreats, dragging the mutt alongside her. A single, white moon hangs in the sky. Blinking red and white flashes somewhere even higher, casting smoke in a faint line, leaving the sound of a crackle as it slices the sky. I never knew the sky could be torn.
With my mind petrified, locking my muscles, resigning me to soak in the jets of water, my body decides for me, urging me back inside to pass Cody's cursing companion.

All I want is to return to the comfort of Fosroth where the world is uncomplicated. I want a cup of tea and a book beside the fire as I warm my bones. I will never bear witness to this horrifying illusion again.

I ignore his companion's threat to take shots, though he holds a bottle instead of a gun, — asking if his friend paid for any more guards to defend this house. But as I stumble towards the closet, squeaking my saturated boots with each step, all I find is another figure, standing there at the back of the closet.

I wager my strength and power over his defenses. The inebriated man called Cody holds the odd, metallic broomstick with his hands together in the center — a technique I've never seen before — and calls out a phrase I can only decipher as a challenge.

If it's a sword fight he wants, I know I can make it to the greatsword leaning against the wall, because if this Auvryan cross-blood wants to wreak havoc on my home life with his illusions, sullying the most sacred place I have to replenish myself and find respite, then I have no other choice.
He must be destroyed.

Cody drags his left foot behind him, bending his knees, leaning his body in a forward squat as if that can stop me. Surely this assassin is an Auvryan, and likely some kind of mercenary: their people are masters with pole weapons. But I doubt his technique is greater than the strength of a full-blooded Human flooded with Essence.

I charge with my armored left shoulder, allowing the Essence to flow into my legs, flooding my muscles with such power that every step deflects the floorboards. I close the distance faster than he expects, but he remains steadfast, standing there with the metal broom raised to chest height, hinging his arms to receive the full force of my momentum.

It's when I'm three steps from deliverance that he bends to get under me — but my muscle memory is far faster. I lower myself further than he can, sliding beneath the pole, driving my metallic shoulder into his chest and blasting him in the air.

He lets out a rasping wheeze when his ribs bend towards his lungs. He's lucky that nothing inside him breaks: maybe it's the alcohol on his breath that hints that his muscles are loose, and that he's feeling a little braver than he might be otherwise.  Cody crashes against my wall, leaving a sizable divot in the aged wallpaper, and before the ground reclaims him, I manage to snag the greatsword with my left hand, dragging it across the floor to assume a defensive stance.

Somehow, he still manages to death-grip the broom between his hands, coughing and gasping for air as he lifts himself to his feet, overflowing with adrenaline and rage that radiate in his reddening face.

I realize I left him an opening to escape. I expect him to cower, retreating to his conjured illusion to never return. But he flips the broom end of the stick to face him, exposing a sharp, hollow edge.
His hapless courage is admirable. Maybe I would have fallen for him if this were training, and we were on the same side of the war.
Cody coughs. "You couldn't just let me go, could you?"
"I need to be sure you can't ever ruin my peace again."
He takes several labored breaths, clutching his chest, swinging the sharp end of the broom in several circles. "So you're trying to kill me, then?"
"It's not my fault that you broke in."
"I was trying to tell you that the door was open. What the hell kind of neighbor are you?"
"You're not strong enough to be my neighbor," I tell him.

The ceiling has just enough clearance to swing the greatsword in a vertical slash. I expect this cumbersome move to give him enough of a start to really escape this time, but he still refuses, standing there with the stick between his hands.

The sword traces a faint line in the wooden ceiling before gravity does the rest of the work. It clashes with the broom — and I fully expect it to break through — but all my greatsword does is well a deep notch in the hexagonal shaft.

He mutters something about the material, cursing about how this broom is personal to him, but I know very little of the Auvrya or their traditions. My blade releases sparks when I try to pull it back, grinding against the notch, but the further I pull, the higher the blade climbs.

I hear the screech of metal-on-metal, and it seems it's his turn to close the distance. He grinds the pole against the sharp edge, driving the sword higher and higher until it falls behind my hands. I'm left defenseless, and he jabs the plastic head of the stick against my breastplate, driving me to the floor.
Whatever that thing is, it isn't a broom.
My mind races, but I still manage to remember the bloody dagger in the sink.
I roll behind the kitchen island as he brandishes the head of the stick against a wooden bowl on the counter, casting a whole slew of produce against the ground.
I lift myself by the counter's edge to dig my hand into the sink, feeling for the hilt of the dagger.
"Your fight is with me, not the damn house!" I say.

He bends down to scoop up one of the apples with the stick, taking it into the basket. I level the dagger at him, taking a butcher's knife in my other hand, completely unsure of what he's going to do next.
His hands shift to the sharp end of the stick, leaving the basket at a certain length behind him.
Then he whips it down as hard as he can.
The apple whizzes past my head, exploding against the stone wall, casting chunks of its sugary flesh and skin into my hair.
"I should have practiced since the club team sophomore year," he says, slurring his words. "Next one's going corner-pocket in your damn eye socket."
"Not if I end you first," I say.

The assassin scoops up an orange with a single flick of his wrist. I ready the knife block. He launches a second one, but I'm quick enough to slice it with my dagger before it blasts me in the forehead.

My eyes burn with the citrus, and when I think he's reeling to throw something harder — like a pear or another apple — squinting as I wipe the juice with my dagger hand, I use my unpracticed off hand to flick the kitchen knife through the air.

It spins several times before embedding itself into the wall behind him. He freezes. I set the dagger on the counter, taking three more kitchen knives into my left hand, certain that I can hit dead-center now that my dominant hand is free.
I whip a second one, letting the Essence tension the fibers of my muscles, launching the paring knife faster than an arrow.
But he's already pitching up the overturned kitchen table.

The tablecloth hovers to the floor like melting ectoplasm before the paring knife pins it to the table. Cody lets out a yelp in fear, surely unhurt since the blade is far shallower than the thick mahogany.
I decide to upgrade to a carving knife, withdrawing all five inches from the block. I judge its balance.
He peeks from behind the table, and I whip the carving knife where I expect his chest to be, thinking it's his body that braces the table upright.
But he bends back.
It stabs through almost up to the handle.
"Holy hell," he exclaims.

I wind up to throw another as he pulls the small knife from the wallpaper, then throw it. The boring knife spins through the air, nearly pinning his hand to the wall. He catches me off guard when he emerges from the side of the table. I reach for another culinary weapon, but I realize my offhand is out of blades.

The oddly-dressed assassin flips the blade to set the sharp edge between his fingers, his eyes dark and piercing as he raises his elbow and lifts the knife behind his head. The panic seizes my heart: this assassin's skilled enough to engage a vetted Royal Guard when he's two sheets to the wind. I'm certain a knife will soon be in my chest, and all I can do is ready myself for the deliverance of cold steel.
And then he throws it.

I expect it to fly so fast that I can't catch a glimpse of its glistening edge before it embeds itself between my breastplate. I expect my consciousness to end, to wash in the next fated moment upon the Reservoir of Souls.
But I can see it.
And it's not coming at me.

It flies so far to the right that I wonder if he's aiming at something else. The paring knife spins horizontally through the air, twirling and spinning with such disarray that it only makes it halfway to the kitchen before it clatters against the floor.
"Damn it!" he says.
The laugh escapes before my hands cover my mouth. I can't even stop the loud snort. His face is crestfallen, even more hurt than the time I rammed him.
"You should stick with that strange basket-stick of yours," I tell him.
Cody's voice wavers. "It's called a lacrosse stick," he says, blushing hard, peeking over the edge with his glasses as he struggles to withdraw the carving knife from the other side.

I thought he was an Auvryan mind-flayer — a mythical master of mental manipulation, maybe commissioned by the Chymaera. But he's no warrior. Just a stupidly-brave commoner that's overconfident in his skills. And a complete idiot.
I can't stop laughing.
"What are you, some kind of combat janitor? Do you sweep floors with that thing?"
His face reddens further, whether it's the booze, his humiliation, or both.  I feel the relief wash over me as the Essence retreats from my circuits.
"Gods above, for a second I thought you were an actual threat," I say.
"Who says I'm not?" He scoops a tomato into the 'cross stick', poised to whip another one.
"Just . . . stop," I tell him. "I'm not going to kill a civilian."
"Maybe you should reconsider," he says.
"Consider this."

I raise my hands and cast a controlled plume of flames. He flinches when they stop only inches from his face, dropping something hard and small from his pocket. He has to steady himself with the odd weapon as he stumbles towards the closet.
"Really, Cody. Do you even understand our training? How much Essence a Royal Guard is conditioned with? How much mead does it take to get this kind of courage? I could snap your bones with my hands!"
"I'm your neighbor. I live right next door . . . through there," he says, lifting a bare arm exposed by his scalded shirt to point towards the closet.
"Why are you living in the military district?"
"I live in Hearthland Ridge," he insists. "The military base is down in Cheyenne, or maybe Fort Carson."
"This is Gaffesend," I tell him.
"No, this is Colorado. The United States," he says.
"Nothing is united in all of Fosroth. You can't be stupid enough to be a tourist at the war front!" I say.
"The war is overseas. It's fought with drones and bombs."
"It's waged with swords and rifles!"

I approach him until I can smell the booze on his breath. My eyes flutter between his exposed chest and his arms, a little impressed at his definition when he obviously has no Essence. I catch him glimpsing at my bare thighs that once straddled him, and then to my breastplate, before returning my glare and slowly backing up towards the closet.
But his heels catch on the threshold.

He falls through the portal, unable to steady himself with his weapon before he crashes to the ground on the other side. I take one more glance at the horrors of that incomprehensible world: all its glistening, colored lights like Essenced lightning bugs. The fear forestalls me from passing that threshold ever again, so I stand there: watching; waiting; listening to the faintness of his breath; until I'm certain his intemperance will keep him there.
But the fear of that other world overpowers my penchant for patience. I slam the door behind him, certain I'll never have to face that stranger again.

Late Sunday morning, around 11:00, I awoke with my neck twisted against the closet door, my face saturated with drool, shirt missing, and a sticky note taped to my forehead with Miguel's handwriting that read "DRINK WATER." The pounding headache had mostly subsided: I must have slept it off, or drank loads of water the night before from how quickly I immediately had to sprint to the restroom. And after relieving myself, I found my phone on the counter with three unread texts:
Miguel Ruelas // 06:37u gotta tell me whassup with that wack cosplay chick. neighbor? break-in? u invite rollplay hookers over when i was asleep?
Miguel Ruelas // 07:13or shit maybe I dreamt it, doesnt explain the bruise on my leg unless something happened that i forgot
Miguel Ruelas // 07:14anyways congrats bro on the house. lets catch up next week im off to church. cleaned up some of the mess. love u bro

I looked around to find that the madman actually cleaned everything. The pillows were arranged on the couch, the beer cans sorted into the recycling bin outside, and even the counters looked like he gave them a clean wipe. I responded:
Cody Dunsmore // 11:12Thanks for cleaning up dude, you didn't have to do that! Let's chill next weekend. Not much else to do when everyone moved away :/

Feeling disgusting, I rushed upstairs to take a shower, getting off the sweat and stench of a failed all-nigher. My shower thoughts brought me back to that dream in another world: getting slashed by a crazy roleplayer and encountering strangers in some semi-modern renaissance world. I looked down at my left hand, as if the warm shower water wasn't enough to tell me whether or not the flesh parted like a bad haircut. But all I found was smooth skin.

It must have been a shared dream, like Inception, because I still don't recall inviting anyone over: hell, I don't even know who to call. But as the scalding water relieves the pounding in my head, I find that all I can think of is the magical woman I fought in my dreams, how she straddled me, threw knives at me, and cleaved that heavy greatsword straight into the middle of my lacrosse stick.

I dried myself off before a different kind of pleasure could emerge from those thoughts: I was more absorbed by the strangeness of that vivid and continuous dream. My curiosity led me to try opening the door to the closet, finding another door behind it that looked as if its handle were blasted with a blowtorch.

I just assumed I'd forgotten there was no closet. Were these pre-builds originally intended for a hotel chain or something with the neighbor door? It didn't make sense at all, but I knew I wouldn't feel safe, and I was actively looking for any kind of excuse to make something stupid in my robotics workshop.

After a drive-thru breakfast, I went to the home improvement store to get one of those school-shooter-stopping door stops: one level shy of something permanent like bolting the damn door in place. With a spare microcontroller, I hooked up a hall-effect sensor and a buzzer — a magnet sensor and a loud speaker, basically — to detect if that door was ever to move. By soldering the wires to the breadboard, along with some AA batteries, and using generous dollops of hot glue to stick it to the inside wall of the strange-looking door, I called it a day around 9:30 PM, returning to my bed for an early night of sleep so I could get up tomorrow, only to spend four hours doom-scrolling through the week's sordid politics.

I consider all these details right now when I'm driving ten over the speed limit. It's not wondering if the notched cut in my lacrosse stick was from when Miguel and I were drunkenly tossing a tennis ball outside, nor is it my missing iPod Classic. It's how I could have possibly screwed myself over this bad.

I set three alarms. Either my dumb ass shut them off in succession, I slept through them, or I did bad math in figuring out the absolute latest I could wake up, forgetting that I had to take a shower. Now I'm screaming down the highway, hating myself as I KNOW that I'm going to either make it right on time or a couple minutes too late.

I skipped breakfast when that ulcerous, cantankerous feeling arrested my stomach, running the numbers over and over and over about how long it would take me to get there. Now I calculate every second as I pull into the last roadway snaking up into the canyon, taking tight turns that jostle my backpack against the back seat, nearly screeching my tires when I pull up to the front gate.
Eight fifty-three on the dashboard.

The gate guard waves me through. Apparently two years is long enough for him to remember my face. I clip the badge to my wrinkled work shirt and gather my bag when my Subaru fits in the last spot available, sneaking in the back door.
Eight fifty-eight.
I sneak in with the technicians finishing their first union-mandated break. The ones I worked with make fun of me for being lazy, calling me an "eighter-skater".
Eight fifty-nine.
I climb the stairs. The rows of cubes are empty, and the sinking feeling deepens. What room is the meeting in? Was it thirty minutes earlier? I'll have to guess since I didn't check mail or Teams.
Nine o'clock.

I try to calm my breathing or else I'll embarass myself further. Fuck, the door's shut. I open the door with a pad and paper in my other hand, meeting six sets of eyes as I retreat to the back, not a chair left for me to sit in.
"Barely on time, Cody," Nav says. In the dark room, his face is only lit by the computer, and the window of emails is up on the projector.
"I'm sorry. I—" don't add kindling to the fire by using an excuse: I find I'm mostly out after this many years.

Navesh continues. "As I was saying. I swear to be transparent with all of you when it comes to this stuff. They monitor what they tell me, because they know I'll just regurgitate it back to all of you, because you deserve that honesty," he says.

Our team looks on with a knot in their stomachs: to my left, the Robinson-Monroe lifers Wilford Sameshima, a mechanical, and Michael Leguziamo, an electrical. To my right, Kei Sakurajima tensions her nails against her slender arm as she watches me for my own reaction, and mid-rank electrical Scott Valdez buries his face in his notepad.
"You all know the Aerospace Division was expecting the contract. Which means power cell assemblies to design, which means busy work making our existing models fit to their demands," Nav says.
Kei types something into her open computer. My wrist vibrates when she hits the return key:
SAKURA_KEI 09:02:15:I thought I had tenure?

It's an inside joke from when we had several electives together, when a professor was fired right in front of us. She cracks a smile that she fights to hide, trying to lighten the tension just a little. The humor joins the emotions inside my chest like adding oil to water, and not much for words right now, I respond.
DUNSMO_COD 09:02:43:Guess not.
Scott interjects, "So when are we looking at here? For the . . . reduction of staff."
Even the lifers are afraid, tenured with all their tribal knowledge. Wilbur says, "How many per group? I mean, we have a small team."

Nav predicates his next words with a warning. "Now, I'm not sure about any of this because they refuse to tell it straight. We're looking at one to two people, maybe. And we're looking at just before Christmas."
"Just in time to get gifts for my kids," I say, before realizing I've spoken.
"You don't have kids," Kei says.
A nervous chuckle circles the room. Nav looks relieved that I tried to ligthen things: it feels like the first time I've been really useful to this team in a month.

"They're probably going to ask me to make a list again, just like I did three years ago, some of you willl remember that. They're going to force me to rank you. And I'm sure you all know generally where you stand." I feel him staring at me through the back of his head: he doesn't have to turn around.
"A team of six is already pretty damn small," Mike says, mumbling into his folded hands. "We're probably the smallest in the company already."

"Which might mean we're fine. But it's not just six of us anymore," Nav says. I can see the notification come across his computer: one of the executives is waiting to enter the meeting after it is over.
"What do you mean?" I ask, feeling my heart skip a beat. If it's HR, that means the reaper is taking someone away.
"It's seven now. We vetted him before we lost the contract," Navesh says.
"Did he even interview?" Kei asks. "I don't think any of us were there to get to know them."

The executive walks in: it's my boss' boss, dressed to the nines, probably lost since someone like him would never even bother to step into a wing of the company like ours. Behind him is a dark-haired, clean-cut guy dressed like any of us used to: slacks, a belt, and a tucked-in collared shirt. Feels like we should stand at attention for such seniority, but I'm already up. The new recruit isn't nervous at all in introducing himself.
"Nice to meet you all. I'm Reed Broderick," he says. The executive hands him two dozen donuts, and he puts them on the table. "I've heard this is how you make an impression."
"You heard right," Kei says. The animals all reach their hands for the box, but I lean further against the wall.
"So where are you from, Reed?" Michael asks, his mouth full of donut. "And how old are you? We've got a lot of young ones on this team now."
"Twenty-eight. I graduated last year with a Mechanical degree, but I haven't found much of anywhere to work until now," he says.
A year older than I am.
The executive cuts in. "I can assure you that he's the best. You know his father, John: he used to work in Aerospace until he moved up."
"So the legacy continues," Navesh says. "I remember your father! We worked together before they made me the captain of this ship."

Reed exudes the rest of his confidence. "I know I didn't formally interview, but I'm really excited to be a part of this team. Let my work speak for me," he insists, walking around the table to join me in the back.
Navesh squeezes words out under the executive's hopeful gaze: "Well, we certainly have fresh energy with all these young people here."
Reed extends his hand, and I shake it. "Nice to meet you, bro," Reed says, and despite the added tension, I find myself relieved to make another possible friend.
"Cody Dunsmore," I say. I'd compliment his firm handshake if it didn't make me feel like I was becoming my father.
"And I'm Kei. Kei Sakurajima."
She extends her hand as the others rise to introduce themselves like it's the start of a church service. The executive lifts himself from leaning against the door frame.
"Then I guess I'll leave y'all to it," he says.

As the others swarm our unexpected colleague, I try to remember my own first day here, but it was really like any other. It was five hours before IT could get my email working, and although Navesh was warm with his welcome, nobody stood from their cubes to do so much as introduce themselves. I had to bring my own 'new guy donuts' the next day to get the rest of the bean-counters and nerds to acknowledge my presence!

We leave the room as soon as everyone gets their introduction. Nav looks like he wants to say something to me again about my timeliness, but is intercepted by Scott, and as we walk back, Reed takes a particular interest in Kei and I.

"Designated seating, I was told," Reed says. He looks at the new edict from HR, a paper map atop his Bankers box of stuff. "Says I'm right next to you, Kei. Hope you're patient enough for all my questions."
I curse the corporate gods of fate that put me in the empty row with Wilbur.
"That shouldn't be a problem," Kei replies. "Cody's bothered me since day one, and he's still doing it."
"How long have you both been here?" Reed asks.
"Three years and some change," Kei says.
"Are you also new?" Reed asks me.
"No. I've been here for two years,"I tell him.
"Oh." His eyes turn from my box on the map, which still reads SUPPORT ENGINEER, and I know I've been asking the same question.
I feel a finger tap my shoulder after the others pass us. "Can I talk to you for a second?" Nav says.
"Uh, yeah, sure," I tell him. My stomach drops further, realizing I have no idea if there's a bottom. We walk a couple steps to the row with vacant cubes.
I try to take the fire from him by calling myself out first, stumbling over the first words that come to me. "I'm sorry I barely made it on time. Moving shouldn't be an excuse, and—"

"I get it," he says. "But if you were any later, that would have been a reflection on me in front of my boss, and the kind of things that I allow here. I'm not safe here either. But, look. I don't know if you're just burned-out or something: you've been on the threshold of the next level for ages, and I get you're feeling restless, but . . ." He pauses because the next words are uncomfortable. "If I'm forced to make a list, I want you to be ready."
"What do you mean?"
"I mean that you're going to be near the bottom," he says, and then clarifies, "by rank."
"Me and the newer . . . guy?" I ask, hushing my voice so no one can overhear me. Asking about seniority is totally my right, but I'm too damn nervous to bring it up.
"You are, roughly."
The rising feeling makes me ball my fists behind my back.
I guess I only matter if I fucking know someone, I think.

I hold back the strain in my eyes, and I find myself thinking that if my dream wasn't to work in that new building a little higher in the valley, and if the fears of that mortgage weren't so punishing, I'd be actively out looking for something else.
Looking out the window at that building calms me down just enough to pedal a false face of humility. "I understand. I haven't been that great," I say.
