One with such power that it leaves the victims as no more than shaded shadows on the wall, giving the survivors illnesses that carry from generation to generation. Then give those weapons to everyone. And then you'll understand why we don't dispute those silly lines we shake hands over," I tell her.

I realize I've gone a little too far when we're deciding between colors of grapes. Her jaw hangs open. I get the variety pack so Katiya can take them home with her, and usher her to follow me on to the frozen meals section.
"You seem to know a lot about war," she says. "You seem strong for your world. Did you fight?"
"No," I say. "But my brother did."
"Oh."
She hesitates to ask the next question, so I answer for her when we step into the large dairy fridge, feeling the same cold he must have felt when he had the bloody holes in his abdomen.
"But he never came back."
"I'm sorry."
"I just think that—" war is, but I stop myself, unwilling to go that far this soon.
Katiya fills the space with her own words. "It must have been hard."
"It's been hard. It was roughly five years ago. Inspired me to make something in college," I say.
She looks down at her calloused hands, then traces the faint outline of a scar that spans from her eye down her cheek.
I stop her before the pleasantries. "I'd rather not talk about it."
She grasps the mesh of the cart as we walk down the frozen food aisle, maybe feeling again that I detest something about her.
"But I need frozen stuff for work," I say, "and maybe you can get something, too. Have you tried an eggwich?"
"Have you tried an Eglich?" She asks.
"No. Running is for people that hate themselves."

"I guess it fits, then," she says: lacing up a set of minimalist running sandals that look like what the weirdos from Cross Country used to wear. "You sprint for a while, then jog. And you do it again and again until you make it back."
"Or you don't. And you're sure this is safe?"
"Running?"
"No. Being out there," I mean.
"I was out in your world, wasn't I? It's no different for you. Same rules: just don't make too much contact with anyone."
"I've fallen a long way since the intramural sports teams, sitting in a cube in an office all day," I say. "Can't we just jog?"
"I guess. But I was really looking to push myself today."
"Anything above a brisk walk is pushing it for me now," I say. "I'm not even close to your level. And I don't have Essence."

"Because we're trying to live longer than forty-five," I say. "But — well, I guess you have a point with running."

"Our people can live past a hundred and fifty if they have enough Essence. The Mask of the old Northaven royalty is pushing a hundred and sixty, I think — Ullrich, and he looks no older than my mother," she says.
"Good for you, then. Let's just get this over with," I tell her, lacing up the trainers I've kept loose for years so that I can slide my feet into them.
It's only when I see Katiya in her last-century running gear that I notice the fabric she wrapped her bra straps in around her shoulders, and the deep lines of crimson dug in from every single run.
"So you haven't invented that yet, huh?" I mutter.
"Apparently we haven't invented a lot of things," she says, scratching the deep line worn into her shoulders. "What is it now?"
"Hold on," I tell her, returning to my world: stabilizing myself as my mind catches up with the temporal shift, sprinting up the stairs to tear through my dresser for the gym drawer.
"Are you skipping out on me, you pushover?" She asks.

First drawer? No . . . second drawer? Nope . . . and third? I find the tight surf shirt I bought freshman year when I thought I'd have time to ever enjoy the beach: tearing the tag off as I race back down the stairs.
"Where did you go?"
"Something that might help you," I say.

"I have enough hand-me-down boy clothes from the Guard. What makes you think—" but then her fingers touch the fabric. "Oh," she says. "Oh. That's really nice. I see what . . . can you leave for a minute?"
I race back across the threshold. She finagles with the unfamiliar shirt material for about a minute before she says I can come in.
"Well?" She asks.
I crack a smile when I see her wearing the bra over the white surf shirt. I start laughing at her.
"What?" She asks. "Do I look too much like I'm from your world?"

I have to interject between laughs when she wears the upper-body equivalent of socks with sandals. "You look like you belong nowhere! Bra over the shirt? The shirt is the whole point, you fool," I tell her.
She fumes as she removes the bra, holding her other shirt in her right hand. "There. Better now, huh?"

"Should be better for you," I say, wiping a tear from my eyes as I catch a glimpse of the BILLABONG logo stretched out where my chest might loosely brush against it. And two bumps from the cool mountain air flowing through the back window.

She traces the path of my eyes before I can remove them, and when she realizes what's got me flustered, she flips the bottom of the shirt up to double-pad her breast, exposing the toned definition in her abs.
"You degenerate! Tricking a woman into exposing herself like that?" She reaches for the knife block on the counter again.
"No, please, I insist! It's common fashion in my world."
"Women walking around in their underwear? How gods-damn indecent!"

She grabs the knife that almost pinned me to the wall, taking aim as I cower beneath the kitchen table, considering whether to flip it again. And then I realize her world hasn't had flappers or half the women's progress I've taken for granted.
I say, "I swear. Look: I considered taking you shopping for some clothes before I realized how weird that might be."
"I have a boyfriend," she says: one line that seems to survive in any universe.
"I know." One that doesn't run with you anymore.
"And you're not helping with our last rule," she insists. "You remember?"
"You're right," I say: my resentment outpacing that stupid part of my mind that will surely hold on to that image.
She puts her mid-sleeve shirt on over the makeshift sports bra. "Well, let's just get moving."
"Of course," I tell her, pushing down the feeling as the fear of her outside world overtakes me.

He never overtakes me, now that I feel so efficient. Without the weight of my chest digging deeper trenches in the flesh of my shoulders, I feel so much lighter: my mind freed enough to take in the sights instead of staving off the thought of suffering.

It's morning just like it is in Cody's world, but the air feels fresher: not saturated with the smell of gas and engines like the capital. Sometimes I wonder if Cody's world traded the splendor of nature for every other sensation that overstimulates the senses: the taste of meaty crunch shells; the smell tag that hangs from the front mirror of his automobile; the can of meadow-scented musk he sprays around the room when he thinks I'm not looking, to mask the odor of his messes.

And in that absence, I think he's begun to enjoy this world, even though it first terrified him. He huffs behind me in desperate gasps of breath, pleading every quarter-pass around the bottom of Lake Gaffesend to take a break, pretending it's because he wants to take in the view.

"It's incredible," he says, drenched in sweat that saturates an oversized shirt of mine in an upside-down triangle. "This whole area looks like a natural park. Takes three hours of driving to get anywhere like this in Colorado. I'd dream of living here for leisure!"
The words sound so ignorant and pathetic when we're halfway between Gaffesend and the place my life changed forever. "Leisure," I repeat.

"Yeah. My world would have houses all along the shores, with docks and boathouses." He gestures along the distant northern edge where bodies washed ashore last week. "Families floating in the middle of the lake on pontoon boats. With a meal or something, listening to Jack Johnson and—"

Every description he tacks on makes my skin crawl. I feel an anger build that I can only remove with pain, with more running. Maybe it was a mistake bringing out an innocent, yellow-bellied civilian that hasn't seen the slightest sliver of war and what it causes. Like my pathetic father that was so damn soft his bones crunched beneath that scalding beam that—
"Katiya? Hey, what's wrong?" Cody asks. My nails bite the flesh of my palms and I can feel my face running hot with my muscles tensed. "Did I upset you? Or did I take too long a break?"

Your whole life is a fucking break, I want to say, and I feel my jealousy ride on the threshold of that first rule we wrote together. But I see the earnestness in his expression— a feeling nobody in my world has the space for — and it refreshes me, somehow.
I untension my expression. "It's just that . . . our world has no room for talk like that. We don't talk in wishes. We only talk about what's real, and what might be coming."
He purses his lips, tracing an arc of dirt with his toe as he hesitates to look up at me. Seems as if he debates whether to speak his mind on that. "I think that—"
"Katiya?" Another voice says. "Is that you?"

A rush of panic floods my circuits before I can reconcile his name. I glare at Cody, gesturing for him to find somewhere to hide — though when I turn around to face him, I find someone else shamelessly walking next to him.

Jullian walks with Oriya and several of his friends. He tries to bury some sense of shame that threatens to take over, so he hides it with another string of words. "What are you doing out here? Communing with the bushes?"
"I'm going for the run we were supposed to go on," I tell him.
"Supposed to?" He asks. "We agreed to go on two runs every week. And not at week's end."
"But we didn't even go this week," I tell him, and noticing how the heat rises, his friends walk ahead. "I thought you said you wanted to spend more time together."

"I was going to tell you," Jullian says. "But you never go on patrol, staying in the town. So it feels like you hardly want to spend time with me, and I'm trying to do the quests that feel like they actually prepare me."

My eyes dart between the trail and the underbrush where Cody hides. While Jullian makes his case for ignorance, Cody's expression cycles between disbelief and anger on my behalf, but I shake my head at him, insisting we keep our worlds separate.
Jullian notices my lapse in attention. "No, what?"

"I just . . . don't buy it," I say. "If you really cared about us, about all those years we spent together fighting for a chance at this side of the warfront — if you really cherished what we built together, you would make an effort. Even the smallest thing!"
"I did make an effort," Jullian says. "We spent the entire end of last week together!"
"That was about an hour. And it was before you insisted on meeting your friends at the bar!"

"I asked for you to come. And just like the celebration all those weeks ago, you refused to even try meeting other people in the Guard." He looks around to make sure no one else is around. "Look. I didn't want to bring this up, but I get it if you're humiliated about what happened. The other guards have been talking, but I've been standing up for you," he says. "Every chance I get. And it's exhausting."

"What I wanted was for you to stand with me. How can we stay close if all you ever do is support me from a distance? I needed you that night. Why didn't you even come check on me? Why did you choose your friends over me again?"

"Because . . . it's just a lot, you know. You have this brilliant energy about you. The reason I love you. But ever since we came to Gaffesend, it feels like you've changed. So much fuller of these plagues of anxiety and panic, and—"
"Are you coming or not, Jullian?" one of his friends says.
"Just a minute," he shouts, before turning to me again. "And I'm trying to calm down. To get us to calm down, because we've made it here, and we have no reason to be so afraid."
"What does that have anything to do with being there for me?"
"Because I'm tired, Katiya. And—"
Cody makes a motion with the zipper on his trousers and cuts across the brush behind Jullian, giving him a start.

"God abo— I mean, Gods above, I'm glad we stopped for a minute," he says, stretching his legs a couple times as my boyfriend turns to confront my housemate. Even though Jullian might be taller and fully Essenced, he looks like a beanpole compared to Cody.
"Who the res are you?" Jullian asks. Then the strangest sense of recognition overtakes him. "Oh. You're that strange scientist from the Royal Academy! With the glowing square."
"Yep," Cody says. "No idea what this disagreement is about. But your friend was getting upset about all the missed runs, and needed a running partner. So I filled in."
"She's my girlfriend," he says. A certain calculus plays in his head, shrivelling his face in a sneer as his mind re-runs the social arithmetic. "And you live close by?"

"Yeah. We're next door-neighbors. The Royal Academy put me here in the military district. Since the houses are already sanctioned for the fighting types, and it's not always a full class that rolls through every time, they had a couple units left over."
Jullian's eyes flash between the two of us, and to his friends slowly vanishing down the path. I watch a certain confidence change inside of him.
Cody laughs. "She's really your girlfriend? I swear, I never see you over there."
"Because I've been busy," he insists.

"Well, don't get too busy, then," Cody says. Your girl is beautiful. And if you don't spend enough time with her, she might just run away." Cody's eyes narrow with a humored smile. "With someone else."
"Jullian! Come on. It's gonna be dark before we get back," his friends shout.
Cody says, "You're already in the clothes for it. Wanna finish this run with us and ditch your friends? I have some . . . designing stuff . . . to do after this, so I can't stick around."

Jullian hesitates. His eyes meet mine as he squirms between choices, but after a while, it seems the guilt isn't strong enough. "I already have plans. But let's go tomorrow. How about I stay over tonight?"
"And stay?" I ask.
"Yeah. And we'll go tomorrow," Jullian says, starting to run in the opposite direction to catch up with the other cadets.
"You sure?" Cody asks, but Jullian's already running away. He turns to me, squinting his eyes with a smug grin. "I can see why you like him so much."
"And why's that?"
"He runs even more than you do," Cody says. "You found the only man whose mental gymnastics can outpace your neurotic level of fitness."
"Oh, shut up," I tell him. But instead of finding a vacant space inside my chest, I find it filled with something else.
A sense of reassurance.
"What a loser," Cody says. "So many guys I've met in my life like him: especially back in college. Do you really have no other options? In my world, you'd never pay for a drink in your life!"

I think of all my female friends from the capital that settled in with children at a young age. Their softness and tenderness. And the way the other men we went out with would look at me: no more than a friend; as almost another guy; unsightly with all the scars from my past. "Not ever in this world," I say.
"Then this world sucks," Cody says. "You're hot." Then adds, "But it's too bad I don't fall for people that stab me."

"But this world is all I have," I tell him. "And your world is all you have. And Jullian really loves me. We got each other through training, watched each other's sibllings, supported each other enough to make it here, we did everything together!"
"But people can change. And now he's a small fish in a much bigger lake." He stretches his legs as he digs his heels into the dirt, preparing to make it back without a break.
"But he's all I have," I say, and I mean it. The volume of all those cherished memories is too heavy to ever tip the scales.
"If you say so," Cody says.
We begin jogging back. I run at practically a walk so Cody has enough breath to speak in fuller sentences.
"But thank you," I interject. "Really, though. For standing up for me."
"He just needs to realize. How much you're worth, Katiya," Cody says. "If you really insist, on this guy, then . . . you've gotta, shake him out of it."
"Okay," I say.
"Yeah," he huffs. "So. Are there . . . any other friends . . . I can meet?"
"You're the science fella," Paxton says, taking a deep swig from the mug in our favorite spot in front of the window. "So you're here for a while, huh?

"The Royal Academy sent me here for a while," Cody lies, reciting the story we rehearsed on the tail end of the run. He crushes the ale almost as fast as Ryder and Pax do, because he was in some alcohol training program in college — at least from how he explained it to me.

I managed to gather all of us at the front of the bar: Aldrin wasn't lying when he said drinking is all you really had to do when the week ends. Naya wets her tongue with a glass of water on the end, too nervous to talk. Bertram, Ryder, and Pax crowd around the middle seat where Cody tries to remember all the important details.
"The device you showed us that night was really interesting," Ryder says. "How did you make it?"
"Some new non-Essenced technology that runs on electricity," Cody says. "Who says you're always going to have access to Essence?"
"So it's for the people, then? Guards are always brimming with Essence," Bertram says. "But I can see how that would be useful for the civilians."
Cody swirls the mug around, probably wondering why I stick to water like the Ahkvasan. "Yeah." He turns to Naya. "So. You're actually part cat?"
My other friends are taken aback by his sudden outburst.
"Where the Res are you from?" Bertram asks.
"You can't just say that," Pax insists, as Cody disappears behind his mug. "Even to half-bloods." He turns to me. "Where did you say he was from again?"
"Uh . . ." I try to think of the most remote place I can think of. "From Blackwater?"
"I'm from Blackwater!" Ryder exclaims.
Fuck.
"What part of the city did you live in?"
"Uh . . . north?"
"No way," he says. "That's where I was from. How did you make it out?"
Cody glares at me for help, but not even I know anything about Blackwater. He defaults to the basics. "With my, uh, technology."

"Did you develop for the Academy? How the Res did you survive the frosthards? Not even this snowdrifter kid I knew growing up, er . . . my brother's friend . . . could stay out there for more than a couple days."
"I don't think he really wants to talk about it," I say.
Cody looks relieved as he finishes the last swig.
"I get it," Ryder says. "I gave up a lot getting away from that frostbitten prison."
Our group fills the silence with a few sips. But Naya surprises us when she speaks up.
"Well, not a lot of Humans up here have seen the Ahkvasa," she says. "Only fire-blooded people survive up here. Our race lives in the jungles. Far from the cold."
"So what can you do?" Cody asks.
She raises the water glass that's empty besides a few drips, turning it over in the air, allowing the last drip of water to exit the rim of the glass.
Then she focuses.
The drip decelerates to a slow crawl as it floats through the air. and the harder she squints her jade eyes, the slower it travels, until it almost reaches a halt.
Cody's jaw drops as she relinquishes her control, allowing the drop to splatter against the table. "You can float things?"

"Float?" Naya laughs: a rare sight, probably thinking he's even more ignorant than Pax. But it's refreshing to re-experience the most mundane aspects of the world through a new set of eyes. "Time dilation."
"Time travel?" Cody asks.
"No," Naya says. "You can't go back, only slow things down. This world doesn't have time travel. Unless, maybe, if you're a Mask or something."
"Huh. In my world—"
I slap my hand against his chest.

He coughs. "Excuse me. In my town, we called them furries. But they'd wear these suits. Pretty impressive." He then realizes Ryder is present, glaring at him quizzically, and adds, "but only in a small area, after this one incident where this guy, uh . . . nevermind."
"You sure you're from Blackwater?" Ryder asks.
"Maybe he's one of those weird rich types, dressed like that," Pax says.
Cody digs himself further. "Had to escape my family. They were crazy."

"No kidding, damn Merlot. How they can lie to a whole people and keep their composure like that," Ryder says. He claps Cody on the back. "Makes me respect you if you wisened up when you had it all like that. I like you, Cody. That must have been hard: harder than anything I've ever been through."
Cody hangs his head. "Thanks, bro." He takes a swig. "So anyways, how do you all know Katiya?"

Cody continues to interrogate each of my friends, and despite the odd force that transforms his language into mine, he speaks with such a charisma that they don't even realize all the questions he's asking.

He manages to get their opinions of Jullian. He learns of my connection to Bertram, and how he saved me on the night of the fire. He even manages to develop a few in-jokes with them, calling Bertram "Barry" and coaxing Pax to do his frozen shotglass trick.

By the time it's over, it's like he's "one of the boys." And when the sun crosses the top of the window, casting its rays to signify midday has passed, we bid goodbye to them, asking again where Cody lives, to which he responds with a generic answer.
We walk back in silence in our running clothes. I notice the absence of a pain that used to dig into my shoulders.
"I'm exhausted," Cody says when we cross the entry door. "I'm good at acting like I'm social, but my battery runs out fast."
"You did well today," I say.
"You think they liked me?" He asks, showing the last sliver of energy he's stored for our goodbye. "Not that I care what they think. I'll probably never see them again."
"They liked you a lot," I say. "Maybe they didn't buy every lie, but you gave them a good time."
He scratches the back of his head. "Say. I know we made that rule to not get too invested in each other's lives, but how about we help each other out?"
"What do you mean?" I ask him.
"Well, you have Jullian, and that childhood friend that likes you."
"Bertram?" I ask. "Not a chance. We're like siblings with how we grew up."
"How cliche," he says.
"What?"
"Nothing. But if I help you with Jullian and your denial of feelings for the other guy, how about you help me with mine?"
"What do you mean?" I ask for a second time.
"I got this girl I've liked for a while," Cody says. "The one we talked about at Costco. And you're a girl. Maybe we could help each other out."
"It would keep us in our worlds," I say. "Not longing to cross this door and live on the other side forever."

"Exactly. Because we sure as hell aren't getting together," Cody says. "I'll keep Jullian on his toes. And you help me with Kei. Because if we're forced to share the same space, we might as well help each other."
"I think that will work just fine," I say.
"I think that will work just fine," Reed says. "What do you think?"

But he's not talking to me. He's approached almost every engineer in the office to ask their opinion about his design choices, and now he's back there with Wilbur, preventing him from dozing back off into his "wake apnea".

I scratch away at the yellow engineering pad, sketching my own ideas instead of relying on others all the damn time. It's easy to draw in 3D when it's just a plate with a few holes in it: far different from the radical ideas my adversary is coming up with.
"What's up with all the rounds?" Wilbur asks. "It costs a lot of money to ask the machinist to clean up every edge like that."
"Huh. I never thought about that," Reed says.
Because he's never been in a machine shop, I think to myself.

Wilbur rambles for another thirty minutes about the history of drafting. Reed eagerly nods his head, and I think it's beyond the level where he's just listening until he can escape. All the while, I consider the different ways I can design the enclosure, sketching several different designs between scrolls through social media to keep up on the people I used to know.
He pops up like a jump-scare when I have my head down, trying to skip an ad about a freemium game. "What have you come up with so far?" Reed asks.

"Not much, really." He should probably learn on his own that designing for aesthetics gets you shot down harder than a Russian jet over American airspace. "Mostly just figuring out how to enclose the thing."
"Huh," he says. He turns his new computer over to me, showing his model of parts that aren't put together yet. "I'm not very good at assembling things yet with this new software."
"Too familiar with SolidWorks?" I ask.
"How did you know?" He asks.
"Who isn't," I say. "I hate this software. But I've been forced to use it for so long I've used it ten times as much as all the SolidWorks in undergrad."
"You're smart for a relatively new guy," Reed says, laying the compliments on thick like he does with damn near everyone. "We'll be fast friends," he says.
Sure, I think.
"Sure," I say, amicably.
"So what did you do over the weekend?"
I talk like the other middle-aged men, minus the stuff about the yard I don't have. "Not much, just went to Costco and went on a run."
"We missed you at the work social," Reed says. "Is it true you've never been to one of them?"
"I just get tired easy." And then I whisper, "I get enough home improvement and little-league talk in the stand-up meetings."
"Even Kei made it," Reed says. "She said she tried to call you."
"Yeah. I just wasn't feeling too great." I start sketching on the yellow pad to try to look busy enough to get him to leave.

"Well I hope I'll see you next time," Reed says. He exits to the floor, off to bother some underpaid union technicians with even more stuff they'll have to assemble. I continue sketching on the notepad, returning the headphones to my ears I bought after I lost Jackson's iPod Classic.
"Quite the eager fella," Wilbur says.
"Yeah," I say. "I guess it hasn't gotten to him yet."
I see him peek his head from the divider into the narrow alley: a balding Asian man with glasses and light wrinkles. "Has it gotten to you?"

"I don't know," I say. The rusted wall fan makes enough noise that only Wilbur can hear my words, so I feel like I'm able to speak openly. "I think I just had a different idea of what engineering was. I liked designing things. But it was when something happened to me — or to someone in my family, I guess — that really made me chase it." I look at the 3D-printed mini model on my desk that I made to show my brother all those years ago. He was amazed by it: so similar to the tech he got to use in the military.
"So I'm guessing it wasn't batteries," he says, narrowing his eyes in a sagacious smile.
"More so flying things. But smaller. And not for people," I say.
"Drones," he says. And when he answers right, I hand him the little geometric prototype. "This is really cool! When did you make this? And did you make a full-size one?"

"Yeah," I say. "For Senior Design: after the incident, they let me pretty much be my own sponsor if I could fork the cash." I feel a rare sense of passion flood my body, and for a moment, I feel almost like Reed. "I led the team to develop it: they let me take on some junior engineers at the school. And you see those gears?" I point at a small pattern in the lines of PLA plastic.
"Yeah. Heck — if this is like 1:10 scale, those must have been really small," Wilbur says.

"Took us damn near a month to find a solution for that. Bevel gears? And that small, with a D-shaft that didn't fit any existing gears we could order?" My chest runs with the excitement of those days as my tongue spouts off with jargon. "You wouldn't believe what we had to do to make it work. Last month of a senior project we had a whole year for, and that was the last thing we had to resolve."
"Gearbox design is fun," he muses. "So how did you do it?"

"Get this: one of the teammates' moms knew another mom that ran a jewelry company. They did lost wax castings— you know, where they pour in the molten metal to take the shape of the wax?" I pause, realizing I'm talking to a lifer. "No, I'm stupid. Of course you know that."
Wilbur laughs, egging me on.

"Anyways, we got this jewelry company to make our gears. Arrived the last week: only a single shot to get them right. And they were perfect: each wrapped in an individually-wrapped vellum bag as if we'd put them on stings and wear them around our neck," I say, out of breath with excitement, and when I realize the fan has been off for a while, I find Nav and Kei standing at the other end of the cube.
"That's really awesome, Cody," Naveen says. "Why did you never tell us about that before?"
"And you didn't even tell the best part," Kei says.
My face flushes with humiliation, always uncomfortable when I'm the center of attention. "I don't know," I mutter, "which part?"
"He won best in show for his year," Kei said.
"Oh, please," I beg. "I had an uplifting story. And they have a reputation to uphold—"
"—And the president of the university took him on a little tour to speak on campus. The press got involved. And he got his story in the Los Angeles Times, can you believe that?"
She points to the article that hangs on the wall of my cubicle:
BROTHER OF FALLEN SOLDIER DESIGNS THE FUTURE

Beneath the big font on the front page are two pictures: one of Jackson and I when we were kids, and a photo of me directing my team in a suit — that last hour of the project when we were rushing in full suits and dresses, wearing smocks over our formal clothes, spray-painting the prototype black.

"Yeah. It was fun. And that's why I'm here," I say. But the high from that memory leaves when reality returns: I freeze my face in the genuine smile I had a minute ago not to lose it, to insist redlines for battery enclosures shouldn't be any different.
"I sure was proud of my boy," a voice says.
I realize it's lunchtime.
My father Alan, a technician, steps between Kei and Nav.
"That's right. You told us a little about Cody before the interview," Nav says.
Dad scratches his salt-and-pepper beard. "Yeah. He used to build things with me in the garage. Now he just designs things on that computer, thinking that's the real world and all!"
"Alright, that's enough, Dad," I say.
"You didn't even finish my redline. The one with your name on the drawing? Those two damn 5/16-18 hex screws that are so close they can't fit a ratchet on them? I put a toolbox together for you."
"Alright," I repeat, grabbing my keys.
"—Not that Harbor Freight shit. I'm talking Snap-On, Gear Wrench, and you must not even touch that stuff if you're that blind to it!"
The three engineers laugh as I rush to push my greasy father out the door.
We're snaking down the switchbacks of Shaleborough Canyon when he decides to take another dig at me.
"I don't think I've ever seen your car this clean." He drags one of his dirty fingers across the dashboard.
"It'll only get dirtier if you get your greasy paws all over it," I tell him.
"Did a girl finally make it into your life? Sweet Jesus, I thought you'd be stuck in that game room of yours playing the Nintendo forever," he says.
"Maybe I did," I say. "Or maybe some girl in my complex wanted to use me for my Costco card."

He sniffs and does a dad cough before offering some fatherly wisdom. "You see, son, women are like raccoons. They'll tear through all the trash you have to offer until you give them something shiny that keeps their interest."
"So Mom is a raccoon," I say, expecting him to relent.

"Well, your mother had the deepest bags under her eyes when she was teaching in the Los Angeles school district. If a woman can handle a gaggle of rats that try to kill her every day, then you know she's tough enough to handle someone like me," he says.

He rambles on about living life at my age in the poor part of Los Angeles, and after a couple more turns, we pull into the only lot that gives us enough time to get him back on union time. He says some choice words about the people around him. Then the gossip from the floor, saying how the men he works with whine more than "any of those housewife shows the stay-at-home moms watch." And by the time we walk in the door of the Wendy's, he's silent enough for us to order and sit in one of the plastic booths, wetting his hands with a bottle of Purell before wiping the sullied table with his dirtier work shirt.

I glance at the play structure from the nineties that I used to play in, when my father drove down the canyon to meet the rest of our family, spending no longer than the time we have now to check in with us. He worked two shifts for the overtime, to give my brother and I enough to flourish with a full childhood, and when he catches me lost in that memory, he gestures to one of the structure's cross-bars zip-tied to a pool noodle.
"You almost broke your nose on that damn thing," my father says. "You remember?"
"Oh, I remember," I tell him. "Chasing Jackson down the slide. He ducked and I didn't see it, then I spouted so much damn blood—"

"Like a fountain. And your mother was so panicked," he laughs, "tearing a whole stack of napkins one-by-one out of the dispenser, while I was smart enough to ask the front for a whole roll of paper towels!"
I chuckle. "Those were times."
"Good times?"
"Good enough to remember," I tell him, just as the tray arrives with our dollar-menu burgers.

He picks the pickles out of one of his, then takes a deep bite before rubbing his mouth with a napkin. I bite into mine just as he opens his mouth to speak, halfway through a mouthful. "You know I meant what I said back there."
"About the redlines." I dip my fries in ketchup.
"No, doofus," he says, staring at me with piercing eyes like mine. "About the project."
"The drone," I say.
"Yeah." He takes another bite, and hunger blocks his next thought for another thirty seconds or so. "You made me so proud that day. I hope you still have that project."
"I do," I say.
"Have you worked any further on it since you moved out? You have the tools now," he says. "And now you know enough to really finish it."
"I'm not sure it would even fly anymore," I tell him.
He shakes a fry at me.
"That's a shame."

"I just had a lot of energy I had to put somewhere in a really short period of time. After the service at Fort Dietz. After I read that last letter, I had burning purpose, you know? If I didn't stop, I think that truth would break me entirely." I sink my teeth into the burger again, distracting myself enough with something savory to prevent the habit of those feelings from coming back.
"We each had our own ways of dealing with it," my father says. "You either channel that empty feeling or it snags you. Catching up in every little moment of those habits he shaped in us."
"Yeah," I say.

We closed his bedroom door for months, petrified the exact way he left it. And we were too afraid to open it, just saving that last experience of throwing open the door like the last voicemails on our phones.
Because once the door was opened, he'd remain nothing more than a memory, forever.
"You reminded me a little of him today," he says.
"Oh yeah?"
"Well, you're the age he was now. Your voices sound alike. And when I was done with that soyboy man-bun kid, ragging me over with questions about some stupid enclosure design—"
I laugh. "You mean Reed?"
"Yeah, whatever. But anyways, when I came up the metal stairs to the room with all the office pukes, I almost thought I heard your brother."
"Huh."
"I just never hear you passionate like that, son," he says.
"Yeah. Redlines are shit."
"But you're not like any of them. Maybe besides that legacy hire friend of yours."
"You really think?" I pull down my eyelid after wiping the salt from my fingers, rolling my right eye into the back of my skull. "Can you see it? Is there a soul still in there?"
"Cody, I mean it," he insists. "I've been working here for a long time, and I've come to understand there's two types of engineers."
"And what's that?"
"There's the ones that do it for the money. The lifers: satisfied with slow work that never changes, with such tribal knowledge that they'd take the whole company down with them if they died."
"That sounds like me without the experience," I say.
"But you're not," Dad says, shaking another fry at me. "You have passion! You're going to design rockets one day. You're the dreaming type that wants more."
"All I dream of is not fucking up," I tell him. "Type two in theory, type one in practice. And I feel like I'm barely surviving the cuts."

"Cuts or not, I just don't want you to lose that part of you that makes you special," he says. "My sons both have . . . had the same spark that I had. The knack. And I want you to live by it the rest of your life."
"I'm working on it. With the job you have, you should know nothing's ideal more than anyone," I say.

We grab the trays, tilting them into the trash as we sip from a second refill. Having exhausted two weeks' worth of real conversation at a man level, he rambles further about floor gossip all the way back, telling me to "finish his damn redlines" as he opens the shop door for me to get back to work.

The rest of the day passes slowly when everybody else is gone: everybody besides Kei and I. The lifers leave early: forced to come in when it's still dark out so they can take care of their teenagers — or if they don't have kids, maybe drink at the bar or something. The young type-A engineers leave a little after so they can make the most of summer's long evenings, whether it's running or biking  out on the trails in the open fields between the housing developments, or finding the motivation somewhere to run a load of laundry.

Then Nav leaves, and Reed and Kei say goodbye to him. Then Reed tries to talk to Kei, the only one left in the section, who responds with short yes-and-no answers unless he throws a free-response question at her. Then Reed drags a bunch of virtual cards around his computer, playing Solitaire for almost an hour until he can clock out half an hour longer than eight hours. Then he says goodbye to Kei, then it's absolutely silent for an hour beyond Kei's mouse clicks, and when 5:00 rolls around, I shoulder my bag and wave goodbye to the workaholic girl I have a crush on, reminding her that there's still a world out there.

But this time, it felt different. And it's consistently felt a little different. Maybe Dad is right that I've changed, because instead of leaving the long dragging hours of boredom to find respite in inaction, there's a part of me that wonders what's happening on the other side of the door.

But it isn't much, and ever since I photocopied the rule sheet that Katiya and I wrote up, the first and last rule catch my eye every time I reach to open the door. Maybe it's just the prospect of that mystical threshold that fills me with excitement. Maybe it's the images and feelings she's left me with that I still fight like hell to resist. Or maybe it's fear of what could happen, overriding the boredom of modern life that comes when you get on the other side of adolescence.

The house is silent when I pull in: the garage door groans as its panels screech back in place. Sometimes I imagine finding her sitting there with a bag of my chips in her combat armor, watching Netflix, but she's been so busy the last week or so, and even though I haven't found a reason to unlock my side of the door since we last went for that run, I feel the urge to let in a chance for something to happen.

I refuse to let in a chance for anything to happen, and that's why I rise early. Earlier than the knocker that comes to wake me. Earlier than the sun: early enough that the morning hours mask my presence while I wear the hood of my uniform, tucking my golden locks of braided hair beneath the fabric.

There's still the early risers that do their training in the mornings, and with the approach of our first competencies that all city guards are required to take, the training fields and the alleys between the barracks bustle with far more sweaty servicemen.

So it's no surprise when the cover of dusk no longer hides me. I hear their whispers when I pass — or maybe half the time I think I hear them — calling me "choke" and making a gagging motion, or asking again why I even bothered, some even saying I'd be better suited "for the shady brothels where I could at least be paid to choke on something." Gossip is easy. Giving up is easy, too: but when I feel the weight of the house key in my pocket, trying to estimate how much heavier it was before the first cadet failed their trials, I remember the other choice is death, and it's a much stronger wind in my sails than whatever storm these troglodytes can throw at me.

My shoulder scrapes the left wall as I take every narrow alley I can. It's the first day I've decided to visit him, because for the last two weeks, I've rued the thought of leaving the infirmary to face their ridicule in broad daylight, though none of them have ever faced anything close to what I've fought.

His messages told me that he'd crack the back door of his room in the single-story medical building, and when I find some old, thick tome called FEAR THE CHYMAERA wedged in one of the doors, I cautiously creak it open.

"So you finally came to check on me," Bertram says. Despite his graze with death, he's the clearest example of why the Royal Guard juice their soldiers on heavy Essence. "You saved me just in time. The medic said my organs would start shutting down, one by one, if you arrived any later."

He gets up from the bed in his white hospital gown labeled HARLOWE-B, stretching with a few twists before he approaches. Despite the pallidness of his skin, and the darkened marks on his extremities from where the Chymaeran Curse seized his body, he seems no less capable than any day I've seen him before.
"So why are you still here?" I ask.

"The damage is inside, and it will take a while to heal," Bertram says. "My outside is as handsome as ever, but that assassin did a number on my insides. Said I can't start training again for another two weeks or so."

"Oh," I say. I sit at the chair next to the window. Between the gravel lot outside and the brutal concrete walls, it feels more like a prison infirmary than anything else. "I think I'd get sicker just by staying in this room," I say. "Do you get to walk around outside, at least?"
"Not really," he says. "But thinking of the effort you guys put into saving me, it makes me feel full."
I smile. "You're worth it. Plus, I kind of owed you for a while."

"I wish I could have a cool scar like you," he says, tracing a finger across his face from brow to cheek. "You must be celebrated out there for all that. Have you paid for a single drink at the bar since then?"
My smile fades. "It's easier to talk poorly about people than to praise them. And I choked a little too much."
"But a noble is alive because of you!"

"But the wife won't forgive me. She made a whole show of it at the town hall before they left. Blamed it all on me, though I didn't pull the trigger." I sigh. "But at least Aldrin knows the worth of my efforts."

He rummages under his bed. "Well, it might have been a while ago, but I think I can be the first," he says. I hear the clatter of glass as he tears through his meager possessions that they let him hold on to. A drawing of the two of us floats across the floor, and I recognize the artistry from my father.
"When was this?" I ask. "And why was it here?"

He blushes: the first sign of life I've seen on his pallid face as he holds two bottles. "Just remembering the ones that got me through it," he says, and then he hands me one. "Ryder and Pax and Naya came by last week. They smuggled in a six-pack, so we had four of them. But I saved two for the day you came back."

I laugh, looking around cautiously as I grasp the neck of the bottle. The Essenced heat of my hands heats the metal cap enough for it to expand, popping off with a light thunk, and we cheers over half-a-success and half-a-failure.
But I can tell something is still on his mind. And after he wets his mouth a couple times with the ale, quickly chugging so we can hide the evidence, he finally speaks.

"You know, I thought about some stuff when I was on the edge," he says, sitting on the left side of the hospital bed in his white gown. "I thought about all the things I hadn't done yet. That I regretted putting off."

"I understand that fear completely," I say, as I sit beside him. "The world is so random and chaotic, sometimes it makes you wonder if the Gods stopped watching a long time ago. But you've been blessed with more time."

"More time to express my feelings," he says: a look of hesitation on his face. "In the week I was on the brink of death, I wrote letters in case I didn't make it. But then I survived. I started healing quickly, and with a second shot, I decided I should go back to the place it all began."
My stomach twists at the thought. "You've lived don't mean—"

"And not alone," he says. "I want to go back to the place our lives changed forever. I want to go to Hillfar with you, and I want to tell you something. And that's why," he reaches behind his back to retrieve two familiar forms, "I insisted that the guildscribes make it official."
"Going back there. I mean—" I stammer.
"If you're not ready yet, I get it. But I think it would be good for us, and I just wanted you to be aware, so you can prepare yourself."
I look at the quest form: neatly written in the script of the guildscribes. A high-value, four-star quest, with the purpose written in Bertram's block script that reads FACING A FORMIDABLE PAST.
"Those days in Hillfar cross my thoughts every day," I say. "I thought time would dull them, but I still feel like I'm there right now."
"Of course," he says, looking down at his own sheet.
"The quest involves going there. And I feel like I have to fully convince myself I've left before I go back."
"Then I'll be patiently waiting," he assures me. He reaches to grab my hand. "You're the strongest person I know."
I tension his hand in mine on a spark of courage. "But I swear to Khiras that I'll find it in me before this ends. By the end of this season," I tell him, "I promise you and I will return."
Bertram's smile creases with the dimples he's had since he was a child, taking my quest form to return it to the folder.
"And if you can do that, then maybe I can find the courage, too," he says.
"To go there?" I ask.
"More than that," he replies. "But it doesn't matter yet. It seems you're the one that will have to be brave first."

We leave the challenge at that. Another ten minutes pass before we hear the nurses start to make their morning rounds, so I stuff the two bottles in my rucksack neck-up, along with the thick paper doorstop.

"So you're going on a local quest with double-L, huh?" Bertram asks, reclining back in his bed as he opens an illustrated book about Blackwater. "He must have had his come-to-Khiras moment about you. Or maybe he feels like he's in trouble."
"No—he just has the first group of friends he's ever had," I say. "I want him to enjoy them. Because I know he'll come back."
"With an apology, I hope," Bertram says.
I disappear through the door just as the nurse announces his name. The lock clicks in place as I draw my hood, dissolving back between the alleys as morning turns to day.
"I want to apologize to you," Jullian says.

He takes my hand as we swelter inside the guard tent. I thought an open-air bazaar meant a cooling breeze might flow through every once in a while—or that the tattered tarp above our heads might block the rays—but the air scalds our lungs like sitting in a kiln.

He parts his chapped lips, and his eyes trace the floor in the same tick of nervousness he's had since I met him. But there are still signs we've grown together. And when he takes another pull off his second fill of the canteen, his eyes meet mine, and he doesn't hesitate to speak his mind.

"I'm sorry because I feel like I've gotten carried away," he says. "Away from all the burdens of the old days: days we spent taking care of our siblings when our moms were working to put food on the table, and now that I have the chance to make my first group of friends, it's like taking off ankle weights. And all I want to do is run."

"As long as you don't run away," I say. I tension my sweaty fingers in his, and he returns my strength. "You should have fun during this please. We should both enjoy it: we gave so much of our lives to be here."
He nods.
I say, "And I want to enjoy it together with you."
"Of course—"

"—And you've just been so far away," I say: careful to distill my emotions through the joy of a love I feel so strongly. "We promised to be candid to each other, and . . . when you leave so early in the morning, before I can even wake to see you or touch you, it just makes me feel so alone."
"And I'm sorry," he says.
"Why do you have to leave all the time?"
He stands up, approaching the edge of the canvas window. "I don't know."
"You don't know?" I approach, refusing to let him escape again. "How can you not know?"

"It's just . . . I've spent my whole life living for others. For my siblings, my family—almost like a good childhood skipped me—and I was forced to give it all away to the ones that came after. And now," he says, "I have this freedom I've never had before, and I don't know what to do with it. And any time I wake up sitting there, just standing still, I feel like I'm spending the last seconds of my youth before I get too old to live it, just full of regret."

"But you weren't there," I tell him. He struggles to look at me, but I can sense the pain of loneliness no different than mine. "Why didn't you stand up for me, or at least come to visit in the days after the attempt on that noble's life? Were you . . . ashamed of me?" I remember when he couldn't even return my gaze when we entered the hall with Bertram. It might have been the first event that precipitated this long spiral.

"I had a moment of weakness," he says. "I should have been there, but every second I wasn't, this guilt just kept getting greater and greater, until the point that I was afraid of facing you. That you'd think I deserted you."
"But you did," I say.

"And I've been terrified of this moment ever since," he says. He brushes a strand of stray hair over my ear. His gauntlets grasp the side of my head, tracing his thumb on my cheek. "I've always hated this weakness I've felt my entire life. This cowardice, of a boy that never made friends, made fun of, and was so scared and unchallenged that he never tried to fly." He tears up a little. "And I guess I've taken for granted the one thing I've thought I would always have, supporting me through it all. You," he says.
The anger and sorrow mix at just a level that I feel them rest at a stalemate. "I want to be there for you, Jullian. But I need you to try, just try, to be there for me. And to stay," I tell him.
I tension my arms around his waist, ducking my head beneath his neck as he buries his head into my hair. I mumble something into his chestplate that he doesn't hear.
"What's that?"
"I said, this isn't very comfortable," I say.
We share a laugh, glancing out across the bustling market: a mosaic of merchants and shoppers browsing and bartering beneath the thin linen.
His mouth curls in a grin after he finds the space to relax again. "You know I love you, right?"
"I know that," I tell him.
"I just thought about what that guy you were with the other day said, you know."
"The 'science guy?'"
"Yeah. I bet he's just jealous," he says. A familiar glare of envy glazes in his eyes. "I think when this is over, we should ditch the armor and—"
A sudden commotion stirs beneath one of the tents when we hear shouts far louder than usual.
"—I mean, we should ditch the armor and—"

"Where is that coming from?" I look at today's vendor map, counting three rows over as an assailant wrangles something from beneath a table. My finger traces the map as my other hand finds the marching tent. It's one of the high-end Essence technology-dealing tables.
"We need to get over there," I say. The cable lines are in place, spanning across the market from the top of the tower. And my hand can take the heat of the friction.
"It's not your job, Katiya," he says. "We just wire it in to Command, and they dispatch the experienced guards!"
I feel something twist inside me. "But it will be too late. And we have the height to—"
"I just don't want you to get hurt again," he says.
The thief is already running across the market. And I see the span of cable that can take me to intercept.
He adds, "Just stop trying to be a hero and stay close to me!"

"You don't get it," I say, leaping out the window before he can grab the back of my cloak, before my mind can catch up on what I'm doing, as I withdraw the channeled metal hand-hold and put my full weight on the wire from two stories up.

I'm lucky my panic catches when I'm two stories off the ground: gravity doesn't hinder my hesitation, but only aids it. The panic makes me hold fast to the metal contact: siphoning the friction of the Essence into my circuits in a rejuvenating reversal.

The energy cycles through my body from my arms to my legs, and though my blood freezes with the initial surge of panic, my circuits are scalding with power. The vibrations in the tether rattle the bones in my arms, casting sparks of hot iron, and when I'm close enough to drop and run, I use the force of the fall to dig the toe of my boots between cobblestones. And with all the energy I've stored from letting the blood pool in my legs for four hours—sitting in tight, padded pants—all I want to do is run.

The stones shift their alignment when my boots break the ground. The assailant runs west, crossing back through the market, and though they're a few rows over, shrouded in a tattered crimson hood with an Essence Tool beneath their arm, I'm still the closest to catching them.

We weave between crowds at different speeds. While I waste momentum weaving around civilians, they cut straight through them—but still, they're uncommonly quick for a human, and it's when the wind sheds their disguise that I see the cat ears. Long locks of black hair trail behind them, and in the absence of short fur, it means they're a half-blood, dipping into their gift of Ahkvan Essence to accelerate time around them.
She almost looks familiar, I think.

I vault over the table of a turquoise tent where Kine changes hands. Now the thief is right ahead of me, and instead of shouting, I save my breath to run faster. Time dilates ever-so-slightly around them, casting their shaded features in blue, but I wager that their abilities are nothing compared to my compass.

But all my running has prepared me for this. As they break the edge of the market, approaching the thin line of houses separating the industrial district and old Gaffesend Castle, it seems they're familiar with Gaffesend's best abandoned places to hide.

Jullian shouts something behind me, straining his voice trying to get me to stop, as several other guards give chase. But as we weave between narrow alleys of the tenement homes, I'm the only one that can see the half-blood thief.

The edge of the district is coming near, where a long wooden fence partitions the district from all the abandoned spaces. The assailant takes their time to amble over the edge with the Essenced artifact, and by the time their feet land on the other side, I charge my Essence enough to directly blast myself straight through the wood, casting charred chips of timber toward the abandoned buildings, knowing I'll be paying for it later with another domestic quest.

I can see them clearer now that we're neck-and-neck, and I recognize the tattered cloak looks familiar as it billows behind her. Three steps behind, we approach the old castle shed, separated from the grounds of the Estate. To a layman, it would be a dead end—but for someone with knowledge of the Royal Guards—it's an ancient egress point, and when she enters the small storeroom lined with aged tools from centuries ago, she knows to slip beneath the busted trapdoor to drop down into the ancient tunnels.

If only I had this much adrenaline during the parade, maybe the outcome would be different, because from all the energy coursing through my circuits and veins, I don't think twice about dropping down into the old escape tunnels. Her boots splash in the murky water, crunching the bones of forgotten skeletons that fought the front lines  five hundred years ago. When I land in the calf-high sludge, I cast a plume of fire that bounces between the walls, lighting the lines of the long earthen tomb until it sizzles in the water, just long enough to see her silhouette shrink down the straightaway.
But I'm not letting her go.

A persistent flame materializes above my head, flickering with the musty air as I trudge-run through the roughly-hewn tunnel. The splashing gets louder as I gain on her, turning right, then left, then left again, as I try to remember the maps from the briefing all those months ago.

My race's skill with healing means I'm sensitive to others—and when I attenuate her vitals, I can feel her exhaustion, fighting for breath as we approach what looks like a dead end, only to burst through a door to a stairwell that takes us up into the castle courtyard.

I find the energy to yell. "You're not getting away from me," I shout, and when we break the threshold of the courtyard, we find drifters and vagrants making camp with tattered sheets, stoking fires with their meager Essence. She scales the stairs of the main edifice, and I wonder why she gains height when it only means she's getting further from the ground.

I'm close enough now that I can feel the wind she displaces. She grabs for a steaming pot and launches it at me, casting a spray of boiling soup, but I duck out of the way, regathering my footing as she tries throwing down debris to trip me.
But she wasted too much on the offense. I grab her cloak as we crest the stairs of the old hall, so crumbled from war and the elements that sunlight streams through the ceiling and walls.
"Enough," I shout.

But she tears out a shortsword with her other hand, slicing through the fabric as I stumble. With the Essence Tool still cradled in her arm, she draws her weapon to face me. I drop the scrap of fabric, realizing from touch that it's a guard cloak.
Her sharp blue eyes catch the trainee insignia on my armor, along with my identifying number. "A replacement," she says.
We circle around a table. "You stole that cloak from a guard," I say, as I draw my sword. "Reinforcements are right behind me. You have nowhere to go!"
"You're as disposable as I was," she says. "Your number. Starting with eighty-four means they have you in the house with the lake view."
"How could you know that?" I ask, but I don't let her mind games shake me.
"Because your name is coming off that damn key just like mine was, and you'll have nothing," she shouts, ripping the table aside as she takes her first swing at me.

We trade blows, fighting in a hall that the old Knights once trained in, clashing our swords with echoes of an ancient past. I remember Derry, the baker, and a name that crests my lips as I try to remember.

Our circling runs me into the edge of a table, and unable to evade, she drives at me with a powerful blow, buffeting me with the Essence Tool. I stumble, nearly dropping my sword as she slices across my breastplate, catching metal instead of flesh.
"Rayna," I say. "Why do you do this?"

She pauses for a moment, as if she'd really give an answer. But then she runs for the spiral staircase to the upper floors, and I give chase, just as I hear the other lagging guards approach the hall.

I take two steps at a time, casting sparks as my steel pauldtons scrape the side of the stairwell. I can hear her footfalls directly above me as we get higher and higher and higher, until we reach the very top.

She's running out of avenues to escape. All that's left are the buildings of the old industrial district that border the castle, and when we're four stories up, running across ramparts that look out to a stark cliffside bordering the forest, I doubt she has anywhere to go.

But then she jumps onto a roof of a wooden building in the servants' quarter. She yelps when her foot crashes through the ceiling, withdrawing as I decide to approach from the other side, aiming for the central beam of the frame instead of the eaves.

We're neck-and-neck as she lumbers with the stolen tool and I struggle with my armor, not quite in grabbing distance when the fall is too much of a consequence. She's heading for the other side of the castle rampart bordering the industrial warehouses, and when I think I'm about to grab her, she channels all her Essence into accelerating for one final sprint.

My breath tastes like poison when it leaves my lungs. Falling further behind, I watch as she runs directly for the edge of the castle wall, as if to jump to her death. But without hesitation, she clambers onto a straightaway of stone slabs, managing seven strides before she launches herself over the edge.

She vanishes from sight. And I wager she's planned this all from the start: planning to live and steal another day, so before the hesitation seizes my muscles, I take the same seven steps and launch myself over the edge.

I can feel the turbulence of wind as gravity comes to collect on my four-story climb. Behind me, I hear Jullian cry my name, and beneath me, a yawning gap spans a thousand years of progress between the old castle and the tall industrial building.

We float in the air at the same time, flying like the Auvryan angels of their floating lands. Her Ahkvan reflexes give her just shy of nine lives to land. I hinge my legs in anticipation of crashing into the gravel roof, and after she rolls off her fall, I thrust myself with a plume of flames to break my speed enough to twist myself into a barrel roll.

The roof is small, high, and flat, surrounded by the stark eaves of industrial buildings that are unnavigable. Out of breath, she rushes for the roof access door, only to find it locked, desperately jimmying the round handle as she groans in exasperation.
"Drop it, Rayna," I tell her.
She complies, placing the artifact on the ground. "As soon as I failed that test, I was always destined to die. So do whatever you have to do with me."
I quickly glance to the edge of the castle wall, so much higher than I remember. All the guards descended the stairs, running around to reconvene inside the warehouse. And I make a decision.
I reach past her, tensioning my fingers against the knob as it glows with scalding heat.
"What are you doing? But aren't you going to take me in? I'm a part of the Den Of Thieves now!"

"You and I aren't that different. Just separated by time, I fear." I gesture for the door, quoting the report I'll write later. "She got away. But she dropped the high-value tool she might have used to aid the enemy."

A look of shameful relief flushes her face. Sweat mixes with tears she refuses to allow to break the threshold of her eyes. "I never wanted it to end up this way," she says. "Aren't you afraid they'll send you to die? And then what will you do?"
"I don't know," I tell her. "But you can choose something else."

She makes for the stairway as I hear a dozen footfalls reach the gravel lot below. Then she hesitates. "There's something brewing from the East, I hear," she says. "Melenia's had a dangerous change in its royalty. And I've heard things."
"Heard what?" I ask.
"Just stay aware," she says. "Watch the East. And . . . tell my sister, that I'm still alive."
Then she disappears past the threshold. My hands clasp the Essence Tool as I give three seconds before I chase her again, but without wares to weigh her down, I find she's already gone.
"That wasn't our job! That was stupid and senseless," Jullian says. He looks at the bare flesh of my arm, scratched enough from rolling on roof stones that it bleeds in a staccato of open cuts.
I can feel his power mend my flesh as we walk back across the abandoned fields, warming the skin and coaxing it to join again.
"I thought you'd react differently," I say, cradling the artifact in my good arm.

"I think that was reckless, and you could have gotten yourself killed." He looks at the ground with the same expression he wore when Cody called him out. "You're not supposed to do all that hero stuff. You were supposed wait for the real guards."
"The real guards? We are real guards," I say.
"But not yet."
I ball my fists in my gauntlets. "But how can you say that, after I succeeded at that?" I ask.
"But she got away," he says.
"But I recovered the stolen item," I argue.
He sighs. "Yeah. You did. And no, I guess I'm wrong — you did something well this time."
"This time?" I ask. The cereal grasses crunch beneath our boots for the last span of nature until we reach the scalding hole in the fence.

He tries to take my hand, and I let him, but there's little energy behind it. He gestures to the huge hole in the wall. "At least your father worked with wood. I hope he taught you enough to fix this mess."
I usher a laugh.
"But hey, it's cool that you got your moment. I wish more people saw it, though — and not just the homeless that live out there in the ruins."
"I didn't do it for the recognition," I say. "But I hope it helps my case."
"I'm sure it will," he says.

We walk through the same twist of alleyways before returning the item to the shopkeeper at the tent. They add an addendum to my quest form with a page-long note about my efforts, and I enthusiastically fold the pages together, burying them in the pocket of my padded pants.

When we re-emerge in the part of town that hasn't heard of my recent exploits, Jullian tries to flirt with me, but I feel distant. I look down at my battered hands. I think of the fear inside the eyes of that girl, Aleena, just a year older than I was, so consumed by the thought of life after failure that I feel nothing when Jullian kisses me goodbye at the door, refusing again to stay the night.
A sweet smell greets me when I return. I find a small dessert sitting on a polished plate that's obviously not from my world.
It's a cookie.
And scrawled in neat letters that aren't from my world either, I find a small note written on a yellow sticky square in dark black ink:
FOR THE BRAVE KNIGHT NEXT DOOR:
I MADE EXTRA.
YOUR TENTATIVE FRIEND. CODY

It came scrawled in messy letters that weren't from my world, written on a piece of vellum fresh with ink. It was only four words that would send a chill down any man's spine: especially if they came smaller on the screen of a smartphone.
Cody:
We need to talk.
- Katiya

But it came with a plate that wasn't from my world, like some kind of antique I'd find at my grandmother's house, with a hot-cross bun that tasted fresher than anything I'd find at the Sunday farmer's market.

But she wasn't mad at least, I thought. And I was right. She was asking me a favor, because she volunteered me for something I never asked to do, because she considered me weak enough to fill the role.

And after I strolled around her town to size me for clothes that wouldn't make me stand out too much, I find myself now standing in an open lot with loads of other townsfolk, arranged in a laughable formation, feeling like I'm at a little-league lacrosse practice if all the dads were swapped out for the kids.

The Royal Guards line the dirt-and-grass lot with sheathed swords. We all face the most important guy, standing at the front as he tries not to laugh at the sorry arrangement of rejects that are only here for the free beer after the event. But at least it's for a good cause. And she volun-told me in advance early enough that I could take paid time off.

"Gentlemen, I'm honored to gather you all here today," Katiya's commander says. "Though our guards are powerful and skilled enough to defend all of Gaffesend, this a chance for you to develop the tools to defend yourselves. To feel comfortable and safe."

The only time I remember doing anything like this was at some other kid's karate party when I was in first grade. And the instructor had to break the balsa wood plank with his own hands, because I was afraid of hurting myself. I look down at the wooden training sword, hoping it's just an odd prop for one of those weird stretching exercises.
I feel a hand on my shoulder. A stocky man whispers in my ear. "So Katiya roped you into this too, huh? To get her two?"
"I guess so," I say. "My hands are soft: I design stuff all day."

"And I'm a baker. Name's Derry," he says, and I shake his large, calloused hand without turning around—too afraid of getting yelled at, though the three rows of husky townies hide me well. "What part of town are you in?" I don't think I've seen you around.
My nervousness impedes my filter. "I live with Katiya," I say.
"With her?" He asks.
"No. No . . . I mean, close to her. Next to her," I say.
"Oh. So what do you do for the military then?"
My mind races back on Katiya's collection of rehearsed lies. "I'm one of the Royal Scientists' prot g s, so they wedged me in with the others, doing some research in Gaffesend."

"Well I don't blame you for being close to Katiya. If I was thirty years younger, with a body like that, I'd fight a damn war for a woman like her," he says, reminding me of most of the technicians at my work. But the commander's voice cuts us off, before Derry can objectify her any further.

"Most of you are too, uh . . . 'heavy-set' for running, so today will focus on basic, self-defense sword fighting and feats of strength." I flex and feel for the strength in my arms, hoping my two-a-week workouts give me enough muscle to overpower an Essenced tavern-brawler. He continues: "While our brave, senior soldiers guard the borders of Gaffesend, this is a chance for our trainees to pass on their knowledge."

I look to Katiya, flushed with that same sense of anxiety that seems like her factory setting. She musters a smile when we meet eyes, standing next to her beanpole boyfriend with their swords drawn, and as Aldrin rambles on about the value of self-defense like a first-amendment technician at my work, I twirl the wooden training sword in the dirt.

"So we'll start with basic technique. I'm sure most of you have at least been trained a little — maybe by a family member or something." I remember playing defense in Lacrosse, jabbing breastplates with the basket end of my stick, and that's about it: besides shooting clays with my godfather in the FBI — but that's at least a hundred years away for these people.

He shows us a basic downward swing before instructing us to stand further apart. I try a couple swings like all the others, without a single idea of what I'm doing, and when the other cadets start to approach, I catch Katiya laughing at me.
I flip her the bird, hoping sign language crosses our understandings: catching a glare from Jullian as he approaches to help his own two volunteers.
Katiya says, "The point is to swing through something. Don't stop short!"
"But there's nothing to swing at," I say.

"Then swing at me," she says. I recall my father's words about hitting a girl. And then she adds: "You've already done it once before, haven't you? So what's the difference?" Her lips peel into a mischievous smile, ready to hurl as many insults as it takes for me to go all out.
Derry hands Katiya his wooden sword to add some fuel. "She's one of the tough ones. I bet you won't last a minute."
And with enough pressure, I chance a light swing at her. She slashes with half her power, nearly knocking the training sword out of my hands.

"I've seen toddlers with less hesitation," she says. She swings the sword a couple times to draw the attention of other townies, adding pressure for me to defend my manhood. They turn their heads. "Come on: do your worst, Cody of Denver!"
I white-knuckle the hilt of the sword like a baseball bat, taking a hard swing from the side. Katiya hardly twists her sword, and my blade glides up the polished flat surface.

My momentum shifts entirely upright as I continue to spin, so committed to the strike that the training blade launches out of my hands. It travels point-first as it spins in the air like a surface-to-air missile with guards for fins, launching towards the commander as he recognizes all the turning faces.

My muscles crumple faster than my soul as I watch Katiya's face change from humor to horror. Aldrin raises his arm in an instant, catching the smooth edge with a single hand. The edgeless blade slides for its full length before stopping at the hilt, the dull point halted inches from his face.

He looks around at all the startled townsfolk, astounded at how quickly this training session descended into disarray. Once he traces the trajectory, the scarred commander stares daggers at me as he approaches from the center of the field. Dealing with my varsity coach was hard enough when I whipped that hard rubber lacrosse ball past his head: I've never pissed off a warrior like him.
He doesn't even have to open his mouth before I'm off in apologetics. He draws the sword so it points directly at my chest.
"I, uh, do numbers and stuff. I'm not any kind of warrior," I insist.
But Katiya cuts in. "It was my fault, Chief. I egged him on by insulting him a little. I wanted to see him angry."
I think he's going to skewer me and roast my flesh over a spit, but he flips the blade around in his hands so that the hilt faces me. "What's your name, son?"
The townsfolk look on with secondhand shame. Aldrin turns to around to shoo their focus away, and by the time I answer, they've all returned to practicing techniques.
"Cody. Well, you have the passion," he says. "And a strong arm. But you need to channel that into technique." He gestures to Katiya for her wooden sword. "Is it alright if I borrow your volunteer?"
Katiya nods.
"The most important thing in sword fighting is balance, Mister Cody," Aldrin says. "You put all your power into a single swing — but what were you planning to do after?"
I stammer as the weight of the sword in my hands becomes awkward. "I . . . I'm not sure," I say, "sir."
"Don't be ashamed, son. You've done the Gods' work coming out today as a volunteer, and I'm grateful you're here. But Miss Katiya, here, is a true professional."
And it feels like a lion training a chihuahua.
Aldrin turns to Katiya. "Why don't you show Mr. Cody a standard forward strike?"
We stand aside. Katiya balances her feet so that her non-dominant foot is in front, with her hips facing forward. The steel sword slides out of her sheath with an iconic ring.
"And, see, her goal is to close the gap between herself and the enemy with the blade," Aldrin says. "But notice there, how she steps away slightly?"
"Yeah," I say, transfixed at her training. She slashes forward with a perfect overhead swing, but steps slightly to the side with her dominant foot.
"And why don't you explain how this ties into balance, Katiya?" Aldrin asks.
"The line of action goes directly at the enemy. But I step aside, in case there's a counterattack. It lets you keep your balance," she says.
Aldrin claps me on the back, handing me the training sword. "Why don't you give it a shot?" He asks.
I draw my left foot forward, as if I'm beaming a lacrosse ball across the field for a breakaway. But I get confused with my footing.
"Why don't you practice with him, Katiya? Hold the sword with him." But then her face flushes. "Don't be embarrassed. Mister Dunsmore needs to learn," he says, smiling as he withdraws.

Katiya hesitantly approaches from behind me. I feel the cold steel of her breastplate press against my back as she reaches her gauntlets to grasp my hands, and I refuse to even try looking at Jullian. Her steel boots align with my feet as I stand off-foot-forward, and as I slice down with the wooden sword, her hips press into mine, guiding my legs to swing in rhythm with the sword, and I end up to the side of that perfect line of action.
"Don't get used to it," she whispers in my ear, and I swear I can feel the heat radiate off her face.
"Very good," Aldrin says. "Now give me a hundred of those: now!"
I tense in tonal panic, locked with the sword in its last position.
Aldrin laughs. "Sorry. Force of habit. Do, uh . . . twenty or something, yeah?"
"Sir, yes sir," I say, as if I'm a pledge in the fraternity again.

I take a couple practice swings, mirroring Katiya's technique as best as I can. And as Derry steps to the side—relieved he doesn't have to leverage his husky frame for sword practice, ever closer to the free ale on the other side of the session, Katiya takes at least ten minutes before she can turn and face me again.

"If you're on the line right now, you don't mind the chance of getting hurt," Aldrin says. His eyes scan the thirsty townies standing behind the line of rope. "Just because you don't get to drink first if you don't do the course does NOT mean you won't drink at all."
"But all the fucking ale will be gone!" One of the beer-gutted strongmen says. Even the hesitant men now join the line, shouting in agreement.

"Well, it's not a race: it's a course," Aldrin says. "And you need to help each other." He gestures around the standard training course used by the Royal Guards, bent in a U-shape that ends with kegs and kegs of booze. Some men look like they're about to cut the whole damn course, but the senior guards are back — and Aldrin set them up so no one can cut the others. I can't see the course behind the backs of the tall and muscular farmers and their field hands. I'll have to play it entirely by ear.
"Your trainees are depending on you to win, because they don't drink until your whole team does. So they'll be cheering you on, all along the way," Aldrin says.
I can feel the adrenaline coarse through my veins, but mostly from the fear of getting crushed or stepped on.
Derry's hand rests on my shoulder. "You're a young fella, and fast, I bet. You'll be able to shoot right through there!"
"If they let me," I tell him.
"I'll make them," he says.
Aldrin counts down. Even for a fun run, I can feel the pressure mount on me as Katiya watches—and every time we meet eyes, I feel the urge build to impress her.

He holds an archaic gun into the air. I hold my breath, waiting for the blast like it's winter track season all over again. I stagger my feet and let my fingers soak into the cold, wet soil, and just as I'm about to anticipate the blast, I feel Derry's hands grasp my back.
The gun blast echoes between the mountains. Derry pushes me with all his strength, and suddenly I stagger into first: sliding a quarter-distance of the mud pit beneath the barbed wire.

I was a three-sport athlete, and I immediately think back to football season in the fall, when snow still saturated the frozen ground, and I'm lighter than I was then when I wore pads and a helmet. Lighter than the ones before me, my elbows thrash the ground as mud splashes in my face, peerless in the moment, absorbed in the cheers that crescendo with my name.

My old-world shirt is soaked in heavy mud, and I'm drenched down to the Under Armor compression shirt, but I feel that rare window of joy seize my body in its entirety, and I'm thankful my emotional curse doesn't eclipse my enjoyment of the moment. I hear the sloshing and clambering of men that look like Vikings, grunting and growling with their lust of liquor.

I rise at the end of the mud crawl, glancing back to find my teammate Derry not far behind: his wife cheering him on from the sidelines. I hear Katiya shout my name, and turn to face the next obstacle: a tall climbing wall with several ropes hanging from the top.
