I'm not as light as I was after a whole four years of shotgunning beers in the fraternity, but it feels as if I have circuits like Katiya, from all the energy that floods my veins.

My hands grasp the ragged weave of rope, tucking it beneath my arm as I take the first steps up the wall. The eyes are all on me now as I compensate for my previous failure. My arms grab hand-over-hand as the mud-soaked townies clamber like zombies, with groans that lust for liquor instead of brains, shaking the rope as they grasp it themselves, destabilizing my footing on the wall.

But I tighten my hands on the rope. Past halfway, I find it stretches less, advantaged by the boost from Derry that left the rope loose for much of my ascent. And as I approach the top, I feel my stomach drop when I look at the other side.

I thought it was another rope down. But instead, I find three logs spanning a two-story-high stretch from one tower to another: the bottom filled with murky, freezing water of an unknown depth. The adrenaline outpaces the panic as the crowd of knights and supporters shifts up to watch as I take my first steps on the log: tempted to hug and hump my way across, but I take a deep breath and take my time.
So far down, Katiya and Jullian stand beside each other, along with Pax and Ryder and the catgirl Naya and a pale-looking Bertram that shakes his fist.
I scrape my muddy feet before I proceed: still a ways ahead of the others, and I take my time stepping across—like an alcoholic walking a line to show an officer that he can drive.

But I catch an odd footing. Panic seizes my chest when the elevation imposes itself, and I fall to my chest as the crowd groans in anticipation. But I hear their cheers still coming strong: Pax chanting "Science Guy" in their tongue until the others join, and they cheer when I regain my footing, stumbling slowly before I make it to the other side.
Next is a span of sixteen-or-so bars dangling over the same sickening drop. I doubt my adrenaline will last if I don't keep going: un-Essenced like the others and at a certain disadvantage.

But I continue: taking the first suspended bar in my hands as my feet decide whether they want to leave the safety of the platform, making the mistake of looking down and noticing patches of grass I HOPE are just floating, and not islands that would break my legs.

But the excitement is too great. My exhilarated mind flashes back to the breakaways of all those lacrosse games I miss so damn much with Miguel—and lost in the emotional rhyme, I realize I'm already halfway across, steadily swinging between rails until I make it to the other side.

I turn back to find Derry waving at the other side, making some gesture I interpret as a "thumbs-up" as he waits to cross, using his meager townie Essence to strengthen his grasp before it's his turn to cross the bars.

The end of the towers is a series of vertical ropes. And as the others gain on me with their powerful arms, swinging like silverback gorillas, I slide down the rope after saturating my hands in the cool mud caked on my undershirt, regaining my footing as I make it to the bottom.

I reach the end of the 'U'-shape to find the joining section as a simple sprint before more low-level towers at ground height, and I take off for the next side, watching as the Essenced knights double my speed to get a spot on the other side.

I feel a presence behind me. One of Jullian's non-guard buddies I recognize from before uses his advantage to sprint faster, and he's several breaths behind me as we round the last turn of the U-shape, coming to a near stop as we approach a bunch of logs that protrude from a gravel pit: a series of one-footed jumps that focus on technique over strength.

Half cheer my name. But half cheer for my adversary, named Delvin. We balance the desire for speed over the failure of the fall, wagering the swiftness of every jump. And as we're neck-and-neck, I decide to dash the rest of the logs, back in first as I make it to the last challenge.

All that's left is one last straightaway with hurdles. It was my event in track when I was lighter, and had a six-pack on my body instead of in my hand every weekend. But the muscle memory is there, and as I take lane two of six, my rival takes four as we sprint with all we have, letting the fanfare flood our muscles where our exasperated breath falls short.

My steps reach a rhythm like I'm sprinting down the hundred-meter span of hurdles on my high school track: over the long logs in seven steps and a leap, seven steps and a leap, seven steps and a leap.

The goal is getting closer, stacked with kegs. The beautiful town ladies are tensioned with corsets that rise their breasts as a beckoning call to the grizzly men behind us, raising mugs of fresh ale as sirens that call their lascivious warriors to come.

A leap and seven steps. A leap and seven steps. And I see Katiya at the finish, smiling ear-to-ear as her boyfriend stands next to her, cheering on Delvin. And I'm so close now, about to place first, when I hear a pained groan and a loud exhale as Delvin crumples into the second-to-last log hurdle.
And I stop in my tracks, inches from the finish. I look behind me to find Delvin grasping his chest without wind as the horde of others is quickly approaching.
But I decide to turn around as I huff for breath, climbing over the log to approach my rival, offering him a hand so he can rise from the sullen ground.

I take his arm across my shoulders. A few racers sprint past us, transfixed by the boobs and ale ahead of them. And as we stumble over the logs in steps instead of leaps, I feel Delvin's weight shift when Derry grabs his other arm.

We finish twelfth-or-so. Katiya and all her friends congratulate the three of us when we cross. The air stinks of salty sweat, but the ale is sweet and savory as we chug the carbonated brew like cold water.

We hang around for a while until Aldrin presents an award to first place, and though he recognizes my efforts, he presents it to another lean, younger man that passed us while we carried Delvin. Katiya and a few friends watch my face as I react to this loss, and though Delvin is distraught, I laugh and cheer as the winner holds his makeshift trophy in the air.

I find an emotion in Katiya's face that I've never seen before. She looks away when I return her glance. Her other friends chatter on about how I deserve the title, and even Jullian offers me words of encouragement, thanking me for aiding his friend.

A long day ends with us walking home. I say I left my stuff at Katiya's so we could all walk together, and when they're all distracted, I slip inside and disappear through the door—quick to feel the bliss of a hot shower.

After toweling off, I head downstairs to grab a glass of water in my boxers. I hear Jullian and Katiya heading upstairs on their side of the dimensional wall. Katiya whispers something to Jullian as he continues to climb the stairs, and after she takes off her heavy boots, I hear her footfalls as she approaches my door.
She knocks with a knuckle. I'm quick to answer on the other side, peeking out no more than my head and a shoulder.
"Hey — thanks for doing this today," she whispers. "You surely didn't start off so well, but you ended in a blaze."
"Of course," I tell her. "It was worth the PTO."

She turns to close the door, but then hesitates for a moment: something still on her mind that she's tempted to ask. "But at the end there . . . you were surely going to win," she says. "Why did you give Delvin a hand before you crossed?"
She looks up with anticipation, as if she disbelieves the face I wore when they were handing out awards. But something makes her want to hear me say it: to convince her of something.
And so I tell her the truth.
"I just didn't think the ale would taste any different," I whisper. "You know?"
And so I sell him a lie.
"I just don't see how this shirt looks any different," I say, "you know?"
He glares at me through the door. "Different? You still look like you were ripped out of the high Middle Ages."
I have no idea what he means. "But it's a shirt with a collar, right?" I ask. "I don't have the fancy noble clothes from your world. This was woven by hand!"

"And it looks like you're off to add your name to the Drclaration Of Independence," he says. Cody cracks a smile as he slips his feet onto a pair of his work shoes, wearing what he calls a weekend-formal shirt with stretchy fabric and a sharp collar.

"Are you really sure you want me to go, then? All you've done is insult me since I showed you the only other outfit I have," I say. "I'm dressed by the guard. They only let me take a hundred pounds of personal items when I came here."
"It shows," he says.
I sneer at him. "Are you done?"
He rises to his feet, taking one last glance at the odd texture of my shirt: thin in some areas, and mildly frayed from wearing it beneath my armor.

"Not yet. Give me a second," he says, retreating back upstairs to rustle through his cupboard. Half a minute later, he returns with another nice shirt. It's stitched with the letters NAVIDSON-MONROE: evidently woven by one of the fancy machines of his world.
"I'm going to fill a whole closet from you at this rate," I say, hesitant to take another garment.

"It's been like a month since the last time I gave you that shirt," he says. "And we still haven't even properly shopped for you yet. I got this in a New Years raffle from my company when they were trying to empty out the old employee storeroom. It's a women's medium, and I don't have the body for it."

He extends his hand though the doorway. I crack the door shut to quickly change, trading the bright, uneven stitch-work for a smooth, silken, short-sleeve polo, surprised by how little I feel of the texture — and in moments like these, it makes me hesitant to indulge any further in even the simplest of his world's conveniences.

"Well?" He asks. I crack the door open again as he takes his work passport into his pocket. His eyes glow with a certain sarcastic pride. "You look like a new intern. Just don't ask the guys for any questions on your projects, or they'll never leave you alone."
I get the impression it's some backhanded compliment. "I'll be quiet unless talked to."
"No, not this time," he says. "The whole point is to interact with people! You get to meet my team: it's an open house. The world left behind keeping women quiet a while ago."
"Okay. And..." I gesture to my boots: the last oddity we haven't discussed. It's the casual pair, emblazoned with the faintest trace of metal around the toe and heel. "Are these really okay?"

"Just means you can go on the floor, if you're wearing steel toes like that." Cody gestures for me to enter his car port. "You look fine. We should really get moving, or else they'll eat all the pizza before we can even get there."

He cracks the door to the car port, and the solid steel gate slides along the rails. It's been more than a month since my first and last adventure in his car, and I feel ready to withstand all the twists and turns.

I gently feather the car door open and sit in the seat. My body feels so light and free without the weight of the armor, as if I'm wearing nothing at all, and after he pulls out of the car room into the street, the gate closes behind us.

We take a different route this time, driving straight instead of turning left. It's been about a month since the self-defense training program, and with all that time passed in forgettable engagements, we share a couple stories from our lives.

I describe how fast the town of Gaffesend transitions from festive joy to dreadful unease. I talk about the letters from my family back home, and how proud they say they are of my brother and I — though I'm glad they aren't around to see what the other townsfolk think. I tell him how my mistake still overshadows me, and that I'm glad they've forgotten my foolish leap between buildings, and how I've returned to prowling the streets.

He tells me about work, but doesn't say much: just that he's nervous about being let go, and that he's developing something "stupid" that might make or break his career. I'm entranced by the unfamiliar foliage that whips past us, pretending we're driving on the backroads between Gaffesend and the capital, surprised at how open Cody's world actually is when you get away from all the tall buildings.
I ask him about Kei: he says not much has changed. He asks me about Jullian, and I say not much has changed, either: still middling in our relationship.

His eyes glaze over with an unfamiliar joy when we wind the switchbacks, taking the turns with a certain passion, and though we're taking his daily passage to work, I doubt it's related to his employment.
We pull up to the gates an hour after midday to find them open. The armor-less guard waves us through, and we come to a stop in a large dirt lot.
Cody looks at me before we exit, as if to say something, but then his face falls.
"Damn it," he says.
"What?"
He rifles through the center cupboard on his car, pulling out a cheap pair of dark glasses with letters on the side. "Here."
"For what?"
"I forgot about your eyes," he says. "I just got so used to them from looking in them all the time."
My face flushes. "Are you—"
"No . . . no! Not at all. Calm down," he says, covering his face with a nicer pair of glasses as he gestures for me to exit. I CAREFULLY open the door, so I don't hit the vehicle next to me.
"You keep disguising glasses on you?" I ask. "When would you need them?"

"They protect your eyes from the sun, dummy," he says, overcompensating for his accidental pick-up line. I feel my nerves rise as we approach the massive building, shaded like night as I look through the lenses, my body masked behind Cody as a nervous shadow.

An unfamiliar voice calls to him as we approach his colleagues. "So you finally made it to your first work event," the lady says. "Even I made it to one before you!" Her face changes when she sees me step out from behind Cody, reminding me a little bit of Jullian. "And who is this you brought?"
"This is Katiya. A neighbor of mine," Cody says.
"Nice to meet you," I say, speaking seamlessly in Cody's tongue.
"And I'm Kei," she says, shaking my hand gently. "Kei Sakurashima."

The installation looks like one of those dug-in shelters on the border of the Purgatory Line, and when we enter the quaint area dug into the side of the mountain, facing the set of reflective steel doors, I expect they'll open to a grand chamber beneath the ground.

But when Cody's paramour presses the glowing arrow button, the doors slide open with a chime, exposing a tiny room that the three of us enter. The metal doors are just about to close when a fourth guy shows up, sticking his hands directly into the metal jaws to keep them open.

It's a young man with the same aesthetic as Cody, except he has beach-blonde hair and a much more energized personality. He stares at me with his hazel eyes. "Ha! Looks like I made it just in time," he says. "Cody, my man, and Kei. And who are you?"
His conversational flow throws me off guard, stammering for words, but he speaks again.
"I'm Reed. Reed Broderick," he says, extending his hand.
"I'm Katiya," I manage, giving his hand a gentle-but-firm shake. "Katiya Bre—"
But as soon as the doors close, the room jostles upwards, catching me off guard as I nearly fall, taking both Cody and Reed's hands.
The two men lift me to my feet.
"Bad hangover, huh?" Kei asks. "I hope Cody didn't challenge you to any drinking games. Ever since he joined that fraternity, he became a fish!"
I ask, "A fish? As in..."

Cody cuts the silence with a laugh. "Very funny. We thought we'd pregame this little mixer to make it go faster, you know?" And then he takes me aside, muttering to me under the tone of his breath. "You can take the shades off now."
"But my eyes," I whisper. "Won't they think I'm weird?"
"It's fine. Remember the lie I gave you?"
"Caused-play," I say. "But shouldn't I at least know what caused this?"

Cody creases his brow with his fingers in disappointment as the man called Reed continues.  "Well, hey, quite a coincidence you work at Navidson-Monroe too, huh?" He asks, pointing to my shirt. It says ENGINEERING TEAM beneath it. "So are you, like, a purchaser or something? Or are you on the Aerospace team? I don't see you in the main office," he says.

I stammer over a response, watching Cody prevent his face from changing shades of red when he realizes he's trapped himself again. "It was that shirt I won in the raffle that didn't fit me," he says, "and I decided to give it to her."
Kei laughs. "You don't have to explain," she says, catching contagion of Cody's secondhand embarrassment. "Unless you're dating or something. But even then, you know. You wouldn't have to..."
"We're not," Cody insists, turning his eyes down as Reed masterfully switches subjects.

"Well then I hope it will be a better raffle this year. My dad said they were just emptying out the corporate closet of shirts before the moths could get to them. And all those mugs and pencils and flash drives they were handing out at the job fairs," Reed says. His piercing eyes meet mine. "Say, Katiya: where do you work if you don't work here?"
"Oh. I work in, uh, military."
Cody elbows me.
"The military?" Reed smiles. "Nice, Just like my cousin. Well, thank you for your service. What branch? Are you at the Air Force base up north or something?"
"I'm in the mountains," I say, unsure how much further I'm digging myself, wondering if I could ever be ready enough for Cody to bring me anywhere.

Cody interjects, "She's stationed up near Grand Lake, working on some topographical research, for uh, NOAA." He glares at me, but in a humored way. "Guess we shouldn't have pre-gamed so hard, huh? I told you to start clear."
"Well, you two seem pretty close," Kei says. "Reed and I had to cheat, making each other our plus one."
Cody opens his mouth to speak, but then the doors open, just as he ushers the words: "So you guys..."

The carriage lets out to a breathtaking atrium with a curved glass ceiling, surrounded on both sides by stairs and private walled rooms. The chatter is almost deafening from the volume of well-dressed people — like a royal ball — and when I look up to the sky, I find a full view of the mountainside through the ceiling glass.

But a lady is poised at the top, standing there with her husband that almost looks like one of our farmers from his brawny arms. As she approaches, exposing a name tag that says KIMBERLY (KIM), I find a reticence suddenly take over Cody, even though it's too late.
"Kei! Oh, hey, so good to see you," she says, smiling with dimples from ear-to-ear. "And there's my son. Won't you say hello?"
"Hey, Mom," Cody says. "And Dad," as he approaches.

"Oh, don't look so surprised. Both my boys work here," Cody's mother says. "I swear. The last time I saw you two cuties dressed up together was Junior Prom. And that's before you vanished into our basement all night, to—"
Cost lunges between Kei and Reed. "Whoa, whoa, already too far, Mom," he says, redder than a tomato.
"Oh. I just assumed you were Kei's plus one, like last time?"
"Not this time, Mrs. C," Kei says. "Reed here asked me to the dance this time."
"Oh," Cody's mother Kim says. "So Cody's flying solo this time."
Cody's dad almost looks disappointed for a second before Kei interjects. "Not this time. He brought a neighbor-friend."
They turn their faces to me. And after they look me up and down, I almost gleam a sense of pride lighting their faces again.
I extend my hand. "It's truly an honor to make your acquaintance," I say. "Your son and I live next door to each other."

"Well isn't he a lucky son of a gun?" Alan says, and I feel the urge to drag Cody away before his redness turns to blue. Reed begins to introduce himself to Kim with Kei as Alan gestures for us to keep walking. "Well, don't let an old chunk of coal like me hold you kids up. It's nice to meet ya." He gives me a firm handshake. I tension my hand a little harder than usual.  "And sweet Jesus, she's got a grip!" He turns to his progeny. Some surly thought skips the queue in his mind. "Son, you know what they say about strong wrists in a woman—"

"Yeah," I say, "nice to meet you." I take Cody's hand to rush him to the water table, pulsing some healing Essence into him so he might not pass out, but he seems fine. I barricade us both with a group of young trainees from a local seminary, led around by their instructor.

He scans the table until he finds something harder, flashing his badge so they give him a painted can. After a crack and several guzzles later, his soul returns. "Thanks for saving me, there," he says.
"That's kind of my job," I tell him. Then I grin. "So is that what you brought me here for? A piece of arm candy to get your love interest off that other guy's arm?"
"It would make sense," he says, fisting a second cup of water. "But no."
"Then why?" I ask.
"I'll tell you later," he says. "But how about we look around?"

I spend the rest of the day in Cody's shadow, avoiding long conversations with his coworkers and eating as much of the free food as we can. And after watching as many of the children's science demonstrations as possible — while Cody eagerly riffed on about all these concepts named after scientists — we take a break on the east balcony that opposes the view from the elevator, looking out across his world's well-developed landscape.
"But it's fluids," I say. "You say you're studying fluids when you study aeroplanes. But fluid is water, not air."

"Air has a lot of the same properties of fluids, so we call it fluids," he says. Then he mentions several scientists from his world as if name-dropping will support his argument. Bernoulli. Lagrange. Some guy he says is an oiler, which sounds like he deals with fluids, only supporting me further.

"It's Euler," he says, beginning to gesture with hands that only hurt his explanation. "So there's streamlines, like this," he gestures, "that you look at," he gestures, "you know," he gestures again, "and then there's streaklines. And you can look at it through the LaGrangian form that emphasizes states of a moving frame of reference, but the Euler form is for a control volume FIXED instead of moving, and in Aerospace, which is what I want to get into, I find that . . ."

There's something entrancing about his passion when he rattles on about concepts I can't hope to understand. I find such a radiant light when I meet eyes with his, and he thinks he's explaining it clearly.

I nod my head as I turn to gaze out across the landscape, still bright with early-morning sun, trying to wrap my head around the fact that this whole landmass is safe from ocean to ocean. And with no clear lines partitioning them, the buildings grow like weeds without the culling force of constant conflict.

" . . . So Bernoulli says the pressure difference pushes up on the wing," he says, spouting more names and using his Navidson-Monroe water bottle now as a prop. I forget to nod. "And now I realize you have no idea what I'm talking about."

I smile. "But your enthusiasm is refreshing. Pray tell: do you know how many people have the emotional resources to be passionate like you where I live?" I say. "Your people focus on designing planes and big machines. All our people have to think about is what's moving around in the dark."
"That's why you should come over more," Cody says. "You might have scared me at first, but I like spending time with you now."

I adjust my sweaty hand on the hot steel railing, unaware I'm sliding closer to his. "You aren't too bad either," I say. We touch with a spark, then withdraw our hands. "A good friend. I'm just afraid of getting comfortable with all of this."
"Understandable," he says.

I put on the sun glasses instead of squinting my eyes, and Cody points out landmarks. A cluster of red rocks in the shape of an amphitheatre. His parents' house in Hearthland Ridge. And our house — I mean, his house, across the lake, muddled in a cluster of homes.

We step inside to tour the last section we haven't seen yet: the Engineering showroom, with models of all the famous planes like the Flawless Diamond and the SR-71. Cody continues his ramblings, dumbing them down a little further as I look at him with a refreshing sense of admiration. He talks in my language of war: about the big bombs named after a little boy and a heavy man, and the cold war between nations that followed. The planes were made for spy missions, surveying enemy lands at unfathomable speeds.
"Maybe one day I can see the view from one of those," I say.
"Maybe you will," he says, turning to face the last presentation wall we haven't seen yet. It reads FUTURE ENGINEERING TALENT, with a few profiles of new engineers.
He scans through the posted pages like trainees at the Academy after an exam.

"What is this?" He asks, trying to mask his words as only those of curious interest, but then mutters, "a fucking email sent to them?" His fingers trace the dates of hire. "Some have been here longer than I have!" And when his hand reaches the profile on the guy in the elevator, his hand balls into a fist.
I approach him. "What's wrong?"

He pulls out his smart telephone, scrolling frantically through it, opening an app with messages that read longer than a simple text. He scrolls the subjects of those correspondences, getting angrier and more dejected as he looks further and further. "So they just don't consider me, huh? Because my dad doesn't have a fucking name around here, and I came from nothing, so they—" He curbs his words when he realizes I'm still here. "Heh. Sorry, Katiya. Just some work stuff," he says, smiling with an embarrassed laugh.
He hears voices behind us coming around the hall, and he drags me beneath one of the displays. I open my mouth to protest, but he covers it, and I recognize the voices in an instant.
"Finally somewhere quiet, huh?" Reed asks. "I might be good at the social stuff, but even I'm pretty tapped out."

"And I never get out," Kei says. She walks towards the display we're hiding behind. I watch Cody's mind scroll through possible explanations to diffuse the embarrassment, but just as she's about to cross our hiding spot—
"Here it is," Reed says.
"What?" We watch Kei's heels pivot as she turns.
"You never got the email about this?" He asks. "You're still new enough, right?"
"The new talent wall? I think I forgot to respond to the email about it."
"It was something the Engineering Director was pushing through. Said he wanted to highlight some of the fresh talent."
We hear silence as they scan the wall for something. "There's mine," Reed says. But Kei looks further.
"Huh," she says.
"What?"
"I really hope he hasn't come in here," Kei says. "Haven't seen Cody or that neighbor he brought, so I hope they went home."
Another silence.
"Oh. He's not even on the wall," Reed says. "Did he not fill it out?"
"He totally would have filled it out. You see the way he looks up at this place? His eyes get more sun dreaming of this place than any of the lifers that sit next to the windows."
"Huh."
"Maybe it was an accident. Some kind of mix-up?"
"I don't know about that," Reed says.
"How can you be so sure?"
"Just something I've thought about since I came here. Some talk between my dad and his best friend, the Director of Engineering."
"Well, he got you hired here," Kei says.
"But there was more," Reed says. "I was listening to them on the patio out back behind our place. He said he's clearing the way for me. And that 'that other engineer wouldn't be an obstacle.'"
"The 'other engineer?' You don't mean..."

"He said Cody was unexceptional. Just did his time and left, not really ever trying once he reached a certain point. That the life left him. That he never makes an effort to meet anyone, and that he'd be easy to make an excuse for," Reed says, and I watch Cody bow his head as he balls his fists. "I mean, I like the guy a lot. We're pretty similar, and I really want to be buddies with him."

Kei takes a long pause. And I almost think she'll stand up for him. I hope she does, for Cody's sake, but she says something else. "We used to be pretty close, you know. High school, we dated: just like his mom said, and he was so full of this joy, it was like staring at the sun."
Reed asks, "But what?"
"But the summer I left for school was when he lost his brother."
"He lost his brother?"

"Yeah. To some conflict in the war: Jackson was a Navy SEAL. And Cody never opened up about it. And by the time his last year of high school ended, he followed me to college, but I couldn't even recognize him. He was just a shell. And he still is, though sometimes there's a glimmer of that guy who had so much joy. That I liked a lot," Kei says, looking around nervously. "I hope something changes. Because he's surely next out of all of us."
They turn to leave. And Reed says, "Well, at least I can be that for you."
Kei laughs. "I still don't know if I'm ready for that," she says.
I feel angry for him. I want to stand up and call them out for speaking so ill of him. In fact, I begin to stand, but Cody weakly grabs my borrowed shirt.
"Stand down, soldier," Cody says. "It's alright. Nothing they said was wrong."

"But this Reed guy is slighting you! His family line is aimed to cut you down because you're in his way, though you're the venerable one," I say, grabbing his shirt while I turn his chin to look in my eyes, finding the crest of his tears ready to break.

"Maybe I deserve it," he says. "I've become a mess since then. I dragged myself through this stupid degree because it's what I used to want to do. I'm running on fumes of a past when I was fueled on that thing: the spark, what Kei and anyone else liked about me." He sniffles, trying to keep his tears to a professional medium. "No passion. No prospect of a girlfriend in years. I don't know . . . I think I just suck now. Even my parents can sniff it out."
His words anger me because they insult someone I've come to care about, and it's him, and of all my years of guarding, I feel nothing more than the urge to protect this guy and his precious dream.

I feel the heat rise in my circuits as I grab the collar of his shirt, forcing him to look at me as I pin him against the display. I dissolve his tears with the Essence in my hands. "You listen. Your dreams are far from stupid, Cody Dunsmore, and you are gods-damn precious," I say.
He looks down. "You're just—"

"Shut up," I command, jostling him against the wall to shock him into a sense of truth. "Can't you see that you're already enough as you are? You say the ale doesn't taste any different. And you're the only person I've ever found who means it. You care," I say, "so Gods-damn much about anyone."
"It's just lonely," he says. He gestures for me to get off him, and I help him to his feet. "I think something broke in me that I can't fix."
"What do you mean?" I ask.

"I said I'd tell you why I invited you here. I mean, yeah — all the engineers and techs and business guys were ogling you, and you're an amazing piece of arm candy. You even made my family have faith in me again." He laughs. "But I brought you here because I have no one else to share this with. It feels like everyone's left me or moved on. And I'm tired now. And it's getting so late."

I wrap my arms around him, letting the heat of my body speak where my words fall short. He hesitates, but then gently returns my embrace, holding for just a second before he releases. And even in his act of forced vulnerability, I almost feel a piece of myself open, too.
"Bastards," he says.
"Huh?" I ask.
"Bastards have probably already eaten their way through the food trucks," he says. "I totally forgot. Usually it's like eight bucks for a slice of pizza, but Navidson-Monroe's footing the bill."
I don't know what a food truck is. But if it's designed to move, and it has food in it, I assume it won't be around for long.
"And hey," Cody says. "You have to be careful saying stuff like that."
"What do you mean?" I ask, noticing his face flushes lightly now that we're out of the dark.
"You have a boyfriend. And yet you almost made me break our tenth rule."
"Then you must be weak," I tell him. "Too weak for me," I say, though I feel refreshed by his sincerity. "But that doesn't mean I can't help you."

She waits until I'm fully seated in the car to tell me the news. And when she does, I feel both relieved and horrified at the same time — like the wife that tells her husband he's packing the largest out of all his friends.
"You did what?" I ask. "Really? But when?"
"It's when you were busy moping around behind the ration trucks," Katiya says, with a smug grin. "But I didn't embarrass you too much."
I start the car, mute the volume, then feel my head lower into my hands. "How bad is the damage? And what the hell did you say?"
"I said you're terrible at communicating."
"Oh, great. And what else?"
"That you and I have nothing between us."
"Okay," I ask. "And what good things did you say?"
"Not much," Katiya says. "Just that you talk about her a lot."
"Oh, great. So I'm a creep and a loser. So it's a pity date?" I ask, starting to feel worse than I did in the exhibition hall.
"No. She almost looked relieved when I said we weren't a thing," she says, "and when I asked her out for you, she said 'yes' right away."
"Really?" I say, feeling a glimmer of hopeful excitement I haven't felt in a while. I put the car in drive. "You're not just saying that?"
Katiya laughs. "Of course not. I can tell. Despite all the tomboy stuff, I'm a woman like her, you know," she says. "She only had one condition, though."
"And what's that?" I ask.
"She wants to be my friend. Says 'friends are hard to come by at this age.' And then she asked for my number."
I pass the gate, waving to the guard whose name I should know by this point. "So what did you say?" I ask.
"I said I left it at home. Then she gave me a sticky page from her purse instead." She holds up a sticky note with flowery girl handwriting on it. "So what do I do now?"
"We get you a phone," I tell her. "Take it as a token of my thanks."
"But won't I get addicted to it? Like the children of your world and their cat movies?"

"You can leave it at my place, or whatever. I don't care," I say, adding the phone store as another stop on the way home. "You can even get a basic one, without all the brain-rot stuff. I'll show you how to use it."
And she agrees. And I'm relieved — because I have no idea how to shop for clothes with her.
Kei laughs, crossing her legs as she sits across from me in the train car. "So you didn't realize that this is exactly the same date we went on all those years ago?"
So it is a date, I think, rubbing the stubble on my chin that I shaved for the first time in months.
"I guess not," I say. "I mean, the last one with you was probably the last real date I've been on."
"Real one, huh?" She leans in closer, showing that same mischievous grin that comes when she's trying to gaslight me. "And what makes it real?"
"I don't know."
"No, tell me," she says, leaning even closer, just as a voice chimes over the intercom, declaring we're at the first stop in Hearthland Ridge on Mineral Street.
The train car lurches to motion, and with her sweaty palms slipping against her bare thighs, her face crashes straight into my chest.

But my mind is quick. "Maybe it's because we just got here and you're already throwing yourself at me." I gently lift Kei up by her shoulders: despite my courageous words, I'm more afraid that she'll sense the swiftness of my heartbeat, and how badly I'm afraid of fucking this up.
"Oh, don't be so sure," she says. Her face flushes. "I bought us the tickets, but that's only because I make big money compared to you!"

My mind is fast at this performance. I wonder when I stopped feeling the humor in the words. "And you'll probably spend every last red cent of it on this date."  I find a smile. "What is it? Another hundred dollars more than me?"
"Who said this was a date?"
"Please," I say. "You said that, like, four sentences ago."
"Oh. I guess I did." She brushes several rebellious strands of her dense, dark hair behind her left ear.

We fix our eyes on the distant mountainscape. It's the only fixed point when residential houses, rusted refuse, and reckless weeds tear past us at a blistering speed. The only place we're allowed to look when too much eye contact with anyone on this train might mean a fight, or an impromptu Sunday sermon.

But despite the courage it took to come back here, it feels like no time has passed. It's not just because she's wearing the same white-and-blue summer dress she wore all those summers ago. Nor is it because she's wearing the same perfume. I assume those two things are just because she's living at home with her parents, not because she's trying to imply something.
Or is she?

No . . . I refuse to make that same mistake again. But I can feel the excitement of that anticipation as I watch her there, trying not to notice the curvature of her breasts change with each jostle of the cabin, nor the slenderness of her smooth legs lightly damp with sweat from a blistering June day. Not letting that animalistic side that wishes to skip all this overtake what I'm searching for — the one track of feeling that I'm afraid I lost.

I try to notice if I notice anything that might show I still feel that way about her. Or that I still have it in me to feel about anyone. I try to remember when I almost said that four-letter word to her, right on the same platform where we boarded this train, before fear and diminishing time sealed that path off from me for years.
But that feeling isn't something you search for. It happens to you. It's a place you only realize once you're there, and I swear to God I have the emotional receipts to prove I was there.

Our view of the Rocky Mountains is shaded by one of those big law firm ads that wraps around the train car, like looking through those bug-resistant screens that pixelate everything into a disparate spread of dots. Looking at the mountains makes me wonder how Katiya's date is going, hoping that she finds all the things she missed inside of Jullian. The silhouette of an image overshadows the entire car through the windows, but I can't see the full picture. I spend more time looking at how beautiful Kei is, accented with dots like the shading in a comic book, how little she's changed since the last time we were here, and wonder how much I've changed in ways that I don't even realize.
I do small talk.
"These windows are scratched to hell, huh?"
"What?" She asks, distracted like she is when I approach her with redlines, still mesmerized by the way everything tears past us.
"The windows. I thought I remembered the Denver Light Rail being a lot cleaner."
"Was it ever clean?" She turns to me with her sapphire eyes. "Cleaning this system up is like sculpting dry sand." And I realize this small talk is getting me nowhere.

I feel that mindless feeling rise within me, dragging me closer to her. She leaned that far earlier for a reason. She's wearing this dress and that perfume for a reason. Maybe she meant to fall like that.
Or maybe she didn't.
And yet all I want is to just make a move.
I look weird now, the way I'm bent over so far.
"You drop something?" Kei asks.

My heart seizes, still absorbed in her words from a day before. "No, I just . . ." and then I feel my body move in an act of fear, finding myself right next to her on the two-seater with our legs pressed together.
Her skin is so pleasantly cool. The smell of her is overwhelming, and I feel that same part that led me to all those meaningless hook-ups in college urge me to move a little closer.
But she's my colleague, I think. Didn't you learn last time that she doesn't see things that way?
She's not moving away, keeping her position either because I made her vastly uncomfortable and she's stuck with me now, or because she's interested.
But I don't want to assume. I don't want to lean on hope again.
Her voice is warm. "Took you long enough," she says, "so is it realer now?"
"Sure," I say. The feeling engulfs me after all these lonely years. I venture my hand on her leg, and she returns by placing her hand on top of mine, leaning close so I can feel even more of her.
"I guess we're right back where we started now, right? And yet you couldn't even ask on your own."
"Well, what can I say? You're a lot of things I like. You still make me hella nervous."
"Hella nervous? I can tell," she says, feeling a slight tremble in my hand. "Is it still stressful dating an upperclassmen?"
"There's no grades here anymore," I say.
"You could have asked sooner. Like in college, maybe."
"But we were both out and around. It seemed like we were chasing a different experience. And neither of us was ready to come down to earth, you know?"

There's a part of me that yearns to break with all the darkness of those years. Meaningless hook-ups, lonely nights when my sorrow almost set me over the edge, and even though I long to relish the comfort of this exact moment, I'm so afraid of showing it. I'm afraid this feeling isn't what I want it to be, losing grasp of my ability to judge, falling headlong into that hedonistic sense of longing.
And so I press my lips against hers to try to remember again.
And so I press my lips against his to try to forget.

The feeling has hunted me since we left Gaffesend in the carriage. It seems to trail every time that Jullian and I get together. It builds with the crescendo of all the unspoken questions: the useless questions that get us nowhere; the useless, pathetic questions that drive a larger wedge between us, preventing us from just enjoying things the way they are.
What more can I want?

The driver of this personal carriage is distracted by the noise of the horses. It's surely not his business to care, anyways: just to focus on our safe  passage from the Knights' Quarter of Gaffesend to the day spa in the springs. And as the carriage jostles us around on uneven terrain, I grab his shirt to pull him closer, stabilizing the two of us while the rest of the world trembles.

I speak with my lips against his for every question that crosses my mind. The nostalgia of this love brings me back to the better times, when all we had to do was study, and not to serve our sentence on the brink of war. He tastes the same way he did all those years ago. And when I shift seats to sit next to him on the two-seater, with our legs pressed together, I find his skin so pleasantly warm, contrasting the cold of the alpine air.
The smell of his musk is overwhelming: the Jullian smell in all the shirts he left behind. I feel that same part that led me to all those passionate nights in school urge me to move a little closer.
But does he still feel that way? I ask. Why did he set this up for us?

That same fear that keeps me from the scouting quests rhymes with the anxiety I feel now. I wonder if his kisses are just performative, because every time I pull away to collect my breath, it seems as if he wants to stop.
"What's wrong?" I ask.
"Just trying to breathe," he says. "Maybe it's because we just got in here, and you're already throwing yourself at me."
"Because you're my boyfriend?"
He glances nervously at the coachman right behind us. "I'm kidding," he says.
"Because he's surely paid to care," I say. "How many Uber drivers—"
"Uber?" He asks. And I realize I'm reciting the most recent thing I learned about Cody's world.

"I mean, how many OTHER drivers care about that? I'll bet you half the people they chaperone in small carriages like this  are couples. No storage on the top: most certainly unable to move a family. Designed for just a group of friends, or two lovers, on a day trip."
And, pray tell, which of those describes us? I think, but I shake my head.
"I hope a carriage is enough. I was gonna get one of those new touring cars with the motor . . . but I ended up spending most of it on the spa." Jullian smiles. "You know I want to treat you right."
Now you do, I think. "What made you change?"
"Change what?" He still smiles.
Shit.
My mind races for something I can actually say. "Well, it just came out of nowhere, you know."
His face falls, still begging the question I refuse to answer. "Change what, Katiya?"
"It's . . . nothing," I claim, retreating to the edge of the narrow bench.
"It's—" he looks to the coachman again. Then he lowers his voice. "It's something that bothers you. That matters."
"Well, we've already talked about it before," I say.
"I know. And I paid for this whole trip for you," he says.
"You paid for it? So money just makes up for..." I clench my fists, hating the entrapment of this state more than how he hurts me, sometimes, so I do the same thing I always do.
I clear my throat, and the cowardice speaks for me.
"I'm sorry," I tell him. "This will be a great trip. I'm excited. And I'm sorry if I come off as ungrateful," I say.
He turns my chin up with his fingers to look at him. "I accept your apology. And I'm sorry, too."
"For what?" I ask.
"For . . . all of it," he says.
Like what? I think again, making sure not to say it this time. "Let's just return to that wonderful part where we were enjoying our time off," I say. "I'm glad we can do this together."
"I'm glad we could do this together," Kei says. "After all these years."
And I realize our entire date has passed in a blur.

We sit downtown at some sushi restaurant on 16th Street Mall. I said all the funny things at all the right times. I made sure to drink as much as I could when we went bowling, to loosen up a little, because even if alcohol makes me feel the call of the void the day after, I need to steal that emotional currency from my future self.
Fact is that we walked into most of the stores, finding myself thinking what Katiya might choose. I chose an outfit for Kei, and she chose a funny work shirt for me.

Fact is that we went bowling. Last time she beat me with her perfect technique, and just as she was about to beat me again, I gave up on trying to win, spinning the twelve-pounder with only two of my fingers in the holes. She laughed at my gutter balls, and when we played a round with the guards up, I wondered how Katiya would fair in a bowling match.

The fact is that she kissed me when I paid for the game. She laughed when I said I scraped together my "level-one poverty dollars for this special date," and badgered me over whether choosing sushi had to do with her ethnicity.
Is this love, then?
Two glasses of Soju in before the volcano rolls, I ask: "So what's your favorite date we've been on?"
She mixes wasabi with soy in hungry anticipation. "Honestly? I think the best times have just been talking to you. Whether it was at your parents' house after class. Or any dinner date."
"What can I say? My voice is mesmerizing," I say, then recite a canned one-liner. "People always told me I had a face for radio. Or was it voice? I don't remember."
"I'd say both, if I liked you enough to date you. And even now, as ragged as you still look."
I retreat to memories of the past. "You remember when your family took me to sushi back in middle school?"
She cracks up when the image hits of me skewering the rolls with chopsticks like meats on a kabob. "How the hell did you think that was the right thing to do?"
"I don't know," I say. "I honestly think I was just trying to make you laugh."
"You always make me laugh," she says, but her eyes narrow. "But, I don't know. It's felt like there's something different now."
I take another sip of the rice wine. "What do you mean?"
"I just . . . well, never mind. I don't want to get all serious."
"No," I say, still flashing a smile. "It's alright."

"Well," She hesitates, but after another sip, finds it in her to finish. "You know, ever since what happened. I've just felt this kind of sadness in you. Even when you laugh sometimes — and I'm not saying you don't laugh sincerely."

My face falls. I guess we're doing this after all. "I mean, it still affects me. But I'm over all that. Life moves on." I gesture the 'moving on' with my hands,  convincingly, nearly knocking over the bottle.
"There's just a pain there that saddens me." She sips again on her third glass since we don't have to drive for a while.
I laugh. "What kind of fortune cookie shit is that?"
"But really," she says.
And then a little bit, just a little bit — I scoop into that emptiness just to draw out a little bit. Not too much, or it might break me. Not too little, or it won't sell.
I start, "There was a time I felt so alive after it all went down. With that project I did in Jackson's name, you know, back in college. It felt like I was processing it, I was working through it."
"But then what happened?"
"I don't know. Then, I guess, the two quarters were up, and so was Senior Design. School was over, along with the drive, and now it collects dust in my garage."
She pauses, having known me long enough to have the courage to ask me further. "But, was it enough?"
My insides cramp. "Of course. After the news report. The presentation. I shared his story. Hero for a day, or whatever."

"Huh," she says. She looks out the high windows of the sunken, subterranean restaurant where many random shoes pass outside. I'm not sure if I've convinced her. And I'm not sure I have it in me to try.

I fight that stupid feeling again that I buried for so damn long: either I had one too many, or scooped out a little too much of myself. But I don't trust her to catch me, afraid that if I fall, that I'll fall apart completely.
So I pack it in, smile, and add, "But that past is over." Because it is. "And my brother Jackie would want me to live on. I have to live enough for the both of us!"

But do I really have that spark left? Is she right? I wove this connection between Katiya and I — I mean, Kei and I, when I had that passion, but that weaving feels like a forgotten craft. All I have left are just the relics from that time that feel foreign to me: a song I forgot how to play, and all I know now is just how to improvise over it.

I feel so drained of energy now, even dizzy. I anticipate those basic-bitch California rolls to absorb all the alcohol in my empty stomach, and I find I'm thinking of Katiya again, wondering what she's doing. It breaks my focus, causing my words to trail off as I grit my teeth and continue to recite even more of our past.

I grit my teeth and continue to descend into the cold tub. My body aches, but not yet from the freezing water. It's from the pain of how heavy-handed those backwater Ahkvasans are — digging their manicured claws into the thinnest muscles on our backs, extracting pain from our overworked muscles by dealing it. And now I'm tasked to withstand the freezing water for a couple minutes, because it's supposedly good for me.
"No Essence," Jullian says, seemingly humored by my suffering as he recovers in the warm tub. "I didn't do it with Essence. No cheating!"
"What, you think I'm a cheater?" I ask. The ache seeps into my bones, as if my marrow is infected with the Chymaeran Curse.
My face twitches.
I ask, "and how long did you say this was for?"
"Five minutes," he says.
I tremble as gooseflesh spreads like a rash, feeling parts of my body contract that are beyond my control. "Well, talk to me about something. I talked to you, didn't I?"
"Aren't we kind of out of things to talk about?" He says.
"How about the," my teeth chatter, "how about how pointless this place is for people like us?"
He laughs. "Just because you hate the cold tub—"
"No. Not the Gods-damn cold tub. I mean — can't anything be made a warm tub with our abilities? We could get in the bath at home and heat it in seconds."

"But what about the nature?" Jullian says, spreading his arms as he gestures to the open-air naked bath. "What about the trip? Getting a little ways out of Gaffesend? The water has special properties. They say it heals you."
"We can heal ourselves, too, you know." I tense my jaw shut to stop that Gods-awful sound of bone-on-bone.
He smirks. "Sounds like you don't like this date."
"I do. All that doesn't mean this isn't nice. It's pain, just like every day. But it's good pain. Pain that's for you, you know?"
"For you?" He asks. "Isn't all pain for the person in pain?"

"No, but pain that makes you better. Half the pain of our training is just lifting stuff all day, or walking laps around the border. But this is to make you feel better later." My arms tighten around each other as I shiver. "Or it's supposed to. Right?"
"Sounds to me like your brain is starting to freeze," he says. "Maybe you should get out. And admit you're weaker than me."
"Or maybe you should admit you're bad at distracting me! Make me feel better," I say. "Relax me."
"I'm not getting in there with you," he says.
"Then talk about . . . the future," I say.
"What about it?"
"About us. About what happens after all of this. After the trials, after probation and all."

I expect his face to warm a little. Maybe from the thought of us living together and depending on each other like we planned, and I want to warm my spirit on that while my body freezes. But he hardly seems to give it a thought.
"I don't know, haven't really thought about it," he says. "I'm more focused on what's happening right now."
"But really, though," I say. "You haven't thought about any of it?"

"I think I'm already in the future I wanted," he says. "And I hope tomorrow is just a continuation of that. Just the prospect of being free is enough: from all those awful years I never had the freedom to do anything. School, then training, then taking care of my brothers. Sleep for a while. Then repeat it all over again," he says.
"You met me in those years," I say, losing the feeling of ice.

"Oh. I mean, of course," he says. "And you saved me from doing that forever. Could you imagine our lives if we weren't free like this? Boyhood was something I never had. And surely you'd admit that you didn't have a childhood either."

"I had a piece of one," I say. "But what we have now is control. To steer our lives somewhere better. That after all the hard work and delayed gratification, we can reach something and call it ours. That thing we both wanted, remember?"
"I remember."
Then I decide to test him. "And what was it?"
"Settling down once we're on the other side. After our service." He sounds like a child reciting chores. Then he opens his mouth to modify that statement, but he pauses.
"But what?" I ask. "What's changed?"

"Nothing's changed. It's just—" he starts, then lets out a long sigh. "I remember being the oldest after both my brothers were born. And I remember school as the only time I had to enjoy myself. And my friends: Gavin and Auren, and how they'd keep inviting me to things, again and again, turning them down every time since I had to walk home and pick up my stupid siblings and feed them. While they got girlfriends, and they forgot about me, and got new friends, and . . ."

Jullian clenches his fist and drives it into the water, but it doesn't launch a plume of hot water. His fist sizzles, sending clouds of water vapor to join the miasmic haze that hovers over the pools.
He says, "you remember the Harvest Festival before we left, I'm sure."
"Of course. The last real fun we had back there," I say. "Just the two of us, walking between booths."

"That was the first festival I've ever been to. And it just . . . gave me a taste of something. Like having sugar for the first time at age twenty." I feel like he wants me to extrapolate the meaning, but I don't get it. "Like — is it so wrong?"
"Is what so wrong?" I ask. "You're not being specific, Jullian."
"So wrong to wish for something."
"To wish for what?"

"To wish my father never died in the mining accident: to knock up my mother and leave me to care for them. Or to wish they were never born, and I could have enjoyed my life. Or if I can't go back there, then to change the present." But then he stops himself in his moment of passion. He recoils, frightened of his true nature for just a moment until his expression glazes over. "Nevermind," he says.
"No. Finish the thought," I say, losing sense of the freezing water. "What is it you wish for?"

"For nothing," he insists. I can feel the anger and disappointment of all these months flood through me, but it can't come out of my mouth. I'm choking on it, like holding back the urge to vomit: the thought of the something that comes after those final words. It's the thought of oblivion. That with how things are going at training, that I'm headed for death anyways. That I don't have the time or the temerity or the looks or the emotional energy, and with all that fear, all I can do is keep holding it here.

I bite my tongue until I think it bleeds, shutting my eyes as I fail to recognize what it does to me. He rattles off with some reason he found the time to make up, and as the panic makes me sweat like those sleepless nights in the dream of the cabin, I can feel the fingers closing in on me, surrounding my body with scentless smoke.
But it isn't smoke.
It's steam.
And then I breathe it in.

I think of things that rest me, but nothing works. The morning runs. The view from my house in the evenings. The love we had when I was building him up. And only when another man's face crosses my mind — that smug face of the outsider when he insults me, but in a friendly way; the expression he wears when he's deep in focus; the way his forearms fill the space in his shirt when he rolls his sleeves — the thought of Cody gives me a sense of control, of resistance.

And so I open my eyes to find the water no longer at my shoulders. It boils beneath me as I sit here tucked in a ball, wondering how much longer I have to savor this mediocrity before I'm sent off to die.
I rise from the tub, covering my breasts with my arm as Jullian's eyes snare on something in the distance, too much of a coward to turn and face me, or even himself.
But maybe that similarity makes us perfect for each other.
I rush to the changing room as Jullian just sits there, without the strength to follow.
I have just enough strength to lead us: after all, I'm the only one whose liver was trained for endurance in the fraternity house.

It feels like I have a knot in my stomach, wondering if all those sushi rolls expanded from the liquor — like the time Jackson swallowed those "Just Add Water" dinosaur toy pills from the dollar store. The doctor pulled them out of his throat like a rope of colorful ribbons from the mouth of a clown. But I feel like mine will be able to come out all on their own.

I clutch my stomach as we stumble along 16th Street, looking no different from all the other late-evening pedestrians. Kei tensions her arm in mine, and deprived of all the energy I borrowed from tomorrow, I find I just want to go home.
"I just want to go home," I tell Jullian, as soon as I exit the locker room.
"But we have a whole night here," he says. "I'm not sure I can get a refund."
But I'm already headed for the front of the complex, carrying my towel and overnight bag.
"Katiya, wait!" He says.

"And where was all that enthusiasm earlier?" My hand tensions further around the straps of the bag as I turn to face him, something he's obviously incapable of. "If you're so damn interested in changing the present, why don't we do it now?" I yell.
He looks around nervously, watching as other couples begin to turn their heads.

"Oh no, poor Jullian. He longs so much to be the center of attention, but not like this! He wants to have fun. To make up for all those wasted years by deserting the one person who's supported him through it all, is that right?"
"No," he mutters, shambling after me.
"Then you better convince me," I say. "You want to stay and finish your spa day? Or are you going to follow me, and prove something you've failed at since we got here?"
"You're embarrassing me," he says. I see an anger build inside him: a stupid, pathetic, unfounded anger that has no right to be here.
I turn and approach him. I stand inches from his face though I have to look up at him. "What was that?"
"You embarrass me," he says. "You continue to embarrass me. You put me down and make me feel like I'm the bad one here, but do you know how much energy it takes to be with you?"

"Excuse me?" I could strike him across the Gods-damn face if this weren't a public bout. I feel my fear losing its edge on the anger that's built over the course of months. "And do you know how much energy I waste on hope that you can still be a good person?"

"You have enough to try dragging me running every other day. You want me to stick around every morning. To spend all my free time with you. And do you know how much it takes to defend dating a failure?"
Something in me twists at that word.
Something that I haven't felt for a long time, and after all the events of the evening, I'm losing control of that edge.

Surely it's the booze from the way the tears leak from my eyes a little, but the train car back is dark, and when I press my nose to the scratched window glass, feeling the vibrations of the rails, I feel that feeling steady itself just a little more.
But the more it settles, the more distance I feel between the two of us, though she leans right against me.
"What do you mean by that?" I ask.
"I mean, look at us," Kei says. "Don't you see it? Late twenties. Too tired to care about anything. We're two sides of the same coin."
"You really think that's all we are?" I ask.

"I stay at work because I want time to pass, if I feel like I can't make any use of it. And you're what the shop guys call the 'eighter-skater.' But, like me, I bet you're just so unsure of what to do with all that time when you lack the energy to put behind it."
"To waste my time as efficiently as possible," I say.
"Where'd you get that idiom?" She asks.

I think of the long years sitting at the window, watching time go by. The hum of the rusted fan like the screech of this train. The smell of summer somewhere beyond the walls of the office. "Just something I thought of once."
She sniffles as she leans further against my shoulder. "Heh. I guess I'm just a whore for what I can't seem to produce on my own."
"What's that?" I ask.

"I'm like a vampire, or a mosquito. Drawn to blood, to energy. It's why I was so drawn to you back then. You have this spark when your eyes light up and you're really passionate about something: debates in Student Government that got us the win; designing that Senior Project was the last time I saw it," she says, and she looks up at me with her bright blue eyes, and I'd cry if I wasn't so good at controlling it.
"Well, I'm tapped out now. Maybe you sucked every last ounce out of me."

She wipes her eyes. She laughs. "If only you were one grade older. If only my parents gave me that extra year in preschool to stay close in age with other kids. That summer with you would have been great."

"I think of that last month of ours all the time," I say, and I approach to kiss her, knowing that though our lips touch — and that this dulled feeling of lust is still there somewhere — we'll never truly fit, seeking the exact same shape of that piece we can't find in each other.
And maybe that peace was never there. Maybe he was always longing for something and just used me as a rope to climb out.
"We were both losers when we met," I say. "We lifted each other up!"

"But I was able to get over my fears. You still cower in them every day," Jullian says. "Not going on a single patrol quest? Have you even looked at the status board lately? Have you trained combat in any drop-ins? Have you even been inside the base?"
"No, I haven't," I say. "But did you think you had it in you to be a Guard? And did I not show you the patience when you were insecure and antisocial? Or am I the only one with patience?"
"I've been patient for months," Jullian says.
"And I was patient for years. Maybe I've been waiting for too long," I say. I pick up the bag and head for the exit. Gods above know I don't care how long it takes to get a damn ride.
He follows, pathetically. "Then what are we, Katiya?"
"You tell me," I say. "You brought me here for something. Maybe your friends told you it would fix everything: that women are simple, and just need a date every-so-often to shut us up for a while."

"Well, no. And — and, I'm sorry for what I said." He reaches for my shoulder as I walk. "I was wrong. I got emotional. You're not a loser, and you're not damaged, either. You're just . . . wounded in a different way, and to a different extent than I am."
He thinks I'll forgive him. That this is just another episode.
But it's not.
And I queue the words I fear.

"Then maybe I should heal alone, if you're not going to stay without me asking. Maybe I'll heal faster if I don't keep getting hurt. By your neglect." I find a carriage waiting, as if divined by the will of the Gods — or the fact that nobody in their right mind would leave on a half-day at the DAY spa.
I reach into my purse for a hefty chunk of Kine. "Then give me one last chance," he says.
"How many more chances do you need?" I ask.
"I'll do whatever it takes," he says. But just a second ago he was insulting me.

"Don't strain yourself trying to love me. I think we're both just discovering who you actually are." The coins clang together when I reach to drop them in the driver's hand: a hefty fee well worth liberating myself from this exhausting day of relaxation.
But Jullian's hand beats me to it. He vanishes around the other side of the carriage until he opens the door to enter, and though I roll my eyes, he ignores my attempt at separation.

"I'm not staying if you're not here with me," he says, courageously. He throws his bag in the back, settling into the seat across from me. "We can go home if you're not feeling it," he says. "I'm sorry you're so upset."

I feel my body physically repelled by him, occupying the furthest possible space as not even my eyes can tolerate to watch. My body aches. I feel emotionally drained of any semblance of joy, and after the carriage sets off, I refuse to lift my eyes from the back window until we're all the way back in Gaffesend.
I refuse to close my eyes or else I might fall asleep.
I blare music on the shared work playlist we made together, skipping all the classical and post-rock shit and going straight for the bangers.

It's funny how I always dreamed of her sitting in this car next to me, right in the passenger seat. Last time, we were both in the back. It was right after my parents bought me this used car for my birthday, because it had all the right "safety features" in some parenting magazine, and it was hot on the market. I was only sixteen, so my parents had to awkwardly chaperone us around in this car until I got past my learner's permit.

But we're long past that age of testing the boundaries of our first relationships. I feel that stupid giddy excitement goading me to ask whether or not to drive her home: like she's some Tinder date from college I went out with for a subtextual pizza.

That kid in the backseat envisioned summers driving around exploring: being an active partner in an active couple, with an active car, going out on an adventure every weekend. He couldn't imagine the complicated emptiness of the emotion I feel now.
Maybe I'll just enjoy the time I have — I thought she was the ultimate end, but maybe I was just made to be alone like her.

"You can stay at mine," I offer, driving an automatic car though I speak with the manual gearshift between my legs. "I have a futon set up." That neither of us will use. "And in the morning, I can drive you back to your car." And I don't even feel the anticipation of whether she'll decline.
"Sure, that sounds great," she says. "After some Advil, we can watch a movie."

We pull into the garage around 11:00 PM. I find myself wondering more about Katiya's date at the spa than what the next course of events is. And when I crack the door to the garage open and enter the kitchen after Kei, I find the closet door shut.
She flicks the lights on to an odd sight that I forgot to hide.

"Why is there an extension cord running out of your closet?" Kei asks. "You must be a major tech guy if you've already run out of outlets." But then she looks closer, turning the corner of the kitchen island. "Scratch that, running IN to your closet."
I panic for a second. "I, uh . . . tried to turn it into a little electronics lab. Soldering iron and stuff, you know," I say, with a nervous laugh.
"Interesting," she says. But her focus is elsewhere. She turns her eyes to the front entryway to confirm the shades are down. "This sure beats 'hanging out' in your parents' basement."
The excitement rises. "Well, the pretext sure hasn't changed."
I head for the kitchen to fetch us each a glass of water — to go with the aspirin —  but she surprises from behind, wrapping her arms around me.
"What do you say we enjoy ourselves a little . . . in the ways we couldn't back before college?" She nuzzles her chin into my shoulder, raising gooseflesh as she plants a kiss on my neck.
But I find myself trapped on a feeling of hopeful hesitation: just enough emotional currency found from digging in the couches of my mind to redeem a single thought.
"I just," I say, "uh, wanna be sure of something,"
"Sure of what?" She asks. Then she smiles when she thinks she understands. "Asking for consent? How cute. Yes, Cody Dunsmore, I want to have sex with you."

"Well, yeah, that too, but . . ." I scratch my head. Shouldn't I be happy?  "I just... I think I've liked you for as long as I can remember. But, like, in a special way, you know," I say, approaching an unused word that scares me far too much. "I know what you said in the train, but, what if there could be something more?" I turn to face her as she still tensions her arms around me, missing the top half of her dress. She seems nervous, maybe even a little sad, like she's trapped in some way, so I add, "I mean, we can't deny that we have feelings for each other. "

I don't know how it's possible to feel like I'm being rejected when she's actively pressing herself against me. I anticipate her next words though she's trying to assemble them on the spot, like building a Lego set from only the picture on the box.

As the calm-and-collected class president that once won the hearts of her classmates through words and promises, she still struggles to come up with a reply. And then after a while, she settles for one.

"I think we should enjoy what we've had," she says, and though I find I'm apathetic to almost everything, I feel something beyond my lust that longs for something real. I mean, if I want a mental vacation to the past, I'll hang out with Miguel.
But that "something" can only be something more if both people want it. So instead, I concede by answering her statement with a kiss.

My heart sinks a little, but I still allow myself to ride the rapture of that feeling that's so fleeting when it comes and goes. I watch from somewhere distant inside myself, taking a backseat to the mindless entrancement of that primal desire, as I peel off the rest of her dress.

I kiss deeply all the warmest parts of her; fully aware that we're going to burn out bright again; succumbing to a rhyme of that familiar learned helplessness. I go through the motions — no longer wondering if I'm in love or incapable of it — as I have her on the couch, feeling her surrender to my strength as I try to ignore the sound of arguing next door.

After the blissful exchange, we shower separately and snooze in my bed. I find it's lighter sleep than the time I accidentally fell asleep with Katiya death-gripping my shoulder, softly pleading me not to go, remembering the feeling of that odd, satiating feeling I don't think I've ever felt before.

I drive her back to her car, and we hug, but don't kiss. I spend the rest of the day tinkering in the garage, trying not to sneeze from all the dust in my senior project's plastic casket.All I know is that my presentation for work is next week, and I've made it exactly the way they taught me — as uninspired, soulless, and simple as possible.
Inspired. Soulful. And as unpredictable as possible.

It was the way my instructors in the Northaven military academy told me to approach my combat: that there were only so many techniques they could teach us to commit to memory, that the artistry of the process would have to supersede the mechanics.

But I was far from inspired or soulful when I woke up three hours ago: the first time in a while that the rapping of the knocker beat me to breakfast, causing me to rush through the motions of getting ready. I wore the odd undershirt that Cody gave me to find the slightest advantage when inspiration and soul feel unreachable — especially after the night before, when I sent Jullian home without any parting grant of affection.

Now I stand in a shooting stall for a short interlude. Test three of four: a brief intermission between demonstrating acts of war. Strength and conditioning were easy because I can train both of them outside the base, avoiding the garrulous crowds that love to speak ill of the weak. And though I placed in the top percentage for each of them, it's the remaining tests that concern me the most. Especially the last one: because defending the innocent is the entire point of service as a Royal Guard.

My finger hovers off the conductive plate of the aged IGR-4 Cinderjack rifle, a beast that's never seen war since it's spent most of its life collecting dust in the armory. I tuck my elbow to my chest, trying desperately to steady my trembling hand on the grip. My overwhelming concern for failure spills over the threshold of my mind, leaking its way into all my nerves and muscles. And the more the anger resists the trembling in my hands, tensing the tendons into a static position, the less control I find I have.

My right hand impatiently waits on my left arm to steady the barrel of the Cinderjack. My eye stares directly downrange through the crosshairs at a disparate spread of punctured points in the paper, depicting the silhouette of a Chymaeran with its sickly, amethyst claws drawn. But not a single shot has hit the two-dimensional bastard in the head, between its triangle of eyes. Only two of the five shots I've taken have ripped the black ink on the parchment.

The Essenced energy coalesces in my right index finger. I can feel the conductivity of the cold steel plate connected to the ignition chamber as my finger is drawn towards the metal, and when I lightly contact the combustion plate, transferring the Essence to incinerate the blasting powder, the round blasts through the rifle, startling me again, punching a sixth hole in the upper left corner of the page.

I look around, expecting laughter, but the shooting range's bays are partitioned by thick steel blinders. Behind me is only the bag of gear I brought for all the exams. And when I look out across the span of twenty sheets, I'm the worst of all of them.

The guard next to me holds a tight spread of eleven shots that are damn-near heart center, surely the best out of everyone — and yet my hands tremble so much that I have to rest the rifle against the stand. I watch my rival's rifle protrude from the edge of the partition one last time to purge the mag of its twelfth and final round.

His barrel is steady. His aim is calculated. And when their finger conducts Essence through the Cinderjack, the rifle hardly jumps as a bullet hole erupts through the black on the page: completing a circle of holes so perfectly apportioned that it clips a single paper snowflake, excising the entire Chymaeran's chest.

And then a set of long, black, manicured nails reaches for the rope of the pulley, dragging their disfigured parchment victim back to the firing line. And when it arrives, I raise my rifle in response, insecure about all the time I'm wasting. I fight the tremor I've had since the night of the fire, but just before I can begin to take aim, I feel a hand on my shoulder.
"Stop for a moment. You have to stop holding on so tightly."
It's a female voice. And I realize that my rival isn't a man after all.
"You're making the same mistake that my older sister did: trying to overcompensate for the recoil. But you'll never be able to control it. Just let it happen," she says.
I feel my ego flare on her words, as if someone my age should be sharing an instructor's commands. But I'm not good enough to do anything other than agree. "Thanks," I say.
"Just — stop for a minute," she commands. "Those rounds aren't going to leave the mag on their own: they can wait for a little while."

Uncomfortably, I lower the rifle and return it to the rack, and when I turn around, I find she's the only other Ahkvasan in our class: a cross-blooded demihuman with jet-black hair and cat ears that stares me down with slits of piercing, blue eyes, a visual rhyme that I can't yet place. She's trying to be helpful, but her words sound like ice, lacking any of the warmth that might comfort me. Yet her eyes light with some odd glimmer of excitement.
"Katiya Breakey-Hilde," she says. "You're one of the survivors of Hillfar that returned to finish the fight. I've heard so much about you."
"Oh, really?" I ask, wondering if now is really the time when I'm in the middle of failing my third exam. "And who told you about that?"

"I was in the same Strategies class. For the final project, you gave that 'after-action' analysis on what should have happened during the Siege of Hillfar — and told the story of your survival. You said you were coming back to 'save whoever your could from the same fate you were too small and weak to resist.' And your courage is actually what gave me the idea to follow my sister here."
"Your sister?" I say. "And I followed my brother. Maybe they know each other?"
"She's no longer around," she says, bluntly.
"Oh. I'm sorry to hear that."
"No. She was too weak. She was sent to the front lines. She didn't make it to the other side," she says, showing the slightest sliver of emotion that immediately dissolves.

I feel the urge to return to my exam, but she keeps talking, extending her hand. "My name is Aryn. Aryn Kesgrisin. I tried to introduce myself when I was standing right next to you at the parade, but we were interrupted."
"Yeah. By a humiliating failure," I say, turning my eyes down to the floor.

"It was an act of courage that others are jealous of. Malicious talk is all they have. Ever since that day I admired you even more," she says. "Jullian says I speak so highly of you that I should be in a relationship with you instead of him, though I don't know what that means."
"Jullian?" I ask. My stomach turns in another direction. "How do you know my boyfriend?"

"Jullian is one of the friends in our group. He talks a lot about you: complains that you never go on quests with us. I think those local quests are such a waste of talent, don't you think? Just an excuse to dole out skilled soldiers for stupid chores."
"A waste?" I ask. "I think they're important. You have to do your time to get to know the people."
"See? That's what I tell Jullian," she says. "He keeps telling us you're afraid. But a person like you, that came back here to protect? I didn't believe that for a second."
"Yeah," I say, hoping I can bend the anger of that truth into six more perfect rounds in a Chymaeran's chest. "I came here to serve first. I'll be living with these people, so I should know them."

"Then I ought to join you one of these times," Aryn says, rolling the target sheet in her claws until it becomes a punctured scroll. "Well, I hope our paths cross again soon. And if it's today, I won't be showing you any mercy. You're a good rival, and there's a lot I think you can teach me."
