"Until then," I say, feeling far more unraveled than I did before. The proctors begin to clean the nineteen other bays for another round of cadets, and when I get a glare from one of Aldrin's instructors, I level the rifle towards the sinister glare of the unwounded Chymaeran silhouette.
I repeat her words, distracting myself with how senseless and insincere they sound. Just let it happen.

I rack the seventh round. Just let it happen, Katiya, though every blast reminds me of the raucous explosions I heard in the distance as a child in hillfar, just waiting for one of those blasts to come closer.
Upper right corner.
Fuck.

Just let it happen. Maybe you should have let yourself die. Maybe you're just dragging out something that should have happened all those years ago. I ignite the Cinderjack again, blasting a hole through the top of the Chymaeran's head.
Just let it happen, you yellow bitch. How about you turn that gun around?
Bottom left thigh, barely in the black.
You were such a hero, the way you let that Chymaeran guised as Bertram just 'let it happen' to that noble.
Midsection. Crotch shot, barely off the black.
And the way you let it happen with Jullian walking all over you. Maybe I'm the one that gave him that hickey on his neck.
Bottom right of the page, entirely off the white.
Let it happen? Maybe you've never learned that if you just "let things happen," that's how you get yourself killed!
Dead-center headshot.
And then I feel the tingling in my fingers, breathing heavily, realizing that I haven't been breathing this entire time.
It's only after I retrieve the target that I turn around to find my friends gathered behind me: Paxton, Naya, and Ryder, with Bertram in his first debut since recovery.
"The final test is up next," Bertram says. "How did you fare on the others?"
"Roughly average. Still can't shoot. I'm done if I fail the next one," I say.
"Then we better group up," Paxton says. "I hear we're facing Jullian and his friends."
"I hear we're presenting to Kei and the rest of the team," Reed says, sipping on his second cup of coffee. He drinks that shit to calm down, while I chug energy drinks just to stay awake.

He invited me to walk around the building. Usually I turn him down, but this time, he said he wanted to talk about our presentations — and unthreatened by his grandiose design I peeked at every time I passed his computer, I decided to oblige.

We walk shoulder-to-shoulder around the rectangular building. The  weather-worn concrete is pallid with ancient tan like those old monitors, mice, and keyboards from the nineties, and when I peek inside, I see the lifers still stuck in their old ways, clicking away on CRT screens that could heat a breakfast burrito on a cold winter's day.
But I'm just trying to distract myself. I created and finished the presentation within an hour: a meager six slides, and only two with text, hoping that the simplicity of my design will speak enough.
KISS. Keep it simple, stupid.

Reed takes a sip from his steaming paper cup. Most times we reminisce on our old days of playing lacrosse like two awkward teammates at a high school reunion. I ramble on about technique: mastering the rusty gate check and ripping corner pockets. He talks about camraderie, and how much he enjoyed the team dynamics.

"But I think it's important," he insists, and I check my watch: thirty-two minutes until the meeting. "Getting to know all the people you can when you get on a team. I find people so interesting. It's like Carnegie says in How To Win Friends And Influence People, you know, you have to mean it."
Christ. Didn't know I was talking to a self-help guru. "Yeah. People can be interesting," I say.
"I just met Bruce on the floor: you know, Brucifer? The guy that wears the tie-die shirts, and always dresses up for holidays like St. Patrick's Day and Christmas?"
I take a sip from the can, then swallow. "Yeah."
"He took a look at my design. Gave me some feedback, and I barely had enough time to add all the changes," he says. "How many last-minute changes were you making?"

I take another long sip, relishing the carbonation, then swallow, hoping to drag out our conversation until it's paper-thin. "Mine's been locked for several weeks. Didn't really require much — I've been more focused on getting through redlines for Nav."

"Huh," he says. I notice his hands are shaking a little, but he tries to steady it. But when he notices that I notice, he feels the need to explain. "Still get nerves over performing. I know it's stupid, but there's a lot of pressure."
"Pressure from who? You're still the 'new guy.' You have plenty of room for imperfection."
"I wish I could think that way," he says. "It seems to work pretty well for people like you and my brother."
His comment catches me off guard, and I lean against the wall to stop us, engrossed for the first time in this courtesy conversation. "And what do you mean by that?"

He looks at me directly. "You know, you come in, do your time, and leave, and that's about it. And I guess there's nothing wrong with that, if the work gets done. A lot of the lifers take it that way. Especially in the battery division."

"That's because I owe this company nothing more than what the contract says," I say, glaring evenly back at him. "Designing battery enclosures isn't that enthralling. Even with this project — you know, one time I let my heart get a little too much into it, and they shot me down. All they want is the cheapest, simplest approach."

"But can you really survive the rest of your career like that?" Reed gestures intensely with his hands, almost upset. "What's your goal here? Is this just a jumping-off point for you? I mean, Navidson-Monroe is pretty prestigious."

"I wanted to design stuff in Aerospace," I say, then correct myself. "Want to. Designing tockets. Thermodynamic systems for engines. Research and development stuff." I turn my eyes to the top of the hill, struggling to discern the lines in the architecture when the sun is in my eyes. "They always warned us at University that we'd end up designing 'door hinges for Ford' for the rest of our lives — and every day it feels like the dream gets a little further."
"It's sad to hear that," Reed says, leaning with a single foot against the brick.

"I'm not asking for your sympathy," I say, trying to keep the conversation at a corporate level. "Why do you care so much? You're great at 'playing the game,' but to what end? Are you trying to get into management?"
"I have legacy here," Reed says. "My father was in senior management: vice president of operations."
"Good for you. Nice to have a chip on your shoulder: start ahead a little."
"We all start somewhere," he says. "Where doesn't matter. It's about doing something with it. And I have to be better."
"But why?" I ask.
"Because my older brother amounted to nothing," he says. crunching the plastic cup in his grasp. "And, goddamn it, I'm the only one left that cares!"

"And I'm the only brother left in my family that's alive," I say. "While your father worked up there, mine was on the floor, working double shifts. Sure, he expects me to succeed. But doesn't yours care more if you're happy?"
"He cares that I participate in the game, here," he says. "He cares that I try. Not that I just scroll the internet for six hours at a time."
I temper my voice. "What, you think that's all I do all day?" My fist tensions against the brick. "Who got furloughed and made you manager?"

"It's because I think you're a brilliant engineer, Cody," Reed says. "My brother was a year ahead of me in my engineering program at Boulder. He was brilliant like you — had that 'knack' that I always wished I had, but he dropped out. Doesn't even speak to us anymore."
"I wouldn't either, under pressure like that, " I say. "And I can't drop out of Navidson-Monroe."
"Look — I looked up your work after Kei and I talked about you."
"And when was that?" I ask.
"After coffee and . . . a movie, a couple times, but it doesn't matter, but that drone project? That's some seriously incredible work."
His words catch me off guard again. "Uh . . . thanks."
"And you did it all alone!"
"Yeah. I did," I say.
"You know, I just think nobody's given you the kick. Nobody ever compliments each other. I get it's just redlines most of the time, but don't you want to feel something behind it?"
"Feel what?"
"That you're getting closer to something," he says. "That you have a goal, and it's still there. That. . ."
A couple bean counters turn the corner, staring at Reed and his aggressive posture. We snap our heads to face them, looking like we're caught in some scandalous after-hours shit.
"Oh. Hey there," Reed says.
"Hey," one of them says.
"Hi," I respond.
I swirl the can.
"You guys alright, there?" They ask.
I take the last sip of my drink, in as chill of a manner as possible. "Yeah. Just arguing over what size fastener to use. Say . . .  do we still use that KANBAN system on the floor?"
They pause for a moment as Reed still holds his position. It's so quiet we can hear the dry grasses in the hills wave with the wind.
"Uh . . . yeah. But why would that change?"
"With quarter-inch increments?"
"Yeah?"

"Oh. Good, then," I say, then turn to Reed. "See, I told you, bro. Five-sixteenths UNC is fine, as long as it's one of the quarter sizes. Not that eighths shit." I wait for them to start to walk away, swirling the last remnants of liquid energy in the can as I ramble further. "You only need one-and-a-half-diameter thread engagement, but you can go longer, and—"
Reed leans back, creasing his brow between his fingers.
"What?" I ask.
"I, uh . . ." he mutters.
"Did you forget where you were at?" I check my watch. "You said I was like your brother. Who's like my brother."
But still breathing.
". . . then date with Kei, then she mentioned your project . . ."
"Date?" I ask.
" . . . then looked it up, then — yeah, and . . . oh, right. I'm just trying to say that people like Kei and I shouldn't be the only ones that care that your name wasn't on that wall."

"So you noticed," I say, knowing perfectly well that they did. And when he says it, it makes me feel something that I haven't felt in a while. It's a feeling like all those times in college, when my roommates kept asking me to go out, but I kept turning them down — but they still never stopped asking, and it meant the world to me.
"So I don't care about seniority," he says. "I'm gunning for a promotion no matter where I'm at. And either I'm taking you with me, or I'm leaving you behind. But you could use a push."

It feels like a face-off. If this were a lacrosse match, we'd be on our knees as midies at the dead center of the field: sticks raised, baskets inverted, pining after the same ball at the sound of a whistle.
But those years are long past. And this is stupid.

"Whatever you say, bro," I tell him, tossing the empty can in the bin, turning for the door with a feeling of fire. "One day you'll learn the same lesson I did. Maybe today, when you'll learn not to add all those fucking fillets."
"It's the best teammate that wins," Reed says. "Not the best design."

But the fire is beneath me: not within, like him. So it only lasts until I make it to my cubicle, calming myself down as I review the templated slideshow, the background pallid tan like every wall in this lifeless building.
The color of hope.
This world will shatter that fucking guy, I think. And I hope today is when it finally reaches him.

I'm certain that today is when it all finally reaches me. It's not because of the spread of punched holes in the target, nor is it the gossip and glare of cadets that watch us atop the old castle walls.

It's the unpracticed way the weight of the armor restrains my body. For so long, the cosmetic shell of thin steel was all I wore on my missions in the interior. Swinging my arms down with a wooden sword feels foreign when my hands have calloused more from benign fieldwork. All my muscle memory remembers is tilling fields and raking leaves, only adding to the panic I feel when the five of us stand beneath the fluttering crimson flag.

The commander orders us to "chalk up," and we dip our weapons into the barrel of red powder. Paxton traces lines beneath the burrows of his eye sockets. Ryder loads powdered crimson marking rounds into the rifle. Naya settles the dusted dagger in a holster across her chest, and as I sheathe the chalk-covered training sword in my holster, feeling no better practiced than someone like Cody, I try to draw the courage to admit how much I need this.

My eyes scan the landscape. It's the decrepit servants' quarter of the old castle: the same place I chased down the thief, only three stories lower and vacant of drifters and vagrants. The wooden roofs either burned in the ancient siege or crumbled to dust from so many cycles of calamitous weather, leaving only the stone walls to partition a perfect battlefield for observation. And we stand at the northeast end, preparing ourselves to strike the blue team in the southwest.

While Paxton's busy deliberating over designs for his improvised face paint — coated redder than the faces of Sun-scorched vagabonds, the special headband still hangs from a peg on the crimson flag, its gold stripe reflecting the meager light obscured by the tall castle walls.
And before I open my mouth to courageously plead, Bertram beats me to it.
"We need a plan," he says.
"But we need to decide on a team leader first," Ryder says. "On that first practice exam, we were defending. But now, we're attacking."
"So we treat the bystanders as hostages?" Naya asks.

"Yeah. And the other team treats them as targets for protection," Ryder replies. He takes the glistening span of fabric from the pole, turning to Bertram. "You've been out for a while. Do you need the boost?"
"They said this is just practice for me," he says. "Doesn't mean I won't pull through. But you should give it to someone who needs it."
Ryder replies," I don't mind leading again, if there are no takers. If no one needs it."
He looks at me, and I can tell he's just trying to be polite — not to offend me — knowing full well of how poor my standing is, and surely enough, the others follow his glance.
Bertram says, "why don't you do it, Katiya?"
"Me?" I ask.
"Sure. I mean, you don't have to come up with the plan, it's just a title."
"Unless you don't want to," Ryder says, "then—"
"I'll do it," I say, snatching the headband from his hands. Even guised without desperation, they know where I stand. "And I'll come up with a plan."
"So what have you got, Team Leader?"

My mind races through volumes of combat strategies, whatever I can remember. It's a lot of facts, of old battles, of tactics and results, but the thoughts struggle to churn out answers when I'm so focused on the inevitable. I think of how it will feel when I return to the warfront. I imagine how Jullian will move on. How—
"Katiya, we need a plan! We're about to start," Paxton says. "When that blue flare fires, we need to fire ours and get moving right away."
"I know," I say. Why am I even here? I wonder, but now is surely not the time to think like that.
"How about I come up with a plan? You can keep the bandanna on," Paxton says, but I know he'd probably just come up with some direct assault, never being one for tact or patience.
But what have I got?

"I've got it. We'll split three ways," I say. The thought comes out by the word instead of pre-planned sentences. "Pax, you're great at being obnoxious, so you'll go it alone. Go ahead of us and create a distraction that will shift their focus behind the house."
I hand him the flare gun.
"And then?" Ryder asks.
"And then we'll split in a basic pincer. Bertram and I go left to find a breach point. Ryder and Naya go right."
Bertram asks, "but what about the breach? Who will go first? Or at the same time?"

I think of the flare gun, and how it's the only tool for communication we have. "Pax will perform quick recon from behind the target. And he'll fire depending on where the hostages are. If they're concentrated on the right side of the house, his flare will fire to that side. Same for left. And if he can't tell, he'll fire straight up."
"And how does firing the flare like that change our strategy?" Pax asks.
"Because the first team to breach will be the side without the hostages, drawing them away," I say.
"Brilliant," Naya says. "No wonder you came up with most of our plan last time—minus the gold stripe."
"And what will I do after?" Pax asks.
"You join the last breaching party." I say. "The one that will have the best shot."
"And if it's straight-up?" He asks.
"Then you either break into the middle from a third breach point directly behind, or make your own judgement call."

"Ready!" Aldrin shouts, and I feel fear fill all the gaps and uncertainties in my plan like water fills a glass of ice. All the months I spent outside the base. All the combat practice drop-ins I missed. The space between the decrepit buildings begin to look like the shadows behind the sickly trees: a pattern of missing information that should be a second home to me, if only I wasn't so pathetic in my fear of the lands beyond.

All these thoughts blitz through my mind in the time the distant blue flare denotes their readiness to defend. And when Pax angles the first flare shell, taking the second one into his pocket, I feel the fear that restrained me in front of the carriage almost wholly consume my edge.
The first real exam begins as the five of us dissolve into the long shadow of the castle wall, finding our footing in the fading glow of the crimson flare.
My presentation begins after the seven of them settle into the semicircle of office chairs, searching for the words to begin as my body blocks the blinding glow of the projector's rays.

The room is dimly lit, and so their seven silhouettes are hard to distinguish when the projector's lens burns the first slide into my retinas, reading CODY DUNSMORE, BATTERY SOLUTION across the Navidson-Monroe PowerPoint template.

The sixteen-point Arial text is just the right size in the center of the first slide. Two lines. It reads: CODY DUNSMORE, BATTERY SOLUTION. Four words, two per line. A perfect split, and it even makes a square with the words.

I swallow. My voice catches in my throat as I can't decide whether to begin. The three unfamiliar envoys from Mahogany Row—far more used to their view from the ivory tower—are still busy typing an email, surely waiting for their Golden Boy to close it all out. But Nav watches closely, so instead of clearing my throat, I decide to proceed.

I temper the excitement from my voice. "After three years under the tutelage of senior engineers that have taught me everything about industry, I've come with a solution that I think will optimize ease of manufacturing," I say. "I wanted to make something as simple as possible. No over-engineering. Just exactly what we need without any extra features." I realize I'm gesturing with my hands, and I stop myself as I depress the clicker.
Click.

The light flashes with a standard fade-to-black transition at 0.3 seconds. Several pairs of eyes dance across the next slide, taking in the intricacies of the preliminary engineering drawing. Five pairs of them, while two are still busy typing an email.
Sameshima squints with his glasses to read the enlarged engineering print. And after the criticisms over my last couple designs, I've managed to get it all on a single page.
"And it's all on a single page?" Kei asks.
"A single page," I say.
"And there's no assembly?" Nav asks.

"No assembly," I parrot. And I find there's a part of me that relishes the look of surprise when they see the reveal of how perfectly simplistic my design is. That unyielding glimmer of hope and excitement rises again: the one that gets me in trouble, dragged into a room a year ago by Nav to tell me that I talk too much.

Their eyes dance over the page, snared on the ANSI callouts and the title block, and as the time passes, my mind pieces together a story of how I came to design it. That I saw a piece of origami on Sameshima's desk and had the idea to make a single part. That it hearkens back to designing the drone back in college. And how it brought back the best worst memories of being three energy drinks deep at 3:00 AM trying to resolve the very core of my entire design, and then I'd make a joke that—
"So, yeah, folds on an angle brake five times," I say, crushing the artistry of my work like stepping on an aluminum can. "Nothing fancy. Entire pattern is laser-cut."
"So you're telling us that you managed to make this whole design a single part?"

Hell yeah, isn't it great? I think, but say, "yeah. Reduces material cost and labor. Current design is three brackets to hold the battery." I gesture to the contours of the 3D view, trying not to reveal the sweat that's saturated my armpits. "And in those lines there, there's a reference to where it mounts on the machine." I pull at my collar, feeling beads of sweat trickle down the back of my neck. "Three holes. And this will cost even less than the three brackets it currently takes to make this."

They sit with their mouths agape: my team, that is — except for the executives, that looked up to find that they have no idea what they're looking at. Maybe my team wants me to tell them more, to boast a little. I surely want to, but something restrains that fleeting feeling.
"This is great," Kei says. "Seriously. It's incredible that you got this down to a single part!"
And their reactions are real. For the first time in a while, even Nav looks impressed, while the executives look bored as hell.
The electrical engineer Michael asks, "what about mounting holes for the supply and ground of the battery wires?"

"That's on the next slide." Click. "I talked to our manufacturer, and they're able to emboss a flange for wire clips." A sweat drop rolls down my nose. I adjust my tie like Rodney Dangerfield, except I think I'm actually getting some respect, and Michael says, "that's also really smart. So the techs don't have to deal with those stupid clips."
"Not at all," I say.

"But how about how it all goes together?" Reed asks. I know he saw my slides before this, but he still looks captivated by the design. And despite our uncomfortable rivalry, it almost seems like he's posing the perfect question to lead me to the next slide.
"And that's why I have this to show you," I say.
Click.

A flash of black darkens the room for a split second, and on the next slide, an animation autoplays on the screen. Since something moves on the page, beyond pre-baked transitions and bullets of text, the executives look up from their computers.
And it's the part I'm most proud of, feeling a rise of anticipation as they react to what I designed from scratch.

They all watch as my design folds perfectly into the shape from the first page, and from a flat pattern of laser-cut steel, the single piece folds from flower-like flanges into a bud as if it bloomed in reverse. The design was stolen from my past self — from all the suffering I went through alone, designing a lightweight drone chassis with an unemployed college student's scrappy budget.
"But how does it fold like that?"
"Folds on an angle break," I say.
"And the holes are pre-drilled?"
"No, cut from the laser, or water-jet."
"And what's it made of?"
"Stainless steel."
"And how can the technicians mount it?"
"Through the relief cuts. Quarter-twenty screws like the last design."

I want to believe I've finally got it when I scan their faces. Maybe this time I can let that fleeting feeling wash over me, relishing in their response when I'm not wasting my talent on those stupid redlines.

I feel like I did all those years ago when I presented the drone project. I remember that sliver of happiness between the brutal beatings of exams and class, and I almost think that back then I was happy for the first time since Jackson died, the way these fleeting moments rhyme.
But then an executive closes his laptop, leaning with his elbows on the steel cover. "That's great and all, Cory, but who would want to buy this?"
My heart pulses. I nearly drop the clicker.
"What do you mean?" I ask.
"I mean, it looks so plain," he says. "Look. Our customers want something sleek. Functionality is fine and all, but marketability is what moves units."
"Plain? This is—" a fucking bracket, I think, but I halt the words.

"I mean, it has to be sellable," he says. "We'll send out a tech bulletin with this part, and no offense, but aren't their eyes going to glaze over if they see this? I don't mean to be harsh, but what makes it stand out?"

I squint my eyes, and through the blinding rays I find it's the man that gave Reed the box of "new guy" donuts to share on his first day. I stutter over my words. I look to my team for that same sense of wonder, but they're silent: too tense about layoffs to argue with the Grim Reaper.

But Kei speaks up. "I think it's brilliant," Kei says. "One sheet of steel? Minimal setups for the ones making it, as long as they hold down the center of the flat pattern?" She points, "look, he even considered that. It mounts right there with a cap screw."

Two more beads of sweat saturate my brow. I try to forestall the feeling of anger I feel: these executives' knowledge of our operations is shallower than a piss puddle; more pedestrian than a preschooler. And after all this effort — to present something in EXACTLY the way they've molded me since the beginning, all I feel is a sense of betrayal.
But it's not the only sense of betrayal.
The executive continues, "I mean, what do you think, Naveen?"

He looks nervous, resisting his genuine sense of awe as he contorts his face into a grimace. "It's . . . I mean, I guess I can see some of that." He points to the engineering drawing on the screen, but he can't even meet my eyes. "Cody, who told you to make the corners so sharp on those bends?"
"I figured they would be close to ninety degrees, if it's in a steel brake," I say.
"You figured?" He asks.
"Yeah," I say. "I mean, this is just an early—"
"But did you talk to anyone?"
"Yeah." A familiar fear settles in my stomach. This will end just like all the others. "I, uh . . . talked to my father about it. It's how I got the fasteners to be accessible."
"But anyone else?"

"Not really," I say. The truth is I didn't want to bother anyone. I don't want to be lectured even more when I can swear I know my worth. And I wanted to surprise them: just to catch that moment I had before.
"And the metal thickness isn't even CE compliant," Nav says. "One-eighth? I mean, if you previewed this to any one of us, we'd be able to tell you that."
"We told Reed that," Michael says.
"This is just a prototype," I say.
The other executive says, "It might be a prototype, but what's our company's motto? What's the second pillar of the House Of Quality?"
"Built by precision," I regurgitate.
"And precision means getting things right," he says. The chair squeaks when he leans back. "Getting things right the first time. And what about the third pillar?"
"Rely on others."
Nav speaks up again. The point is to show your process. We don't do this work alone, and newer engineers should ask for advice." And then he adds, "Like Reed."

I want to tell them I wasn't trying to work alone. I want to tell them that I was excited to see their reactions from the moment I considered this, challenging myself to get this down to a single part and pulling through in the end. But all I can do is stand there and take it — like being a pledge in the fraternity again, bludgeoned by broken rules when my works should at least be acknowledged.
At least someone seems to get it. While the others are stone-faced and unwilling to defend me, I find an unlikely voice of dissent.

Reed balls his fists on the table, but still waits his turn to speak. "I thought Cody's folding concept was incredible! Mine uses far more parts than his does. And it's heavier. And it's bulkier. And yet Cody rolled out this design as if—"
The executive says, "but Reed, you asked the whole damn department for their input. So this is everyone's design."

Reed purses his lips, and an awkward silence spans the lineup of this unwitting firing squad. The projector whirs overhead. We can even hear the clattering of tools, machines, and raucous chatter behind us, as I wait for someone — anyone else — to speak up. But it's not a friend: there never seems to be anyone in my corner here.

"I think we agree that the problem with your design is that you didn't ask for help," one of Reed's visitors says. "The problem is that you came up with this, and you didn't ask for help. Or else these issues wouldn't be there." Another silence as the projector whirs overhead. "But I like the folding thing. And the animation on the second slide. Folds like origami."
Another silence.
He says, "do you have any other slides for us?"
The unfolding box plays over and over on the screen as a GIF: my presentation was only four slides by design.
"That's it," I say. "I was trying to keep things concise, not over-explain."
"Concise? How long did you spend on this?" He asks, scribbling something on his empty pad.
"Weeks," I say.
"Weeks?"
I turn my head away. Through the shades of the back window, I can see the glowing reflectors of the Aerospace building, and maybe it gives me just enough to reply.
"Yeah. Weeks," I say. "I thought you wanted something . . . optimized, you know. Inexpensive. And simple."
"I think it's simply great," Wilbur says, with enough years and irreplaceable knowledge to say whatever the hell he wants. "Cody, you did a great job, and this is really impressive."
I smile. "Thanks, Wilbur."
"No wonder I still have a lot to learn," Reed says.
I smile. "Thanks, Reed."
"Nice," Kei says.
I smile. "Thanks, Kei."
I turn to Nav, to Michael, to anyone else, but they're still as cardstock.
Another silence.
I press my thumb against the clicker, and after a final flash of darkness, a blank slide says QUESTIONS. But I'm sure I know their answer.

"Thanks for your feedback. I'll look over all that again. Wall thickness. CE compliance. Bend angle," I mutter, pulling the HDMI cord from the side of my machine, returning the room to darkness as Reed recircles to plug in his.

The screen lights with a bright and colorful presentation, bathing the walls in a mirage of hues like the northern lights: certainly not the standard template from the folder. And as he opens his mouth with a smile, he delivers his first, rehearsed line, with such a naive and enviable spark of genuine excitement.

Only the Gods above know how the other team will answer my plan. Beads of sweat absorb in the weave of the golden headband, without the exertion to warrant it: we've been advancing so slowly this whole time. But the light piece of fabric feels heavier than any piece of armor I'm wearing.

The old servants' quarter is so silent I can hear the cadets' conversations atop the walls. And though the voice inside my head is louder, recalling every moment I could have prepared for this, both voices gossip about the same thing.
All the eyes are on me again. Aldrin leans over the edge of the parapet with binoculars, and the reflection of his lens looms like a searchlight in the shade of the scorched stone buildings.

As Bertram and I advance west, the glowing eye dances between the north — where Ryder and Naya make their own advance — and to the enemy's western corner, where Paxton sneaks to gather our first piece of ordinance.

Our steel boots crunch the dried leaves and charcoal. For a while, our two strike teams were neck-and-neck as we dispersed across the diamond shape of the battlefield, but now we no longer catch flashes of crimson between the narrow alleys. Either they're ahead us or behind us, but either way, I feel the anticipation rise for Pax's flare.
"We need to go faster," Bertram mutters. "We should be in front of the others. Why are we stopping?"
"Because we can't die before we get there. What if they run a forward ambush like we did last time? The move that brought us the victory?"

"You can't control for that," he says, as we pass the neutral flag, marking the exact center of the diamond. "I say this as your best friend, but you can't hesitate. We have to get there. Your plan will be dead before we even arrive!"

Somewhere ahead, something hard glances off a piece of metal scrap, and it freezes me in my tracks: waiting, listening just like I did every night at the window of the cabin, fighting a losing battle between my muscles and my mind.
Bertram sighs as he drags me by the breastplate. "That was nothing."
"But how can you be sure?" I ask, hastening my pace when Aldrin's reflection focuses on us, casting a widening disk of incident rays the further we get.
"Because the others are already long ahead," he says. "Look at where Aldrin's light goes: the others are already in position!"
I curse out loud with an exasperated sigh.
He says, "You're giving them time to come straight to us! Every second—"
"I know, Bertram, I know," I say.
"I don't have anything riding on this," he says. "I'm just saying that now isn't the time to hesi—"
A loud blast echoes through the quarter, and with such high walls bounding the battlefield, I have no directional sense to tell where it comes from.
But it's directly in front of us.
I duck for cover.
"Katiya, now's not the time!" He mutters.
I say, "We need to get around—"
"We need to go straight, and run. Run! Now!"

He drags me again as we sprint through the wide alley, presenting himself as a shield to pacify my cowardice. I level the training rifle behind him, and when Aldrin's scope illuminates us, I advance so I'm shoulder-to-shoulder with him.

Another blast echoes through the air. My body lunges for the nearest alley, but Bertram's strong grasp prevents me from escaping. And for the first time, I see his infinite patience with my trauma begin to crumble.
"Gods damn it, Katiya!" He says. "Show some spine and use that anger. How are we ever going to get to Hillfar to make peace with the past, when—"

Aldrin's searchlight hovers over us again, and then a little east. My bout of hesitation plays out in the limelight when we're both exposed, and it's when the light flickers a little north that I know exactly what's going to happen.
If I hesitate one second more, they'll all see what I really am. A fraud. A coward. That I'm still that terrified little girl, pretending to be a guard.
And maybe that's all I'll ever be.
"Gods damn—"
Bertram's head cocks to the side, catching a glimpse of something that I don't, and as my muscles lock up, he pushes me with all his might.

Bertram takes a full blast of chalky, blue powder to his chest, blown backwards against a stack of broken crates that crumble under his weight. The red chalk that decorates his face now blended purple, marking him as the first victim.
"I can't keep saving you," he shouts, balling his fists as he winces, and now finally I hate myself enough to act. "I can't keep being your shield. One day, this is going to be real!"

I peek out of the corner, sighting the adversary that's reloading the rifle, then pull the trigger. My first round misses, and I dive behind the corner of the alley while Bertram's disappointed glare propels this self-hate to unprecedented heights.

I groan again, cursing myself as I rack another round. Something slams against the other side of the wall, casting a cloud of blue dust into the air, and in the space that Bertram's killer takes to reload, I raise my weapon, steadied with my shoulder against the corner of the wall.

But I remember my accuracy moments before. Jullian's friend is in my sights as my finger feathers the trigger, but all I can think of is the instructor's red marks on the target sheet, giving me a failing score.
Failure, I think. And so the chance passes.
As my hands tremble with the training rifle, a second figure strolls fearlessly in the middle of the street, illuminated by Aldrin's lens that reflects a blue-and-gold headband.

It's her again. She levels her rifle in my direction, ears twitching with every sound that might reveal me, and when she sees my face, she pulls the trigger with an accuracy that punched perfect holes in paper targets.

Another cloud of blue chalk saturates the air as my heart jumps into my throat, followed by two more blasts from her rifle. And as Bertram returns to home base, his hands raised in reluctant surrender, I wipe the faint blue mist from my face, trying to decide what to do next.
Aryn directly calls out to me, sending gooseflesh down my arms and legs. I'm unsure whether it's her tone, or how afraid I am of the thrashing I'll receive at the end of this.
"What leader lets their teammates take bullets for them? Come out here and fight me, Katiya!"
I crouch behind the corner, still deciding how to use this spike of adrenaline.
"Do you plan to lead from the back forever, Katiya?" She asks, and as I hear her getting closer, I decide to run: running down the next alley to race to the original rally point.
Fight defaults to flight, but at least I'm running, fueled wholly on disappointment as I draw my dagger, putting the two insurgents behind me: exactly where I don't want them.

The intended action point is approaching, and at least my conditioning can get me there fast in this heavy armor: all I've ever done my whole life is run. I hear the blasts echo from behind, running in a zig-zag pattern like a hare evading the jaws of a predator. Blue chalk accents the walls to the left and right. Aryn shouts something else, but I'm unable to hear her when my heartbeat pounds in my ears, drawing raspy breaths that taste like poison as the breach point approaches.

But then Pax's radiant signal launches into the air, followed by a loud pop. I'm still running, exhausted; mind racing too fast to respond quickly when I blast through the door; heart racing too rapidly to catch a breath before I breach.
And it fires straight up into the air.

This was a plan based on time, and my fear has left me behind. Expecting Bertram and I to be waiting on the other side, I hear a crash as Naya and Ryder bludgeon their way through the far door, and a long five seconds later, I finally find the wall where Bertram and I should have been waiting.

Several blasts echo between the walls as Aldrin's searchlight illuminates the entire footprint of the roofless building. I lower my shoulder to breach through the door, entirely unprepared for what I find waiting for me on the other side.
Reed's entirely prepared as he advances towards his last slide. In the lower corner, it reads 20 OF 20: even with a custom progress bar to show the stages of his presentation.

"And, again, here's a full view of my assembly," he says. "Not animated in that cool way like Cody's, but I've colored each of the parts." Each of the five parts: two more than the current design already uses. And although his design looks really cool—with even the company logo laser-etched into one of the faces- the design doesn't have a single sharp edge, defaulting to the rounds called fillets that are a bitch-and-a-half for machinists.

But this is everybody's design, according to Naveen. I watch his expression twist in all the ways it did during the presentations I gave in my first year, calling out impossible corners and stress concentrations. But he's been silent this whole time, along with all the others.

"This is my first effort in designing something here," Reed says, putting his hands together in a prayer-like gesture. "I'm new to this, and I want to humble myself before the process, though I can't tell you how excited I was to present my ideas."
"I like how the L-brackets save on cost. Going for what already exists, just like I told you," Sameshima says.
Michael adds, "and the holes for mounting wires."
Nav adds, "and you got the metal gauge down to the right width.
I feel like I'm expected to praise him, too. "And you used the material I recommended. It'll definitely be lightweight with Aluminum."
"Please," Reed says. "Not as light as a single piece of sheet metal."
"Well, you did well," Naveen says. "It's the best first presentation I've seen." Yet with that familiar expression, it looks like he has something else hr wants to say.

But what? I think. The egregious number of fillets? The oversized mounting screws that could hold up one of our airplanes? The cuts that don't contribute anything? The laser etching somewhere a laser couldn't reach? The surface finish? The stacked tolerances? The unmarked dimensions? The fact that this thing is over-engineered so evidently for aesthetics over function?
"What is it, Cody?" Nav asks.

I realize they're all looking at me. Maybe my face made some stupid contortion. "Nothing." They draw the silence out longer, and I try to offer the most meager critique. "I thought this was a design review. Shouldn't we be, uh . . . critiquing each other evenly?"
They stare at me, blankly. I spent the whole presentation obsessed in watching them react, and as someone who's fielded more criticism than an intern, I can see it in their faces.
Reed's father's friend replies. "Well, I don't know. I think Reed got all that out when he asked the whole damn company," he says, followed with a corporate laugh that all the others try to mimic.

I look down at my sheet of paper. It's still vastly overcrowded with criticisms I jotted down for myself than ones for Reed, but I feel something inside usher the words without being able to stop them. My pen taps the first one. "Nav, you told me that the angles on my design were too sharp. But what about the ones on those two parts," I gesture, "over there?"
Nav looks pissed all of a sudden. "This isn't about me, Cody. But sure, I can see that?"

I tap another bullet point on my sheet. "And what about the screws? They might be oversized for the application. I remember Sameshima once told me to keep from doing that.He gave me one of his design charts."
"That's a good point," Reed says, jotting it down.

I think my words might usher other obvious criticisms, but from the way the executives glare at me, I find the rest of the room is still silent, but something inside urges me to keep going. "And the fillets. Kei told me once to keep them to a minimum, only for stress concentrations. Don't get me wrong, your design looks fantastic and is more serviceable than mine, but you might want to . . . dial it back a little?"
Reed jots it down: not offended, not upset, but professional, yet it's the other lifelong corporate dregs that have an issue.
"All I've heard is the ways that the others have criticized you, Cory," the executive says. "If you're so good at taking criticism, then why can't you be a good employee and ask for it?"

I ball my fists as my face flushes with heat, barely able to keep my composure as I think I'll snap the steel drafting pencil in my grasp. It takes everything to level my voice flatter than the landscape below the mountains — the view these pencil-pushing fucks take for granted while they take the elevator to get down here.
"There just hasn't been any criticism yet. And I had a couple things to share."

I see Naveen catch a glance at my reddening face with sympathy. He knows what's really going on. But like everyone else here, the coward insists on just playing his corporate game: the game our new hire seems to be miles ahead of me on.
I look around, pleading for anyone to stand up for me before my emotions push me to an early professional grave.
"Reed," the executive says, "you've done a great job. It's no wonder you're on the wall of future talent."
A cloud shades the landscape beyond the glass, casting the bright reflection from the solar arrays in shadow. And then the words leave my mouth before I have the wherewithal to form them.
The entire room is stunned for a second. Even the executives are surprised.
"Excuse me?"
"I said, three years of busting my ass here, but it was never about the work, was it?" I parrot.
And at least it's my own words I'm repeating this time.

"People like you stroll around the shop and design floor like you have your fingers on the pulse of the company, but you don't know anything about design. I didn't ask anyone for help — you know why? Because I've had three and a half years of critique to hone my works, and I've listened to every word." I feel myself stand, no longer trembling with fear. "I've remembered, and recorded, and meticulously followed the script for as long as I can remember — only to have my boss critique me on the exact things he instructed me to change!"
Nav looks terrified. The rest of them are too afraid to argue as I crumple my page of notes in my hands.
Nav mutters, "Cody, you need to—"

"You know how long three-and-a-half years is? To someone that's dreamed of this company since they were a child in Hearthland Ridge?" Their expressions change ever-so-slightly from anger to something else. Because I have something other than just some short temper. I turn to Reed, and he looks sympathetic, so I spare him. "You're going to be a great engineer, Reed. I know it. But I don't have a golden spoon up my ass like you do, and I don't have a sympathetic audience to turn their words in my favor." I rip the badge from the retractable reel on my work pants. Work pants that my shirt was actually tucked in to, because I hoped that today would be different, because I let that stupid feeling inform my actions again. "If you're not going to give me a fair shot, and if the only thing that matters is who I know, then why the hell am I even here?"
The silence is thick. The fear still furrows their faces, and as I'm about to turn, I find an unlikely voice in the struggle.
Reed taps his pencil against the lectern. "Cody's points are valid. I mean, his idea is way better—"
"Get him out of here," the executives say.
"Enough, Reed," Nav says: the guy who's supposed to impress his superiors by how he cracks the whip. "Cody, that's enough! Go cool down. We'll be having a one-on-one after this."
I nod. Then I awkwardly return to the front of the room: grabbing my work laptop and the crumpled page with all the criticisms I intended to take to heart.

My hand falters. My fingers kick the page on the floor, so I have to go around an embankment of three desks in humiliation as I grasp the crumpled ball of graph paper, feeling the horror wash over me like the guys in the control room during the Cuban Missile Crisis: entirely aware of how my future trajectory might have irreversibly shifted.
"I'm sorry. I just—" I manage, but the stream of tears beats the words as I turn away to hide them,  rushing down the hall and out the door, debating whether I have a desk to return to.

If I don't act now, I won't have a home to return to. When my shoulder bludgeons open the door to the roofless, charred edifice, it is not an act of courage, but the response of a frightened girl that can't resist the currents of fear.

I flow like water from the heights of terror to the lowest point of controlled panic: just an autonomous reaction, and I rue the fact that I haven't the mental space for clever and quickness. My trembling hand grasps the chalked wooden dagger from the holster on my chest, trying to mask my heaving breaths of exertion as Aldrin's beam animates the shadows between the cracks of the uneven cobblestone walls.

Rifles aren't allowed in close quarters, so I'm prepared to pounce on anyone. Last time I had the upper hand with Cody — and a window to watch him stumble through the foyer first — but here, I'm met with an uncomfortable silence, more unsettled by my adversaries outside the walls than the contents of this flame-lashed footprint.

I check the corners, ready to strike at the slightest provocation: my grasp on the dagger tense but unsteady. Maybe they were in the North Wing, where Naya and Ryder breached. All that commotion — could it already be over? And when I press through the center of the space, squinting my eyes as I try to distinguish the features through dusk, the western door bludgeons open, casting me to the floor.
Paxton looks twice his size when he tenses all his muscles, and though the searchlight meandered in the east, it quickly snaps back to the blue team's house after I lift myself from the floor.
"Where are they?" Pax says: his hands ice his grasp on the sword with the same power that stacked shot glasses in the tavern. "I heard commotion, and then nothing: what's happening?"
And then another figure emerges from the north: impossibly silent on her feet.
"It was Ryder and I," Naya says. "We managed to take out two of them, but Ryder was killed."
"Where the Res were you, Katiya?" Paxton asks. "You were late!"
And then the words leave my mouth without the wherewithal to stop them.
"We were ambushed. Bertram and I. We tried to put up a fight—"
"But where are they?" Pax asks. "Where are the hostages?"
Naya says, "we went right while Bertram and Katiya went left. And Paxton went around."
The only conclusion left is preposterous. "That's an incredible wager," I say. "You're telling me..."
"If they get to the red flag, it's over!" Paxton shouts, retrieving the training rifle from his back. "We need to rush them!"
And just then, the blue team's flare takes its turn illuminating the battlefield.
"They have the advantage — what's happening?" Naya asks, her tail frayed with apprehension. "It's three versus three, and they have a straight shot to victory."
"They're not going for an easy victory. Aryn isn't going to leave any of us alive," I say.

The blue flare feathers out, leaving us in the wake of its ambient glow. "So what are we going to do?" Paxton asks. "Whatever they're doing, they're doing!" They turn to me: our two other confident tacticians are dead.
I idle. "But how did they get around?" I ask.
"It doesn't matter. Get to the windows," Pax says, and shamefully, I begin to untie the bandanna from my head.
"Stop," Naya says, grasping my hand with her claws. "There's no time to denigrate yourself." And then the quiet one gives me orders. "Get to the center window."

"Alright," I say, resting the barrel of the red-powder rifle against what remains of the windowsill. We hear the thunder of rocks resounding against any metallic surface. The three sound like an army of hundreds coming to cleanse us from this battlefield, and as I sit at the window, I can't help but feel like that same petrified girl that once listened at the window, until one day her nightmare came true.
And, just then, I hear a blast from the south.
"I got one," Naya exclaims, but just as she's about to turn to face me, a loud blast from beyond powders her spotted fur with blue dust, casting her towards the wall away from the window.

The clatter of stones and pebbles accelerates like a hailstorm of bullets against steel, brass, and bronze, as if the Gods themselves cast their judgement on my cowardice from above. The maddening, raucous clatter crescendoes as Paxton takes up arms at the rear windowsill.

"They're behind us!" He shouts. A round rips through his window, decorating the back wall with blue powder that darkens from the cloud of ash and dust, only inches from my head. "Run for the red flag, Katiya, it's the only way you can save this. Touch the hostages. Save our—"

He takes a round to the chest, and it hardly staggers him. Two more crackle off his chest armor, and before my mind can interpret the death of my last misled comrade, I leap through the window, evading a maelstrom of blue-powder rounds as I fire blindly, decorating the sky and ground and walls with red.

I'm running down the same thoroughfare as the weakening reflection of Aldrin's eyeglass observes me. There is no space for reason when my heart is in my throat, along with my lungs, and running straight for the front with my rifle leveled, I feel myself pull the trigger at the first figure that emerges from the corner.

The figure crumples, falling to the ground as they wheeze, grasping their unarmored chest. Aldrin's reflection catches the bright green linen they're wearing, with a thick weave of gambeson armor on the top.
"Hostage down," Aldrin exclaims, and riding the fumes of bitter resentment, my mind concludes the rest of the hostages are around the corner.
The rounds keep whizzing, grazing, and missing, displacing the air around me, not a single one contacting me loll as I turn the corner to touch as many hostages as I can.
But instead, I touch the cool breastplate of a soldier: one that lashes me to the ground with the wide face of her broadsword.

"You will never save anyone if you're always the last to respond, Katiya," Aryn says, glaring down at me with her piercing, slitted azure eyes. She raises her hand to stop the others from claiming victory prematurely, granting me the clemency to lift myself from the ground. And as my body crumples on another episode of public mortification, Aryn remains still and absolute, speaking with a voice and expression like one of Cody's automatons.

"Prove yourself to me. Prove to all of us that you're better than you act," Aryn says, as Jullian steps from behind her, unable to bring himself to look at me again. "Fight me," she says: "fight me and regain your honor!"
She takes a slash at me with the training sword at full force, and I deflect with the dagger in my left hand, barely able to catch her rounded edge with the hilt.

My other hand withdraws the light, wooden sword from its sheath. The rest of the world fades to darkness as the sun sets behind the Purgatory Mountains, leaving only the searchlight that sketches a circle in the street.

The dead approach from both sides, saturated in homogenous purple: the victims from the blue team; Bertram and Ryder and Naya and Pax; and the other active blue-team soldiers with their weapons still drawn.

"Show me you deserve to be here," she says. "That you deserve Jullian. That you deserve a key and a home. That your presence isn't just an insult to all the ones that didn't make it!" She hammers me with blows on every line, driving me further away from the trembling ring of light. My wordless rebuttal only lies in blocking her sword, as amethyst dust clouds the air. Every assault comes at full force in a furious flurry of slashes, without the inefficiency of hesitation.

Every strike is another scene that plays within: every evasion of the base; every quest spent meandering around the city; every time I turned down my friends that only wished to challenge me from a place of love.
I'm driven further out of the ring: to a premature death, towards my colleagues that cower in secondhand shame.
But in her mechanical string of attacks is an absence of variation.
It's a pattern.
Like the pistons of touring cars, her strokes land all the same, and when I draw on the flood of emotion that immolates me from within, I find the faintest opening.

A creative force of Essenced energy flushes my circuits with one last spark of intention. The maroon dust clouds shimmer with notes of blasting powder. Between blows as I'm drawn to the absolute edge, I let my hands scald with the energy of life and fire. And when she lunges for a final blow, I ignite the air and dive behind her, closing my eyes as the blinding flash stuns her.

I level my sword to strike, catching her in an unprecedented moment of weakness. I turn to face Aron as she reflexively wipes her eyes, my strike committed and absolute, but just as I'm about to deal Aryn's death, a close-range slug of blue powder explodes against my back, sending me directly in to her as we both sprawl outside the circle.
"Drill is over," Aldrin shouts. "Blue defenders win four-to one."

I turn my head to find the rule-breaker that blasted me at close range, and I find Jullian standing there. Maybe his glance is one of pity, or maybe it's fear. Or maybe it's relief — from how his jealousy resists any motion I make towards redemption.

My body lacks the strength to stand up, but Aryn finds her footing. She hesitates to extend a hand, offering one last string of words before Jullian braces her, taking her arm over his shoulder as another one of her teammates approaches.
"You will never save anyone like this, Katiya," she says. "You're worse than Rayna. And you'll die faster than she did."
"I saved Rayna," I mutter, but it's too quiet for her to hear.
"You will always be a victim," Aryn says. "And to think you were my inspiration."

Bertram and Paxton lift me by the arms as Ryder draws the Essence to mend my minor scrapes. I hear Aldrin's voice call for me to approach overhead as they carry me towards the wooden elevator, grasping the railing as they pull me from the battlefield to become an observer of the grand map.
"I'm not sure why you chose to wear that headband," Aldrin says.
"I had a plan," I tell him. "I had a great plan."

"But you were late! You cowered, and hid, and had Bertram here dragging you like he is just now. You're a casualty. A piece of twine that guises as a steel link in the chain," he spits, "and a leader that waits until it's safe. Leaders don't wait!"
"I . . . but I —"
"I've given you so much leeway, Katiya. You have talent, but Gods be damned, why are you even here?"
I choke back tears to withdraw the words. "Because I have a dream," I say. "I had a dream. To save someone. To save anyone. To make my family's death and all that pain mean something! Or else . . . "
"Well, you're below the line, Katiya," Aldrin says. "The first one this term. And I KNOW you have it in you."
"Yes, sir."
"I need to see a whole success from you, from start to finish. No hesitation!"
"Yes, sir."
"And more patrol quests than domestic quests."
"Yes, sir."
"You have until next test to prove yourself."
"Yes, sir," I say.
"Or else . . ." His words trail off.
"Yes, sir" I add.

"And here." He withdraws a small envelope from a folder, extending it to me. "You haven't been to the mail room in ages. This has been sitting there for a while. You've got a letter from your family: hopefully it can act as motivation."
Maybe it's just another check-in card, another undeserved pulse of praise from afar.  But I quickly realize it's something substantive from the weight.
When I remove my left arm from Bertram, slicing back the top of the envelope with my dagger, I find a dense pack of pages. My eyes scan the first lines of my mother Stella's stationery.
The date was a month-and-a-half ago.
And my stomach drops further when I read the first lines of the long letter.
Sometimes this numbness can be a blessing in the same way that it's a curse.

It's a curse that makes tearful graduation speeches from my father sound like lectures from a professor. It makes moments of intimacy with the woman I thought I I'd end up with feel like a meaningless hookup. But in moments of toleration — whether it's the long, dragging pledge process, an hour-and-a-half waiting for a new license at the DMV, or the verbal lashing I received from Naveen — the curse can be a blessing.

I observed myself from the corner of the room just like I do in every situation, fully detached from the experience like I'm reading my own story, like the words are already written on the page and I'm anticipating what comes next.
All I know is that I'm not getting fired. I've spent most of this car ride home just trying to locate the debris inside me, thumbing through flesh for the fragments from my explosion.
But I don't think anything is there.
Either my soul is too calloused, or its affects phased right through me, just like all the other acts of love when feeling and setting aren't aligned by chance.

Cody was sitting in the dimly-lit room with the shades drawn. He was called in there from his desk by his boss, before the others could return from the meeting. He was certain he was being fired, but he found the strangest sense of relief in the idea of starting from scratch, no matter the pain of what that process entailed, or the dangers of that mortgage for the interdimensional house he took out in his name.
But he quickly found that the lashing almost felt like a formality.

The punches felt they were being driven by something else: weak and auxiliary, like catching blows from a marionette. Naveen said the leadership decided to go with Reed's design, and despite all the effort he put into it, channeling everything he learned only to be told to discard everything he learned, he realized that all he could do was just ride out the slow swell of mediocrity.

Maybe Reed really is better than me. Maybe Kei really does deserve someone better. And maybe all that someone like me can aspire to is just to mull around designing batteries and fixtures for the rest of my life.

Maybe I am that second type of engineer, I think to myself. Maybe I'm the type that digs a foxhole into a single forgotten field, while the rare few are able to ride their passion. Have I ever been passionate? Why did I even choose this in the first place?

All I know is that the anger is still there. It's hot and uncomfortable, and when my foot sinks the pedal to the floor, apathetic to that pointless, abandoned light at the bottom of the hill, I blast directly through the red without any observers. I pound the wheel. I scream as loud as I possibly can with the windows down and the wind at eighty miles per hour and climbing rushing past my face, shouting obscenities and trying to let it out though the discomfort is still there, thinking that if I coax it out by going through the motions of people who feel, that I might find its release.

But all I have is speed, and the feeling of inertia when the car jostles over the uneven hill before the highway, forcing me to slam my brakes so I don't flip off the on-ramp. My fingers tension the rubber wheel, ruing this feeling of internal anguish and the fear of what comes after when I return to the office. Maybe the enclosure design failed for bureaucratic reasons, but I still have the battery project. And maybe I just have to impress them so much that they can't help but promote me: to acknowledge the talent I KNOW I have inside me.
But no. That's the feeling of hope again.
Maybe I all I have is just to do it at minimal effort, and pass time like all the others in my company that settled early.

Cody pulls in the garage a little after 17:30. I hope it's excitement that brought him home so quickly: maybe to relay the news, that the presentation gave him everything he ever wanted. I was happy to be a spectator for his rehearsal this morning, though I wasn't listening to a word of it. It wasn't because I didn't care. It was less because I didn't understand, and more from rising panic over the demands of my competency test.

I couldn't stand to stand or sit or lie down in my own home, to relish in so much as a square cubit of undeserved space. It felt as if the ground might vanish beneath me if I put too much weight on it, and thusly, I retreated past the threshold to rest in the calmness of Cody's world.

I sit on his couch in comfort clothes that he gave me a couple weeks ago: cozy pajama pants in a strange black-and-red pattern that Cody tells me is reminiscent of tree-cutters — called jacks of lumber or something — and a thin, cotton shirt that's tight around the chest, reading SHALEBOROUGH RENAISSANCE FAIRE. With nothing but time to waste, I try to thumb through the device he got me, wondering how it could fit all the literature of his world in so small a space.

The garage closes. And the door bursts open as if he were kicking it for a breaching drill. His face is red, and his eyes are red, but it doesn't look like he was crying. The crescents of his eyes are worn deeper than I've ever seen them, unshouldering his bag pack as he covers his face with his hands, letting out a loud exhale.
"So what happened?" I ask: it's what asked me when my world first fell apart.

"Everything," he mutters. I watch his body sink onto one of the barstools. Then he settles for the floor, crumpled with his head resting in his hands.  "I'm pretty sure I lost everything," he says, "or I lost everything at the start, and only now, I'm realizing what's gone."

He's distraught, but I find a strength in his weakness that's entirely absent from my world. A strength to lose races for friendship. To make jokes. To bleed publicly. And despite the anguish of all my shortcomings, I find the overwhelming desire to do nothing but protect him: because I think he's the only person I've met who understands.
And I try, one last time, to draw out those feelings from within myself.
I rise from the couch to join him on the floor. "I wonder which of us had it worse," I say.
"I found out my company doesn't need me," he says, and instead of heaving breaths that will surely lead him to a panic attack, the sentence provides enough pause to slow his breathing.

The thought of Jullian makes me hesitate to touch him: maybe it's because of the fear of being hurt; that I'm still trying to reconcile how something so great can devolve into apathy. The rules are still taped to the door: the last one circled several times in impossibly bright yellow ink.

"I found out that my 'company' might be better without me, too," I say, focusing my eyes on his face until he decides to turn and face me, but he still hides with his head in his hands: ears red with tufts of short brown hair displaced by his fingers.
I want so badly to touch him.
"And what did you do?" He asks.
"I failed an examination. A very critical one. They said I was too weak. That I'll never save anyone. And then I lost to my rival in a humiliating way," I say, and I sniffle.

"They showed me that I'll never be good enough. All they care about is the ones that play the game. But I had a shit hand to start," Cody says. "So my dad is a technician? The union are just scabs for corporate guys to pick off one by one."
"And weakness of any kind is a malady. And my past keeps getting in the way," I tell him. My head sinks slowly until it's about to rest on his shoulder.
"At least you had a chance to fight," Cody says. "My struggle was fixed from the start."
"Oh, please. At least you didn't have to fight with your fists," I say.
"Fight?" It's the first time he flashes his dark brown eyes at me. "Violence isn't the only incisive way to shred a person's soul. I spent three years trying day-in and day-out."

"And I tried just like you," I say, sternly, discomforted by a new hole for my anger that I haven't the time to suture shut. I know what he means, but the words leave anyway. "What, you think it's all just in my head?"
"In your head? What are you talking about? Your struggle is actual violence. I'm just saying professional death can hurt, too," he says, slowly sliding away from me.
"I never said it couldn't," I say.
"I know. I'm just saying you have the agency to change things. To choose what image you fight for," Cody says, "but . . ."

"So you are saying it's all in my head!" I exclaim, rising from the floor to look down on him. "Tell me, is your family dead? Were you the victim of unfathomable violence that scarred you in places you'll never be able to find?"
"No," Cody says, standing up as he backs against the icebox, nearly tripping over his bag. "I'm sorry, Katiya, I misspoke. I mean that—"

"You weren't even there when your brother died. He's more of a warrior in any sense than you'll ever be," I hear myself say, balling my fists until my nails might break the flesh on my palms, and I feel the unfairness of all the world exit my mind wholly through the keyhole of my mouth. "How do you get better at sitting in a box?"
"Fuck you," he says. "What are you going to do, Wonder Woman? Stab me again?" He pushes a buttering knife across the counter, confident enough to know I won't use it.

A sliver of me relents for an apology, for how messed up the words are that left my mouth. I piece together the first words to even begin to tell Cody that I'm sorry, to try to mend this, because I feel a different feeling still drawing me closer to him, almost strong enough to overcome the white hot rage.
Cody says, "Your father died before he could teach you how to chill the fuck out. And that's not my goddamned fault."
"At least I try," I say. "You don't even try at all! You're a coward, so struck by a death you didn't even witness that you give yourself permission—"
"—and all you do is no different," Cody says. "They were right. You won't save anyone if you can't even leave your town!"

The knife on the counter tempts me. But it's the other unfamiliar feeling that tempers me. "This was a mistake to ever think I could depend on you," I tell him. I tear the power cord from the wall, tugging and tugging and tugging it from my world along with the meager array of appliances that crash as they fall from the counters. The hot box. The toasting unit. The charger for the smartphone. And the power strip.
He tries to say something, but it gets lost in the raucous clatter. With a final tug, all the life-softening devices cross the threshold, and I kick a toaster that blocks the door across the kitchen.

"I hope one day you can be stronger than the pathetic weakness that is legion in your world. Your brother would be ashamed of what you've become." I hurl the smartphone in his direction, but without the strength to hurt.
And his words are the last I hear before the door slams shut forever.
"And, and don't come crying to me again. I won't be there. I mean it! I—"

I slam the door, scalding the new handle until it's unusable: the handle that Cody installed after the second time I crossed over. The threshold closes for a final time. No longer will that avenue of solace be open to me, because all I have left is to purge every trace of weakness from my process.
For my family this time.

Maybe Cody is right in his approach. Maybe he's right to extinguish his sense of spirit when nothing ever comes of it. And maybe that wrenching feeling of discomfort will become a new home for me, when I'm doing all scouting quests instead of slothing around the town of Gaffesend raking leaves and guarding potatoes.
I hear a thunk on the other side: something contacts his door after he slams it. Maybe it's his head. And maybe he's sitting there too. And maybe there's a chance I have to say something.

It's the new feeling he gave me that almost entirely overpowers that experience of fear in speaking up. The one I got when he stood up to Jullian, and the one I find when he flashes that stupid smug grin of his when he says something provocative. It's the same feeling I got when I received the letter from Aldrin: I panicked more at the ramification of my mother's words than the failures in my training.

I open my mouth with the hopes that something will come out to rectify this, to yell across the door, but I decide to push those feelings down. They're feelings that have only gotten me into trouble, because I can't be the perfect soldier like Aryn: no wonder Jullian and all my friends are over me.

Instead, I reach for the letter sitting on the low table, reading and rereading and rereading the first set of lines again and again, wondering when I'll have to meet them, and what I'll say when I pay them a visit.
It was dated a month-and-a-half ago.
DEAREST KATIYA,
NEXT MONTH, WE WILL BE MOVING TO GAFFESEND, ENTRUSTING THE SAFETY OF OUR FAMILY TO THE STEADFAST BRAVERY OF OUR CHILDREN.
It's the cold snap that brings him back again.

The cold snap of steel-on-steel on the press-check as he sits in the starboard door seat of the helicopter, just fiddling with it at this point, having recited the words and pictures of the plan a hundred times over.

The six-man patrol of an Army long-range surveillance detachment flies under the cover of darkness in the predawn hours, kept awake by the thrum of the rotor — and the talk of anything that might distract them. First it was family, then to food, then it devolved to getting Keller to retell the story of his "favorite worst pregnancy scare."
But now the conversation is anywhere else, and instead of Helten delivering another sobering recitation of the plan, Gjersee decides to start a war.
He rubs his mustache. "You fuckers don't even know what good food is. My mom makes the best food. Her enchiladas are amazing, passed town from my abuela."
"Best she can make from the Dollar General," Dunsmore says, dragging the large Pelican case out from beneath the seat. "You people are almost as bad as India in thinking spice equals flavor."
"You take that back," Gjersee groans.
"I'll take it back after you try my dad's tri-tip. He's a beast on the grill, even makes his own barbecue sauce."

"Please," Gjersee says. "We add a tenth as much spice as the sugar your white whales dust on their pancakes," he says. And then he turns to Aberbook, sparing no-one in the free for all. "At least it's better than this guy — he can't  taste anything his mom makes, because anything that tastes like something isn't Kroger."
"Kroger?" Aberbook asks.
"Yeah, Kroger," Gjersee says.
Keller leans in. "Like Costco? So you're saying she only buys frozen stuff?"
"No, jackass. Kroger — like the Jews can eat it."

"That's Kosher, you idiot," Aberbook says, and they share a laugh over the comms. "I bet the highlight of your life was the day you won a shirt at the Army pull-up challenge at your high school. The day you realized you were only as good as a GED!"
Gjersee searches for words. And Dunsmore leans in to add: "He's calling you stupid, if you can't put that together. A GED is the piece of paper you were supposed to get at..."
"Enough!" Gjersee kicks his boot against the Pelican case. "Play with your stupid toy. You're a nerd like your brother."

"Don't talk shit about Cody," Jackson says, as he unclips the latches around the top cover, revealing the smooth contours of the RQ-11B Raven drone recessed in the die-cut foam. He frowns when his fingers touch the chassis, feeling the coldness of the metal despite the seven hand warmers pinched between incisions in the foam.
Aberbook squints his eyes when he looks down at the drone. "Say, Jackie, did you plug that thing into the wall last night, or did you forget?"
"It's not that," he says, taking the battery pack underneath his arm. "She's  more of a warm-weather girl. Prefers the sandbox over the tundra."
"Is it still on full charge?"
Dunsmore taps the controller, lighting four green bars. The fourth bark flickers. Then a voice cracks over the radio.
"SITREP on infil. Two mikes out."
Team Leader Helten raises two gloved fingers before he flicks off the cabin lights. "Two and closing. We'll be Oscar Mike as soon as we touch down. Check white light: we're going dark."

"Going dark," Dunsmore recites, and flicks off the muzzle light he was using to inspect the position of the latches. And after the fumbles over locking the last three, he slides it beneath the seat: closing his eyes, trying to remember how this moment rhymes with the helicopter tour he took in Maui, convincing himself that the biting cold is similar to the numbness of bright sunshine flooding through the window as they descend into the valley of the landing zone.

The dream ends when the door slides open. Synthetic daylight glows green in his night-vision goggles. He removes all his belongings faster than a civilian on a short layover: dismounting the rumbling steel chassis to plant his boots in the dry snow.

It's after the six disembark that the blades accelerate, and moments later, the helicopter is gone, disappearing rapidly into the cover of night, leaving the six skilled foreigners with their feet planted two hundred miles inside a foreign land.

"We're Oscar Mike," Helten says, urging his team to motion. "We're ten klicks out from observation point Alpha: right on the ridgeline of the suspected logistics hub. And we've got about an hour of dark to get there and set up."

But they're well-conditioned despite the burly camouflaged coats and protective gear: each hauling a load of equipment. In Desert Storm, it was hours spent suffocating in gas-resistant NBC suits under the punishing sun, but even with the alpine cold and constant snowfall, the ache of muscles and thinness of the mountain air makes it feel just as exhausting.

Helten tells his team to "stay frosty" when they break the summit of the first ridge, and Gjersee reminds him that they already are. They walk in a single-file line, compressed by heel and toe so that the snow fills in faster. The others seem alright, but Dunsmore feels his panic rise over the contents of the case.
"How much further, Helten?" Dunsmore mutters.
"About three klicks out. Why, you got somewhere to be?"
"No. I'm not asking for me." Dunsmore gestures to the case. "Some of us can't stand the cold like humans do."
"Then we'll launch shortly after establishing our position," Helten says.

Dunsmore tensions his grasp against the handle, as if he could transfer the rest of his meager surplus of heat. He requisitioned an extra battery, trying to warm it inside his coat as his other hand carries the case, trudging between the sharp needles of unfamiliar trees as Helten heads their caravan.

The sun foreshadows dawn with a hint of deep red, but the cloud cover still saturates the sky, offering an extra hour of absolute darkness, and in that time, a long thirty minutes pass until they arrive.

They pick a fold of the landscape that gives eyes to the valley, but still masked by the shadows of the western slope. Helten runs micro-recon on wind direction and snow density, muttering coordinates in MGRS as Dunsmore transcribes them into the tablet. Gjersee and Aberbook unroll the camo cover to thaw against the brush, setting a tarp down in an odd recession of the ridge that masks the mast as just another continuation of its rocky edge.
Chemlights are planted in the snow with the glow facing down, and the infrared strobes are tested: only visible as a green shimmer on their night vision goggles.

It's hard enough to set up camp when Jackson dedicates so much of his focus to warming the heart of the drone, reminding him of the battery on his GameBoy Advance back in middle school, when his family took ski trips to the mountains and his brother Cody hoarded the console for too long.

He finds the courage to peek at the power level indicator: two lights out of four, and it hits him with a panic. It's been nearly five minutes since setup and the camo tarp already bows under the weight of the fat flakes, and though it blends them further into the landscape, Gjersee works to gently shake off the residual clumps of sticky snow.

Jackson's hands feel so slow when he withdraws the Raven's controller, cracking open the pelican case for one last time as he steadies the small machine in his hands. He snaps the battery into its slot as Aberbook watches — steadying the drone in one hand like his father Alan once did with the model plane at the park.

And in one smooth throw from behind cover, tangent to the perimeter of the logistics hub, the engine whirs to life, climbing as the small, matte, metal bird struggles to settle in the slipstream of the valley's wind lane, scanning with its watchful eye.

Helten records this stage in his logbook: 0428 / INFIL COMPLETE / OP ALPHA ESTABLISHED. Above their heads, the silent drone slices the precipitous air with its long, curved wings, and even higher, Overwatch listens for every word of their transmissions, transcribing their reports to the last surviving record of OPERATION BLUEWINGS.
The team settles in absolute silence against sleepless shadow. Jackson flies the grid as the rest of the team stakes the sectors and posts observers.

The heavy gusts knock the Raven sideways as it tries to stabilize.
