Without the feedback of the whir overhead — or a haptic sense of the drone's disturbances — Jackson Dunsmore feels deprived of critical senses that might allow him to steady the small machine that's bullied and buffeted about the sky.

He holds a breath until the thin air burns his lungs. The console's power indicator flicks down to the second bar, and the wind is getting stronger, covering the display with flakes of snow that are too cold to condense.  And as the Raven approaches for its first pass over the logistics hub, the first signatures of enemy life illuminate the screen: far more dots of white-hot heat than they anticipated.

"I'm counting at least twenty tangos on the ground," Jackson mutters. It was supposed to be just several men that were sustaining the supply line, and he doesn't have to infer what that means to the other four of them. There were rumors of his presence in the area, and whether this was an act of God or unfortunate coincidence, the discovery overwrites the assumptions of their plan, and how well-defended this compound might be.
Helten transcribes the discovery that sends an even colder chill through all of them. "Overwatch, confimation of HVT present in facility."
But there's no reply. Dunsmore eyes the rubber antenna pointing like a tiny flag into the darkness.
"Overwatch, do you copy?"

And as the wind accelerates, casting an array of blinding flakes that vanish their operating point into a room of white, Dunsmore struggles to distinguish anything through the drone's camera. The battery level flickers between one and empty, and only halfway over the logistics hub, his controls transfer over in slower and slower responses, like remotely driving a rover on the moon.

He wants to curse, but the fear of violent crosswinds carrying his foreign words halt the words in his throat as his freezing hands tension further around the control sticks. It's then that the feed disconnects entirely, plunging the bright-green rectangle of the screen into darkness.

LIVE FEED DISCONNECTED, it reads, though the vitals of the machine still come through. He drives blind by the accelerometer's roll, pitch, and yaw, panic-stricken by the precipitous pitch that tells it's pointed forty-five degrees down, like a surface-to-air missile without a payload.

Aberbook mutters something to him, but he's too lost in panic: far from staying frosty when his mind is ablaze, struck with the decision whether to level the drone above the enemy's heads in audible detection range, or plunge it straight into the ground to stop the sound.
Then the feed flicks back: only for moments, flashing with the white-hot ruminations of a gathering of tangos, so close that he can distinguish the heat from each of their fingers.
Fate makes the decision for him when the power cuts out. The drone accelerometer coughs one last string of readings: so steep the absolute position is lost in gimbal lock.
And over the console:

Jackson's throat goes dry as the tablet flashes red. "Viper Six to Overwatch — Viper Six to Overwatch, come in. Raven is down . . ." his mind fumbles for the recited coordinates " . . . Raven is down, grid 13T VH 679 334. TIC. Request QRF/CASEVAC. Over."
Static eats the end of his sentence: white and granular like the snow, and moments later, the base's alarm blares loud enough to fight the headwind, radiating the air with flashes of red.

Now thirty sets of enemy eyes scan the ridge, expecting them, with far better equipment than their team could carry on foot. Tracer rounds radiate the snow in streaks of red, punching the crust of the ridge as the team coalesces behind the barrier, their only line to Overwatch severed by the brutal storm.

"This is all my fault," Dunsmore mutters. His voice trembles: their LRF detachment wasn't intended for combat, and six M4 rifles against the concentrated might of the enemy feels like lobbing stones at an M1 Abrams tank.

"You can't control the weather," Gjersee mutters, just as the shrill sound of snowmobile engines undercuts the whine of the alarm. But Dunsmore eyes the antenna, allowing shame to stir his emotions towards an act of courage.
Helten urges them to move. Keller keeps trying the comms, but to no avail, and as they stumble up the wooded hills with aimless bullets whizzing overhead, they struggle to crest the summit.

The belligerent snowstorm conceals their forms, directed now only by the sense of "toward" and "away". Somewhere below, the snowmobile engines cut off as the enemy follows their footprints, firing volleys uphill as Aberbook takes over trying the radio.
"Viper Six to Overwatch, Viper Six to Overwatch," he says, breathlessly, as rounds eviscerate the bark of trees on their uphill climb. "Request QRF/CASEVAC."
And then static crackles over the radio, interspersed with the words of Overwatch. "Repeat, Viper ... exfil ... activity ..."
Gjersee turns to Dunsmore. "The signal is getting better: once we get up there, we just need a wi—"

The first round finds flesh instead of bark, stealing the words from Gjersee's throat. The punctuation is in the awful gasping sound as Gjersee chokes on blood, unable to breathe enough to continue his climb. Aberbook rushes over to grab him by the vest, dragging him up the hill as his other hand holds his medical provisions. They're so close to the crest of the hill, and as Dunsmore offers his other hand to help Gjersee as the life loosens from his limbs, the first coherent string of words rattles over the comms.
"Viper Six, provide SITREP. Viper Six ..." and then the words retreat to static when the weather accelerates.

Dunsmore is kept viscerally awake by awful sound of Gjersee next to him, as their medic Aberbook tries to tend him on the run. Helten and Keller stay several steps ahead and to the left, firing in bursts back downhill as covering fire.

Dunsmore feels the sting of something hot in his left shoulder, so flooded with adrenaline that he barely registers it, still holding tightly to the antenna as a plan forms in his mind. In the frozen fog of war, the summit is only several steps away. But it's when they cross the threshold that their feet fail to find flat ground.

They haven't the time to warn each other. Aberbook falls with his hand tensioned around Gjersee's collar. Dunsmore holds strong to the antenna as he cascades down a chute of stark land, feeling the texture of every rock and branch that isn't covered with powder, rolling as the strapped rifle flails violently, reaching with his arms for anything to stop him. He stops uphill of the others after several rolls, slamming his back against the bark of a tree, knocking the wind from his lungs in a cloud of exhale.
He hears his comrades falling further as he inspects the antenna and the communications equipment: the last link his team has to Overwatch.
"Regroup," Helten manages over the comms. "Regroup at the bottom for exfil."
"Negative," Jackson says, able to distinguish patches of land from his high point on the eastern slope. "I'm getting us a direct line to Overwatch with coordinates."
"They're right behind us," Keller says. "That's suicide!"
"We each have a job here," Dunsmore says. "Mine is this. Now get the fuck away from here."

He has just enough energy to get high enough on the summit. He parrots, over and over, until his elevation is just enough, as the enemy combatants come closer and closer, able to distinguish every syllable of their language through heaving breaths in the climb. The rifle is too defective to fire, but his handgun is still strapped across his chest, and he withdraws it after he makes it to the top.
The adversary expects them to still be far. It was a couple snowmobiles that raced over here: maybe two tangos per machine, so maybe they're just a small detachment that took a stab in the dark.

Jackson Dunsmore peeks over the edge as the sun barely peeks through the storm, just enough to distinguish their forms. The six climb the hill in a line, and Jackson's pistol is still topped off with fifteen rounds.

He doesn't hesitate to pull the trigger: stabilized with his arms against the hard shell of his equipment. The first two rounds punch through the furthest targets: two headshots, painting the trees with red gray matter stickier than the sap, and when their panic makes them harder to target, Jackson turns the gun to the two closest, delivering two rounds to each of them: enough to cast them to the ground, rolling back downhill as they disappear from sight.

He ducks back behind the ridge as several rounds whiz overhead from automatic weapons. He abandons the equipment for a brief moment as he slides along the edge towards the first two victims: hearing one voice become quiet and another become louder, surely commanding each other to "split up."

Jackson waits as he hears volleys of rounds from the eastern slope, and looking down, he finds the team far down and right, providing covering fire as a distraction, to edge them away from Jackson's position.
Surely enough, the closest combatant turns to approach the other. Jackson hears his voice though he still hides behind the ridge, and when he stands up to fire his rifle, he doesn't expect a seventh.

The trigger pull sounds off a blast in stereo: two simultaneous pulls at two different targets. And though the enemy in front of him collapses, Jackson feels a stinging pain in his chest as he falls to the ground, holding weakly to the summit's edge.

He tastes and smells the iron in the air. It's too dark to distinguish the color fo what flows out in front of him, but the directive changes when he eyes the antenna sitting roughly twenty yards away.

Rounds from his friendlies blow eviscerate the seventh crouched behind him, and he hears a shrill scream as rifle rounds tear through the flesh of his attacker.  Past the antenna, the last survivor crouches behind the other edge, and as Dunsmore wills his fading body to approach, he reloads the M9 with a magazine: reaching for the first one to find the bullet blasted through his chest and out the center — then for the second one, removing the empty clip and trading it for another.
The last enemy is injured, in a state of incontroverible panic — maybe just some low-ranked, dutiful base-dweller servicing snowmobiles and taking stock, and it shows in the spread of bullets.
He pulls the trigger in Jackson's direction until the mag runs out, pulling three, then four, then five times past the hollow click, reaching into his pockets for more.
But Jackson is faster. And when he raises the handgun, it takes just one pull for deliverance.

The adversary collapses against the eastern face with part of his jaw missing, twitching before gravity reclaims him, casting him downhill like the rest of Jackson's team. And when he hears the second wave of reinforcements surely responding to the exchange, he rushes faster than his wounds will let him, steadying the antenna as he takes enough wind into his lungs to speak.
"Viper Six to Overwatch, Viper Six to Overwatch, SITREP."
"Solid copy, Viper Six," Jackson hears.

"This is Viper Six, patrol size: six. We are taking contact at grid 13T VH 678 342. Enemy dismounted, seven tangos down with reinforcements along the ridge to the west. Raven down at grid 13T VH 679 334. We are breaking east to rally point Delta. Two WIA. Request immediate QRF and MEDEVAC; priority CASEVAC, over."
He can hear them getting closer: the second set of soldiers ascending the hill after they turn off their engines, then the sound of a helicopter approaching from the west.
He speaks again.
"Viper six to Overwatch — repeat grid thirteen T, VH, six-seven-eight, three-four-two. Enemy moving into the old logging road. Do not clear fires over the valley until we're on the mark. Over."
"Copy," Overwatch says.
Jackson loses his grasp on the edge. Darkness begins to swim around him: the long blood trail from south to north begins to glisten as light breaks through the storm.

"We're pulling . . . we're pulling . . . viper six out. Jackson, over." He fumbles with the transceiver when his hand can barely hold the button, but manages a final, dutiful breath to mutter one last string of words.

But they aren't the ones that Aberbook's ghost writer wrote, nor were they the ones delivered in his eulogy. They weren't the ones misquoted in the Wahlberg movie that was based on the true story, either.
In this nightmare, he looks up at me with our mother's eyes and father's nose, and asks the question to me directly.
"Why is it so hard for you to let go?" The question comes from thirty feet below.

Three young boys stare up at the dense canopy of trees, squinting their eyes to watch as the girl makes her way across the branch, approaching the point where two trees are ten seasons from shaking hands.
"How did you even get up there?" A boy asks, watching from the ground as she dangles above the village's ancient stone wall.
"The bark of these trees thicken with age," the girl says, swaying with the long branch as her feet swing freely. "Widen your arms and pull together hard when you climb!"
"You don't even have to be that high, Katiya. What if the village elder sees? What about this branch right here?" Bertram asks. "You don't have to go that high to get over."
"Because I wanna," she says, gathering momentum that bends the high branches as she swings her feet. "And you're the boy, so you get to carry the tools to add to our fort."

The whole tree shakes. And when she knows the two younger twins are watching — Raph and Raven, who were brought along for their first adventure beyond the walls — she launches her slender body skyward, floating through the air like an ascendant Auvryan before she wraps her arms around the branch on the other side.

"Gods, Katiya," Bertram says, emasculated enough by the short-haired tomboy to force his stocky frame up to the second branch: death-gripping the veins of bark as the pit in his stomach seems to make him lighter.
"And now you cross," Katiya laughs, shimmying further across the second tree's branch. "You get to climb the wall 'cause you were too scared!"

"Am not!" Bertram says, his voice trembling as he hugs the narrowing branch: high enough to drop-and-roll and pray to the Gods that he doesn't sprain an ankle if he slips. "It's only because I'm carrying all your dad's stuff you borrowed."
She's about to open her mouth and call him something else.
"I said I'm coming," he grumbles.

Bertram springs from the end of the branch after his feet register on the narrow edge, dragging his husky body over the top of the ancient cobblestone wall, then grasping the rope that his village crush tethered for their return.
"We shouldn't be doing this," Bertram says, scratching his arms where a long scrape itches. "Katiya's Dad said we could do another wood making thing."

"My dad is boring," Katiya says. "He only wants us to stay close where he can watch us." She raises a rotten stick from the ground, and levels it at Raph, as if to knight him. "Don't you want to explore? To show Raph and Raven our treehouse, and put them to work?"

Bertram hesitates, but the other three have already disappeared into the shaded hollow to the east. Since as early as he could remember, his parents regaled him with tales they bought from the old book shop in Gaffesend across the lake: tales of adventure, of courage and glory — so how could they get mad if he was living the same spirit of the dungeon-crawling adventurers a hundred years ago?
Katiya drags the stick against the ground, tapping every tree with a whip of the wrist. "My Dad says he'll make all of us swords when we're double-digits," she says. "A year is so far away!"
"And we're only seven," the twins say.
"It's okay. I'll let you play with it," she says. "Bertram and me will get one, and then we can have duels!"

The ground begins to slope downwards, and Bertram thinks he can hear the distant sounds of war getting louder. They left this part of the world off the village map for a reason, and all he has are the instructions he committed to memory.
Due east to the clearing. Turn North to the treehouse.

They arrive at the clearing on the other side of a hill, where glistening fronds of cereal grasses reflect the sunlight: a circular clearing nearly a hundred yards in size. It's familiar to Katiya and Bertram, but a sight in the distance surprises them.
Far on the eastern side of the clearing, beneath a dark canopy of trees, they find a couple older boys that take turns pushing each other into a pond.
"It must be deep if they can dive like that," Raven says. "That's deeper than the shore of Lake Gaffe!"
But Bertram grabs the young boys by their collar before they can run.
"We don't know them. We should go around, and go to the north where the fort is."
"But they're playing," Raph says. "They don't play during war!"

Bertram turns back to Katiya, and notices a rare look of unease in her bright, amber eyes. "We're the older kids. We promised their parents to get them back by sundown. Maybe we should turn around and head west: do the wood stuff with your dad again."
"You're right," Katiya says. She sighs. "Maybe more wood-shop with my dad isn't so—"
But a branch cracks behind them, and they realize they never should have turned their backs on the two mischievous twins. Raven sprints east across the green space, shouting to the strangers.

"Khiras above," Bertram curses. "And—" Raph runs after Raven, assuming  permission in the absence of authority. The other strangers notice the two boys running toward them, and stop pushing their friends into the lake, quickly jogging over to meet them.
They look human. Or at least they do when they're halfway across the field: as rare as it is, they were always warned that Chymaeran adults could make themselves look like kids.

"Gods damn it all," Bertram says. He can't consider the fate of two reckless boys when he's deciding whether to just run home. "They're so stupid! Stupid, stupid. There's no way," he says to Katiya, "we can't—"
Katiya grabs his wrist. "We're responsible for them because we're bigger. You remember the rules of the village?"
"Yeah, but . . ." we're not in the village, Bertram begins to say, but Katiya's steely glare bleeds the conviction out of his words.

The strangers call to them as they shake the boys' hands. Katiya drags Bertram straight toward the group as he shields himself behind her, and over her shoulder, he sees a group of older boys and girls — maybe eighteen or something — older kids that none of them recognize from  upper seminary or the neighboring villages.
"They said they want to play hide and seek with us," Raven says.

"Our Elder said we shouldn't talk to people that we don't know," Katiya says, trying to drop hints to the other twins. She struggles to make eye contact, because it's something about their glare that discomforts her: their eyes all dark brown despite their different colors of hair, and just like the trees, he can almost convince himself he sees amethyst in the brown.
"But we're not the bad guys," one says, laughing a little longer than usual. "The Chymaerans are big and purpley and thin, no?"
"But they take faces!" Bertram protests.
"I don't see any faces laying around here," another laughs.
"But what if you're walking in the flesh?"
"Fleshwalking?" The first older boy says. "You know that only a tiny number of Chymaerans can do that."
"Like the elite ones, the Death Scouts. And they're trained for years and years and years," one of the others says, but then a girl strikes him in the chest.
"But we're like you, see?" The girl says, and a few of them offer their hands. One of the boys standing aside them looks timid and nervous: trying to approach Katiya as he walks around the circle.
The four Hillfar kids touch their skin: Raven and Raph the fastest, while Bertram and Katiya hesitate. The skin is cool and wet: likely from being in the pond, though their clothes aren't damp.
"Are you convinced? Can we play now?" The older boy asks, withdrawing his hand.
"I don't know," Katiya says. "I think we're going to play alone."
"We should play us versus you!"
"But you're older kids!" Raph says.
"Then how about we give you a big advantage?" He grins. "Let's play hide-and-seek."
Raph and Raven lean closer. "That's what we were going to play!" Raph exclaims.
The older children begin to circle the Hillfar kids until they're surrounded, spaced evenly without effort. Most of them are excited. A few others look uninterested.
"So what should we play for?" Their leader asks.
"Play for?" Bertram asks.
"We'll play for fun," Raven says. "We don't get to have fun back home."
"Back where?"
Raven says, "In—"
"Gaffesend," Katiya says. "Our moms and dads said we could play here for an hour."
"Moms and dads? So you're trying to say they'll be looking for you," the leader says. "That's wise of them. But I think we should choose what we're playing for."
"If we win, then you have to let us play in the pond," Raph says. "Dad says I can only swim if I have an adult. You can watch us. Can you push us in, like you did to your friends?"
They laugh.
"Sure. We can go play in the pond, all right," the leader says. "But what if you lose?"
"I dunno," Raven says.
"How about if you lose, we get to throw you in? You get to float either way," their leader offers. "But we should get straight to the fun. So we'll be the seekers."
Katiya feels a freezing hand on her shoulder as one of the older kids takes a knee, and she shivers before he can deliver the words.
"You shouldn't be playing with big kids like us. I think that some of us can get the other ones to let you go home."
"Why?" Katiya asks. " Should we be scared?"

"I just . . . think that kids like to play to have fun. But," and he chooses the next words slowly, "sometimes grown-ups don't play to win. Some of them only have fun when other people lose, and lose really, really hard."
"What the Res are you telling them, Vylen? Are you giving them an advantage?"
"Nothing, Nhytyx," he says, emphasizing the strangeness of the name. "I was just telling Miss Katiya here that—"
"—We need to play," Nhytyx says. "Come on: we all have the same blood around here! My daddy Ullrich is human. And so is my mom, so I am too. So we're gonna seek and you're gonna hide."

Vylen whispers to Katiya that they don't stop when they start playing, but the twins are already running towards the North: probably headed for the treehouse though they don't even know where it is yet.
Katiya feels the lucid reality of their situation finally hit her, far beyond the range of her father's shrill whistle that might bring them home. But her mind hasn't yet been taught to hesitate.
"You just lost ten seconds for cheating!" Nhytyx sings. "Forty. Thirty-nine, thirty-seven, oops ... I mean, thirty-eight, thirty-six ..."
"Now run!" Vylen urges Bertram, seizing Bertram's heart with such panic that he'd freeze if Katiya didn't grab his arm again.
Katiya's voice cracks when she speaks, and it almost scares Bertram more than the uncertainty of what awaits them.
"We're all going home," Katiya insists.

At twenty-eight, Katiya and Bertram are already halfway across the field, stumbling over uneven patches of dirt as they run as fast as their bodies will let them. Raph and Raven are laughing gaily as they cross the threshold of the tree line at eighteen, followed by Katiya at fifteen, and Bertram at fourteen — choking on the rancid taste of exhaustion in his breath as he struggles to keep up.

Nhytyx's voice gets louder after they break the edge of the field, and it sounds ever-present as if he whispers in their minds, accented with the faintest resonance of Chymaeran clicks, and at twelve, while their leader's voice crescendos with excitement, Katiya can barely distinguish their slender forms from the narrow shape of the trees. The distant, thin trunks of the bordering tree line sway with the wind, but a few of them seem to lean in the other direction.

At ten, Katiya manages to clench her fingers around Raven's collar like a mother cat collecting wayward childen. His face drops when he sees the unfamiliar look of panic, and when Raph turns around, Bertram grabs him by the shoulders, releasing a shriek when he pins him against a tree.
Bertram is inches from his face from six to four, spitting with each syllable. "This is not a game," he says. "You need to stop playing and fight for real."
Raph pants. "But—"

"We're going to the treehouse," Katiya says, just as Nhytyx calls TWO. The unfamiliar chill assures her that they started running long before the count. She pulls Raven so hard that he's almost flagging behind her as she runs for the knotted rope ladder: it's not in sight yet, but she can feel the shape of the forest from twelve trips before.

The sound of snapping twigs sounds behind her, but too far behind her, so she doesn't dare to turn around. All she can hear beyond the heartbeat in her ears are the last words she spoke to the twins' parents, saying they'd be out to play late, and not to worry, telling a bald-faced lie about some stupid game she made up on the spot, and they were stupid enough to believe her.

And now they're too far to be saved by anyone. She thinks she can see obsidian shadows moving faster than her tiny legs in the corner of her eye, but her vision is too dry, and as the sweat burns and dries them even further, she can only run on the newfound feeling of panic that overwhelms her.
But she made a promise, and she's going to protect them. They're going to climb up the treehouse and go from there. They're going to climb up the tree and—
Where is it?

She stops. Anticipation swells in every space of  her body where muscles aren't fighting to escape, and she looks up to the top of the canopy, and surely enough, the treehouse is still there — but the rope ladder is snagged in a branch from some heavy gust of wind.
"Gods damn it!" Bertram says.
Katiya catches two seconds of breath, her body urged to act before she can think, climbing the tree with all the holds she memorized before they could smuggle the rope.
"Go, Katiya, go! Or else we'll have to go to the shrine," Bertram says.

Her arms strain, and she hasn't the time to climb carefully: scratching her body everywhere as she fights nature more than the chase. She can hear whoops of laughter. And as she fights to withdraw the line of the ladder without falling, she gives up and jumps for it: leveraging all her weight on gravity  to bring the shoddy ladder down from the branch.
And it gives.

Her hands tension around both strands of the long loop of rope, wrapped once around a thick branch, and when her feet try to find the thin rungs of the ladder, she feels the wood snap beneath her, helpless as she falls to the ground and the wind is knocked out of her.

But the boys are already climbing the ladder before she can find another breath that will enter her lungs. Bertram grabs her as she hears an inhuman voice click in the distance, claiming that "climbing is cheating," but she finds she's already on the ladder below Raven and Bertram, leaving the last boy to climb alone as he wets his pants.

She can see them now. Bertram drags Raven over the edge of the platform, then pulls Katiya as she scrambles through the splintered hole in the logs, and then Katiya reaches for Raph, only to notice that he's much further down the ladder than she thought.
"Please don't leave me," Raph sobs, snot covering his reddened face as he struggles to lift himself up the ladder.
His left foot reaches the step that Katiya broke, and he stumbles, just as something dark and obsidian slices the air where his head was like a scythe harvests grain.

And Katiya feels something weak and feeble that she hates inside her bring her further over the edge to reach as the Chymaeran Death Scouts cycle through the faces of human children they stole to terrify them further, and when she slips over the edge, Katiya and Raven grab her ankles, giving het just enough distance to grab Raph by the wrist.
The Chymaerans give them space at the spectacle: maybe impressed a little, and maybe that slash was just a controlled act of terror.
Nhytyx changes back to the form of the older boy as fast as Katiya can blink. "You're a lot faster than the other children. But you get up there, and where will you go from there?"

Bertram and Raven pull with all their might. Katiya winces as her waist is stabbed with a thousand tiny splinters as she comes over the edge with Raph, the smell of excrement wafting through the air as the suspended twin cries. But when they pull him to the top, they realize his cries are of pain instead of panic, and when the dark crimson begins to soak the severed halves of the treehouse's planks, they find the reason Raph was light enough to pull.
He crawls with a single foot as his skin turns pale: colder than the Chymaerans, and somewhere far below, the boys play catch with the part of him they left behind.
"I guess one part of you is going to get to dip its toes in the water first," Nhytyx clicks. "But the rest is soon to follow!"

Raven holds Raph as he's on the verge of passing out, clutching the stump at the base of his twin brother's leg. The treehouse trembles as the scouts shake the trunk, casting amateurly-assembled planks driven with shallow nails, and as they hold to the only parts of the fort that hold their weight, Raph slips from Raven's grasp, sprawled across the uneven surface as his blood flows like sap between the gaps.

Katiya tries to reach for him as she hugs the largest branch, but something resists inside her. The dry, severed logs are cracking beneath the weight, and when she finally wills her body to grab for the dying boy, he crunches through the platform, falling headlong as Katiya follows after.

She falls for seconds, and she doesn't feel the rapture of swinging between trees. Below, the boy called Vylen extends his arms and catches her, barely able to slow her fall as something else catches Raph.

Katiya lands to find Raph expressionless, yet impossibly upright as Vylen reluctantly claims that he "found her," failing to convince the others that their game is over. But Katiya's head rests against something else, something uneven and organic. Something that sliced the flesh from her left brow to her cheek, and something that separates her skull from Raph's.

The boy chokes with a guttural cry as he reaches for his head, finding that a branch has pierced directly through his jaw and out his mouth. Ralph stands fully upright, barely able to touch his toes as he tries to speak her name, but it's just the consonants.
And Katiya screams.

No longer does she remember the two other boys still hiding in the tree. She flees away from the treehouse, and away from home though she doesn't even realize it, and she runs and she runs, sobbing and weeping and screaming with the rapture of a fresh new emotion she's never experienced before, running and running until she breaks the trees, running through the clearing though she's lost every sense of direction and can't hear if they're still following her.

She stumbles over something soft on the far side of the clearing, but doesn't have time to look. The pond is murky, dark, and motionless, as if the waves forgot how to move, but her nose is too stuffed from the crying to tell the contents of the brine.
It's when the second clothed object arrests her feet that she falls headlong into the still water — finding all the other friends that Raph said they were pushing in.

It's the cold snap that brings her back again, to find herself floating in a pit of flesh and brine. She must have been warmed by the panic of her rapid breathing in the last moment she remembers: feeling her meager volume of Essence sear her skin with the powers of fire she hadn't even learned yet.

And in the odd moment of stillness, before she finds the space for the newfound habit of panic to arrest her again, she wonders if she's made it to the Reservoir of Souls when she looks up at the blanket of stars, like the planes of dark obsidian in the barren, dimensionless landscape where all their souls will convene to be born again.

But she doesn't hear the voice of her grandfather calling her into the mist, or the voices of all the ones she's told will die long before and after her. She hears the voice of the seekers approaching as they hoist Raph's body in the air.
She thinks something must have dislocated in her mind at how easily the panic arrives, but can't move when her body's so numbed by the languid brine of blood, rot, and water.

Their voices click in their foreign tongue, passing through excited vibrations as their guises dissolve from the faces they stole. And as the cold brings her signature of life to a near halt, feathering the edge of death, she can only listen as they start to slide between languages.
"What happened to the two in the tree?"
"They ran sometime after the boy and girl fell, and that bitch ran," another says.
"And where did she go?"
"Probably ran home like the others, doesn't matter. Those kids and all their friends and family will all end up in holes like this one, whenever the reinforcements shoe and we get the others."
One of them laughs, saying something in clicks. "Speaking of, our work isn't done. And I think we have one last contribution to make here," they say.
"Dumb fucking kid," another laughs. "Makes all this shit almost worth it. Swimming in a pond? Pushing each other in?"

"Well, let's make his last moment count," Nhytyx says, and Katiya hears the rustling of fabric. They count in clicks as Raph is still too weak to make a sound — blotting out the starry sky like a small, dark comet before he slams into the solid, wet mass of bodies, shaking the entire mass as Katiya remains motionless.
"This pit is done. Let's dig half the next and save the rest for the morning," Nhytyx orders. "The rest of you set up camp."
And when their thin silhouettes no longer shadow the constellations, Katiya reaches over her head for the small boy, pulling with all her might, dragging to her chest the outcome of her cowardice.
It was only last week that her father began to teach her how to heal, but she can feel the dying Essence in the spilled blood of the hapless civilians like electrons flowing freely between atoms.
To pull the vital source is to feel flashes of those final moments, but it's nothing compared to the incessant sound of digging somewhere past the edge of the pit.

At every slam of the shovel, she pulls Raph closer although she can barely feel him holding on: his tongue a dead instrument though she can feel the faintest rhythm of his heartbeat, his severed stump cauterized by Chymaeran frost so they could derive pleasure from delivering on the result of their game.

And as she wraps her arms around Raph, tighter and tighter as she leeches every last spark of Essence from the dead that no longer use it, she feels the longing for something crystallized into an indebted purpose inside her as the slamming of shovels sounds off in an endless staccato, waiting forever, just for a chance to break for home.

And the chance arrives after the shovels stop, and the distant clicks no longer echo across the landscape. Lantern light wanes, and when Katiya tries her muscles, she finds enough of the proffered dead Essence to lift herself from the mud and tar, feeling a debt to the victimized grow with every shambling step she takes across the wide, open field.

She has no words for Bertram or Raven when she finds them at the rope, waiting there all night on the faintest hope of their return. Nor does she feel anything for months in the other end of the verbal lashing when they claim they fell playing heroes as they swung between the trees, hurting Raph so severely that they spent all night afraid to bring him home.

She would never speak of that night again, because the only living witness without a tongue to tell would later die in the fire with his brother, when the Chymaerans chose to deliver on their promise to return.
And every night since, Katiya waited at the window, feeling the chill in the air wrap around her like a wet blanket, listening to the sounds of the war front as she waited.

"I want you to know that you've improved a lot since the incident last quarter," Nav says. He scrolls through notes on the tablet's touchscreen as he sits across from me in the dinky, makeshift break room — the break room he booked as a conference room for our weekly one-on-one.

I don't say anything. I just nod until it gets him to continue, speaking further about deadlines and redlines and upcoming builds that he'll just regurgitate in our standup meeting, trying to fill every minute of the quarter-hour block so we don't get lost in small talk, at least until we get to the end.

I stare at his tie as he previews the three weeks ahead, wondering if his son bought it for him: little ones-and-zeroes in colors that rhyme with Navidson-Monroe's navy blue. There isn't much left in my mind when I promised myself all those weeks ago that I wouldn't leave space for anything else. My neurons packed the boxes with every distraction, leaving only my internal clock.
But it's worked.
"I've noticed your efforts," he says. "You get in at seven o'clock now. Your redlines are done early. Less time 'dreaming,' so to speak, and you even come to most of the after-hours events."
"I am here for the team," I say.
"And the free donuts," Nav says, twisting his lips into a light smile, as if he requisitions a response.
I don't catch his attempt at a joke until the pause grows uncomfortable.
"Huh?" I ask.
"Like you've said the day before all the morning meetings?"
"Oh," I say, losing my grasp on the numbers I was pulled from for all this idle chatter. "Yeah. Free donuts."
"Well, at least today's better than donuts. Don't forget we have the company luncheon today, around noon."

"I'll stay hungry, then," I say, though most days I'm not hungry enough to eat anyways. The numbers on the scale have been going down: going to the gym with Miguel is about the only social thing I do every week. Most weekdays I sleep for five hours. Most weekends, I sleep for twelve.
"And there's some announcement or something," I say. "What was the cryptic email about?"
"I'm not allowed to say," Nav says.

"I thought we were headed for layoffs, and there's a promotion?" It's probably one of the buyers after the initial layoff: one that makes the lower office even more of a ghost town. People pinch monitors, gold-tipped HDMI cables, standing desks, and black-mesh paper trays from late peers like how buzzards peck at fresh kill in the desert, leaving only the bones of thumbtacks and used paper clips.
"Maybe, maybe not," Nav says. "I'd suggest you just enjoy the free food and not think too much about it."

He opens the door, unplugging his computer as fluorescent light exchanges for the blinding blue screen that now reads HDMI_1. I pass the chatty row without a glance, retreating to my desk to realize for the first time in three hours that I left my phone in the car.

But I don't touch grass to go and get it. I complete two tasks. I check in the changes. I fill out the paperwork, and when the calendar reads 12:00 COMPANY LUNCHEON (MANDATORY), I head down alone before Kei and Reed can catch me.

The food is good: they always spend well on these things, and it tracks my father's words. One lunch, he told me that "office pukes" will "always work under the worst conditions, if management buys a box of shitty donuts for them once or twice a month."

But I can't complain. It's not that bad here. Even though they still separate lunches for the elevated Aerospace team — then for the technicians and the rest of us — barbecued brisket served by managers takes my mind off the mortgage. And when I sit with my father, avoiding the ire of upper managers I lit up with those irrevocable words, he's always got some gearhead vet reminiscing about brothels in Okinawa, or using fruits to describe the new girls working at a strip club in downtown Denver.
The laughter abates the anger and ennui for a while, and when my father claps me on the back as he laughs at every joke, I realize it's the first time I've been touched intentionally in months.

I try not to think of the premonition I've had of the meaning behind that cryptic email. The announcement comes after the raffle, and it's easier to depress that feeling of rapturous static when I've confirmed that I'm always rolling loaded dice.

The husky technician across from me opened his raffle prize to find an extra-small women's golf polo, and put it on to give us all a laugh. We all  got USB keychains, at least: labeled MONROECAREERS.COM, probably leftovers from last month's college job fair that'd fill too much space in the supply room.
And then, finally, one of the executives clears his throat when we're all halfway deep into a slice of red velvet Bundt cake.

"We want to thank you all for your hard effort," he says, then talks about moral values, then immediately boasts about financial values. "And I have a special announcement here for one of the Miscellaneous Equipment Group teams, to celebrate the work of a possibly overlooked young man in our company. And, more specifically, one of the young men in the battery division."

My flesh crawls more at the sensation of my father putting his meaty paw on my shoulder. He gestures to his friends with a smile, and I can't even bring myself to meet his eyes and glance at his expression.
"He's been with us for a while," he says. "He's put in long hours and developed an exceptional prototype for an assembly we'll be using in our new power controls."
"Sounds like I know the guy," my dad jokes, joshing me by the shoulder.
"And he was on the wall of engineering talent, where he belongs."
I look across three tables to find him sitting next to Kei, who rests her hand on his shoulder just like my father does to me.
"Reed Broderick, stand and be recognized!"

And I feel my father withdraw his hand from me slowly. He reluctantly puts his hands together before muttering something he might tell me after a bad little league game, and when I look to the stage, I try to avoid Kei's eye contact when she glances back at me.
"This young man has only been here for a little under a year, but he gives us all something to aspire to."

I can feel the rage I thought I buried all those months ago leech through the surface like coffins in a flood. But I don't have the currency for another outburst, or even to leave, so I put my hands together just like my father who tries to hide his true feelings, clapping tensely without spring in either of my wrists.

But remembering the fear of layoffs and the mortgage is the only thing that can humble me: the feeling of the long, looming shadow since that first meeting I almost overslept in spring — when they said they were coming, and to prepare ourselves.
"You are," my dad starts as he whispers, "you are still my son, and I'm proud of you."
Reed returns to his seat next to Kei as I bury my head in my hands. "Thanks, Dad."
"And you're doing just fine," he tells me. "I guess ... you know, I'm just not important enough to give you a fair shot."
"It's not your fault," I say. And I smile. "I should have watched my temper. They hate me now."
"Just don't forget what you'll always have," he says. "You have the essence that you need."
And when I mishear his words in self-immolation, an idea begins to form in my mind.

I thought approaching the table to congratulate my rival would be the last I'd have to see him today. I left before he got the new insignia for his cubicle's nametag, before all the other strangers could approach him and offer their praise.

But when I saw the large, crumpled box labeled MCMASTER-CARR on his desk, taped with a manifest from the machinists' cell with REWORK emblazoned in a large red stamp, I should have known he'd suffer quietly for another thirty minutes after he returned.

Reed only shuts up for a while when he's nervous: the only other sounds in the office are the 3D printer's whine, Wilbur's wake-apnea, and Michael's drastic fit of coughs every quarter hour, and when any of them are missing, I know that something's wrong.

But he's not the kind to go it alone. And when I'm sitting in my chair, watching myself do grunt work as my mind goes blank, he approaches me with the heavy box in his hands, choosing me as the elder subordinate to help him.
I try to look busy, but it's hard not to notice him: holding a box between his arms in a mess of paper and packing tape, struggling to keep his grasp as I decide to wait a little longer.

"Cody. Hey, Cody," he finally says. as a couple bolts fall out of the bottom of the box, disappearing under my desk. He reflexively reaches for them with a burdened hand — then one of the mild-steel panels tears a hole in the side of the box, sliding out slowly until I push it back in.
"I, uh . . . could use your help," he says.
"No shit," I say, removing the other ear of my half-worn headphones. "Why aren't you holding it by the bottom?"

"It was a box when I started lifting it," he says. He shifts his weight to support the clattering mess of parts and washers and nuts and bolts inside, as Wilbur peeks his head over the partition. "I heard you were born with a wrench in your hand," Reed continues, "and I could use a second set of eyes on this prototype."
"Oh," I say. The pieces start to look familiar. "It's the one from the presentation?"
"Yeah, but..." he gestures with his head to the manifest. "There's some issues. And I think you understand this better than I do."
The technicians slapped a barcode sticker that summarizes it better than the manifest, and beneath the pattern of lines is three words.
"Shit don't fit," I read.

He drops the box in the empty cubicle across from me, unable to withhold the loud clatter of big metal pieces and screws, so loud that the purchasers across the room begin to laugh. "And I'm not looking forward to the techs making fun of me over this," he says.
And maybe they should, I think, and there's a part of me that so badly wants him to fail the way I hoped he would, the way I told him off after our walk all those months ago.
But Reed is desperate, still hugging the pieces together as he begins to tremble from the weight. "So can we grab a conference room?"
And I ask, "is that an order?"
He looks at me with a different kind of panic, as if I poached the elephant in the room while it was weak. But I spring from my chair, finding an odd relief in the spectacle.
"Kidding," I say.
I reach with another set of hands, unloading the uppermost pieces from the box. The parts are so smooth: it looks and feels more like an industrial art piece than my soulless origami design.
"You put so many fillets on this thing, I can't feel an edge," I say. "No wonder all this slipped out."
"I tried to apply your critiques and all, but they already ordered it," Reed says. "They said it was just a prototype. And I'd have to rework it, but I don't know anything about putting it together."
And yet you got the damn promotion, a part of me says, but it's something about his vulnerability that keeps me quiet, even if today's the second-worst day I've had working here.

We settle in the conference room after placing down rubberized mats from the machine shop, and ransacking my father's toolbox for all his lower-drawer, half-broken tools when he's having a smoke outside.

He sits as I take the assembly in my hands, trying the fit — remembering the vicious wisdom of all the unsettled technicians that approached me in the two-and-a-half years before Reed got here, distilling it into something constructive although the anger is still there.

They'd lambaste the poor bastard over fits. One of the holes is designed for thread, though it's supposed to let it through. The square edge jams into a round because he forgot a chamfer, and sitting in the same seat I almost lost my job in, I tell him what to fix as he takes notes on a printout.
"So we need to rework this ourselves," I say.
"But how?" He asks.
And so we go to the floor.

I enter Dad's code for the supply box. I kit him out with gloves and sandpaper and taps and drill bits, and we head to the belt sander. And I let him work the steel surface like my father did when I first got here — humored by his panic at the silver sparks that launch from friction.

And then to the mill. And then with the two-fluted end mill that we chuck in three pneumatic chirps, where I explain that this two-ton, belt-driven beast can only change gears when it's in motion, unlike the lathe that changes gears when it's halted.

We set the pieces so they're square with the machine and clamp them down, and when the spindle reaches its speed of eight hundred rotations per minute, I find myself back in the zen of the machine shop all those years ago: shaving fifty thousandths at a time on pass after pass of quiet precision; casting slivers of scalding steel from the surface that dance in long, mesmerizing ribbons; hearing the coolant sizzle against the steel when I spray before Reed makes another hand-fed pass.

And two hours later, the pieces fit — and Reed's printout is saturated with greasy fingerprints and red scribbles, our gloves pleasurably dirty with the grime of hands-on work, and for a second, I think I remember what I thought I was going to do here in the beginning.
"The church of iron," Reed continues. "The gym. You have a membership too, right? We should go sometime."

And on the rare feeling of energy spurred by a high of action, I oblige, before I find myself sitting back at my cubicle, reviewing my ongoing battery design that hasn't progressed a click since last week.

The clock reads five-thirty, and when I look out the far window to the floor, the shop lights flick off one by one. Even Kei is no longer here — and as I try to understand how such a miserable day could end so reasonably, I feel that feeling of hope escape for just a second before I can recapture it.

My steel-toed shoes crunch the dry leaves beneath my feet as I descend the crumbling stairs, eyes watering from the hills of dry grass in late fall, and even though the failures of the day turn over in my mind for the full ride home, I still find the energy to toil a while longer in the garage — working on soldering for some stupid project that's captured my free time when I'm still not friends with any of my neighbors.

And in the silence of the dark garage, I'm lit only by shop lights as I roll around on a scrapped shop stool I stole from the dumpster at work. As the soldering iron sizzles against the damp sponge, my mind replays the half-baked encouragement from my father, remembering how he told me that "I have the essence" of what I need.
I stare at a strange, otherworldly pouch that rests on the corner of the workbench: Katiya filled it with some exotic powder that was supposed to help me grow plants on the porch.

It's a stupid act of bored curiosity that leads me to powder it on the top of the terminal for the old flashlight that I'm trying to repair — the kind that stacks three D-size batteries in series inside a hollow center. I tin the tip of the soldering iron, recirculating the sharp end with a growing bead of molten tin until it's almost too heavy to hold by surface tension.

My hand slowly approaches the negative button end with a trembling bead, hoping it will work as flux to accept the molten metal, and the closer it gets,  the connection glows brighter with faint crimson light, no brighter than an LED.

The sight distracts me from a healthy dose of hesitation. It was so easy to forget that there's an entire other world beyond the door with different rules, and when the glowing bead finally adheres to the powdered lead, drowning the contours of the cheap metal tab with scalding metal at liquefying heat, I'm unprepared for the realization of what comes next.
And what comes next is nothing.
The powder works as flux.
"Fuckin' genius," I mutter to myself as the glow fades away, and although a little extra powder crunches in the hollow tube as I screw the flashlight back together, it shouldn't matter too much.

I angle the flashlight to the garage door, pointing it directly above the hood of my car as my other hand fumbles for the string of the shop light. And when my finger flicks the slide switch, I feel a massive jolt of energy kick the flashlight backwards as it slips through my hand, casting the entire garage in a bright, crimson glow.

The nurled handle of the flashlight embeds itself in the pegboard, displacing all the tools in a raucous clatter as a wall-mounted bucket of tiny screws explodes like shotgun pellets, but the crash is silent compared to the otherworldly, phantasmic screech that rings in my ears.

My eyes and ears need seconds to recover — my heart even longer — as my eyes fall to the triplet spread of holes in the far wall, siphoning streetlight in three beams that take shape from floating dust.

But it's not in the steel of the garage door. It's in the solid wall, and when I approach it, I peek with one eye through the half-inch peephole to find two MORE new holes a hundred feet across the driveway, glowing with heat as a road sign now reads ST P.

"Stop. Please," I beg them, rolling my eyes as I sit across the table. The tremor in my hand's been going for about a month now, so I rest my wrist on table between bites of stew, or else the metal spoon will shake in my grasp.
"Stop telling my daughter that I'm proud of her?" Stella asks. "Of my two children risking their lives to defend the empire?"
"I'm defending nothing right now," I remind her, gesturing to my brother. "It's him that's doing all the work."

Erik takes another spoonful, and then another. The two of us eat as quickly as we can out of habit, but it's nice to have mother's cooking again: I even recognize the silverware, a set my late father crafted that survived the fire.

This dinner provides the briefest respite from the last two months of agonizing intensity, but I remain on-guard against myself. My left fist clenches beneath the table to try to prevent me from relaxing too much, or else my head might plunge into the porridge after all the sleepless nights I stayed awake — dreading every tomorrow for the same reason every morning.
"So you've been scouting every single day, I hear," Stella says, squinting her bright, amber eyes. "How brave you've become!"

I glance to my younger brother and sister, Zane and Terra, noticing how their symmetrical burn scars wrinkle their faces as they blow the spoon before taking a bite. The rest of them has so easily grown around their past: such a small part of them that I almost struggle to notice. And I wonder if I have the strength to protect the rest of them.
Then the man that hyphenated my name enters the room, returning from his toil outside the cottage: my stepfather Holden Hilde, smiling when he sees his two eldest stepchildren.
He claps his calloused hands together as a cloud of soot spreads into the air. "Have you told them the news yet?"
"Not yet," Stella says, giving him a kiss as he bends down to join us at the table. But she lightly stabs a fork against his chest. "Hey there, aren't you forgetting something?"
He looks down at his dirty hands, dark as night after working metal for an entire day.
Zane and Terra chuckle.
"Oh. Of course," he says, retreating to the kitchen for a quick rinse.
"So anyways, it was perfect timing for us to move here. The house was owned by an old blacksmith, who passed—"
"The news?" Erik demands, after reaching the bottom of his second bowl. "Is that the reason you invited us?"
"Well, I always seek an excuse to see my children," Stella says. "I don't get to see you on the job. Only in passing, and I'm never on the border of Gaffesend."
"So what's the other reason?" Erik asks.
"It's, well..." Stella starts, but Zane slams his spoon against the table, beating her to the punch.
"It's her belly," he says.
"Her—" Erik starts, but he freezes. We look at each other, reflecting the amber in each other's eyes for a moment as we try to reconcile the gravity of her announcement. "You mean, you—"
"Are having a little one," Stella says. "And the virologist just read the child's Essence markers. We didn't know until three days ago, but ... it will be a girl!"
Erik's stoic face washes over with a rare excitement. I do my best to match it, even though something stabs my heart with the same signature as their letter three months ago.
Another child. Unmarred and unscalded, to be brought into this world. Another life to be protected, I think. And it needs so much to keep it that way.
And then I feel again the chill of middle fall that's grown over Gaffesend, goading us closer and closer to a frozen lake.

My hand trembles further as Erik expresses his excitement. My vision narrows, and the words of excitation sound so distant as I hold tightly to my smile, managing to meet the eyes of my mother as my stepfather's strong hands pinch my shoulders, relaxing me in an instant.
"Surprised, daughter?" Holden asks, massaging the tender meat of my shoulders that have tensed for weeks, even in slumber. "You look like you're going to pass out."
"No. This is great news," I say. "Just a lot to take in."
"And this child will have the protection of her eldest siblings," Stella says. "Erik is already a guard, and Katiya's in the top of her class, so close to joining him."

Erik looks at me with a glance only I could recognize, almost coaxing a confession. But when he feels my hand tremble against his under the table, and he takes two long breaths to weigh circumstance, he responds for the two of us.

"She'll be on my side in no time," he says, placing his hand over my clutched fist to try to get me to release. "I've been watching her personally. And she's been working as hard as she did in the Academy."

"That's so good to hear," Stella says. Tears crest her eyes as she rests a hand on her stomach. "So many years we've waited, but this is a chance for us to be a family again. To take back everything."
And we raise our glasses: Zane and Stella and Terra with their currant juice; Holden with a hearty post-work mug of mead; Erik and I with a smaller glass of red wine.
My hand trembles. But the blood-red chalice doesn't spill when I lift with all my focus.
I can't let a single drop stain this new house.

I leave dinner, but the feeling overstays. It's rare for my brother and I to walk the same way since we live in two different parts of town: I live in the west half with all the apprentices, while Erik has settled into the employed half. But it still takes a long walk north to get to our split.

These walks are the only time I've been able to see him, and I still struggle to reconcile how much he's changed since he left for Gaffesend while I was still training in the academy in Northaven. He used to be a bean sprout, but he's built muscle, and traded his odd humor for an unfeeling stoicism.
We walk into town on the same dirt path the nobles took all those months ago: light still in the sky since Stella ushered us home early, concerned for our safety though it's supposed to be our job.
"You know, it hurts every time I have to lie like that," Erik says, as he wraps his guardsman's coat around my shoulders, mistaking my twitch for a chill. "But I understand."
"It will only be a lie if it doesn't come true in the end," I say. "So I have to make it happen — or else one day, I'll just disappear."
"I don't know what I'll say to them if that happens."
"Just tell them I went too far to the east again, and instead of Raph, it was me this time."

I stare at the ground though he still looks at me.  "It won't come to that, Katiya, I know you. And I know your strength," he says, "and you should too," then he asks, "but haven't you done better since the test three months ago?"
