"Yeah. Buster. The one that wore the cone all the time," I say, laughing at the thought of little Jackson screaming in fear as he raced for the other fence line. "And we'd watch from the play structure eating those shitty popsicles from the ice cream truck."

"That's why I always had a dollar-fifty in my pocket when I came over," she says. "So we could take turns buying for each other. The picture always looked so amazing on the side of the truck, you know, the ones of the characters? But then you open the wrapper, and it's all melted."

"And yet we'd fall for it every day," I say, "thinking it was just a fluke, that the next time it would be different." I look again towards the stalls. Our friends get closer to the counter, and I know our time is running short.
"So why did we buy it?"

"I know why I did," I say. "I don't think it ever mattered if those disgusting, black licorice gumball eyes were missing or not, but I just remember the joy of giving my allowance so I could hold the both of them and give one to you, and it didn't matter who was buying. Seeing you happy was worth more than what it tasted like."
She smiles, looking relieved. "Then I think that small amount of joy was doing all the work the popsicle should have been doing."
"It did all summer, until your dad got the new job and you had to move to the next town. I was sad for a while, thinking you'd never have ice cream again without my allowance!"
"Oh, it was awful!" Kei says.
"But I don't know. I just look back on all those times together with such joy. It makes me happy to just know you can still find that feeling, and that's enough for me."
I look to Reed, buying two large pretzels, and then to Katiya, struggling through her first transaction to get two burgers.
"Even if we can't earn enough of that currency to support each other, the only thing that matters to me is that we have enough. Even if that exchange is with someone else," I say.
"Well, I hope you find that person," she says.
" I think I'm getting closer," I say. "I love you, Kei, and I have for as long as I can remember. But I love to see you happy even more."
"And I love you too," she says. I hear her sniffle a little. "And I'm sorry."
"No. Don't apologize for chasing what makes you happy," I say, as the others start to approach: Miguel trying to stabilize a foamy pitcher of Coors with plastic cups balanced on his jester's hat.
She says, "then just promise me one thing."
"What's that?" I ask.
"To always stay close to me, Cody," she says.
And I promise her.
"You said you promised," I say. "You said you'd let me win for him. So why are you fighting so hard?"

"Those other fighters were nothing," Rayna says, as the two of us circle in the center of the dirt arena. "I've got a taste for it again. I haven't fought like this since the Academy, and you're the only one that's put up a fight!"

"Then it's no wonder you're so rusty," I say, launching another jab at her as she leaps backward. It's hard not to use Essence or acrobatics: Cody sternly told us not to go all out, saying we'd either get kicked out or end up working here.

He cheers from the stands as the rest of the party chants our names, reminding me of the exhibition matches we held at seminaries — convincing young children to one day join our ranks. She said she'd lose so I could impress him, even though I never asked in the first place. But Rayna doesn't make it easy. I can tell she's stretching time in the narrow moments when she strikes, so fast that the rattan sword bends before it even hits.

But I'm too fast, and the other four challengers were nothing compared to us. We rose up the bracket so fast that the Ring Captain asked us to stretch it out to fill the thirty minute time slot, taking out adults in silver-painted football pads in a single strike, jabbing them in the chest so hard that the end of the sword blossomed like a parasol before snapping back to its original shape.

But Cody's eyes are the only ones I care about, even though so much of the faire has gathered around the hill to watch what was supposed to be a show-tourney. Half the audience cheers for "Rayna The Cat," while the other half cheers for "Katiya The Brave."

There are even more that pour in by word-of-mouth, suspending the more serious ring of warriors that are allowed to fight with metal. I can feel my body respond so fluidly when I'm not afraid, blocking and dodging before my mind can catch up, and I whirl in spins of showful strikes as my adversary parries.
"If you're joining us now, not a single one has yet landed a blow, but they look like professionals," the Ring Captain says. "This is the final match, and we've been at it for five whole minutes!"
She tries to sweep my feet, and I use Essence — just a little bit — to drive my muscles to propel me in the air enough to flip sideways.
The crowd roars.
"That's not fair," Rayna says.
I strike back. "Then stop bending time, cheater!"
"I'm not," she says, flashing her subtle fangs in a toothy grin.

But she's less brazen after I get a sense of rhythm for the ebb-and-flow of the push-and-pull of time. She anticipates a strike and tries to slow my motion, but I feint, and by the time she's accelerated herself for a turnabout, I drive a blow against her chest, using her own energy against her.

She staggers backwards as the crowd erupts with cheers. Someone asks to "take my hand in marriage." And when I look up to the false king that rules this acreage, adorned with a crown embedded with fake rubies and diamonds, I kneel before him.

"Miss Katiya The Brave, you are our champion," he declares: voice omnipresent as it echoes through the speakers. The Ring Captain retrieves a plastic crown from a cardboard box labeled TROPHY CROWNS WEEK 12, putting it upon my head as Rayna comes to kneel next to me.
And then another actor approaches from behind the king's miniature wooden castle: a prince, holding a rose as he approaches me.
The King laughs. "You have earned the right to take my son's hand in marriage," he says, although the two of them look nothing alike. He extends the rose to me and offers his gloved hand.
But then I hesitate.
"Or is your heart already taken, milady?" The king asks. "Has another paramour already captured your heart?"
"This is true," I say, turning around to look through the crowd as loads of bachelors reach toward the arena with both their hands.
He blushes as he sits there on the hill, too afraid to get up and embarrass himself, but when I gesture for him to approach, Miguel and Kei nearly throw him off the hill.

The audience cheers when he takes his first steps. I feel I've gotten more praise than I ever will in all my life, even if it's all pretend, and as he shuffles nervously across the long stretch of dirt, I head directly for him, riding high on the mote of undeniable attraction I find in his eyes.

He slows down as I get closer, as if afraid of what I'll do next in front of a hundred people, but Im speeding up as I reach out with my gauntlet, grasping the shirt I bought for him and pulling him in close, steeling myself for an emotional act of stupid bravery.

I pull him down a couple inches as his face flushes further, and the audience cheers when the two of us make contact. It's just a brief peck, but I find my gauntlets grasping the back of his head as my other hand tenses in his shirt, feeling an arm wrap around my waist as we take the beat we've forestalled forever.
I disengage when I remember the rules and the emotional high eclipses. But he's in good humor, and when I hand him the rose, acting like he's the feeble prince, the crowd laughs as he takes my hand.
We make a point to wait for Rayna as she dashes across the field, and when I raise her hand, she gets the last round of applause before we disappear into the crowd.
I mutter to Cody after circumstances catch up to feelings. "I'm sorry if — I mean, it was just the high of the moment, playing the part, and—"
"It's all good theater," he says. But after I release Rayna's hand, he still refuses to let go, maybe even holding tighter.
"How do you train for that?" Miguel asks. "And the damn flip, that was dope."

I rehearse the cover story Cody crafted for me. my mind's so busy rehearsing plot points that I don't notice when the mood shifts — only when Cody's hand goes limp, and the three engineers pull out their phones.
"On a day off?" Reed asks.
"It's that stupid lab thing," Kei says.
The strength returns to Cody's hand, but it feels deliberate, and though he still holds it for the rest of the time we're there, refusing to let go, he never relaxes.

He's able to laugh just as easily with all his cherished friends on the car ride home. His fingers grip the steering wheel hard enough to choke the rubber, and if the others weren't here singing along to some song, I think I'd try to take his hand again.

His face falls after the others leave and it's just Rayna and I. He says he's exhausted, though he has enough energy to find a drinking glass to vase the rose, and after the three of us watch movies for a couple hours, leaving Rayna with a blanket to sleep on the couch, we retire up to Cody's room to sleep separately together again, but he's snared in something. Hr still refuses to check his phone beyond setting an alarm.
And it's then that I find the courage to ask, though he's turned away from me, facing the window.
"Are you alright?" I ask.
"I'm fine," he says.
I speak slowly. "Do you want to talk about what happened?"
"Just an email," he says. "And I really don't want to work tomorrow."

I rest my hand on his bare shoulder as I turn to face him, separated by only one sheet this time. I can feel him shake, and so I hug his back to my chest, trying to transfer a warmth beyond Essence, thinking maybe it will release something from him.
And it does.
"So they got the wrong guy," he says.

The pride of my fictional victory is enough to earn a restful night of sleep in Cody's bed, but it doesn't come to me quickly. We face in opposite directions with a sheet still separating us, and while I glance out the window to watch the metallic automobiles zip past beneath the miracle of electric light, I listen to Cody's uneven breathing.

And it's not even that he's snoring or gasping — but they're short and heavy and persistent, and for the longest time, I hesitate to turn back around and address him, afraid I might be a bother. But sometimes I think I hear short mutterings — whether it's a curse or cry or a a whimper between breaths — and I'm sure I can feel him tremble in bed the same way he did the night of the break-in.

After almost an hour, I finally find the courage to turn around and offer my warmth to him. My arm extends around his waist: and I try to pull him in: a position of protection my ex would never let me do, and whether Cody's sleeping or faking it, I finally feel his breaths rise and fall slower with less trembling in his throat.

When I find sleep, I'm outside the cabin again, sitting there as I watch the sunrise, surrounded by all the ones I know and cherish. I'm telling my father of my day in Cody's mockery of my world: the tournament of challengers with fearsome names and lackluster technique. The stands of craftspeople my father would love to meet, with all their trinkets, odds, and ends, and I think another peaceful dream will find me for the second time — until the sun rises red with blood and I can smell the smoke in the air, itching my throat and burning my eyes until a loud screech shakes the entire town.
But this isn't a dream I escape when I wake up.

The screeching follows from beyond the dream, and when I look up, the small white circles on the ceiling flash with small red lights as smoke fills Cody's bedroom, catching the early morning sun in cloudy beams through the window.
The clock reads 6:40: Cody's gone because he said he had to go to work, and he must have just left. I was planning to do an evening quest, intending to sleep in for the first time in ages.

But the screech is deafening as I throw open all the windows, bolting downstairs in my nightgown in case Cody left something on after making breakfast. My hands rise with Essence on-command to siphon the energy from any open flame, and though the smoke is worse downstairs, I don't sense anything emitting enough heat to warrant such a sightless plume.
As I throw open the windows and turn on the electric fans, I realize the only other place it could come from, and my stomach drops when I come to the realization.

The shattered window I covered with fabric did so little to prevent the overwhelming flood of ashen smoke from the outside air. My floor is covered with specks of black: some still glowing with heat from whatever unfolds beyond my walls, and with my connecting door left carelessly ajar, the specks have scattered onto Cody's polished floors.
I rush back into my world of Gaffesend as I throw the door shut behind me, finding Rayna in a state of incontrovertible shock as she's crumpled on the couch.
"What the res are you still doing here? There's a fire," I say, "we have to get out of here!"
"It's not a fire," Rayna says, as muscle memory takes over for dressing into my guard uniform.
I cough. "What do you mean? What else could it be?"

"It's something worse, and I think one of your friends was trying to get you. He knocked on the door frantically, saying your name. Then something about a town nearby, then about a major Essence event to the north. That Blackwater erupted."
"There's no volcanoes up there: what do you mean?" I ask. I cough again before she hands me a clean dish towel to cover my mouth.

"There was a massive column of crimson and amethyst light that broke the clouds: so bright it must have woken everyone." She reaches behind her. "And your friend left you something: he was knocking really hard until he slipped it under the door . . . looks like one of those—"

"Quest sheets," I say. My eyes water, but I can so easily recognize the handwriting. It's the same sheet he tried to give me in the hospital, when I was too afraid to leave the town. And when I rush out the door, covering my mouth as I rue the fact that it looks like I slept in, I try to catch up with him, the world so obscured by the ash and smoke I can only make out the silhouettes of the townspeople as they rush past me.

When I rose from four hours of sleep, I found that same feeling of dread I found in college when the world finally caught up with me, when I remembered it was a heavy day of finals. But this was a test I couldn't study for.

I usually leave no later than 6:30, but I awoke around 5:00, finding the knight still sleeping next to me. But it was like waking from a restless night with a severe cold, because once my conscious mind became aware of the great discomfort, there wasn't a chance I would be able to get myself back to sleep.

I thought of leaving early. Maybe if I showered and made it in when the early risers do — like Reed and Kei — I could leave earlier and still finish eight hours of work, but then any odd action might be an admission of guilt, and surely they would know what I was trying to do. So I couldn't go in late, either: I would have to go in at exactly the same time, acting none the wiser, as if a wide-sweeping investigation wouldn't be stalking me as soon as my badge number registered on the door's security console.

So all I could do was lay there with my thoughts like I did last night. Last night I was tempted to re-read the email for the tenth time, but I didn't want the bright screen to wake the girl sleeping next to me, and I knew it wasn't good for me either, so I just let the thoughts run their course like a fever until my mind was too exhausted to trouble me any further. By the time Katiya noticed enough to wrap her arm around me, suffusing me with the warmth of her otherworldly touch, I found just enough comfort to pass out.

But now I rest uncomfortably as the room glows brighter with each passing minute, longing for another sense of touch and warmth. It isn't fear I feel. I'm more frightened of how unafraid I am, pulled back to the depths of my apathetic exhaustion that covers me like a wet blanket although the sheets that wrap around me are dry. Maybe last night I could find a couple tears before my body misconstrued my attempt at exorcising that long-forgotten emotion for a yawn, but as the clock finally reaches the time I'm set to rise, I only have enough energy to shower and dress myself. I wear Navidson-Monroe blue with the logo proudly emblazoned on the breast pocket, and I tuck it into jeans with a belt. My stomach is too empty to fill, so I bring nothing to work with me, fully expecting to be out by midday at a bar somewhere.

The rain starts sometime before I pull out of the garage, and the ride is silent when music can't quell the anticipation: instead the raindrops patter in a continuous drumroll against the metallic roof; all sound without tonic or resolution.

I'm walking up the concrete stairs before I even realize that I parked, and I can't even remember where. Dodging between hallways feels like playing paintball in close quarters until I make it to my desk at the exact average time I get in every day, but the discomfort catches up with me. Maybe it's the breakfast I skipped, or the sleeplessness, or the call of the void that left me without an appetite, dragging me to the bathroom to slam the stall door shut to get on my knees and lose the nothing I ate before this, dry-retching as someone else quickly washes their hands and vacates the bathroom.

I wipe and rinse my mouth several times before I leave, turning the corner to start down the long hallway of half-height cubicles. Several unfamiliar heads float above the partitions on the left side — my side — and I frantically count how far down they are, whether they're looking for me, and whom they're talking to.
But there's no stopping on the direct route to my desk, and I try to quell the feverish feeling as inevitability drags me closer, noticing they're in my row, asking Wilbur something.
I turn the corner, ready to weigh the level of recognition in their faces. My heart races, but my face remains still, as I try to turn a play at confusion into a joke.
"You fellas lost?" I ask.
They respond with another question.
"Are you Cody Dunsmore?"

When I arrive in the west-facing conference room, flanked by a phalanx of employees I've never met before, I find the shutter shades drawn so tightly that the only glow in the room comes from their laptop screens. From the long chain of tables spanning most of the room, with three chairs on one side and seven on the other, I can tell the seating is assigned since there's only one spot left to fill.

Naveen sits in the left chair, and my father sits in the right, still refusing to turn and face me as the outlines of seven unfamiliar people on the other side of the table block the faint glow from between the shades.

"Why don't you have a seat, Cody," someone says, and I find my place between my two mentors. But calmly, and it discomforts me more than all the things I know are coming. Now is the time to be afraid: yet I find the fear isn't there, and as they shuffle through their manila folders for notes to start the meeting, I feel like I'm watching myself from the corner of the room.

Usually I'm fighting the waves of my depression for a spark of energy, but for the first time, I'm almost glad there's nothing left. The representative from Internal Affairs opens his mouth to start us off, and I realize I might be too absent to feel the heat.
The recorder clicks.

We state our names and the hour, and then they say they're only "finding facts," and to "say only what you know firsthand," and that "there's no blame yet for anything." But when the still image of my silhouette shows on the first projector slide, I'm not sure I believe them.

"So there was something odd that happened late last week." The rep from IA drags his finger across a sheet of paper that's been meticulously highlighted. "At five thirty-four PM, someone entered the advanced technology lab with Alan Dunsmore's credentials when he was already logged out of the system. And yet Alan was already clocked-out: he left at 5:08, within the ten-minute time window specified by his union contract."

Alan's union rep nods, writing something down. The HR lady records the words on her laptop with a flurry of keystrokes, the only other sound in the room beyond the low hum of the outdoor heating unit. I feel my father tap his foot against the floor until he realizes we can feel it, and yet Nav is perfectly still.

I can feel that first question coming, the one I've been waiting for since the email, and after a whole night of mentally debating myself over the best approach, I find I have no emotion left to obscure the clarity of the right answer.

"But Navidson-Monroe office staff are not required to clock out. Their badges are only read when they enter through one of the four office or warehouse doors. We do know, however, that an engineer's computer was active until exactly 5:23, when he logged out."

He's building the case with the anticipation that I'll try to deny it, and when he points his ballpoint pen at me, leveraging a cold, corporate stare that's devoid of malice, he finally gets to the question.
"And where were you, then, Cody?"
I clear my throat.
"Yes, around that time. What were you doing?"
"I was logging off my computer," I say. "That computer."
"And then, where did you—"
"—I went down to the battery lab to test my prototype for the entry-level learning project."

The room halts. The two men I'm sitting with turn to me, but it's not a gasp of revelation. It's a different surprise when they thumb past the first twenty pages of notes, expecting that they would have to work me over harder for the first confession.
"So it was you that was in there," the Lead says.
"That's right," I say.
"And would you mind telling us how you got in?"

"I was under the impression that it was an open lab, as long as the safety course was complete. I've been using the CAL-04 bench for the last month. I was told it would be left open for Reed and I to test our projects between other assignments."
"And who told you that?"
I turn to Nav, but not completely. I'm not trying to hang my boss out to dry, even if I know he told us on the first day.
But he speaks up. "No, it was I that told Reed and Cody."
"And who gave you permission?"
Nav starts, "It was—"
"—It's been an unspoken agreement for almost a decade," my father says. "Any time there are entry-level engineers running their projects, we try to leave it open."
And then the Quality Assurance director speaks. "Gentlemen, there's a reason we have SOP's. It's so we can formalize these things."
"SOP's require tasks under billable hours, and this doesn't fall under that," Nav says. "It's a rare case where testing is done for experience, not financial gain."

"But he certainly can't be operating without a lead present," the safety director says. "The nature of these projects happening without operating procedures is a big problem we'll talk about later. But this engineer can't be in there without a supervisor!"
The Lead adds, "was he given permission by his manager?"
"He was not," Nav says.
"Then Cody," he asks, "why were you in there?"
"I was there because I'm running out of time to present my battery project, and though it's passable, I want to prove I can do even better."
"But your calendar says the presentation isn't due for another three weeks," the Lead says. "If you have time, why did you choose to work after hours?"
"I . . . I was particularly motivated that day."
"Motivated? As in..."
"Pressured," I say.
"How were you pressured? Was it a coerced act?" He asks.
"I was pressured to perform because it was the day I learned that management thinks I'm not good at my job. Or not good enough . . ."
"Cody," Nav mutters.
"I wasn't raised to quit, but I was raised to work harder, even if my skills are subpar. I was in there to test a new idea I had for the project." The words anger my father, but he's not mad at me.
The Lead closes the manila folder, perching with his elbows on the tan cover as he draws a deep breath.

"Look, Cody, even if you were convinced you were finding a cure for cancer or had the noblest of reasons to be down there, it doesn't change the fact that the Department of Defense is . . . discontented, that one of their golden samples was disconnected." He opens the folder again, thumbing through pages of terminal records. "We could ask about the strange results, and it would be fine to assume it's just an amateur operator. We could ask about the HVAC system reporting a significant chill when you ran the first test, but that isn't what matters. What matters is how we show reconciliation for a multimillion-dollar government project that costs tens of thousands of dollars a day, and the fact that the project was halted due to negligence," then pauses to look at me — "negligence of someone that shouldn't be in there in the first place, and we have to provide corrective action."
I bow my head as I await the final sentence. But my father's anger releases with an admonition.
"My son was just following instructions," Alan says.
I say, "there were no instructions. I acted on my own—"
"I clipped the seal," Alan says.
The entire room turns to look at him.
"I'm sorry, Mr. Dunsmore, what did you say?"
"Dad," I say.
"I said I clipped the seal. I told my son he could use CAL-04 that day, and only realized I promised him after I started running the test. I'm not going to let my own son cover for my stupidity."
"Dad, that's not—"

"I was going to run it the next morning. You see the test log was dated a day later?" He gestures to the page as they flip through their folders. "I was planning to run it the next day, and I figured I would just change the identification number."
"You're a lead, Alan. A technician level four, and you should have known better: we don't hot-swap numbers under the table!"

Alan's union representative looks confused at the revelation: he can sense the same lie that I do. "Now, gentlemen and ladies, look, I think Alan is confused here. He just told me before the meeting—"
"And you're saying you gave your son permission?" The IA lead asks.
I can see Dad rewriting history as we go along. His back is turned so I can't see his face. "I bet you found he used my number instead of my card, right? Because I told him. 0-6-0-8."
I say, "But I clipped it. I clipped the identifier—"
"Stop lying, Cody!" My father looks furious. He sweats at his self-immolation.
"Then what about Cody's sample?"

"He's an amateur," my father says. "Just a stupid kid like his brother. So if you're going to punish anyone, punish me. You've ignored my son's efforts for three-and-a-half years, so why should you start noticing him now?"
The men of the Dunsmore family are the best at taking bullets. And as the only one left whose number hasn't been called, I carry enough survivor's guilt for the three of us.

I was prepared to be vanished today. The private sector dodges a lot of the slow, bureaucratic cycle of government, and I was sure they'd already drawn the documents for my termination, but they left themselves another option just in case. So after they got their pound of flesh through my father, I was no longer essential to taking the full force of punishment.

Maybe the other technicians didn't notice when my father was escorted out of the large steel door because he wasn't wheeling out his toolbox. No matter the result, I would end up turning in my work laptop by the end of the day, trading one line of work for another, where I was forced to follow in my father's footsteps, stripped of the pride offered by my degree. As of Monday, November 30, I made the lateral transition to assume the role of an entry-level mechanical technician, survived by a rusty red box of tools that I still don't know the half of, left to look up through the office window at a realm that is no longer privileged to me.

The only real explanation I got was from Nav. He gave me ten minutes in an abandoned conference room before they repossessed all my stuff, saying he would explain my plight to the others and mitigate all the humiliation, though I'd be the first thing they saw looking out the window to the shop floor. He was at least the one that tried to stand up for me: as they chose my fate in a few minutes, he protested that I was a new entry-level engineer being dropped like a hot rock into a competitive market. So after they decided to let me stay under austere conditions, Nav explained that it was "my chance to walk away quietly, with a shred of dignity and a believable lie."

I didn't even get to see my father after he left, but I don't think he wanted to be seen. I think his anger was real. I think he thought I expected him to save me: maybe he thought it was his role as my father to gish-gallop the room into a mess of threads that couldn't be untangled, painting the target on his back so brightly that they could only shoot him. The last I saw was the same expression he wore for months after he got the news about my brother, shouldering a crushing truth by only ever lifting with his back and never asking for help.

I hate the way I am, but I can't separate myself from who I am, so I think I really just hate myself, and right now, I really, really hate myself. Has this apathy castrated me so much that I've lost the will to fight, or to care at all? What if I begged, or broke down, or got angry, or lost it, or whatever — enough to make them feel they got their justice? And what if I cared enough about my father's pride to extinguish his act of suicide?
What is perfect courage without the ability to feel all the things you have to lose?

It's a new feeling that finds me when I'm rushing through the open streets, one I felt the day before when I heard Cody's voice cheering my name. It's an energy that races my circuits with the same signature of power but a different medium — like how human Essence can give rise to powers of both life and fire — and if Cody's faith in me lifted a sense of life, it's a fear for Bertram that blazes a fire.

The feeling carries me through the streets in a rush: one hand holding Bertram's quest sheet as a tightly-rolled scroll while the other holds a damp dishrag from Cody's world to my mouth. Some civilians watch from the windows of their homes: others head south, shouldering enough provisions to wait it all out.

It was supposed to be winter when the Chymaera planned their attack, and if the Essence event to the north is their handiwork, it's because Blackwater runs in a cold, eternal winter. Rayna left to pursue answers from her contact shortly after I left. All I know now is that Gaffesend is the last northern base holding the Purgatory Line — leaving Hillfar as no more than a burnt offering.

He had to have returned to base, I think. There's no way he'd go alone. Maybe he was the only one that had some family stubborn enough to stay, but he'd wait for me. Why else would he slide the unsigned quest sheet beneath the door?

I could rue my decision to sleep in Cody's world. I was told to take the morning off until the carpenters fixed my window, so I could scout into the evening, but now my absence is suspicious. The anger fuels me as I weave between civilians that march to the base for a sense of sanctuary, and when I break the threshold of the large, metal gates, I'm surprised when I find all of the junior guards sitting around.
I catch my breath through the wet rag, saving me a cough as I search for anyone that I recognize. Sharp claws clatter against my shoulder plate as a nervous voice purrs behind me.
"Katiya, where have you been?" Naya asks.

"I was meant to scout in the evening," I say. I turn to face her, finding our other friends leaning low against the perimeter wall. Paxton sits on the gravel floor, talking to Ryder as he reads a book, and there's only the two of them, dragging me further from any reassurance.
"Why are we all just standing around?" I ask. "And where's Bertram?"
She flicks her tail. "Comms are down in all the surrounding areas. We've been ordered to stand by and defend Gaffesend, where we're in sight of each other."
"So It's foul play?" I ask, then change my question immediately. "But where's Bertram? Did you see him? He left this at my house," I say, holding a quest sheet.
Ryder overhears my panic. "He said he was going to fetch something he forgot from his house."

Pax says, "he was rambling about his cousins to the east. And then he heard about the comms going down. Said he had to grab something, and I offered to watch his stuff so he could get there faster. Then I went to take a piss, and he wasn't there when I came back."
I glare at Ryder: he's the one that knows it all. "I don't know. He went the wrong way to be going home: he was headed for the stables."
The unease grips me harder. "Gods damn it, Bertram. And when was this?"
"A while ago," Ryder says. "Long enough that I thought he might return with you: maybe forty-five minutes?"

"Shit!" I say: it's a curse from Cody's world, but finally, they're beginning to realize my cause for panic. They follow behind me as I sprint to the stables, and their speed rises with the same urgency of fear.
"There's no way he would do that," Pax shouts.
"They'd stop him," Naya says, "right?"
My mind's too occupied with the last words I spoke to him. No. I can't think this way, I tell myself, but feeling and logic play on two different channels, and the feeling is taking over.

I drag the heavy door open to the stables, and if I was any less exhausted I might have popped it off the rails. There's two other junior cadets that inspect an empty stall — Flint's stall — noticing all the excesses he left behind. Aryn lifts a broken necklace, the string tethered through a pendant he fashioned from the debris of that fateful night. And Jullian holds his bag, still full of all the scouting provisions he pretended that he left behind.
The others catch up, circling the empty stall.
"It's Bertram," I say. "Bertram left!"
"We were ordered to stay," Aryn says. "And he knows that. Why would he leave?"
I explain in a few breathless words.

"Well, he made his choice," Jullian says. I can see that fear in his eyes, but when he looks at me, it seems he can't find it. "What, are you going to go after him? Command will be here in minutes, along with all the other senior guards. Our orders were to stay."
"I can't let Bertram die alone," I say. "I made a promise to him, that we'd return together."

I press against Ryder as he blocks the stall door, and he gives, disbelieving that my words could be anything but just talk. But he doesn't know the feeling that still burns in me when I think of my closest friend's face, realizing all the feelings I failed to tell him.
I can't even remember the last thing he said to me.

"You steal a horse and you're cooked, Katiya," Jullian says, and there's a genuine fear in his voice — but now it's for me. "What if it's nothing? What if the Chymaera aren't there, and there's no act of bravery to be had? Leadership will roast you alive!"

But I've already thrown open the gate and saddled the horse. I can hear Aldrin and all the other senior guards approaching the stable, but it feels like the result is now inevitable: just as certain as Bertram's fate.
"I'm still buried in Hillfar with my father," I say, climbing the dark horse named Soot after I untether him from the post. "I'm saving Bertram, and I'm saving myself."

I don't look back until I pass through the wide stable door. Aldrin and his royal knights dive to the side as Soot noses between them, catching a glance of my fluttering braid as I coax Soot to full speed, unable to hear whether the shouts behind me are admonitions of my commanding officer or the voices of friends I might be hearing for the last time.

The clattering of hooves ceases when I break the line between cobblestone and dirt. I fight the blinding smoke for enough vision to lead Soot as my eyes water, breathing shallowly in the space behind Soot's neck that he drafts with air. While Soot toils with speed, my mind races over coming up with a plan: something, anything to turn Bertram around and get him back home safe.

I race along the trail around the lake, the one I know from running every morning. For the longest time, I hear nothing but the wind whistling in my ears as we race through a long straightaway. It's only when we pass the limit of my runs, where the trail bends right to curve around a small cove, that the shouting finally has its chance to carry across the water.

It's two voices, high and low, and when I listen closer, I can hear the rhythm of hoofbeats. I can't let them turn me around when Bertram is all alone: if I'm paying for my disobedience, I better spend every last Kine of it.

The trail tapers off at a rugged delta of shallow streams, feeding south to Northaven from the high mountains, and though I coax Soot to go faster, he's confused at where to go. As Soot and I ford the first stream, kicking up splashes of river water as I goad him to run, I hear my pursuers gaining on me, and I refuse to look back until they dare to drag me home.

I keep riding, riding carelessly, carelessly enough to distance myself, with only the thought of Bertram's fate twisting in my mind. The image is loud enough to drown out their cries, and by the time I've crossed the shallows, they've disappeared into the haze.

I ride through the forest, beginning to recognize the landmarks from my furthest treks from Hillfar as a child. Soot gallops on without awareness of any danger, and it means my hesitation can't stop me anymore.

That is, until I spot a felled tree on the side of the road tethered with a brown horse. The village is getting closer. These are the outskirts of where I used to walk, just beyond my father's sight where his shrill whistle could bring me home. Maybe the nostalgia would bring an air of peace if it weren't for the glow of amethyst in the bark, and the sound of commotion somewhere several hundred yards away.
I tether Soot next to Flint, realizing all motion is now my own. My legs tremble, yet the feeling from this morning still resonates inside me, and I think it will be strong enough this time.
This is courage, I think. This has to be courage, right? It all has to add to something!

And just as I'm about to take the first steps toward Hillfar that I can call my own, I hear a twig snap behind me. I haven't the time to react before they respond to their own mistake in stealth, and then they tackle me to the ground, covering my mouth as I expect a cold, obsidian limb to skewer my chest.

I'm about to scream before I realize the hand is warm. There's no dagger to my throat: the only sensation I feel is the deceleration of time as my adversary anticipates what I'll do next, and when I turn around, Aryn's eyes narrow with fear, as Jullian stands behind her.
"I had to be sure you wouldn't run — make the same mistake as your blockhead friend," she mutters.
"But why?" I ask. "Why did you follow me?"
"I couldn't save my sister from her fate. But I can still save you," Aryn says, "the one that inspired me to join in the first place."

I look at Jullian for the first time since that night in the tavern. He's not jealous. It's not because he thinks he owes me. He looks afraid, and says, "you know there's people that care if you throw your life away?"
"I won't be useless anymore," I say. "And I need to move before I lose the nerve."
"You need more than nerves. You need a plan," Aryn says. "What are you here to do?"
"To make him come home," I say. My voice trembles, and it's time for me to go.
"But how are you going to do that?" Jullian asks. He shout-whispers as I head for danger. "Katiya!"

The chill of death is no different than it was all those years ago. The cries of the victims are just as hushed as they were in the siege when the village is so sparsely spread between the pines, but there are still the diminishing sounds of combat.

I pass through a smoldered gate once carved by my father's hands. His handiwork lives on in all that's left of the intricate carvings: two burnt half-posts left from an arch that once had our village's name.

But my hands don't trace the pattern. They feel for the woven thread of the grip on my holstered blade. I'm the first to advance since I know the  landscape, passing through the exposed foyer of Old Lucy's cabin as I stare through the skeleton of a doorframe at the footprint of my old house.

I tiptoe along the line of sight my father had, when Bertram and I used to paint rocks in Old Lucy's house. We head for the ghost of an edifice that's stood longer in my dreams, and as I struggle not to think where their bodies have been all this time, I hear the growing sounds of a dying resistance.

Volleys of fresh obsidian shards stab the petrified charcoal like arrows. I pray the civilians had time to escape when all the human corpses wear the leather armor of the Hillfar Militia, interspersed with the dark-shelled bodies of crumpled Chymaerans at an even balance. The longing for his voice pulls me closer to conflict though all I want is just to call his name.

I discern the first string of words when our backs lean against what's left of the log wall in my bedroom, but they're not human. It's a series of anxious clicks at low frequency, and my mind races back on a decade of training to translate them.
"You heard that?" Jullian asks, racking one of the two rifles they stole from the stable's armory.
"Two words," Aryn says. "Reinforcements. Soon."
There's so few humans left to fight. Surely it's only the most stubborn ones that refuse to leave, and when I finally hear a human voice, I recognize it from my past.

The memory of the first trial all those months ago flashes through my mind, and all the quiet nights of humiliation that followed, until the agony becomes worse than death and sets me over the edge, parting from the wall my father once built to pursue the friend who's saved me twice.

Aryn's fingers slip through the fabric of my uniform when she tries to grab me, and I sprint for Bertram's old house across the way, dodging between trees as I find a stranger standing outside the rebuilt cabin's entrance. They shout for someone else that isn't with them, and when they turn to find the flaxen-haired girl with a scar that missed her eye and severed her brow, they recognize me in an instant.
"Miss Katiya," Bertram's cousin says, "why are you here?"
"Where is Bertram?" I demand.
"He's pinned down somewhere south of the house," he says. "Went to save his niece."
I hear rifle blasts behind me: it makes them jump before he realizes it's human.
Something grazes my leg.
"Gods damn it, Katiya! Get back here," Jullian says, and I see the two of them crouching behind the south-facing wall.
But I'm not done.
"Where is he, exactly?" I begin to say, turning back to ask the cousin. "Tell me, can you point—"
An obsidian needle sticks through both sides of his skull. His eyes froze so fast that the fluid exploded, leaving icicles hanging in flash-frozen drips from his hollow sockets.
Someone is firing on us from the west: a Chymaeran Shiver, launching obsidian quills as an off-axis overwatch.
When I hear the whisper of something long and sharp splitting the air inches from my ear, I take his rifle from the ground and dive into the building.

The floor is littered with toys I recognize from a past generation, and I suddenly remember Bertram's family did our schooling. The children must have made it out in time: the only forgotten shapes are just toys and dolls abandoned in the middle of play, and when I rush for the shattered back window, hearing the clicks of a couple Chymaerans advancing in a pincer, I finally catch a glimpse of Bertram holding his niece in a small shed.

I have the element of surprise: I've been excluded from the Chymaerans' calculus, and with the loaded weapon in my hands, I'm prepared to either save him or die in a complete circle of life. My hands don't tremble when I steady the rifle on the windowsill, and when Bertram sees me in the window, I find a sense of hope reinvigorates him from helplessness.
We trade hand signals. He's been pinned there the whole time, so he's surely counted everything around him.
Three remain. Two left, one right, behind the shed, he signals, gesturing to each side of the shed, and shows he's holding a sawed-off shotgun. Then he points to a hole in the back of the shed.
He surely means he'll be taking one of them, but I only have one rifle.

Their clicks are getting louder. They approach to find solace before their reinforcements arrive, and just as I'm about to signal that I'll try for both of them, Aryn and Jullian make it to my window.
"What did he say?" Aryn whispers.

"Two left, one right. Bertram fires the first shot and we take the rest," I mutter, just as their long shadows begin to cross the backyard. "Aryn's a deadshot. You take the one that's furthest to the left, and I'll take the other. Jullian shoots whatever's still standing."
And then we see them.

I hold my breath when I find my position on the long windowsill as the others prepare to fight. Bertram instructs the little girl to cover her ears, then nuzzles the barrel into the gap as he uses a knotted hole to peek.

The blast echoes across the entire village as the other two Chymaerans panic, watching their comrade's dark carapace explode into amethyst fragments. The Essence in my hands ignites the rifle that was only designed for wielders of fire. I pulse Essence to blast the one on the right two times and drop them: Aryn puts a round right between the left one's triangle of glowing eyes, and Jullian pops a round into each of them.
Hillfar returns to dead silence: we're the only ones left again. I let the quiet hang a little longer as we scan the outside for any sign of the enemy, and when nothing answers, I call to Bertram.
He cries tears of relief. "You saved us, Katiya," he says. "You saved me again!"
"Saved you again?"
"From the fire," he says.
There's something that still feels off, but I ignore it. "You're safe now," I shout. "You can come back!"
Bertram takes the young girl's gloved hand, leaving the shotgun in the shed. "Our circle is complete," he tells me, holding up his crumpled copy of the quest sheet.
"But Katiya, what shot you earlier?" Aryn asks.
"Shot me?" I ask, but I feel nothing.
I motion for him to come to the window as he guides his reluctant niece to his family home, directly out of cover.
"I mean, what shot you, in the thigh?"
She gestures to the cauterized needle sticking through my leg.
I never felt it. It must have hit when I was outside: I thought it was a graze. Which means there's one Chymaeran left I never accounted for.
Aryn winces as she gestures to Bertram before the words can catch up.
"No, Bertram, go back!" I shout, and I look back at the two of them, just before the plume of slender needles slice through the air.
The one that pierces his neck freezes his mouth in a permanent smile, setting his eyes in panic. And  when another stabs into his brain, he dies with his face forever trapped between two complexions.

Jullian reflexively pushes in front of me. I close my eyes before I can witness the rest of it. Their deaths are quick and soundless, beyond the thud of two rigid, frozen bodies collapsing to the floor.

It's the first time I feel Aryn tremble, even if just a little. "It's not over. Stay away from the windows," she says: the three of us are light on ammunition, with only our bladed weapons to resist a breach.
My Essence floods the blade, heating the iron edge until it glows—a hairline of red running the full length of the steel. The metal chatters softly as the hotter iron expands within its colder body.
"Their reinforcements will be here any second," Jullian says. "We have to get out of here!"
"It was all for nothing," I mutter.
"That doesn't matter right now," Aryn says.
Jullian counts the rounds in his pocket. "We need  to take out the Shiver. I have four rounds."
"And I have three," Aryn says. Katiya has whatever's loaded."
"Covering fire," I hear myself say. "I'll provide covering fire for you to get out of here. Give me the ammo."
"But how will you get out?"
"I don't have to," I say, approaching the window before Aryn and Jullian both drag me back by the collar.
"You're not thinking straight," Aryn says. "Your friend is gone — that doesn't mean you have to join him in the Reservoir of Souls!"
I try to resist as I sob uncontrollably, but it's three against one, and I realize I don't even care to check if there's anything left in the magazine. "I failed!"
"You tried," Jullian says.
"I saved him incorrectly," I say, and just as I'm about to make a little progress in resistance, we hear the sound of rifle blasts near my old home.
It's a human force, and when we peer through the north-facing windows, we see the red-and-gold standards of the Royal Guard.
"Shiver is down," a voice reports, and it's my brother's voice. "They left the horses back there, but I seen them with the bodies. Dear Gods . . . Katiya," he calls out.
"If they're not dead, they'll wish they were," Aldrin replies. "They're lucky our plan was to scout here in the first place."
But not in time.
I shout the day's countersign while my adrenaline still blocks the mourning, and moments later, Aldrin and Erik step into the building.
The drawing reads REED because he forgets to use his last name. It was checked by SAKURASHIMA, then approved by PRADESH, and now the chain of custody ends in my greasy hands, putting it all together.

The red toolbox won't be fooled by the hand-me-down fatigues that were just my size, because even if the woven tag reads DUNSMORE, and my likeness is spread across twelve Polaroid photos of my father and I — magnetized to the inner lid like a refrigerator door — I don't know what anything is for, and there's no father to explain it to me.

The technicians all loathe me since word travels fast. They call me names in other tongues since I got their favorite friend fired. And at the bottom of the union pecking order, with about a week of seniority, all I build is just the sub-assemblies — or subs — with about three different screws I have to fasten in the holes.

I circled the sheet with a red pen, the only possession that survived my "lateral transfer" since it was in my pocket. One of the holes on the drawings is deep enough, but Reed specified the wrong depth for the thread: probably just went with the default setting in the software instead of checking the parameters. It's something I could fix in minutes if I still had access, but since my new masters crack the whip — asking every hour when I'll "get it done" — I have no choice but to go exactly where I don't belong.

My steel-toed boots sound different than when I once climbed the shop stairs in dress shoes: loud and heavy and cumbersome, leaving me no chance to sneak in and out of the engineering office. I skulk down the aisle of cubes as a stranger in a familiar land, fighting the urge to hide in an empty row at any provocation, but this is the fate I accepted. Nav said it was my chance to "back away quietly," but I never took it: now I'm a remorseful ghost, longing for resolution for a time that long passed.

I approach the first set of the Battery Team's cubes for the first time since the last time. I'll pass my desk before I make it to the row with all the others, and when my heart can no longer take it, I dip into the lone row I shared with Wilbur, too weak to go straight to the source.
My old mentor speaks in a hushed tone, but he's amiable. "So good to see you, Cody," he says. "You deserve so much better than what happened. And all of this."
"I expect nothing anymore," I whisper, but sulking won't get me changes. "Anyways. Can you . . ."
I peek over the wall. Reed's still loudly talking, and it's useful in masking my voice.
Wilbur says, "Can I?"
"Can you get Reed to come out real quick?"
I know it's lame, but I can't bear it yet.
"He's in. He's right over—" and then he pauses once he realizes what I mean. "Yeah, of course. I'll send a message," he says, then checks his watch. "In one minute. So you have time to escape."
"Thanks, Wilbur. I—"
"Cody," Kei says. "Feels like I haven't seen you in forever!"
I hear the others rise from their chairs in the other aisle, filing out once they hear my name.
"Oh. Hey," I say, picking at a stray thread on the insignia of my father's fatigues. My eyes never meet hers.
"What brings you up, brings you . . . here?"

"A little issue with one of the subassemblies," I say. Reed approaches from behind her, along with the rest of my old team. I regurgitate a laugh as I suppress the urge to run. "Guess I'm the one writing redlines now, huh?"
I hold the drawing between two hands to keep them from trembling.
Kei asks, "what's the problem?"
"Mis-spec'd a tap hole for a #10-24 UNC fastener: thread depth should be longer. I remember the default from SolidEdge — must not have been changed. Need a revision before I re-tap it."
"Sure thing," Kei says.
I hand it to Kei, and she hands it to Reed.
I stand there empty-handed as they look it over, and in the silence, I run my mouth again.
"You know, I'd do it myself and all, but..."
They chuckle. Because there are no words they can respond with that won't cut me.
"So yeah. That's all," I say, but they're still blocking the aisle: maybe searching for some last sentence of reassurance, but nothing comes to them.
So we stand there. By habit, I almost sit in my old seat, but the desk was already cleaned out by the old janitorial staff, and my hands are so dirty.
"Sure," Reed says, folding the copy of his drawing. "I'll be out in a sec."
"I just need a revision. I'll check the updated drawing."
"I insist. It's my bad," he says, as the others return to their row with a morose look, whispering something to Kei before I pass them.
"Well, you know where to find me," I say.

I look out the window to the shop floor, where the lone red toolbox is still open, and minutes later, I'm staring up at the same spot I once stood, as two engineers descend the stairs instead of just one.
I'm not entirely sure why I do it, but I turn to the table to look busy, recalling the scant description of the task:
You take your finger, put some of the greasy "oo" on it, scosh it a tad 'till the Allen wrench fights 'ya a little, and keep it in the fingers, 'cause sore wrists means a bad sex life.
I'm saving my wrists when they show, and I don't turn around, using words instead. "Got the drawing, saw it on the shop computer. I'm good to go."
But Kei puts her hand on my shoulder. "There's something we wanted to tell you, but the timing never seemed right," she says.
"You have nothing to apologize for," I say. My hands strain at the hundredth sub I've built today, callousing my pink palms beneath the gloves.
"It's not an apology. It's a fact," Reed says. "And I owe you a drink: Kei tells me it's your birthday today. So can you meet us after work?"
"Where?" I ask.

I tilt the glass until the liquid beats the foam. My phone buzzes with messages and notifications from friends, all sending the same default message. But there's a message from the group chat with my parents: one that I've still hesitated to open.
"They tried to call, but I couldn't bring myself to answer," I tell Kei and Reed. "I feel like an asshole. But, birthday or not, I'm just not ready to talk yet."

They sit across from me in the booth, and we look like we come from two different worlds from the color of our collars. Kei swirls the large cube of ice in her old-fashioned, and Reed scratches his head, looking like he hesitates to say something.
"What is it?" I ask.
"Just something I remembered. But this dinner isn't about me," he says.
"Please," I say. "Go on."
"I just had an older brother like you. Well, have," he says, and his voice wavers. "Ever since we met, you've reminded me of all the best parts I saw in him."
Kei takes his hand on the table.
"Is he a technician?" I ask.

"He was a year ahead of me at CU Boulder. I followed him, since we come from a family of engineers and engineering managers, mostly at Navidson-Monroe. And he had this . . . spark . . . that I guess I never inherited — 4.4 weighted, out of high school with a Harvard-level ACT score."
My calloused hand leaves the glass as I look in his eyes. "But what do you mean, 'had?'"
"I don't mean to offend you since you actually lost someone," Reed says.
"No, not at all," I say.

"But it feels like it. He burned too bright, too fast. He was more like my mother: my father could work a room, but she could work nothing into anything. He taught himself guitar in a week, and piano in another two. He brute-forced high school and earned his place as valedictorian: got first place in the race, but traded paint with just about damn near every guardrail to get there, and didn't have it in him to change in college. And he gave up."
"Like he didn't finish?"
"Pretty much," Reed says. "My parents' expectations never changed, just like his approach to life, and he dropped out entirely, from everything."
"And you were the last legacy left," I say. "Just like I was."

"It's like racing an Olympic athlete that gets a heart attack before the finish line. So I'm in first now, but did I really earn it?" Reed says. "You design with brilliance, just like my brother did, and you actually feel it."
"And you don't?" I ask.
"I play the game," he says. "People like me end up as managers. But people like you and my brother belong on the cutting edge."
Kei adds, "and I know you still have that passion. You had your day in the national spotlight for that senior project!"
Reed turns to her. "The drone thing, right?"
"He designed a surveillance drone prototype, in honor of his brother Jackson. Made the news, and he did a whole bunch of interviews."
"See?" Reed's fists hit the table. "That sounds exactly right!"
"What ever happened to it?"
"It's in a box in my garage somewhere," I say. "Now that I think of it, I should probably take out the LiPO battery before it explodes."
Now it's Kei's turn to hesitate. "Speaking of batteries — well, there's another reason we asked to talk outside of work beyond your birthday."
My eyes widen. "Oh, espionage, my favorite subject!"
"But really. The events are so fresh that it was hard to bring up before, but I found something." The cube is smaller when she swirls the glass this time. "Is it okay to talk about it?"
"Uh, yeah, of course," I say. "It was a stupid indiscretion on my part."
"But there's more to it. I was looking at the security request, and realized it wasn't human."
"Human? What do you mean?"
Kei's eyes flash with excitement: maybe she was sitting on this for a while. "So basically—"
"How is everything?" Our server asks.
"Oh. Great," Reed says, raising his glass. "We're great."
"Just wanted to let you know your food will be out in a second. Kitchen is a little backed up," he says.
"No worries," I say. "No rush here."
Kei turns back to me, ready to open her mouth.
The server says, "can I get you anything in the meantime?"
"I'm fine," I say, taking the last swig of my beer. "Or maybe an iced tea, unsweet?"
"Water here," Reed says.
We turn back to Kei, who's reorganizing her thoughts. But the waiter still waits on her answer, and takes a while to notice.
Kei smiles. "This is enough for me," she says.
"Okay," the waiter says. "Just let me know if y'all need anything."
"Sure," I say. My fingers drum on the table. I turn to Kei a fourth time, hoping she hasn't forgotten.
But she does.
"Where were we?" She asks.
Reed says, "Cody's—"
"My fuck-up," I say.
"Fuck-up?" Reed asks.
"Oh yeah. So the ticket that was filed. The ticket . .  . yeah. The ticket was—"
"So sorry," the waiter says. "Did you say sweet or unsweet?"
"Unsweetened," I say.

Kei says, "The ticket was filed the same night as your 'fuck-up,' as you call it, but it wasn't escalated by a human. Your access was just an automated flag that should have been dismissed at the first tier, not raised to Internal Affairs!"
"That doesn't change the fact that I clipped the battery," I say. "Even if I was allowed to be in there after the training."
"But it shows nobody was targeting you. They think it was escalated by evidence of fraud or sabotage, but it was just a glitch!"
"So it was—"
The plates arrive at the table, steaming with heat from the hot-lamp in the kitchen.
I wait a little longer.
"—it was filed by the system?"
"You broke nothing," Kei says. "It should only be a slap-on-the-wrist. But they had the wrong assumptions going into it!"

"That's great and all, and I thank you guys for all your concern," I say. "But I'm not going anywhere. I'm worse off than where I started, and I better look elsewhere if I want to work in an office." The overtime is killing me just to keep up on my mortgage. I can barely afford groceries after the last salaried paycheck hit.

"Kei wasn't the only one looking for compensation," Reed adds. I'm about to take a bite of my burger after removing the pickles, but he stops me. "I have connections through my family — like I said — and maybe Aerospace's distance from the battery division gives them the perfect separation."
I feel a little bit of something radiate inside me: something I thought I've lost for good, and it scares me. "That's nice of you, Reed," I say. "But—"
"No," he says. He takes my hand, and now all the three of us are holding hands. "Listen to me, seriously. I talked with some family friends, and they said they've got an opening."
"I'm in hot water right now," I say, and I remember that email from all those months ago. "I don't even know if I'll make it past those winter layoffs they told us about in the spring!"
"Who knows: we're not safe either. But they said they've got a showcase, like a brown bag event, for employees to show off their projects, and I think I can get you in."
He's trying to be platonically sincere in his own way, but I'm more afraid he'll lace his fingers in mine. I already have a bromance going with Miguel.
"Oh yeah?" I say.

"Yeah, you're worth it, Cody," Reed says. He fiddles further with his phone, and then I feel a notification vibrate my pocket. "You get two slides and five minutes. Just give me some time to 'play the system' a little: I think I can get you in the room."
"Like you do best," I say.
"So yeah?" He asks.
"Maybe."
"Maybe?" Kei asks, so I get honest.

The warmth from their kindness lasts until I get off the highway: it's not from the single drink I had, because I'm fully sober.
