"Then why is there all this anger?" I ask, gesturing to my phone. "Feels like I'm watching my own world, a hundred years from now. You're all humans, the SAME race, yet people always seem to be yelling at each other. If you've solved war by taking it as far as it can go, then where is the peace?"

"Peace isn't profitable," Cody says. "And it's not that comfortable either. If life is still hard, and prices are still high, and you don't have something that everybody can agree is worth fighting, I think people start to turn on each other."
"So hardship is the default," I say.
Someone shouts his name.
"I guess," he says.

Cody gets up from the table, and moments later, he returns with two drastically-different drinks. One is blacker than Chymaeran tar in a clear glass with cubes of ice floating around. The other is light brown and cloudy, with foam and a sugary drizzle on the top.
He sets the drinks at exactly halfway across the table, refusing to push one further towards me than the other.
"So I got the dark one," I say.

"Yeah," Cody says. He watches me hesitate, and a mischievous smile splits across his face. "You got the dark one. And you're right we can't get 'distracted by sweets:' I guess I just broke the rule, right?"
"Well," I say, feeling my cold stoicism slowly thaw with the warmth of my desire. "Well . . . I'm going to try this one," I say, snatching the sugary one.
He frowns. "But you ordered this one!"
"Well, you left yourself that 'room,' didn't you?" I ask, taking a loud slurp through the straw, tasting something so sweet and rapturous that it's hard to contain my bliss.
He grumbles before he takes a sip. "Like fuckin' dirt," he says. "And you drink this? Are they trying to prepare you to die by taking all the smallest joys from you?"
I'm too busy sucking down the flavors. He grumbles again, then pours in two sugar packets, then takes a sip that twists his face again, and then pours in some milk.
Once he's satisfied, he takes a long sip, punctuated by a few words.
"Don't get distracted now," he orders. "We still have a plan to . . . uh, plan."

He turns the grande-sized drink around in his calloused hands, probably struggling to believe that the cup isn't glass. He finds his name scrawled in Sharpie, and it reads TIEDUS <3 in a girl's handwriting.
"Just don't think too hard about any of it. Just try it. And you too," Katiya says, motioning to Rayna and Sylvia: she ordered for the three of them before we left.

I find the most amusement watching Titus, trying to mask his enjoyment as the "strong, silent type" while he guzzles the first half of it, looking panicked when he realizes it's halfway empty. We got Sylvia something cherry-flavored since she seems to really like the color red, and Rayna has the same drink Katiya stole from me.

The injection-molded Starbucks cups are out of place in a world with rough edges everywhere. Sylvia takes Titus and Rayna's cup, heading to Katiya's sink to rinse it, but I protest before she leaves the couch.
"Throw it away?" Sylvia asks. "But isn't that such a waste? And look how perfect it is: it even has my name on it, in your world's writing."
The cup reads SALVIA :).
"I mean, sure, you can keep it," I say, so she stacks them together, adding the cups to their pile of possessions.
Katiya starts. "So I hope we're ready to make a plan: Cody and I started the conversation, at least."
"Okay," Titus says. He scratches at his beard, missing a tuft with caramel cold foam still stuck to it. "We're here to earn our keep, so let's hear it."

Katiya and I stand together with our backs to the window, and it feels like I'm getting another design review. "So we talked about our problems, and it seems they actually have a lot of overlap," I say. "My chance comes first, in a little more than a week. And Katiya meets with Rayna's contact tomorrow, where she'll get more information. And the through line is this." I tap my toe against the only other perfect shape in the room beyond the Starbucks cups: a Pelican case, holding the prototype for my drone I shelved almost half a decade ago.

The focus of our small audience is entirely absorbed by the contents of the box. From the windowsill behind me, I retrieve two batteries: one I bought from a hobby store, and another that got me in loads of trouble.

I say, "I'm told that the southern fields of Gaffesend are open and sparsely populated. That means it might be the perfect place to test some technology that might give us an advantage." I lift the non-magic battery. "I'll test on this battery to get some data for the interview. But this one," I lift the Essenced one, "will run the drone when it's in operation on your side."
They still look confused.
Titus asks, "so what is it? A drone, you call it?"

I flip open the latches, feeling a lot like my brother. The drone is the same as I left it, minus the layer of dust I polished off. I lift it in my hands, and knowing Titus is a gearhead, he approaches to inspect it.
"I flew something bigger than this once. It didn't go over well," he says.
Sylvia turns to him. "What do you mean?"
"A story for another time," he says, then holds it up to me. "But what kind of information are you supposed to get from this if you can't ride it?" He squints. "I mean . . . you can't, right?"

"It lets you see through it, like you're looking through the eyes of the bird. But you control it, and you can see what it's looking at from a long ways away. You'll have to set me up somewhere in your world, but for whatever's coming, you'll have all the information you need."
Rayna asks, "and how will you tell us if you're already out there? Flares? You can't fire them in the town."
"Short-range radio," Katiya says. She holds up her phone, and though she's wrong, I'm proud of all she's learned.
"The other one," I say.
"Oh." She reaches for the plastic shape with the antenna on the window sill. "A walking talker."
"Walkie-talkie," I say, then realize I'm mansplaining when she glares at me. "Sorry."
"You can talk at any range. Like radio with the music and the talkies, but it's personal."
Then Titus points at the last item leaning against the wall behind me, still charred around the muzzle from erupting with megajoules of energy. "So comms and overwatch are covered, but what's that?"
"An experiment," I say. "One that's far too dangerous to test in my world, but I think if we get the ratios right — and buy the ammunition in bulk from Costco — it could give you a serious leg-up."
It's hard to contain my excitement when I feel like one of the Mythbusters that's been spirited to a magical land.

"So weapons, intel, and communication. A week to get everything together," Titus says, "but there's just the four of us, plus anyone else Rayna's envoy decides to send. Katiya, what resources do you have here?"
"I have some reconciling to do, but once it's over, I trust they'll have my back," she says.
"And we'll keep an eye out for some of our own allies. They're making the journey a little while after us," Sylvia says.
Rayna adds, "and I was under the impression that this wasn't just some information drop. This Ahkvasan and her friends are powerful and invested in how this plays out."
"So it looks like my side is covered," Katiya says. "But rebuilding that machine will be no small feat. What do you have?" She asks me.
"I can help," Titus says. "I might be a tactician, but I also studied to be an engine-master."
"Sure," I say, "and like Katiya, I've already started my own tour of reaching out. I have enough friends that can help — and if they can't design, at least they can keep us all awake."
Katiya rolls her eyes when his face flashes in her mind. "You're inviting him?"
"This isn't a party, dude," Cody says.

"A kickback isn't a party," says Miguel. "It means the alcohol is only making some of the decisions." Rayna and I watch from the threshold of the doorway as he sets a box of cans on the coffee table. "You nerds would get too bored without me here. You'd fall asleep before you got anything done!"
"Yeah?" Cody laughs. "And what are you going to do?"
"I built a car with my dad, you know," he says. "You losers might have the computer shit on lock, but you probably suck at building stuff."
"Remind me," Cody says, "did it ever run?"
"Fuck you," Miguel replies, tearing the side of the cardboard box to retrieve a can, and cracks it open. "Say, where's the drone thing? You only ever showed me the video from the news."
Cody points to the Pelican case at Miguel's feet.

"Oh," Miguel says. He takes a sip and turns to us, leaning back against Cody's entryway as the door is still ajar. "This guy was in the news, can you believe that? In the 'heroes' section of People Magazine — not in print, but online. And he's still available, I'll have you know."
Cody punches his arm. "This isn't some club in Denver, you jackass! You don't have to rizz me up."

"Oh, what, are you not available anymore?" He laughs. Then he looks at me, then Cody, then me, then laughs again. "Ah, I get it, so it's you two." He turns back to Cody, and mutters, "I always thought you'd end up with—"
"You mind moving?" A female voice says. "It's freezing out here."

Kei pushes Miguel out of the doorway, unwrapping her scarf as Reed carries in both of their backpacks. Miguel shifts to the black faux-leather futon, and while Kei debates whether to remove her pink, woven beanie, Reed shakes Cody's hand, exchanging pleasantries over some inside joke.
"Surprised to see you here," Kei tells me. "Are you here to help, or to drink?"

"Neither for now," I say, as I lean back through the portal to find Titus and Sylvia looking over Gaffesend's map, circling a few points of interest in red ink. "I've got my own project I'm working on."
"Cool," Reed says. "Is it the cosplay thing?"
Maybe a few months later I'd flatly reject the question. They were fighting words the first time I met Cody, but instead, I just shrug. "Yeah, something like that."
"Well, good luck," Reed says.
"Thanks."

Miguel snaps open the big case as Kei demands he "handle it carefully." Rayna crosses back to see what Titus and Sylvia are looking at. And as Reed bends a knee to get a first look at the project, Cody approaches me.
"So you're good?" He asks.
"As good as I can be," I say. "If it's not, I know you're close by."
He puts up his fists and takes a couple practice swings, getting several things wrong in the span of a couple seconds. "My track record isn't great over there, but I swear — I'll die for you."

"Save your breath," I say, retreating through the door though we still face each other, separated only by the miasmic veil between worlds. I look up at his lips. He looks down at mine, and though I think for just a second that something might happen, something crashes, and Miguel calls him over.
Cody laughs. I feel his warm breath while his face is inches from mine.
"Goddamnit, Miguel!" Kei says. "What did I tell you?"
"It's not my fault it was loose," he whines. "Where do you even find screws this small?"
He turns to me one last time as he grasps the edge of his door. "Save your world and shit, yeah?"
"Yeah," I say.
"I . . . look forward to that tomorrow. Let's see how much we can get done today."
"Of course," I say.
He lingers one more second, hesitates, then softly closes the door behind him. I lock my side, then turn to join my small militia of outcasts.
We spend an hour reviewing every detail of the map with the foreigners. The two moons hang just above the horizon across the lake, providing just enough light to see the map with the curtains drawn.
"It's still just so hard to believe," Titus says, looking down at his grandfather's hand-drawn map of Blackwater, trying to hold it northwards at the right distance from Gaffesend.
"We were taught that the world was ice," Sylvia adds. "That all of Fosroth was frozen after the fall of Northaven!"
"So what made you go south?" I ask. "Was it just a lucky guess?"
"It's where the tracks run," Titus says.
"With the all produce," Rayna says. "And where does that all come from?"
Titus' gaze becomes distant. He looks down at his wrist with all the threaded scars. I think Sylvia might turn to console him, but she seems just as lost as her partner.
"It's no longer there," Titus says. "But I have to believe that what I . . . that what happened was for the better."
"It was," Sylvia says. "They're free to step into the light now, just like we are."
"Yeah," he mutters. His eyes soften after they return from infinity. "So anyways. We don't have the information we need yet, but at least I have a better idea of Gaffesend's defenses."
I feel the presence of something watching us from behind the front windows. Something shifts, but this time, the stranger's smart enough to use their voice.
"Katiya," Aryn calls, as Rayna hastily leaps behind the couch. Aryn's fist pounds against the door, as several other junior guards stand behind her.

The file's the same as it was half a decade ago, before I had any understanding of version control, zipped in a folder titled REVISION_47 at half a gigabyte in size. The mates are all broken, meaning the computer model is cobbled together with programmatical duct tape: it was from before I spent three odd years honing my mastery of the process.

The swish and flick of the mouse is a feeling I miss as I navigate the model on my TV screen. We decided today was just a disassembly day, and as my three friends take apart every piece to carefully explode it across the floor, I manually explode every piece of the model.

Miguel bites into his third slice of pepperoni pizza, then reclines across the couch to scroll through something on his phone — Kei joins him for a break, recounting some our shared memories from high school. My stomach rumbles, but it's a feeling I've become used to. The fear I get from stretching that last salaried paycheck is more than enough to chew on, and gum is a lot cheaper than food. The first slice I grab from the box is the first thing I've eaten today, and today is thirty minutes from over.
Reed approaches when the two are distracted, setting down the front half of the carbon fiber casing. "Just so you know, I've made it official," he says.
I'm surprised when I find there's no jealousy there: I'm just genuinely happy for them. "That's great, man. When did you ask?"
"I emailed last week."
"Emailed?" What the fuck? "You emailed her?" I look over at Kei. "What about in-person?"
"It was a dude," Reed says, and now I'm even more confused. "Met him through my dad, works for the Aerospace division."
I know Reed's good at climbing corporate ladders, but I never saw him taking it this far. I remain quiet, hoping for him to say anything else.

And he does. "I asked my dad to introduce us. I talked about your project, and the brown bag event, and get this: he said he saw your resume in the pool for positions. Seems to imply they'll treat your presentation as a pre— what? Why are you laughing?"
Kei and Miguel look across the room at the two of us. It's hard to stop once I start. "You," I say, "you said you made it official, Reed, do you know what that means?"
He stares, blankly. "Yeah. It's official now. Unlike when we were at Chili's."
"I thought—" I gesture to Kei when the two get back to disassembling. "You and her?"
"Oh yeah."
"Yeah?" I ask.
"No. No, not yet," he says.
I grab his shirt to pull him closer. "Look, man. You help me with this project, and I'll help you out. Take her to that sushi place on 16th and ask her there — it's her favorite."
"Yeah?"
"Yeah. Downtown's her favorite place," I say.
My stomach grumbles again. I hate how every time reminds me of my fears like Pavlov's bell.
Reed smiles: maybe now they both finally have my approval. "Thanks, man."

Miguel lifts the battery chassis into the air, the last accessible part. "So I think it's done," he says. "You were right. All that oxidation in California rusted the shit out of some of these bolts. And..."
Kei's expression twists. "Miguel! What did you—"

"It was like this. I swear," he says. The days of the project were so long and stressful that my mind tried to forget, but when I see the long fracture severing both halves of the aluminum chassis, I remember instantly.
"He's right. I forgot," I say.
"Forgot what?"

"Forgot I crashed the damn thing," I say. "Not hard, but it happened sometime after the project was presented. Never thought I'd be presenting it again, so I didn't bother, and it was hidden beneath all this time."
We glare at the uneven face as Miguel still holds it in the air: the only one that's jagged, beyond my piss-poor machining skills leaving all the faces a little chattered.
"So what should we do, then?" Kei asks. "We can't 3D print it."
"What about the work machine shop?" Reed asks.
"I doubt they'll let me in," I say. "Haven't had the training yet."
Miguel shrugs. "I mean, my uncle has a lot of scrap metal. You could probably find something this size. And you're like family to them, so they'll give you whatever you need if you tell them why."
"That's great," I say. "But I'll still need to make another, and I need access to a machine shop."
Kei turns to Reed. "What about the empty four-car garage?"
"The . . . oh, yeah," he says. "My dad's hobby is working on cars. He has half a machine shop kitted out. They're all manual mills, though."
"Steel and metal?" I ask.
"Yeah, and wood," Reed says. "You're welcome to stop by. My parents have been looking forward to meeting you."
My stomach turns a little at meeting another executive. "Sure. That would be great."
"And what about the rest of these bolts?" Miguel asks, holding a fistful of rusty set screws that look like clogs of dirt. "And the holes?"
"I'll re-tap them," I say. "Or helicoil."
"And the software?" Kei asks.
"It worked last time," I say. "Should work enough for a demonstration."
"Then I think we have enough figured out to get started," Reed says.
"Come over to my uncle's shop tomorrow for some scrap," Miguel says, as I scroll to my original print for the part. "I'm sure you'll find something."
"And stop by once you've got enough to machine," Reed says. "I'll drop a pin."
"And . . . I'm not sure how I can help yet," Kei starts, "but I will." The two engineers shoulder their bags. Miguel grab his box of beers to let them roll around in his car some more.

"You've done enough," I tell her, then address the rest of them, saying, "you've all done enough. Your charity's the only way I can pull this off: you know how much the materials cost? I'm lucky the college covered it for publicity," I say.
"We promise we'll get you there," Reed reassures me: the last to lean in the doorway before they all leave. "But once you get in that room, it's all on you."
"I promise I'll walk you there," Aryn says. "But once you get in that room, it's all on you."
I've only left a narrow crack in the door: so slight we can't even see each other. She extends the wax-sealed envelope from a gloved hand, turning it upright to fit through the opening.
"It's alright. You've done enough for me," I say, as I grasp the end of the envelope, feeling a resistance in her hands that doesn't want to let go.
I pull harder and it slips her grasp, making me feel like I owe her some kind of contrition. But I can't involve her yet: not while the sister she thinks she lost in the war hides behind my couch.
So I offer her words instead.
"I'm thankful for what you did to save my life," I say. "I'll never forget your act of courage."
"Sure," she says, and I can feel her discomfort through the door. The delivery is done but she still lingers there.
"So thanks," I say. "For coming to deliver this. Surely softened the blow, and at least I have a date now."
"Yeah," she responds.
I wait a couple seconds, hearing a lack of footsteps on the other side: her boots should be crunching the ice down my walkway, but the signature of her Essence still lightly feathers my circuits.
I push to close the door, but something relents. Maybe it just took a little resistance to force the words out.
"I'm not a person that lingers, or hesitates, or really reacts at all, but . . .  for the second time, I've found someone that makes me want to stay," Aryn says.
I stand in silence behind the door, my shoulder tired from holding it in place like a shield from something honest.

"I'm sure you've heard about my sister: the one that failed out of training in the class before us. She used to live in this house, you know, and all that time she spent alone, I wasn't there for a second of what she went through." I feel her push against the door a little harder, maybe hoping to come in and revisit the ghost. "But in your absence — not seeing you for a whole week since we buried him, I hate how much that makes me wonder, that makes me regret not being there."
Rayna peeks her head from behind the couch, maybe hoping to catch a glimpse of her sister through I refuse to open any further.
"But you couldn't do anything," I say. "You couldn't travel here then. You probably didn't even get the news until long after: it's not your fault, Aryn."

"But you're here right now, and you won't even open the door to look at me," she says, holding an unfamiliar inflection in her voice that gives me chills. "You're not at fault either, can't you see that?"
"I know, but—"
"But you've been holed up in this house for days! I know you're embarrassed: maybe you're indecent, or you haven't bathed in a while, but I just want to see you," she says.

I stuff my body into the eyeline, then crack the door so she can't see anything else. She looks up at me from the porch: probably thinks my hair is disheveled from days of loneliness, but I've just been busy plotting my throes of redemption.

I hear Rayna stand from behind the couch, and it frightens me: I can feel how much she's longed to reconcile. Maybe she just wants a glance of her, to see how much Aryn's changed in her absence — but she's clumsy in her reproach.

I hear the dining table screech against the floor when Rayna bumps it in the dark. She gasps, and when I hear something slender and metallic slide across the surface, she grasps the utensil in her hand before it can crash to the floor.
Aryn's expression quickly congeals, pushing with an intention that catches me off guard. "Who's in there? Katiya, it's against regulation to house strangers!"
So I tell half a lie.
"Refugees," I say. "I wanted to help. To do something when I couldn't serve."
Rayna dashes for Cody's door. Titus and Sylvia step away from the opposite wall, and I hope Aryn only notices the two of them.
But she doesn't. Her Ahkvasan vision is too acute.
"Who was that?" Aryn asks. "That was an Ahkvasan — or at least a demihuman like me. Blackwater doesn't have demihumans, so she's not a refugee!"
"She's with us," Titus says: the only person in town with an expression enough to out-ice her. "She's promised us work in Melenia. And Katiya offered to quarter us for the day."
"Melenia's more than two weeks of travel away," Aryn says. "What could possibly bring her here?"
"I don't know," Titus says, putting his arm around Sylvia. "But we're desperate. And work is work."

Aryn glares between Titus and Sylvia: from how her flesh shivers, she reacts to their immense energy that same way that I first did — and though she could surely prod further, she relents. She clenches her fists with the slightest tell of fear, slipping back through the doorway.

"I'm not sure what I believe," Aryn says. "I don't know what's going on, or what you're got yourself into with these people, Katiya, but please," she looks one last time to the door her sister disappeared through— "just please, tell me when you need my help."

The village holds its breath longer as the nights get colder. Villagers pass every morning along the lake to watch for waves: even though only the shoreline is frozen, the ice inches faster and faster towards the center of the lake each day. Soon they'll be hurling boulders to judge whether our finest barrier is no more than a flat plane of solid ice — the Capital's already sent its first detachment to defend the village from the east, quartered in the eastern barracks.

I'm cloaked by the hood of my old guard uniform, wrapped by an unfamiliar green scarf that Rayna received from her informant, a scarf that identifies the connection Rayna settled on. Rayna wears the only set of clothes she owns, and Titus and Sylvia don decorated armor from their forgotten life, though they cover it with a dark shawl.

The village is busy this time of day, but it's busier with all the reinforcements. We walk between soldiers from the Purgatory Line enjoying their window of respite, sampling all the goods they can stomach in the Main Street market — and it would almost feel like tourist season if their faces weren't scraped with the thrashings of war, and their bellies weren't as bottomless as the appetites of the conflict beyond the lake.

We slip through the crowds, ducking arms extended with precious Kine in trade, weaving around clusters of native townies complaining about the crowd, and when we finally make it to the edge of the market, short-cutting through long alleyways, the buildings get shorter, until only a wide, barren field of frost and frozen dirt spans between the town and the old castle: where our informant awaits.

My eyes begin to scan the landscape for any sign of the emissary. My fingers brush the foreign fabric of the green scarf, dry and thin like the desert, with sand still stuck between the stitches. Titus and Sylvia begin to flank around the sides as overwatch, leaving just Rayna and I to cross the middle of the field, feeling watched from behind the entire time.
"Where's the spot?" I ask Rayna.
"They were intentionally vague," she says.

The crumbling perimeter walls are scattered with vagrants. We approach the entrance through which I once chased her, stopping at the steps as we wait for any sign of interaction from the strangers all around us. One leans against the wall, rambling madly with delusions. Another cooks squirrel meat on a makeshift grill, and a patchy Ahkvasan eats it raw.
"How will we know?" I ask Rayna. "What if this is a trick?"
"It's not. This informant and I fought for our lives together: this isn't a ruse."

I stare at the floor as I sit on the steps: my hood obscures vision of anything beyond the weathered stone stairs. I can feel the world's quiescence grow the more I wait, my heart beating slower as it feels like the weather is getting hotter. I thought it might be a rogue ray of light, but the sun hasn't parted the thick clouds all day.
"Hey Rayna — you think they're just late? Were they even expecting us?"
I gasp, suddenly feeling breathless from a meager two sentences. Then I try again: this shortness of breath isn't from a feeling.
It's something else.
"Rayna?"

Sitting doesn't help, so I stand, grabbing Rayna's shoulder, but I don't feel warmth. I grab harder, but the fabric refuses to bend. She doesn't even react: still as stone, her face frozen in an expression similar to that of my cherished friend in his last moments, and the sudden panic races my heart.

She's stuck like all the ancient statues of knights that the homeless tether their tarps to, forever bound to a pedestal. Her mouth is left agape, but I realize it's not from emoting a sense of terror.
She's trying to respond to me, but she can't get the words out.
Or maybe they just haven't come out yet.
I descend the stairs. The air is hot wherever it rushes against my skin, and when I reach the bottom, I step to crunch the frosted grass beneath my feet.
But it won't move.

My ankle twists on the fibrous fronds that refuse to give, and I nearly fall before recollecting myself, feeling such a strong sense of heat the more my muscles labor to keep me upright. The air is thin as the lack of pressure pops my ears, and with the taste of ozone in my breath, I finally look up.
The world is still.

I stumble over the uneven plane of grasses, stiff as steel rods, finding Titus and Sylvia in the distance. But they're not watching the steps. Something grabs their attention in the direction of the village, and without any other visual cues, I try to follow their line of sight.

I head back towards Gaffesend, trying to find a sense of motion in anything as the birds are stuck in the sky; the flames of torches unwavering; the first snow of the day kept still like stars during the day.

But the strangest sight is a lone Royal Guard, still as cardstock as she stands a hundred yards away, right where Titus and Sylvia might have seen her. The fabric of her hood is contoured to the peaks of her ears. Her eyes stare directly at the old castle; her expression tense yet apprehensive; the poise of her pace swift from the way her black tail bends behind her.

But there's nothing I can do to stop her, to stop Aryn's curiosity from getting the better of her. And I don't realize I've been distracted until I begin circling again, stumbling across the uneven landscape, searching for any sign of motion as my flesh begins to sweat — the beads hanging perfectly in the air as they slip from my skin.

It's only after a minute of silent stillness — around when my ears start ringing — that I see the lone, cloaked wanderer adorned with a similar shawl to my scarf approaching from the northern tree line, headed directly for me as I decide whether to run or to stand perfectly still.
But the stranger decides for me.

They raise their hand, releasing me ever-so-slowly from the binds of time. I watch the positions of every one of my footsteps combust with heat as my backlog of motion cashes out — scorching the grasses — and scalding where I grabbed Rayna's shoulder with a sudden burst of flame. I'm stuck between frames of entropy with nowhere to run, at the mercy of the timeless stranger.

Without entitlement to fast or slow, I'm in a halfway home between two states of motion. It feels like these dilations of time don't even encompass my whole body anymore: my body feels slow as molasses while my mind races just as fast as it was before, giving me a headache as I turn to realize how close they've come.

My senses fail me when the stranger excludes my nerves from this pocket of entropy. My mind pleads for information, and with only my sight in full function, it fils my thoughts with every detail I can grasp.

There are two peaks that crest beneath the worn, hooded robe, but their face isn't smooth like Rayna or Aryn. It's an Ahkvasan like Naya, but their fur is a different color — and a different color that isn't natural.

But purposely unnatural: their coat is sullied with dirt, yet it doesn't look like some feral Ahkvasan that's weathered the wastelands. The roots of their fur — her fur — are radiant and impossibly golden, shimmering with more light than the world can offer, yet the strands taper off into flat, unnatural clods of brown, of dirt, and by the time this Ahkvasan's emerald eyes meet mine, I notice the missing span of her cloak that she tore to make this scarf.
I'm almost relieved when her hands reach me — to finally feel something touch me back after several minutes in tactile isolation.

"Don't panic," she says, and her voice booms with an air of veneration. My body catches up to my mind, flooded with sensory information that's ourdated, and when she tugs at my cloak, we begin racing towards the north. I can feel her tremble with exhaustion, and I can sense this grand display has costed her a substantial amount of Essence.

She slows time when we approach the tree line to ensure the grass has long enough to bend, so that our footfalls won't combust in mysterious flashes of heat. When we make it to cover, the world recovers, and once again I hear all the sounds of life I took for granted beyond the pounding of my heartbeat in my temples. We catch our breath for several seconds as she rifles through her pockets, careful not to tatter the fabric with her claws. I'm too stunned to speak, so I continue to let her pull me deeper into the woods, approaching the small northern lobe of Gaffesend Lake, though we surely won't be able to cross.

"I'm sorry to petrify you with time," she says, and while I'm figuring out whether she means physically or emotionally, the golden Ahkvasan pulls a spherical, green stone from inside her pockets. "We need to get somewhere quiet. I understand you brought protection, but beyond Rayna, I can't trust anyone right now."
"This seems pretty remote," I say.
"We have an appointment with another. A couple hundred miles north," she says. "You've been through the bends of time, but there's one more quick voyage we have to undertake."
"Hundred?" I repeat. "But how? Are we going to fly?"

"We're already there — that is, if she's there," the Ahkvasan says. She hands me a second smooth sphere, and I grab it, but it doesn't rotate in my hands. It's light and so easy to lift — like a paperweight, but won't twist no matter how hard I try to turn it. I feel an otherworldly energy spin my circuits, and as I hear the omnipresent words of an ancient tongue.

I don't even feel my body lurch to motion, but it's  like orbiting around the Earth on one of Cody's computer maps that show his entire world, as if the still sphere refuses to move because it's connected to something else I can't see between space. My mind can't reconcile the sight of anything around me, so I focus on the sphere. The jagged marble-like surface scrolls through textures as if it ripples, but it never changes size, feeling like we're being folded and pulled in a direction I've never felt before, and when I look up, I find the world is still again.

There's a third hand touching the sphere that I grasp between my hands. It's green and calloused with veins like leaves: the fingers fibrous, cold, and resilient. The Ahkvasan touches their other hand — which holds another sphere — and when we step back, I discover this cold-blooded figure is a member of a forgotten race: a forgotten race that lives with veins, but no blood.

Her two eyes are darker than night, like those of an insect, but larger than a human's. Crimson vines descend from her head beneath long, colorful leaves, giving her bangs, and her face is contoured with features like those of a grasshopper: a distinct, sharp, scraggly mouth with mandibles on the side.

I feel like I'm going to make sick after being bent through space and time: it's obvious these two hold a terrifying amount of power, far beyond the pale of even the strongest commoner. Most go their whole lives without meeting one of the Masks of the Gods, but I don't doubt for a second that I've met two of them over the course of a single day.
I clutch my stomach as I look around: the air is much colder, and we stand at the front of some natural amphitheater, vacant of any signs of life.
"Where's this waypoint?" The Ahkvasan asks.
"Due west of Blackwater proper," the Verdalan replies. "I prognosticated this position as the egress point of the leyline: traversing that long passage to scour dying rooms in the caverns of space."
"So the signature was here, but it wasn't...here," the Ahkvasan says. "It was on another plane."

"A dying bubble of existence that was abandoned. So many chained together that we barely made it out  before the walls of rotting realities could consume us," she says, and then I notice the two humans standing behind her, wearing the same armor that Titus and Sylvia wear. One's bald and dark-skinned like Ryder, and the other one is a short, blonde, Demi-human girl with cat ears, but no tail.
But they both look so much worse for wear. It's weird enough hearing a plant talk with a better vocabulary than I have — and it's probably not even her first language.

"So you're the contact," the Verdalan says, before looking to the Ahkvasan for a nod of approval. She touches one of the trees, and part of her consciousness leaves her for a second. "We're safe here. Beyond the winter hare, there isn't a soul that trudges these wastes for miles."
I look between the two humans' faces: the only familiar sight though they're two strangers. None of us are even on a first-name basis yet.
"I'm sorry for the cloak-and-dagger," the Ahkvasan says. "I'm from a place where the color of my fur is a namesake that could topple an empire."
"And will," the Verdalan says.
"My name is Jade," says the Ahkvasan. "A Mask of the Gods, and the rightful heir of Melenia."
"And I go by Aliaki. One of the last Verdalan Masks to span the space between Fosroth and its moon. The last messenger of Xi'Nu."

"And I'm Katiya." They wait for an epithet. "I, uh, was a guard for a while. A world-crosser. And I have some refugees from the north at my place that look like those two," I say, gesturing to the two humans, but they don't speak, looking exhausted from some recent ordeal.
Aliaki turns to them. "The anomaly is attached to a dying world, so she can't return in physical form. She'll have to inhabit what this world left behind."
The burly human asks, "and where will we find her?"
"She'll come to us," Aliaki says. "When she rises from the depths, she'll come to the last place we met: the leyline that led us home."
"Then we should head south now, Romin," the girl tells her partner, tugging gently at his sleeve. "The rest of our fireteam waits down there: not a chance they've made it further."
"And they have no idea of what's coming," he responds.

I have no idea of what's coming when the streets are unlit. Those woodsy, rich neighborhoods between Hearthland Ridge and Shaleborough are full of those wealthy types that wanna feel a sense of adventure when they're driving home on an unlit road that snakes up a hill — the same people that drive white G-wagons and never plan to take it off-roading.

But it's the idea of it that's exciting, I guess, and I still have no idea what's behind the third unlit stop sign when I've spent a full day on the floor, cranking a wrench in a sensory-deprivation bath of fluorescent light. My eyes still ache, and my headlights aren't bright enough, and since my braking foot aches from standing all day, I decide to just go for it.

The scrap from Miguel's cousin's uncle's shop rattles in the trunk. They loaded me up so at least I won't be shy on materials. The only shyness I feel is the anticipation of meeting Reed's extended family of Navidson-Monroe royalty — watching the houses get bigger and bigger as I wonder when this hill is ever going to end.
I forget Reed's been on the phone this whole time, trying to give me directions over the hands-free system.
"This seems pretty remote," I say.
"I think I see you," Reed says.
"So the pin you dropped was back there, but it's not...here," I say. "It was a couple hundred feet back there."

"Hundred? No way the internet is that bad out here," Reed says. "Hey, I think I see your lights!" Feels like talking to an elementary school friend on your mom's phone, that just can't wait to play with you.

"I think I'm here — that is, if you're here," I say, grasping the smooth, rounded ball of the automatic gearshift, popping it into park. Reed waves in the window, and I pop the parking brake before turning my wheels as far as they go.

I exit the driver's seat into pitch darkness, swigging the last of my second energy drink. I take the scrap under my arm from the trunk. A second wind of energy coarses through my veins as I hear Reed's voice calling to me from the porch.

His parents surprise me when I enter: I look so much worse for wear in my father's old technician clothes, while every member of Reed's family is cleanly-dressed with dirty blonde hair — like a family of overachieving golden retrievers.

"So you're his best friend," his father says, before looking to his son for a nod of approval. He strangles my hand with a business handshake before pulling open the blinds, looking out at the incredible view of Denver from the hilltop. "We're pretty isolated out here," he says. "Beyond about three neighbors, there isn't a soul out here for miles."
I look between Reed's mother and father: the only unfamiliar sight though they seem to know everything about me. He insists Im his best friend, though of us are even on a first-name basis yet.
His mother smiles. "So nice to finally meet you! My name is Lauralee. I was once a receptionist at Navidson."
"And I'm Geoffrey," his father says. "I swear, every day at family dinner, Reed's either talking about you or his girlfriend."
Reed blushes, expecting me to stop his suffering.

"And I'm Cody." They wait for an epithet. "I, uh, was an engineer for a while. And I have some scrap here for the machine shop — but I don't want to get your house dirty," I say, gesturing to all the white-and-gold as two of his siblings come upstairs, but they don't speak — nervous at the presence of some dirty stranger.
Lauralee turns to them. "Why don't you say hello to Cody? He works with your big brother. And he might stay for dinner!"
I feel so hungry since I forgot to eat again — stretching paychecks like taffy that I can't swallow. "Oh, please, you've done enough opening your home to me."

"We insist," his father says. "Tell us about your trip to the Renaissance Faire out on Shaleborough!" He gestures out the window again, to the broad landscape out past Daniels Park. "You can see it from here when the sun's out."
"That's great," I say. My arms are getting heavier with all the scrap. "Say, could I power through this part first? It's aluminum: shouldn't take too long on a four-axis mill."
Reed's mother gestures. "It's out in the downstairs garages."
Downstairs? Garages?
"On the first level with the corvettes," Geoffrey days.
"First level?"
I said that one.
"Yeah. The last couple bays," Geoffrey says: "Reed will show you. And he can help, so put him to work: all he does is sit in a box all day."
"Sure," Reed says, as I unlace my steel-toed boots. He leads me downstairs, and I find that I have no idea of what's coming.
"We know exactly what's coming," Jade insists.
"But the Ahkvasa?" I ask. "We've been allies since the fall — for at least two hundred years."
"And that's exactly what the leadership of your realm tells us," Aliaki says. "These ground-level generals know nothing about the machinations of politics."
I scratch my head. "And I'm their subordinate — or I was. So I see less than anyone," I say, asking the true royal for a better explanation.
"It's how you rally a people together when nothing else is popular," Jade insists. "When all is broken, and there's no unity after all the people turn against each other."
"You make an Other," I say. "Give them something to hate together . . . but why would your people choose us?"

"You've been in an eternal battle with the Chymaera. You're the wall that protects us, and you've been taking all the blows," Jade says. "Your mainland is rife with soldiers, but this time of the year is when the north is sensitive. And to fight a war of two fronts..."
"Is impossible," I conclude. "It's an obvious strategy, sure — but how can you be so certain?"
"Because we were in the room when the plans were drawn," Aliaki says. "And we heard all of it."

I swallow. Rayna's stories give me enough conviction to believe it's all true, but the question is whether I believe in my capacity to carry their will. My wounds are still fresh from the recent loss — and with a formalized tribunal on the horizon, happening in a mere week and a half, it's only now that I realize how these two avenues intersect.
"Miss Rayna had her connection to the leadership of your town, but her reputation was destroyed," Aliaki says. "Her mission was to find a resource with the greatest potential, and she chose you."
The words sound like a possible insult to my ears, like wishing someone a day as great as they are.
But she holds conviction in the words. "Rayna's one of the best reasons we survived capture," Aliaki says, "and without her, we wouldn't be here. So I trust her convictions."

"And you're the one that knows this town better than anyone." Jade says. "You know who to call. You know every shelter and egress. You know how to find the support you need — and in the days preceding, we'll arrive to provide all the support we have."
"And hopefully with another ally of our own," Aliaki says.
"You can count on me." I insist.

Aliaki rifles through a woven satchel to withdraw a map and a blank piece of parchment. She overlays the thin, blank page atop the map, and holding it in the dim light of the sky, she grows hardened indentations like bark in the paper where the contours of the landmarks shine through.

Jade approaches the table, circling several critical points. "The new Ahkvasan Army has already mobilized its forces. A sizable unit sneaks through the north in the abandoned lands, over here," she says, drawing a line in emerald ink. The pen dances over the hills manifested by Aliaki's Essence, and after scribbling several notes on meeting points, she rolls up the map and hands it to me.
And then the meeting is over. For beings with the gifts of time and space, it almost feels like they're in a rush. Maybe it's the only chance I have to ask.
"So what brings together an Ahkvasan and a Verdalan?" I ask.

"We're just two agents on an eternal campaign against the two forces of Fosroth. The Eternalists seek to manifest Essence to live forever, withholding souls from reincarnation in the Reservoir of Souls. And the Ephemeralists seek the right to die and live again."
"And which are you?"
"We seek to die when the time is right," Aliaki says. "That means even if that right isn't when we think it should be."
"Romin and Valentina will seek you out when they make the trip," Jade says, as Aliaki extends her hands with the two perfect spheres.
"Why don't they travel like this?" I ask.

"You ever hear of that boat puzzle, where you can only take so many people across the river each time?" Jade says. "You need an initiator on each side to set the point of departure if it's a new location."
"This sphere is a single solid in a higher dimension, each one piercing our world at two points. Fire blind and you'll end up missing — maybe fused somewhere in the heart of the planet."

I rest my hands in Aliaki's, grasping the small shape as tight as I can. Just as fish live peacefully knowing nothing of the world beyond the water, I close my eyes softly this time, wishing for nothing more than an ignorance of higher dimensions. And by the time I open my eyes, I've already returned to the shores of Gaffesend alongside Jade, finding two familiar faces rushing to confront us.

Reed's father follows us as we descend the stairs, trying hard not to hover though his curiosity gets the best of him. As we pass aerospace merch from all the way back to Reed's great-grandfather, this Navidson house feels like I'm walking down a five-minute hallway.
"I don't get many friends that come all the way out here," Reed says, then mutters, "not really at all."
"It was a damn journey," I say. "My blood's so full of caffeine, I shouldn't have been driving."
It's hard not to pretend to notice the third set of footsteps behind us as Reed doesn't even notice. He says, "and I'm sorry about my parents: the whole best friend thing, you know."

"It's cool, bro. We've come a long way. I talk to my family about you guys all the time," I say, as we turn the corner of another span of double garages, finding cars parked three-in-a-line with different trophies from car shows on the walls. It's the only dirty room of the house, looking like it housed a tractor during their build process. The windows are covered, and when we enter, Pink Floyd's Comfortably Numb autoplays over the speakers.

I forget we're being followed when the double garage looks like a museum of beautiful, antiquated machines: an old LeBlond engine lathe from the 1940s, and another mill with a CNC retrofit, overtaking the manual controls with automatic displays that blink red and green. The wall holds a massive tap-and-die chart that even my grandma could read without her glasses: reminding me of the old machine shop back at university.

"She's been itching for action," Geoffrey says, and it startles me. "Sorry. I wanted to see you boys at work: white-collar management is so zoomed out from the battlefield, that it's nice to see some action from time to time."
"Sure," I say.
"Here's some trivia: you should know since you taught my boy the other day. Do you gear-shift the lathe before or after it's running?"
"Give him a second, Dad," Reed says. "At least let him set up first!"
"Before," I say. "It's gears."
Geoffrey wrings his calloused hands. "And what about the band saw, then?"
"It's belt-fed," I reply. "You can only change speeds when it's in motion." I almost destroyed the shop's band saw yesterday — the only reason I remember.
"Very good," Geoffrey says. "See? I hope you rub off more on Reed here. I had to coax him into being a gearhead..."
An uncommon expression clouds my friend's face, unable to respond to his father's calloused, nervous chatter at an unfamiliar guest in his home.
"He's rubbed off plenty on me," I say, deciding where to zero the hefty chunk of uneven metal: still branded with PROPERTY OF RUELAS, NO SCRAP.
"And how's that?" his father asks, expecting another joke.

"Taught me how to be on a team," I say, and Reed's eyes lighten. I drive down the table of the mill's bed like I'm lowering an old car window, then lubricate the thirsty ways with a little oil. "I was a lost sheep for a while. He taught me how to make friends, I think. To care a little more. I mean, goddamn, your son's like the fuckin' sun—"

I cover my mouth when I realize I'm not in the shop anymore: this isn't some temporal enclave of the 1960s, despite all the hardware. Instead, I'm surprised to find that Geoffrey laughs, clapping Reed on the back.
"He sure is the friendmaker," his father says.
But his expression changes when he realizes the garage is about to be filled with harsh noise.
"So I heard you've got a presentation," he says.
I almost drop the chunk of aluminum.
"Yeah," I say.
"What happened was unfortunate. I only heard about it because of what Reed told me."
"Oh," I say.

"Reed told me about what your colleague found: you've got some good friends if they're working this hard to help you," Geoffrey says, but then he gets serious again, like he's giving me an early performance review, or negotiating a new salary. "Look. I came down here to tell you that the first I heard of any of that was from Reed, so as far as I know, your slate's clean."
"That's a relief," I say.
"But that doesn't mean you're close. I've been told your slot was last, which should help with recency bias — but Cody, you should consider this presentation your first interview."
I swallow, tasting coolant in the air. My hands nervously fumble with the hand wheel, feeling how real this has all become in such a short time.
"Do you have any questions for me?" He asks.
I clamp the scrap to the table, setting my first datum. I'm ready to make my first pass on this project since college.
"How much time do I get?"
"Fifteen minutes in the Aspen conference room. Give them something to see outside, and maybe you'll have a while longer."
"A working demo," I say.
"Means you can't hide behind transitions in a PowerPoint."
I search through a bin of end mills, finding a flat-end one that matches the collet. The cacophony of noise gives me time to think. "So that means it will have to work the first time," I say.
"That's right."

I look down at the shattered piece I've come here to recreate. It's a stress fracture: sheared at forty-five degrees because the weight was too much, and I hope the next one is made of something better.
There's so much I've learned since the last time.

"I can do that," I say, tracing my finger against the malformed face of blistered metal. I grab the collet with my coolant-stained hands, chucking up an end mill with two shrill chirps from the pneumatic vise.
"If you treat your colleagues like how you've bonded with my son — and you show true passion for your craft — then you'll fit in well."
"Will do," I say.
His hand grasps the doorframe as he leans into the hallway.
"And one last thing," he adds.
"Yeah?"
"Please stay for dinner," he says, "and I'm not asking: my wife will kill me if Reed's mysterious friend stays an anecdote."
"I'll stay," I say. Or else I won't eat.

I lack the time to explain before my allies turn on each other, and though Jade feels exhausted from bending time to a near stop, she still manages to slow the world enough for the two of us that they can't hear my words.

Sylvia drew her bow with Essenced arrows as soon as we appeared in a flash of light — and when she saw my panicked expression from weathering another long, short trip, she identified Jade as the enemy, refusing to take any chances.

Jade tenses the polished sphere in her claws: she might not be driving its magic, but it looks like she's the one that's now doing the pulling. A low thrum rattles the bowstring when Sylvia's nocked arrow leaves her fingers, flying fast enough to challenge Jade's grasp of time. The flint arrowhead combusts with white-hot Human Essence, and Titus unsheathes his sword, resonating with another loud hum.

"Aliaki," Jade mutters, and I hear someone coming to even the odds. The sphere scrolls rapidly as the anchor point shifts, and as Sylvia's first arrow crosses half the distance between our two parties, Jade reaches to grab it by its end.

The blistering heat doesn't have the time to sear her flesh and fur, but she winces when she turns it back around, hurling it directly for Titus' head. This extra lapse of time already burdens her enough — like holding back the flow of a powerful river — and as the world begins to settle, shuddering with the urge for progress like tired muscles on their last effort, Aliaki arrives in another flash.

I reach desperately for the rogue arrow, but time no longer waits. Titus refuses to flinch though a white death stares him in the forehead, and in an instant, the flint head erupts into tiny flecks of molten rock.

The shaft combusts into soot, decorating Titus' face with a flash of dark powder. He thinks he has the space to charge an attack as Jade fails to negotiate any more with time, raising his sword to charge, but Aliaki clenches her fist faster.

The pale light in front of us shifts blue. Twenty yards crunches into twenty inches, and before Titus can realize he's been shorted on his approach, Aliaki withdraws a plug from the large waterskin on her back, drenching her fibrous flesh. It goes dry in an instant, and she grows from a meager five feet to more than seven.
Titus tries to shift his weight with fewer steps to gain momentum. I throw myself between the two of them to try to get them to stop, but I've been shorted for just as much space.

Aliaki materializes a spear she's kept in some space between spaces, and lunges at the fearless human, about to make contact with his heart before I nudge the weapon just in time. It pierces through his armpit, but Sylvia can't see his face to know he's fine: that the spear is nothing more than a graze, and when she shouts his name, she invokes a strength from somewhere within that feels more powerful than any of us.

Her hair glows white with the light of a thousand suns: one trapped in each strand of hair, and we feel our bodies overcome with something ethereal that casts us to our knees. It's only when my hands touch both of their chests — a conduit of peace between Aliaki and Titus — that their adrenaline quiesces, and Titus drops the spear from between his arm, along with his blade that Aliaki condensed to a tenth of its length.
"Give reality a rest," I say, "you're going to break it!"
"These are surely not your friends," Aliaki says. "Refugees, they said? They're lying!"

"And who the Res are you?" Titus asks: the two push against my hands, and I feel like an insect stopping two mountains of Essence from colliding, but they don't push hard. Jade catches her breath as she sits on the ground: sweat cleansing her golden coat of all the dirt, and it shimmers in the pale light.
"I recognize him now. It was him," Aliaki says. "In the frames of every forgotten world: I saw his lifeless husks in all the realities he left behind."
"So he's the anomaly," Jade says.
"No. He's something different. And he sacrificed his gift to shed no more."
"I've come to peace now," Titus says, as Sylvia takes his arm. "I'm an outcast for what I've done, but if you witnessed even a moment . . . of all those ends, can you understand what it was all for?"
She pauses, drawing a breath of our exhale. "It must have been madness. But you completed your mission."
"A circular path only ends when you decide to stop," Titus says. "I left the circle."
"And it brought you here." Aliaki turns to me. "Fate brings us to the same mooring point: to her, no more than a common soldier, and yet the linchpin of three Masks of the gods."
"So you know about Sylvia," Titus says.
Jade's eyes narrow, exposing thin green slits. "But she's one of the Chosen, Ali — right? Isn't it four?"
"Her class hasn't been in this world since the Second Awakening. She's the incarnation of something far, far older: maybe she doesn't even know it."
"I have an idea," Sylvia says.

"Then it seems that fate points us all in the same direction," Jade says. She lifts herself from the ground after taking Gaffesend's dirt in her clutches, muting the shimmer in her strands. "I came to tell Katiya of an ambush from the west, but what I didn't tell her . . . is that it was futile."
I squint. "What do you mean by that?"

"That I was relaying a message, so your people had a chance to save themselves. Aliaki found a source of tremendous Chymaeran energy in the northern wastes of Blackwater, and she thought that if she could save them — and bring them into the light — that this Mask might be able to delay the incursion."
"What mask?" Titus asks. "There were only two. And now I'm the only one."
Aliaki says, "They should be headed here now, shepherded by two other Blackwater refugees. That is, if she's survived the transmutation: her soul will be split."
"Well, is it now the whole truth?" I ask. "Is there anything else important that you're hiding?"
"I'm sorry," Jade says. "Aliaki and I are in the service of a greater mission than Gaffesend: to reclaim a stolen empire, and this was meant to be a warning. We were headed to Northaven—"

"These are a people," Titus says. "You're privileged to a truth, and that truth binds you to a responsibility." He grabs his wrist with all the threaded scars. "That makes you their hope, even if you don't ask for it."

"And that hope has changed with new information." Jade looks between the four of us. "They can't predict what even I was unaware of, so it means we have a real shot," then she looks at me. "And you're the one that fate decides will bring this all together."

I return home full and exhausted with a clean, new replacement part. They sent me home with expensive glass Tupperware containers that "you can send home with Reed," packed with cuts of tri-tip Geoffrey seared and grilled.It has a whole two shelves of space to breathe in my fridge, besides a Costco trip from mom, Katiya's Chinese leftovers, and a rack of Pabst Blue Ribbon that gives me a taste of college.My muscles ache from the chatter of the machines. Micro-abrasions on my fingers sting with hand sanitizer, and I'm about to head up to take a shower when I hear the sound of crying next door. So instead I grab the leftovers, inching my way through Katiya's door with a container, slow enough to not invoke the wrath of another stranger. I think it's Rayna at first glance, sitting on Katiya's couch in her foyer, but then there's a copy of her. They both look like Rayna. The double doesn't cry: she just stares at her reflection with piercing blue eyes. I knock on the door lightly, yet the two catgirls jump."Intruder!" One of them says."Cody," Rayna says. The name brings the other to lower her weapon. "What's happening this time? Did you duplicate yourself?""This is Aryn," Rayna says, "my sister.""Who are you?" Aryn asks, but she squints harder. "Wait, I remember you — you were outside this house. The noble. That Royal Inventor that got the slice on the hand.""That's me," I say, while Rayna sniffles. "I heard crying next door. What's going on?""An unexpected reunion. A dead girl walked into my town, and I found out that she's my sister." She turns back to Rayna, raising her voice again. "Was Katiya hiding you here the whole time? Is that why she was so secretive?""I'm only here because I forced myself upon her goodwill," Rayna says. "She has nothing to do with this.""I thought she was mourning!" Aryn slams the coffee table, and her sister jumps."She still is," Rayna says."I trusted her, and she used that trust to hide everything," Aryn says. "You should have come to me. Or at least — why didn't you go home? Mom and Dad could have protected you. They would give anything."Rayna sniffles, lowering her head even further. "So why, Rayna? Tell me," Aryn says, flashing the contours of her fangs. "Now!""Take it easy," I say. She glares hard enough to drive me back a couple steps, then tries to soften her voice, but the anger still abrades the words in her throat. "Just tell me," Aryn says. "Please—""I couldn't bear it," Rayna says."Bear what?" Aryn says."I couldn't bear to face you," Rayna says. "But we swore to protect each other, no matter what, and I don't care if you're in trouble. You're my sister.""I was better off dead to you. And that choice made you a whole lot greater than I could ever be, because you deserved—"Aryn slaps her sister across the face, and Rayna recoils against the couch. "You don't get to decide that for us. You made a promise," Aryn says, "and you're so much more to me alive..."Aryn raises her hand again, but it falls to her side. Rayna grasps her cheek. I can't shake the thought all I ever wanted, for years, was to yell the same way at my sibling after they left for the last time — but watching how it plays out secondhand is painful."Hey," I say.
